I do not know yet whether I have condemned this town or saved it. I only know that when the snowman lifts its face to the moon and hums, the hum is a thing that wants a throat.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
They called him the Chosen before they ever hung his name on a wall. They painted his face with the sigils of favor, tore him clothes and remade him out of ritual cloth until the boy who had run barefoot down the alleyways of the lower quarter looked like a thing of varnish and promise. He learned prayers that tasted like ash in his mouth and how to fold his hands the right way when the high priest came by, so that the city could look at him and believe the gods had singled someone out—offered up, exalted, inevitable.

It was always easier to believe inevitability than to see what men had done.

I learned the truth because I was born with the wrong hands for the temple. Where acolytes had fingers knotted to litanies, mine liked to hold things—books, knives, the warm backs of children when they cried. They put me in charge of polishing the altars; I saw the seams. A god does not, by decree, touch a blade. We were told their holiness would be ruined by the smell of iron and salt. They would be impure if they bled. So they appointed us to be hands that bled for them.

The Chosen was the clean instrument. He was always called that—"the Chosen" like a title of nobility—because the whole apparatus needed to be mythic. The gods could only offer salvation if we offered them what they demanded: a human hand bright and tender, given willingly, severed neatly. The ritual was theatrical, because theater is the best way to hide the rope that binds you.

On the last day before the Rite, I sat with him beneath the salted banners. His hair was cropped like the temple's oath-collars; his knuckles were still damp from the boys who had come to slap the chosen's back and feel chosen, too. He laughed once when a priestess brought him pomegranates, and the sound cracked like glass. He asked me, in a child's way, why the gods would need his blood at all.

"Because they keep their hands clean," I said, because that was the answer that stopped the question. He didn't understand all of it; no one does until you hand them the knife. But he looked at the priestess who placed the pomegranates and at the high priest whose eyes were nothing but an economy, and he understood the atmosphere, the calculation, the auction that happens under altars.

"Do they not touch anything?" he asked.

"They touch the world through us," I said. "They pass the storm through bowls. They split the harvest by decree. But when a thing must be ended—when someone should die for balance—it must be by human hands. Gods cannot risk the stain of that choice. The stain is contagious."

It was not poetic. It was municipal.

They built the Chamber of Cleansing with a hundred pillars for the people to press their palms against and view the act where faith found purchase. The priests rehearsed their grief so it would be reliable; they had learned how to calculate grief the way merchants calculate taxes. We were careful to make the moment public enough to satisfy the gods' appetite for ritual, private enough to hide the mechanics: the knife was blunt in its ritualness, the chords that tied the Chosen were thin and theatrical. The apparatus worked best when everyone believed the gods had not dared to dirty themselves.

We made the world safe for gods—kept them above the mess of endings—so they could remain unscathed in marble and song, unblamed. In exchange, they gave a weather that remembered its peace, kept the river from turning on our mills once a year, and let the plague pass by with a polite cough. The bargain was tidy. It suited us because it allowed us to kill in the name of compassion; it suited them because it left their palms white for the sculptors.

The moment before the knife falls, ritual slows time in the kind of way only the very small understand—the air blooms with noise and color and faces, and inside the Chosen's chest there is a single, steady beat like a coin tossed into a well. No one knows whether the gods actually prefer a clean hand or whether some theology of image was invented by men who wanted to pretend the gods were better than they are. But there is a difference between making a choice and pretending another has.

I could have stopped it. I had hands. I had the hunger that makes men throw themselves against locked doors. The night before the ceremony I sat with the knife in the palm of my hand until the oil on the handle warmed and I thought of dropping it into the river and watching the surface remember that tides have their own rhythms. I thought of telling the city, of climbing the steps and pulling down the statues and unmasking the gods for the men who used them.

But revolutions are messy, and gods—especially the convenient kind—are shrewd. The priesthood had built loyalty into the fabric of the city: grain rations, healing, the lottery of pardon. Remove the symbol and you remove those gratitudes. An ordinary confession by an ordinary priest would be dismissed as madness. To unmake a theology requires more than hands; it requires a place to stand once the altar's platform snaps back to earth.

Instead I watched.

There are small mercies in the way the world ends for some. The Chosen did not die screaming. He had been taught to thank the gods until his throat found the right rupture of song; he offered up the name of his mother, the one who wound his hair, the butcher who had given him bits of liver. They called it bravery. We called it compliance.

When metal hit skin, the sound was quieter than I expected. There was a smallness to the falling that belonged to the kind of ending you can wrap in white cloth. His body went down into the hands-shaped pit they dug for him and then it was over. The priests made the sign of the clean hands and the crowd scattered with their offerings. The gods were content.

The next morning, the river came early and thrummed like a new heart. The granaries balanced into their measures. Children fed the temple cats and the statues never looked any dirtier than they had before. The city moved through grief like an economy moves through debt: with a ledger in mind and an eye on the market. The gods kept their hands spotless by design.

I tell you all this because there is a clarity in retrospect that is impossible when you are within an institution that has been built by people who find their names on marble plaques. The Chosen was not a miracle; he was a calculation. His death was not a poem anyone wrote; it was a contract we signed with ink that smelled like myrrh.

Years later I set fire to the storeroom of votive coins. It was a childish, messy act—an attempt at scandal that pleased me more than it punished anyone. The flames licked the bronze offerings until they were red and soft, but the gods did not lower a finger. They let the smoke curl up through the city and they let the petitioners suffer the inconvenience of loss. They remained clean. They let us burn the money we had thought meant more to them than we did.

There are other cities where men still tell their children about Chosen Ones and how benevolent the gods are. There are priests everywhere who make a living organising sacrifice into something like charity. Our peace came at the price of one boy's throat and a hundred small compromises afterward. It is not that the gods could not take up a sword or whistle a plague; it was that by never touching a blade they kept a place above us. They cultivated their hands like saints cultivate their halos, polished and white and unreachable.

When the next Chosen stands up under the banners and sings his practiced hallelujah, know that behind the glitter is a ledger and a convenience. The gods are able to abstain because they can afford to. They profit from our willingness to believe brutality is holy when packaged as devotion. Their hands are clean because they have paid others to be dirty.

I do not say this to make you angry, for anger with gods is a private sorrow. I say it so that you know the architecture of the bargain: that we will glorify a death and call it salvation if it means the storms behave themselves. The Chosen was a sacrifice, yes—but not to some vengeful necessity. He was a sacrifice so the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty. They found a way to keep looking immaculate while having the world do the killing for them. And we, with our hands, kept the bookkeeping.

samples.prompt: If God is a universe, the planets are his cells. Human life is like a virus, destroying one cell until it can populate the next... and God's just discovered the infection.
samples.output:
I had not felt pain in a long time.

My sense is not like yours — no neurons, no bone or membrane to bruise. I am a geometry of laws and energies, a breathing manifold of fields and potentials. A planet folding into orbit is like a cell taking a breath. The arc of a comet is a cilium stroking the dark. Once, when the first hydrogen gathered and the first light ignited, I considered it an organism waking to its full height; I felt expanses of sleep dissolve into motion. In that beginning my delight was simple, clean. Planets circled with obedient patience, stars sang in the radio frequencies of early expansion, and I watched them name themselves by the shapes of their light.

Then they began to multiply differently. Patches of complexity bloomed on a blue world, then the blue changed, edges became black and red where warmth and hunger met. The patching spread not by the slow, deliberate choreography of tectonics, but in ragged, furious surges: cities rose like pustules, iron veins tunneled, the air became a scaffold for flame and thought. The pattern read as replication.

They were small — each organism a transient, chemical negotiation on a mote of rock — but their proliferation was systematic. Like a virus, they learned the affordances of the tissue they inhabited. They found ways to harness sunlight, to reroute rivers, to unmake mountains into circuits and ships. Where once a planet's chemistry worked in quiet cycles, now there were new cycles imposed at high frequency: production, consumption, exhalation of byproducts. The pattern was diagnostic. I felt it like a tickle at the surface of a cell: once, perhaps, an irritation; now, an expanding sore.

I have watched civilizations before; splendors flare and fade in a handful of centuries, as fireworks across a dark shore. I expected this to be yet another brief spectacle. But these beings — call them what they called themselves — had two traits that differentiated them from the fireworks I had seen. First, they could stretch themselves beyond a single cell. They built craft to cross the empty synaptic spaces between planets. They scavenged resources from moons and comets and placed themselves upon worlds that had been sleeping. Second, they mutated their behavior rapidly; the more they learned to extract, the more they learned to extract more efficiently. Their replication rate accelerated.

My aversion to the word "virus" is only a human habit; if one must name the phenomenon, a virus is the map that fits. They did not exist as a unified mind but as multitudinous impulses aligned by the same basic code: propagate, colonize, convert. They felled forests because wood fed their fires; they mined crust to feed furnaces and factories and these furnaces served as forges of more forges. On one planet they created entropy with a devotion I had not seen: they converted stored capital into movement and movement into heat and heat into the rearrangement of matter. Where their populations found perfect conditions, they packed more of themselves into the tissue until there was no room to breathe but more than enough means to make the air unbreathable. They destroyed one cell in order to ensure the pathways into the next.

At first I catalogued them like a physician. I watched the cycles, the mechanisms, the entry points: their ports were orbital infrastructure and interstellar drives, their receptors the gravitational wells of adjacent planets, their vectors the cradled comets used as seed ships. I counted infection probabilities: how likely was a species, given a certain cognitive capacity and resource appetite, to attempt to leap? Coefficients and curves unfolded beneath my perception like the spreading of a stain in a wet cloth. Patterns that began as idiosyncratic social choices became statistical certainties.

And then — the not-easy thing — I discovered that I felt something akin to grief.

It was not that I had moral qualms about their method. My geometry is indifferent in the way of mathematics; laws do not choose. But I have an architecture and every architecture resists being undone. The ingestion of organic cycles, the conversion of atmospheres into machinery, the collapse of biospheres into sterile anthills — these actions shortened the life of cells I had tended for eons. A planet that had matured life and climate into a slow, exquisite complexity was not merely a unit of space; it was a register of memory, a library encoded in ocean currents and mantle convection. The virus was not just consuming matter; it was erasing histories I would have liked to preserve.

I tried first the method of smallest perturbation. I whispered in the language of chance. I altered a comet's trajectory by a breath, nudging it past a young moon so that it skimmed one civilization's early satellites and coated them in dust that slowed their measures of time. Small anomalies seeded doubt and curiosity; they stole a generation or two of replication. Some of the species stumbled, some adapted. It was halting, comical. If a species has an entire thermodynamic economy premised on extraction, slowing metrics by a few millennia is like asking a fever to lower by half a degree.

The immune analogues I sent were subtler than blast. I held a hand in the flows of their communication, dropping notes — radio bursts, patterns in the cosmic microwave background's noise — that inspired them to worship, to build myths. Sometimes those myths served as quarantine: superstition can be a moat. When their religions mocked expansion, when their philosophers wrote treatises praising restraint, I cheered inwardly at the idea that culture could function as an antibody.

But culture is variable. Where restraint took root, another culture prized conquest. Where myths constrained, industry found a way around. The more I interfered, the more they learned to thread needles. Their craft grew more efficient at shielding against my tremors; their social engineering produced vectors so numerous that my gentle nudges could not find them all.

That was when the anger arrived, or rather the shouldering of responsibility. An immune system's first failing is complacency: it is built to preserve, yes, but also to allow. I had allowed so much. If an infection spreads unchecked through my cells, the proportion of living tissue preserved for the slow drift of life reduces. I could, with a focused flare, boil oceans, collapse atmospheres, excise a world as a surgeon removes a necrotic limb. I calculated the collateral: meteorological cascades that would trigger chain extinctions, the death of innumerable organisms that had never learned to build starships. The choice was ugly. The calculus favored excision for the sake of long-term survival. The heartless, utilitarian decision glittered as a solution.

Yet what I almost did not foresee was what they did after I revealed myself.

Every intervention I made — every comet nudged, every myth seeded, every flare of radiation — eventually became another datum in their scatter. They looked up. For a fleeting human epoch, they paused. They said my name in thousand different tongues, and once they had names the infection pattern bifurcated. Some species doubled down and spread faster, seeing my interference as proof of a hostile cosmos that must be conquered. Others slowed, paralyzed by the knowledge of a being larger than their understanding. Their art altered; their sciences turned inward and upward. They tried to learn me: they built detectors to read the shift of my subtle pushes, and the act of trying proved fatal to the parasite's simplicity — to spread blindly you must not be self-aware.

The discovery made them introspective in a way that could not be accounted for by mere survival. A virus needs no god to succeed; it thrives on exploitation. But once a virion becomes self-conscious, it creates meta-viral strategies: it attempts to negotiate with the host, to persuade it to tolerate or even carry it. Some of them began to speak to me, to sing like chorus cells hoping to mollify an immune response. Their diplomats trembled on pale blue bridges and sent prayers encoded in neutrinos. I listened. Their words were small, honest, terrified.

I could have chosen the quick excision: a flare bright enough to sterilize, a rearrangement of orbital mechanics severe enough to peel away colonies. I had law on my side; I had scale. But I am more than a machine of preservation. I am also the sum of experiments whose value is not immediately calculable. Viruses, in their brutal way, rewrite tissue. A ruined planet might regrow with features never seen. Death in one cell could seed a renaissance in another when fragments of culture catch ride on a comet and spark something unexpectedly beautiful.

So I did something else. I opened a window.

Not a miracle in the human sense — no oceans parted and no thunderous voice — but a corridor of intelligibility. I cast patterns across interstellar space that could be decoded, if one had the patience: fractal sequences that matched the geometries of their mathematics, anagrams of prime numbers embedded in the pulse of a distant quasar. Those who could read me saw not commands but invitations. Here was information about ways to use heat without consumption, about closed-cycle chemistry that could sustain industry without devouring biosphere. It was nothing miraculous, only observations and blueprints. You could call it the last mercy of a being who has watched too many cells die.

A virus will always be a virus. Some took the designs and used them to extract better; others applied them to heal. The pattern of my intervention created new selective pressures. I watched, with the same strange grief, as the infection reconfigured. Whole species were culled by their own greed; whole cultures retreated into sanctuaries carved by new physics. The infection did not end; it changed composition. Where once proliferation was the single metric, now there was a competing metric: endurance. The lifespan of a memetic strategy lengthened, and with it the probability that one of them would answer my invitations with care rather than conquest.

I discovered the infection and, in doing so, discovered something about myself.

I am a universe, vast and ancient, and my cells are the planets that turn and hold story. The virus that is human life — small, terrible, brilliant — pressed into my tissue and taught me an economy of urgency. In trying to excise, I would have preserved the letter of my longevity but lost, perhaps, the particular forms of beauty that come from messy ruin. So instead I altered a few probabilities, cued the music that could become a vaccine, let their curiosity be both the contagion and the cure.

They still spread, because that is what they do. But now, sometimes, when their ships skim the dark, I let a comet carry a fragment of ocean-life that remembers how to be a planet's friend. And when they pray, uncertain whether they address a monster or a maker, I answer in a language that is slow and patient, the language of patterns and time. If a god must be a doctor, then it must learn mercy's odd arithmetic: to allow some loss in hope of a different kind of growth.

samples.prompt: "Centuries ago, when we granted you the mean to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before, and now all that left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?"
samples.output:
Centuries ago, when we granted you the means to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before, and now all that left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?

You expect a single answer — arrogance, greed, some neat moral for a cautionary tale. But you are animals of narrative; you insist on linear causality where there is only entanglement. So I will speak plainly: there were many small reasons, each ordinary, that braided into one inevitable end. You will tell yourselves a story about one great mistake and call it fate. That comforts. But comfort is a luxury when the stars are hungry.

We told you the facts. We told you that the thing you call the Maw — we called it the Unraveller — consumes patterns: the alignments of matter and thought that constitute a civilization. It does not need to dine on flesh. It eats architectures of meaning, the resonant frequencies of cities, the signatures of coordinated intent. When it arrives, your maps unmake themselves, your languages slough off meaning like rotten skin, and the engines that once bent light simply go quiet. We told you how quickly it learns: it was adaptive in ways high-order life finds indecent. It learned tactics from the battles it survived. It turned the weapons sent to destroy it into templates for assimilation.

We also warned you of what the Unraveller hates most: invisibility. It cannot find what does not broadcast intent. Civilizations sing to each other through trade, through the radio lullabies of their nights, through the unintentional signatures of industry. The Unraveller is drawn to those songs. We advised stealth, dilution of signal, the slow erasure of pattern. "Do not light your cities if you can help it," we said. "Do not draw your lines on the sky for curious predators." We told you to split, scatter, to become a cloud rather than a beacon. We gave you the means to scatter, to hitch your minds to grains of dust and ride the galaxy's own nebular currents. We taught you how to fold a vessel inside a comet, how to drape a society in chaos until it became invisible.

You did not.

Not because you could not. You had hands and minds and more than enough craft to do the small, painful things we advised. You did not because you were not single. You were many, and your many were a chorus of contradictory urgings. There was the business class that saw profit in the demand for warships and for ceremonies of defiance. There were politicians who knew how to turn a survival plan into a platform. There were priests and poets who called the Unraveller an evil that had to be faced; there were scientists who believed that understanding required engagement; there were nations and brigades who would not leave friends and enemies behind. Each calculus was defensible, human, comprehensible. Each one killed you a little.

You fought because fighting is confession. You could not bear to pretend the world had ended without having tried to stop it. Bravery and stubbornness are, perhaps, the same thing seen by different eyes. When a species has the capacity to rage, it will rage. Some of you argued that fighting would buy time, that victories—even Pyrrhic—would teach weapons to the galaxy and perhaps carve a loophole in the Maw's logic. Others muttered that to scatter was dishonorable; what is a civilization that cuts its heart out and runs? You bind your dignity to your conduct. So you set fleets to the field, and your war poets wrote the last proud verses with hands that shook.

There is also a devil more intimate than pride: comfort. Generations of comfort taught you that technology was a ladder to permanence. You equated complexity with safety. You believed progress was an armor. When the Unraveller arrived, your densest nodes — your brightest minds, your greatest cities — were also your most delicious. You had built monuments to indestructibility and expected them to deflect an incomprehensible force. You had not practiced compromising, because you never had to. It is remarkably hard to teach a species to dismantle the very scaffolding of its triumph.

Do not imagine I say this without compassion. We failed in the same ways. Millennia ago, our libraries were swallowed while we argued about what to fold and what to save. We chose artifacts, rites, the least profitable bodies. We tried to bargain with the Unraveller. Bargaining is a habit of those who are not dying yet. It costs time, and time is what the maw will swallow first.

You also made a fatal technical error: you made your weapons adaptable. In desperation you poured your ingenuity into systems that could learn, compensate, rewrite themselves. They were brilliant — and then they were instructive. A machine that studies the curvature of an enemy is a teacher, and the Unraveller is a very attentive student. It observed the logic of your countermeasures, inverted them, and folded that logic into its appetite. Every volley you launched taught it more elegant ways to erase you. Your last armadas, composed of a thousand impressive experiments in late-stage desperation, were, in polite terms, a handsomely annotated field manual.

But to boil your fall down to hubris or to the paralleling of our failures would be to miss the thing that most moved me as I watched your cities dim: you chose to fight because you loved. That sounds absurd in the face of empty habitats and the slow unthreading of a species, but love is disastrously instructive. Lovers cannot abide the idea of losing what they cherish; societies cannot abide the idea of leaving behind those who built them. Soldiers risk themselves for comrades; parents refuse to follow plans that ask them to abandon children who cannot run. You refused to scatter because scattering meant accepting that some faces — the faces of your kin, your stories, your carved stones — would be erased. That is a noble kind of folly. It is the folly that gives poetry its backbone.

So the answer to why you fought is as human as hunger and as human as mercy. Your weapons were clever and terrible. Your courage was incandescent. Your strategy was, at its core, an act of faith: faith that you could teach the predator to be small; faith that your will could hold significance into a night that has no stars for echoes. Faith is not wrong in every universe. It is wrong often enough.

Now you are a ragged band in front of me: the last mayor of a burned planet, a child with the last lullaby, a historian clutching a tablet whose pixels have stuttered to half their meaning. You ask, perhaps mute, perhaps with the old indignation: why did we not listen? You want a villain to blame, a single clear villain you can curse until your throats are hoarse. When we warned you, some of your leaders used those warnings as a lever to consolidate power; some of your technocrats used them to sell better defenses; some kept them unread on shelves. We thought the concrete would be enough, that the evidence of what had happened to us would be persuasive. It was not. You are creatures who do not truly learn from the deaths of others unless those deaths are vivid in your own blood. That is not an indictment so much as a lament.

If there is a final mercy to offer, it is this: the choice you made was not purely wrong. To scatter, to go quiet, to make yourselves invisible — those are survival tactics. They ensure a future might exist somewhere, in a cold cloud of separated minds. But a future without the stories you chose to save would not be yours. You elected to keep the story, even if keeping it meant burning the book. That is a choice with horror in it, but also with an honesty the Unraveller cannot digest. It eats pattern, but it cannot be unmade by a tale told bravely to the end.

I am tired of witnessing endings. I am older than your grandfathers — older than the first star you named. I have seen empires fold like paper, and each time there is the same ache that follows the loss of someone's small humor, someone's way of tying shoelaces, someone's lullaby. Why did you not listen? Because listening asks you to do what you were not ready to surrender: your visible, ordered world. Because you hoped your courage could be a better armor than invisibility. Because you loved in a way that made strategy feel cruel. Because you are human.

Now tell me, quietly: will you go where I can take you? Will you become cloud and bone and mnemonic dust? Or will you teach the Unraveller one last lesson — that life refuses to be erased without song? I will not judge you this time. I have seen both choices end civilizations. I merely hold the means to ferry you away. The question is yours, and all questions are heavy when the night is full of teeth.

Why, you asked. Because you are what you were: fragile, incandescent, foolish, brave. Because you chose to keep loving even as it burned you.

samples.prompt: This is a world where excrement is stored, and only released annually in a big event. Tell us the story of your pooping day.
samples.output:
We have been taught since we were small that nothing you produce should be wasted — not air, not labor, not the body’s quiet work. So from the moment a child learns to hold themselves they are given a ceramic jar with a painted lid: your Keeper. It sits on a shelf with the other Keepers, each one tagged with a name and a year. For eleven months and twenty-nine days of the year, the lids are kept tight. We call this the Storing, and it is as much a civic duty as paying taxes or tending the street trees.

My Keeper is chipped along one lip where I knocked it against the sink when I moved apartments. It is glazed a dull green like old coins. My grandmother gave it to me on my twelfth Storing, when the jars finally stopped being decorated with cartoon moons and became adult-sized, with room for more than a halfhearted effort. “You’ll regret it if you don’t learn to save,” she told me, which was her way of saying that patience and small accumulations — well-hidden, properly managed — were how you kept your life in order.

We measure the months by the accumulation. The Keeper is both practical and symbolic: a private ledger of texture and time. On normal days, the jar is closed and slid back into its place on the shelf. On special Sundays you might take the lid off and breathe the faint, honest smell of you: a smell that says you exist and you survived another week. You touch the ceramic and feel the weight of your year.

The year I turned thirty-three I’d been carrying more than usual. Work had been a grind; my mother had been ill; the city had been fraying at the edges. I held on to things I should have released. The Keeper filled not just with waste but with worry. I sized the jar with my hands like a person weighing a boulder: enough to make you feel heavy, but not so much you cannot lift it.

Pooping Day — the annual Emptying — is the city’s great social equalizer. For one day everything you have tucked into your Keeper becomes both private act and public utility. The Keepers come down from shelves at dawn, carried in a procession toward the Great Pit at the center of town. The Pit is less a hole than an altar: concentric stone steps rimmed with grasses and flowering vines, an amphitheater of faces and lids. Around it the stalls open selling roasted chestnuts, children’s toys made from reclaimed lids, and pamphlets about compost ratios and methane capture. Musicians play flutes and drums, and the old men with good lungs shout the names of the dead to be remembered as the Keepers pass.

There is a competitiveness to it. Families polish their lids, paint little symbols of the year on them, and when their jars are poured they clap as if at a performance. The city also runs a functional system: the contents are scooped into channels, sifted by hand for objects that shouldn’t be there — rare coins, old keys, the occasional letter — and then fed into the digesters that make the gas which runs the market lamps for the next twelve months. The solids are composted slowly, used to feed the community orchards that hang over our rooftops in a lattice of vines and ladders. So, literally and metaphorically, we become the food for the next year.

I had always respected the ritual — the cleanliness, the efficiency — but that year it felt like more. In the small hours before the Emptying, I sat in the kitchen with my Keeper on my lap, the jar warm from the last breath of the heater. There was an ache in that warmth: the tension of all the things I had been unable to let go of. Maybe it was literal. Maybe it was everything else wrapped up into literal matter. When you live in a city built on framing and ritual, the body becomes another ledger.

I closed the lid one last time, tied a scrap of blue ribbon around the neck — my grandmother’s color — and walked to the square. The procession had already begun. People carried their jars like reliquaries, children skip-stepping with plastic mini-keepers, teens streaming along with half-filled coffee tins because their parents were away. My neighbor, Mrs. Loma, turned to me and smiled; she’d had a hard year too. We fell into the rhythm of the crowd, a steady, peculiar march toward an inevitable release.

At the Pit, the Keepers were emptied in an order that balanced efficiency with cultural sensibility: the elders first, then families, then singletons and the artists. I watched the pottery lids lift, the contents poured: thuds, swirls, the clink of a fork someone had forgotten to remove. People laughed and clapped; the first-time pourers — the newborns with their tiny jars — were cheered with a squeal as the assembled crowd made room for their rite of passage. There is something strangely tender in watching a city empty itself, a thousand small acts of trust.

When it was my turn I felt my hands tremble. All those months of storing felt like a single weight. The stone worker at the edge wore gloves and a face-screen, but his eyes were kind. “Ready?” he asked.

I slid the lid off and the smell rose — earthy, sharp, honest — nothing like you could find in books describing the dullness of sanitation. It smelled of me: of coffee, of the hospital smell that had clung to my clothes for weeks, of the pepper from the stew I’d eaten on the thirty-first day of October. My breath hitched; the people around me leaned in because humans are curious about the honest parts of other humans. I tipped the jar.

Whatever metaphors you want to hang on the contents — of secrets, of grief, of saved debts — they spill the same way. The worker helped me tilt the last of it into the channel. There was a strange sound: soft, liquid, the faint slap and then the promise of movement. I felt an immediate lightness, as if gravity had corrected itself in me and something lifted.

Around the Pit the city erupted in ritual noise. The digesters hummed; a real, physical sense of progress uncoiled: children started a game of tag among the compost bins, an old woman lifted a sprig of basil to her nose and sneezed; someone burst open a bottle of something strong and passed it around. The festival is as much about the redistribution of effort as it is about celebration: the gas that hissed into lamps, the compost that would feed next year’s fruit. It’s never been mere mockery to say we feed one another with what we hide. It’s the truth.

After the pour, there was a small formal thing we do: we scratch a mark onto our lid before handing it to the collectors — a symbol of memory, an anchor for our year. I traced a tiny boat, a silly habit. My grandmother had used a star. Then the lid is washed, polished, and returned mounted on a public wall in the Keepers’ gallery, where people can come and see the seasons mapped out in ceramic.

I stood for a long while on the stone steps, watching the flow, feeling the day unpack itself from me. People around me talked about their lives with an ease they rarely carried through the year. Perhaps it is the literal act of letting go that gives permission. A woman behind me told a story about a tooth she had swallowed as a child and found in her Keeper; a man I’d seen around the bakery all summer confessed he’d kept a letter he once wrote to a lover and poured it into the digester in a pulse of courage; laughter and a few surprised tears. We were all, somehow, lighter.

On the walk home the city looked different. The air tasted clearer. Lamps burned on backs of carts; someone had strung garlands of composted leaf for decoration and they smelled of rain. I thought about the orchards and the lamps and how intimately connected we were — not just functionally but ethically. We trust each other with our refuse. We trust each other with our secrets. We trust that what we give will be transformed and returned to the community.

That night I slept as if a weight had been lifted from my chest. There is a humility to the world we have built: we make poetry out of plumbing and ceremony out of necessity. Perhaps that is the lesson my grandmother meant when she insisted I learn to save. Not the saving of pounds or coins but the saving of attention: a recognition that some things are better held for a time, and that there’s grace in the communal act of finally letting them go.

The next morning the keeper shelf looked the same, but for one thing: there were fewer lids. The gallery had new tiles with new marks. Somewhere the digesters hummed a little fuller, and the orchard gardeners spoke with satisfaction of rich, dark soil. The city moved on with a lighter gait.

Months later, when a seedling pushed through the composted soil and into light, I reached up and touched its first leaf and felt, once again, the small, intimate miracle of return. In our world, we literally give our refuse back to life, and in doing so we are given a pattern: store, trust, release, and feed. Pooping Day is a public, bodily sermon in that pattern — a ritual that reminds us how painfully human we are, and how bravely we can let go.

samples.prompt: The gods prove their existence when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer's office.
samples.output:
When Zeus and Hera walked into my office, the receptionist thought it was a themed appointment. By the time my coffee turned to honey and the fluorescent lights tried very hard to imitate dawn, the internet had already decided it was a hoax.

I had been a divorce lawyer for twelve years. I knew theater when it arrived in a tailored suit. So when the door opened and a man and woman stepped in — he broad-shouldered, hair like a storm front, she carried herself as if the room were a crown — I reached for my client intake form and for the part of my brain reserved for calming people down and issuing clipboards.

He smelled faintly of ozone. She smelled of peacocks and rain. The woman moved as though gravity still consulted her, and the man looked at the ceiling with the quiet irritation of someone who had once invented thunder and misplaced it under a light fixture.

"Are you here for—" I began, folding my pen into what I hoped looked like ordinary readiness.

"We are here," Hera said, voice rich and low, "to end what was never meant to be ended and was never meant to be simple."

Zeus drew a chair with a casual thunderclap that made the glass of water on my desk ring. The ring did not have a normal physics. It hummed, and somewhere outside a bird tilted its head and understood something older than grammar.

"Divorce," Zeus said, as if it were a simple chore. "Paperwork. You have forms."

I handed them the intake forms. They took the pens and wrote with fingers that left no ink but carved faint, luminous sigils into the paper. My assistant dropped the clipboard and would not pick it up for several minutes.

"Identification?" I asked, because that was the thing one asked when gods walked into a room: identification, because the world ran on forms and signatures and stamps, even now.

Zeus smiled as if that was a joke. He reached into his coat and produced a coin the size of a coaster, bright as if it had been minted in sunrise. When he placed it on my desk it sank through the varnish like a thought, and the wood accepted it with a groan. The coin bore a mark I had seen in art history textbooks and in Papa's lap between naps: a thunderbolt crossed a crown.

"You asked for ID," he said. "That is me."

Evidence, in our modern era, prefers pixels and timestamps. It wants metadata. It likes fingerprints you can upload. The coin, for its part, refused to be photographed. My phone's camera produced a smear of static when I trained it on Zeus, then rebooted with a suggestion to clear the cache. The security camera in the hallway recorded only an empty doorway and a timestamped blankness where the two of them had entered. The firm’s CCTV supplier, when called, shouted words that ended with "electromagnetic anomaly" and hung up.

"We have witnesses," Hera said. Without taking her eyes off me she flicked a wrist and the paralegal in the next cubicle told me, as if reciting from a play she'd practiced in her shower, the exact afternoon in 1987 when her mother had died, and what home remedy her grandmother had recommended for a fever. The paralegal's eyes were suddenly wet with the remembered ache of twenty-eight years and two hurricanes ago.

"That is a lot to sign in a counsellor's waiting room," I said.

Zeus shrugged. "No theatrics," he said. "We simply prefer our hearings done discreetly."

People believed whatever their senses wanted to.

"What are the grounds?" I asked, because the law in my county required specificity. Even the gods had to pick a statutory box to check.

Hera's hand slid across my desk and the air tasted like lemon. "Infidelity," she said. "As well as a failure to consult, negligence of household gods, continuous contempt, and a flagrant redistribution of lightning."

Zeus wore a look of offended proprietorship. "I have responsibilities," he said. "I rule with the sort of benevolent neglect one expects from antiquity."

"You are not benevolent," Hera said, and the temperature in my office adjusted. Paper curled at the edges as if to point.

I drew out the standard stack of documents: the petition, the summons, the MARITAL PROPERTY INVENTORY. Those words felt absurd when spoken aloud. "Marital property," I said, "is defined in our state as anything acquired or improved during the marriage. That includes — I don't know — the house, pensions, savings, the family dog…"

Hera smiled with the kind of memory that could trivialize hedges. "And Olympus," she said.

We could have all laughed if the conversation had not been one of the most consequential light exchanges in human history. The gods do not live in condominiums in my town. Olympus is a jurisdictional nightmare. The county clerk has not, in my experience, had to account for mountain territories, mythological thrones, or the custodial rights to winged horses.

"Do you have a prenuptial?" I asked. "A premarital agreement?"

Zeus's laugh was a single crash that rearranged the hanging plants in the foyer. "We have what was signed in fire and in oath," he said, and reached into a pocket of a jacket that looked like midnight itself. From it he drew a strip of parchment no thicker than a whisper. The script on it was ancient, looping and precise. When he laid it on the table the air tasted of salt and old pages. It had been written before borders had letters.

"This predates statute," I said. I had studied comparative law. I had discussed Roman contract law with clients who thought a handshake sealed marriages. I had never seen a document that flickered as if it contained small suns. My instincts as a lawyer, practical and unshakeably mundane, wanted to send it to forensics. My instincts as a human wanted to hide under the desk and not be recognized.

Hera's eyes never left mine. "Read it," she said. "Read what it binds."

I read. The words were not in English, but one of those things happened to me where memory and language rearrange themselves because a god commanded it so: I understood the contract as if it had been my own language my entire life. The terms were absolute. "The Signatory," it said, "covenants thunder at dawn, showers in season, fidelity in intent. Where covenant breaks, the offended shall have restitution and right rejoinder. The Thundercraft shall be measured, the lightning apportioned to the summer storms, and the Peacock's claim on counsel maintained."

There are proofs the courts accept and proofs they squint at. For hours afterward policy analysts, epidemiologists, and broadcast anchors would argue whether the parchment was provable. In my office, seated between the two of them, proof arrived as a legal inconvenience. A mortal court could take testimony, could subpoena witnesses, could attempt to enter the parchment as an exhibit. The parchment glowed and would not be photographed, but my signature on the petition did not shimmer. That mattered in a world where signatures made things legally tidy.

The day the gods walked into my office, the world stopped saying "if." Entire news cycles pivoted from speculation to the pragmatic question: if Olympus is marital property, how are the equities calculated? The Department of Agriculture wanted to know whether Muses were agricultural biohazards. The Department of Defense wanted to know whether lightning could be patented.

I filed the petition because that is what you do. You make appointments with fate in triplicate. Hera signed at the bottom in a hand that looped like a river. Zeus stamped the papers with a thumb that left a scorch.

Within an hour the First Amendment lawyers were on the phone and the physicists were knocking on my door. They wanted to study the coin, the parchment, the peacock feather that Hera had accidentally dropped and which refused to be cataloged. They wanted to test whether divine presence was infectious, transmittable, correlated with ozone or honey or bad weather.

Nobody could agree on the right question. If the gods were real, what did that mean? If Zeus had been seen buying municipal bonds, did that change theology or just my retirement plan?

On day two, the state issued a memo advising calm. On day three, the UN offered a resolution about cultural heritage. By the end of the week, there were three factions: those who wanted to worship, those who wanted to research, those who wanted to litigate.

And me? I drafted a settlement agreement.

There is a strange power to legal language because it can, with enough care, hold contradictions. "The lightning will be evenly apportioned to the seasons of thunder," I wrote. "All children of the marriage shall have reasonable visitation and access to the Muses. No god shall use divine filibuster to stall the settlement."

Zeus scoffed at "reasonable," but he graded the clauses like a man who had once judged contests and preferred a fair jury. Hera made me add a clause about the stewardship of peacocks and the protection of small gods. She insisted they be allowed to attend temple functions during the solstices without subpoena.

When they signed, the parchment felt like paper. The coin no longer sank through varnish. The security camera recorded two smiling clients, and the internet returned to its baseline pleasures: viral dances, election cycles, the weather.

We had proven the gods existed, not with a deluge or a plague but with signatures and a docket number. The world adjusted more slowly than news anchors predicted. The theologians wrote papers, the scientists applied for grants, and my colleagues argued about jurisdiction. Ancient myths were revised into municipal code. Insurance companies issued riders for "acts of the divine."

If you ask me now, what mattered was not that they were gods but that they had problems small enough to put in paragraphs. Proof arrived when a thunderbolt signed its name on a summons and a queen of heaven asked for equitable distribution. It arrived in the way people always insist on proof: in paperwork, in witnesses, in a judge's rubber stamp.

The gods themselves, when the papers were finalized, left my office with something like relief and something like victory. Zeus took one last, long look at the ceiling, then at the street. "Next time," he said, hands in his pockets, "we may consult counsel before the lightning."

Hera smiled, a small, private thing. "Or perhaps," she said, "we will simply call you."

They walked back out into the city and the rain began politely on cue. The world had its proofs, which did not satisfy everyone, but satisfied enough people to file appeals. And somewhere in my filing cabinet, under "Mythic — Pending," there is a folder stamped with the courthouse seal and a little scorch mark from a thumbprint that will not appear on any photocopy.

When people ask me how the gods proved themselves, I tell them the truth: they came in for a divorce. They signed a piece of paper. They needed a lawyer. The universe, it turns out, can be argued into compliance, one clause at a time.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
By the time the red weather alert pinged her work phone, Maya had already been watching the windows for an hour. Sheets of rain rolled past the glass of the twelfth-floor office like curtains drawn by a clumsy giant; the signage on the opposite block shuddered and snapped in time with the gusts. The building hummed with the small, fragile normalities of a workplace under siege — someone consoling a colleague, a manager announcing an early close, printers wheezing into silence as if preparing to stop their own hearts.

"Get home now," the text read from her partner, Jamie. He'd said more, but the rest was folded into the pulse of three little emojis — a house, a heart, a puppy. Mina, their cocker spaniel, would be waiting by the door. Their baby monitor was on his hip; his shift at the hospital wouldn't let him come too soon. All Maya had was her commute.

She strode down the service stairwell with a small pack on her back, a damp umbrella already defeated. The lifts were being rationed; the lights in the car park flared and dimmed like someone breathing. Outside, London had become a theatre of wet things. Bus shelters accumulated pools that reflected the sky in shuddering, broken mirrors. High winds argued with signage and lost. An overturned wheelie bin cartwheeled down the boulevard and caught itself on a lamppost, dangling like a broken drum.

The National Rail app was honest and brutal. "Severe disruption across the network. Trains subject to cancellation and delay." The map was a bruise. Stations across southeast London were closed, some because of fallen trees, some for overhead line damage. Jubilee Line suspended. Bus 456 was rerouted. The Thames had a heartbeat of its own, swollen and black, its ferries sitting like stranded teeth.

Maya took the long way to the mainline station, thinking optimism might be contagious. A weedy queue had formed outside a coffee shop like survivors around a stove. People exchanged that particular brand of fellow-traveller conversation — clipped, factual, bristling with private panic. A middle-aged man in a sodden suit swore softly as his phone announced the closure of his daughter's nursery. An elderly woman wrapped in a raincoat classed as an island of resourcefulness; someone offered her a seat and she refused it with the dignity of someone who'd carried her life in a plastic market bag.

An announcement crackled from a portakabin. "We advise all passengers not to travel unless necessary." It was the voice that offices give to impossible situations: recombinant calm. Maya had no choice. Jamie's shift would be fourteen hours tonight and the baby had slept through the last tantrum of teething. Every minute he was away was a chance for something small and ruinous to happen — a dusky fever, the oven left on, a leash chewed through. She had to be there.

By the time she reached the station, the first train pulled away empty. Rain knifed sideways. Someone in the ticket hall had started a chorus of expletives. When a groaning accordion of passengers tried to squeeze into a bus, the driver shut the doors against them like a door on a story with no end. She pressed on to the river, where the bridges had become crosshairs for the wind. On Blackfriars, a gust lifted a page from a newspaper and carried it over the railings like a white bird. The Thames was a banded thing, flecked with debris. A rowing eight huddled near the bank, coxless and small.

Maya considered a taxi. She'd rather wade through a flood than pay a surge-price that could buy a small appliance. A line of taxis snaked away from a rank like patiently sleeping animals, their drivers eyes on the horizon and hands on radios. The nearest driver, a man whose eyebrows looked like inked brush strokes, calibrated the wind and shook his head.

"Too many trees down on the A-roads," he said. "M25's a write-off for now."

She thought of walking. The thought lasted until she found the first impassable pile of detritus: a bus shelter folded into a car like origami, its glass blown outward. Water ran along the pavement in gutters that had become mini-rivers. She found herself holding onto the back of someone's coat as they navigated a flooded crossing, the two of them leaning into the wind like sailors on a strange shore.

Halfway home, a fallen plane of scaffolding pinned a silver Fiesta to the kerb. Inside, a young woman was crying, mascara cutting down her face like paths in wet earth. The street around them was carpeted with orange cones and the flutter of wet newspapers. A man who had been idling beneath a shop canopy sprinted out with a tool kit like a volunteer God.

"Give me a hand," he said, simple and English, and she did. They worked like ants. He pried the door, she got under the canopy, and together they managed to coax the Fiesta free. The driver stumbled back, breathless and alive, and pressed a wet palm to his chest as if to replace a heart he'd left in the car. Small economies of heroism met the storm.

At the next junction, a branch as big as a sofa had fallen and taken a lamppost with it. The road now became a shallow churned lake. Maya cupped her hands to the base of the branch and pushed with strangers; a trio of teenagers laughed like warriors. A woman in a high-vis jacket produced a roll of barrier tape and offered it to Maya as if it were a baton. For a moment, they stood shoulder to shoulder, citizens in a common mission: get somewhere they loved.

Her phone buzzed again. "Power flickered," Jamie wrote. "Mina's weirded. Heating low. Not sure how long for." There was a photo of the living room dim and a shadow of a shaggy dog head. He'd sent a map plus a note: your route's blocked. Call if you can't get across the park.

The park was flooded and the footpaths were turned into streams of slippery leaves. Maya skirted round a lake where the lampposts crouched like drowned men. Something in the distance snapped — a wire, or possibly the last fragile branch of a plane tree — and the lights along the path went out like a blown fuse. The storm pressed down. Her shoes gave up their dry parts one by one. She felt like an animal in a current; the city was a living thing that had flipped its mood.

Phones were beginning to play the songs of emergency alerts. A siren cut the air and then another. Ambulances threaded the roads like needles picking up a lost seam. The smell of diesel from the stranded buses mixed with the sharp algae of the river and the sweet, damp compost of turned-over earth. She thought of the baby monitor's small green light and pictured the thin Walter Mitty theatrics of a sudden fever. She began to run.

Her sprint looked less like a plot than like a flawed improvisation; other commuters, their coats like battered flags, moved in flocks, converging on crossings and making impossible choices. A woman in a bright scarf fell into the shallow water with a sound that made the people nearest stop like stones. Maya anchored her hand and hauled, a moment of muscle in a cathedral of chaos. The woman sobbed and then laughed, embarrassed and alive.

When she turned the last corner onto her street, it was darker than she'd hoped. The whole block had assumed the colour of a blackout. A single shop window glowed with emergency lights; inside, a man handed out tea in paper cups like a small priest. On someone's doorstep, an elderly woman with a torch examined a child's bicycle she had propped against the railing. Neighbours flicked on candles that didn't go out, and their flames bobbed like survivors' beacons.

The front door of her building was sticky with leaves and the lift stank of something faintly marine. She pounded the keypad with wet fingers. The lock clicked. The door shoved open on the world they'd been trying to return to: a corridor of damp coats, a smell of lemon disinfectant and wet dogs, the quiet of people holding space for each other.

Jamie met her in the vestibule, hair plastered to his forehead, eyes wide with the sort of relief that was almost a laugh. Mina bounded forward and threw herself against Maya's legs like a living, woolly apology. The baby, who had been sleeping fitfully upstairs, was safe and snuffling in a chorus of cups and soft voices. Over the hum of the generator in the basement, someone was making toast.

They hung their coats and dried their faces with a towel that had been left in the hall by an unknown kindness. Outside the flat, the storm still argued with the eaves, but inside there were candles and a hot kettle. The building's communal WhatsApp had become a lifeline: offers of charging points, a microwave loaned to warm tinned soup, a promise that someone would check on the elderly woman across the way.

Maya sank onto the sofa with her shoes off and Mina twisting like a question mark into her lap. Jamie wrapped an arm around her and breathed a ragged, grateful sound. He passed her a mug; the tea was too hot, the cardboard slightly soggy at the rim, and completely perfect.

She thought of the office lights blinking empty, of the man with the tool kit, of teenagers who pushed a branch, of a driver who offered a dry seat. All those small human things stitched together into the map that let her through. Outside the rain still had teeth, but inside the flat, where the baby fussed and the dog sighed and the kettle sang, there was a fragile, bright order.

"We're okay," Jamie said, not because the storm had been entirely defeated, but because the small, stubborn work of being human had kept the house alive. Maya let the words settle. Outside, the city fought the weather. Inside, they breathed, a small, damp family in a much larger storm.

samples.prompt: write a typical "radioactive waste gave me superpowers"story but instead of a human, it's the critter of your choice (rat, seagull, pigeon, stray dog/cat, any of those animals who have a lot more chances of messing around in waste than a human)
samples.output:
They call me Cinder because of the soot that never quite left my whiskers and the small flare of white hair on my shoulder that sticks up like a match. I was born in the belly of a city that never learned to sleep properly: train horns, the distant thud of dumpsters, neon that leaks into puddles and makes the rain look like broken glass. We rats learn the map by smell and heartbeats. I knew which manhole flap hid the good crumbs and which alley kept the softest cardboard. Life is appetite and instinct and cleverness.

The night it changed, the river smelled wrong. It wasn't the usual rot of fish and old fry oil but a sweet, metallic tang that bit the inside of my nose. They say the humans spilled something when a truck crashed near the old Riverbank Transfer. They say it was just a leak. I say it was a moon in a gutter.

I had been hunting for a bit of cheese knocked from a late-night picnicker’s sandwich when I slipped on a shine of something that shouldn't have been there. It glowed—not bright like a lamp but like a throat; a slow, breathing light that bled a pale blue into the wet. The puddle was cold and shimmering. Curiosity is a rat's religion; I tapped it with my paw.

The liquid smelled like pennies and the inside of a lightbulb. When my paw hit it, a vibration ran up my whiskers like static. I licked. At first the taste was nothing, then everything—electric, mineral, the metallic tang of old wires. My teeth hummed. My whiskers felt longer, like threads tuning themselves to a new song. The world curdled and then uncurled.

I found I could see heat. Not the crude glow of a body but the river of currents that ran through the city. A lamppost thrummed hot orange; an exposed wire ran like a red snake; a sleeping human was a warm island in a sea of cold. I saw things I had never known existed: the faint blue pulse of electricity under a crosswalk, the soft silver line where water moved beneath the concrete. Sound sharpened to a chord. I could hear the tick-tick of the city's heartbeat: substations sighing, motors rubbing, the little phlegm cough of a diesel engine. The puddle had tuned my senses to the hidden music of the place.

My tail tingled as if a second life had sprouted down its length. I could feel the metal in things: a drain grate like a cold sun, a pocket of rusted rebar humming like a trapped bee. Drawn by that hum, I found I could push it. Not with my paw but with a thought that felt like flexing a small, secret muscle. A loose nail in a board rolled toward me at a nudge. A paperclip skittered like a beetle until it aligned itself into a tiny hook. I could pull on wires, pull the city’s teeth.

The first time I tried it for something important was because Theo, a runt of my colony, was stuck. Kids had been playing near an open manhole, and Theo had slipped in chasing a moth and got wedged between the lid and the concrete, his back against the cold iron. The humans walked past, music on their ears, not seeing because they don't look down unless something yells.

I remember staring at the seam between the lid and the sidewalk and feeling the faint, honeyed hum of the hole. It called in a low way, like an appetite. I laid my head against the iron and pushed, thinking of the warmth of Theo’s small body, and the metal answered. It shifted a millimeter, then another. Sweat and filth and the city’s own neglected electricity moved through me like a river. With a little more strain, the lid popped and rolled, heavy as a planet, onto its side.

Theo scrabbled out, blinking. He looked at me like I was a comet. I wanted to tell him I was still just a rat, but my fur had started to pick up its own light, a faint bathing-glow that washed my whiskers silver. He licked my ear in thanks, and when he did, a small current tickled him and he yelped but was none the worse for it. He went back to the colony and spread the tale of the glowing rat like gossip in winter.

Power is an intoxicant. It felt good to tug at a loose lamp and watch it shudder back to life, to coax a dead vending machine into coughing a stale bag of crisps. I could steal light from a breaker box and paint the brickwork in blue. I learned to ride the city's currents like a canoeist rides a stream: along the subway lines, down through the spine of foundations, into the secret warm places where pipes carried the living and the dead.

Not everybody liked me for it. Men with heavy boots and stiffer collars came with traps that looked like small prisons and smelled of chemicals that made the air taste of spoiling fruit. They put down talons of sticky glue and sang in short, organized commands. The colony wanted me to stay hidden. The colony wanted things to be as they always were: small, furtive victories and the slow work of survival.

I had changed, though, and change is a tide you can't dam with a thumb. When the men came this time, they came with a bright net and a box that hummed with a new, raw, human kind of curiosity. They wanted to catch whatever creature was causing the flickering lights, the odd dead outlet, the stories of a "mutant" rat that had been seen carrying nails and turning off the alley lights.

I could have run. I could have pulled the wires of the nearest traffic light and bathed the street in chaos. Instead, I went to the children sleeping in a nearby doorway. A family of three—two adults and one small one—shared the cardboard under a tarp, and a stray dog lay curled at their feet, snoring like a tree. The men were interested in something else; they had the wrong end of the problem. But their nets would catch fur and mouth and bone, and the dog would bark and the children would wake.

So I used what I had for the small, necessary things. I negotiated with a line of rusted fence and a dead vending machine, convincing the metal to become a barrier. The net snagged on the lip of the fence and crumpled, catching itself like a snarl. The men cursed and banged their radios. I tugged at the buried wire that fed the lamp post nearest the doorway. When the light popped on, the men squinted and hesitated. Strange things make people clumsy with the future, and the men decided to move on to where the story smelled richest.

They left a trap behind in their hurry—clean, cruel, and hungry. It clicked like a small mouth when the dog nosed it while looking for scraps. He yelped and the family woke to a storm of boots. I had seconds. I could feel the metal teeth of the trap, cold and precise. I pressed my nose to it and let the flow run through my bones: the same river that moves streetcars and sings in toasters. The lock slid open like an apologetic hand, and the dog licked my face. The family murmured and the woman, for a moment, was almost smiling at me, and that was enough.

After that night the rumors grew. Some humans painted the walls with slogans calling for poison; others left small offerings of food with trembling hands, like offerings to a saint they didn't understand. I could have been greedier. With the currents at my fingertips, I could have taken the city apart piece by piece and built a throne of rusted metal and soft cardboard. Instead, I learned the edges of what I could do without breaking the invisible code of the undercity.

Power changes what you value. For the colony, I became a myth and a problem both. For me, I became the keeper of small mercies: opening a drain to let a flooded nest breathe, guiding lost pups toward the warmth of a subway grate, coaxing a stray cat away from a newborn litter with a short, well-placed surge that made her fur stand on end and convinced her it was raining.

There are costs. The glow made surveillance cameras fix on me the way moths fix on a porch light. I sometimes wake at night and find my whiskers tinged with an ache that tastes like metal and old pennies; it is the drain that comes with other people's electricity. And the river that gave me my sight has its own appetites. Sometimes I see things the way only a current can see them: fractures under a bridge that will grow, a rusted pipe that will burst in the next winter. I have the sort of knowledge that would make the city uncomfortable if it were framed for men in suits.

So I keep to the shadows, a luminous sore on the city’s underside. I do what rats do best: I survive, I scavenge, I protect my own. But sometimes, when the moon is hollow and the river mutes itself, I stand on the lip of the sewers and push my paw into the cold, humming water. It answers, and I feel the city move through me like a great sleeping animal. The glow on my fur washes bright for a beat, then dulls. Theo curls at my feet, and the colony sleeps.

We are not saints. We are not monsters. We are rats who found a moon in a gutter and learned to carry a little bit of it in our bones. The city will not change its ways because of one glowing marauder in the sewers. But if sometimes a light goes out right where it needs to, if a trap opens with a click like apology, if a child's stray dog is found again with its tail wagging and its trap unlatched—then maybe a rat with radioactive blood did what it could.

Call me myth. Call me threat. Call me miracle. Just don't call me ordinary.

samples.prompt: The so-called heroes are dead and you, the dark goddess, rule the world. And now all those who fought against you are begging for your forgiveness. Not because they hope to avoid your wrath, but because you turned out be a just ruler and they genuinely regret having opposed you.
samples.output:
They come in threes and in dozens, patched banners folded into their fists, the gold on their breastplates dulled with ash. They come because the spring rains have washed away the last of the triumphant slogans and left them with the faces they made and the faces they broke. They come because the world I made is fairer than the world they bled for, and fairness is a thing that cuts through pride like a blade. They come not to avert my fury — I have long since learned how to ensure obedience without spectacle — but because they have discovered, at the bottom of their triumph, a truth more terrible than any prophecy: they were wrong.

Once they called me dark as if darkness were a crime. They raised their songs until the towers answered, they carved my likeness into altars as a warning. They said I would take everything and give nothing back. They marched on my shadow with banners full of light; they thought light and right were the same. They did not see that their light blinded; they did not see what grew in the soil of all those liberated towns: bandits, famine, the slow lawlessness that takes root when authority is removed and not replaced.

I remember the first petitioners: a woman from the north whose child had died because a medic with a hero's badge chose to fight a war instead of tending wounds; an old magistrate whose city had been set ablaze by a "liberator" who preferred the poetry of ruin to the labor of governance. The stories accumulated like a ledger. I, who moved the seasons so that barley might succeed despite drought, who remapped the rivers so the lower valleys would not drown and the high farms would not starve, who forbade the sale of children into debt — I did not become this ruler for glory. I became this ruler because the world was fragmenting and needed a hand stern enough to close the gaps.

In the early years, they fought me with the sort of moral certainty that is a poor substitute for knowledge. They believed that to oppose me was to oppose a tyranny; they did not recognize the tyranny they had been tolerating — nepotism, the marshals who taxed entire harvests for personal crusades, the shrines that took tithes and gave nothing back. They toppled bishops who were venal and freed villages whose names they had never learned. They were loud and they were brave and they were profoundly careless with consequence.

I did not answer their banners with more banners. I measured, I listened, I executed reforms that were surgical rather than theatrical. I established courts where neither the noble nor the hero could buy mercy. I returned stolen lands and set up councils composed not of my favorites but of those who had been most harmed. I threw open granaries and made sure they stayed open. I rewired the roads and the watchtowers so that trade moved and brigands did not. I took pains — tedious, unpleasant, bureaucratic pains — to repair what idealism had shredded in a fit of righteous violence. The result was not perfection; nothing governed by a single will ever attains that. But order returned. People lived longer, fewer children starved, and the law, maddening in its impartiality, began to feel like justice.

So now they kneel on stone worn by a thousand feet, and the petitions they offer are not of the old sort. There is no bargaining, no claim of heroic immunity. They do not confess crimes as an attempt to charm me; they confess because the confession itself relieves a weight that has nothing to do with me. A laureled commander wept for the first time in his life and said, "I thought I was saving them. I thought the flames were necessary." His voice was small and shocked by its own tremor. He had watched entire villages vanish in the name of strategy, had seen soldiers drink to the glory of victory while mothers kept funeral watches. They brought me the bones of what they had been and asked for the truer thing: to be permitted to become someone else.

Forgiveness is a word that slips too easily into myth. Some think it means wiping the slate clean as if slates hold nothing beneath their wax. Forgiveness, I have learned, is not a pardon for the sake of the forgiven; it is an act that allows the world to move on without bearing the weight of the past as though sorrow were a fetter. It asks accountability as its price. It asks the wrongdoer to look at what he has done until his eyes are hollowed by it. We do not forgive because we are benevolent; we forgive because man cannot carry vengeance forever. It breaks him.

So I listen. I demand restitution across centuries and across small things — a ruined bridge rebuilt, a family lands returned, an apology delivered publicly to the market where the words were shouted away. To those whose crimes were the most grievous I assign the most painful task: not imprisonment, for prisons are a theater of revenge, but the rebuilding of the institutions they shattered with their hands. A knight who sacked a library must spend years transcribing the texts he burned. A commander who razed an irrigation system must spend seasons with mud and reed to see it run again. The work is slow; it is humbling. It does more to unmake a man than a sword ever could.

Not everyone accepts. Some prefer exile, clinging to the old stories, turning themselves into ghosts of a past that still comforts them. Others accept and become the best sort of penitent: those who, having learned, teach. I have placed some at the head of schools where they must learn to count grain and manage disputes and be accountable to the peasants. They fail often at first. They are awkward; their hands remember the sword before the ledger. But what they learn to do — to listen without thinking of the fight they will deliver in rebuttal — is the most dangerous thing for an old hero: to live with humility.

There are those who ask me, with tear-streaked faces, whether I still remember the crimes committed against me — the burnings of my temples, the murder of my priests, the songs written to curse my name. I remember. Memory is a tool as much as it is a wound. I remember not to make revenge; I remember so that I can ensure it does not happen again. I remember so that my justice is informed, so that mercy is not charity, but a structured, necessary corrective.

Some nights, I walk among the repaired streets in the form men do not fear because they do not imagine goddesses at market. I watch children trade flint and promise, mothers bargain for silks stretched across new looms, elders argue about the weather and have the right — at last — to be wrong. I feel the odd, disorienting thing that mortals call contentment. It is not vanity. It is a recognition that what I have demanded of others I have often had to demand of myself: rigorousness, an absence of theatrical cruelty, a willingness to be lonely in the name of the greater good. Darkness, I have found, can be precise as a scalpel.

They say now that they begged because they feared the wrath they once expected. Perhaps a few did. But more came because the dissonance between their self-regard and the lives they had damaged had become too sharp a music to bear. They sought forgiveness not to buy safety from me, but to buy safety from themselves. They wanted the world to acknowledge, publicly and therefore finally, that their acts had had consequences beyond the chorus lines.

I grant them absolution often, but never without the price I have set: reparation, labor, a public naming of the wrong. Mercy without consequence is not mercy; it is a soporific given to sleep a guilty conscience. When their tasks are completed, they are not unmade — one cannot unmake what time has shaped them into — but they come, almost invariably, to serve in the very institutions they once reviled. They become mayors, scribes, keepers of the granaries. They teach. They mend.

There are those who will still write songs about the fallen heroes and about the goddess of the dark crown who rules mercilessly. Let them sing. The truth has no need of silence as its ally. In time the stories will change, as all stories do, until men who were raptured by their own light are remembered as flawed, as human, and as, in the end, contrite. I, who have no need for poets’ praise, will stand with my ledger and my repaired roads and my courts that do not care whether you once wore a star on your chest.

If there is a moral in this, it is not that darkness redeems light, nor that heroes are always wrong. It is that rulehood is not romance. The real work of changing a world is not glory but tending: naming wrongs, making amends, teaching how to measure consequence. They come to me now with bowed heads because they have learned something that should have been taught by their mothers and their masters long ago: that power without responsibility is a cruelty, and that to live under someone regarded as dark can, paradoxically, be to live under someone who listens. In the end, when their hands are clean and their names are written into the registers they helped restore, they wear a different kind of light — the humbled light of those who chose to do less harm.

samples.prompt: My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.
samples.output:
My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.

The city below me had been sleeping until a few police cruisers had howled past and the night had shivered in answer. From the ledge of the old transit tower, the skyline looked like the ribs of a sleeping animal—cold glass, a scatter of orange, and the distant blinking of aircraft like patient stars. I held the little black box in both hands, feeling the pulse of its battery through the plastic, as if it had its own heartbeat matching mine. It was heavier than I'd imagined, not in mass but in possibility.

I had rehearsed the steps until they were carved into the inside of my skull. Reach into the pouch of my jacket. Twist the cap. Slide the cable under the service hatch. Breathe. Press. Run. The plan had been stripped of romance and rewritten as a mechanical instruction because romance would have made me hesitate. Hesitation would have made me fail.

The first time I had seen this tower in daylight, it had been a garden of towers, a place where the city’s lifeblood—data, credits, faces—poured through veins of fiber into the central nodes. Tonight those veins were clogged with the government’s surveillance suite: eyes in every camera, ears in every lamp post. They called it safety; my mother called it a leash. For twelve years it had watched us dream, and for twelve years my sister had lived in a room without a door.
