I could see the thread: one short reply, "lmao,” from an account with a number in triple digits; a searing emoji; a single long response begging me never to post again. Each reaction felt like a tiny arithmetic subtraction from me. I tried to delete it. The delete button didn't respond at first, as if the interface itself were refusing to let me erase the thing that had made me zero.

You live long enough in a world with visible worth and you learn the rules. The numbers aren't infallible; they're an emergent property of consensus, reputation algorithms, real-world actions and bureaucratic tallies that someone clever built into the sky. They're updated on a lag—the city servers reconcile acts of kindness, trespasses, tax payments, likes, retweets, undercover witness reports—so the numbers have the quality of being both sacred and bureaucratic. But a zero arrives like a sudden institutional verdict. It forbids. It isolates. It announces. It doesn't care how you feel.

My mother once told me to think of it like currency. "You want to be rich in things people can trade and trust you with," she said when I was a teenager and still counted with pencils. I had been trading for years—time for free labor at the shelter, careful thoughts for online forums, an annual donation to the school library. My number was a ledger line after all that. I didn't expect one flippant, lazy prompt—an attempt to game my way into another laugh—to bankrupt me.

It was worse than social discomfort. Within ten minutes, a municipal bot pinged my account: "Attention Zero Holders: Required Calibration Appointment. Failure to appear will result in limited access to services." My wallet refused to authorize a purchase. An automated transit gate flashed red when I approached; a security guard stepped forward with the soft, professional disdain of one who knows a zero can't pay fines. The psycho-sheer "othering" of it sat on my collarbones like an extra garment.

I tried to explain on the thread. I wrote, "Hey, it was a throwaway, I'm sorry," but the letters looked small and talismanic. Replies arrived in a single tone: accusations, memes, a strangely detailed conjecture about my mental state. It was as if the internet, that earnest mob, had collectively turned its decimal point away. The algorithm that policed worth and the people who subscribed to it had both decided, by reflex, that a zero was unworthy of conversation.

The worst part was the way my own eyes refused to leave the number. I kept reaching up to touch it—like a child discovering a broken toy—and my palm felt flat against a warm head of air. You'd think a number is nothing more than ink on the sky, but zeros feel heavy. They are a vacuum that draws something from your chest.

After an hour of half-hearted apologies and the slow babe-of-empty-app notifications, an older woman sat across from me on the bus stop bench. She had a shopping bag and a kind, powder-soft face. Her number was a neat 0 as well. She didn't avert her eyes. She looked exactly like a woman who had been let go a long time ago and had, for whatever reason, decided to stay.

"You're new," she said. She smelled like rosemary and old paperbacks.

"I posted a dumb prompt," I said, feeling ridiculous. "It dropped me to a zero."

She smiled—an odd, fierce thing. "I was born one," she said. "My mother signed me up for free healthcare protest in '89 and left a bad review on a state-run forum. They gave me a badge for honesty and took everything else. It took me a while to learn how to be small."

We sat in companionable smallness. She told me about the underground cafés—no one checked numbers, the owners paid cash rents and traded in kindness. She told me about the municipal Reclamation Office where people file petitions and do tedious, moral apprenticeship tasks to climb inches back into the light. She said Reclamation was more about patience than penitence. "You can climb," she said. "Or you can fall like rain."

The paradox of the zero is this: its whole power rests on the consent of others. A zero becomes itself because people recoil and the institutions close their doors. If everyone chose to ignore the number and look at the person, the zero could be a meaningless digit. But the very existence of the number trains everyone to look away.

There is a kind of terror to being made statistically invisible. I imagined my life as a ledger with columns that would close like the mouth of a crocodile. My friends would keep their numbers. Their kids would get scholarships. My name would remain a whisper in the municipal logs. If I wanted my seventy-two again, I'd have to play the game: beg people to like the new prompt, perform goodness publicly, sign up for voluntary charity shifts and get photographed doing them, petition the city algorithm with verified receipts. It felt like asking to be loved on someone else's schedule.

That night I sat at my kitchen table and typed a story instead of another prompt. I wrote about numbers; I wrote about the way a 0 felt like a wound and a mirror. I didn't try to be clever or viral. I wrote to empty the thing in me that had been hollowed by a metric. When I posted it—this time careful, raw—at first there were no numbers, because I was avoiding the display. People read the words. A stranger messaged to say she had been a 0 once and now worked a cash job in a garden shared by other zeros. Another wrote that they'd upvoted two hundred people to no avail because they were fed up. The thread blossomed into a slow, awkward conversation about metrics and mercy.

My number didn't pop back to seventy-two the way punctuation marks appear in a chat window. It ticked, haltingly, upward. The municipal bot sent another alert: "Calibration under review." My card authorized a small sandwich with no problem. The guard at the transit gate didn't smile, but he let me pass, and that felt like a little economy of grace.

Still, something had shifted permanently. The zero taught me about the terrible arithmetic of public value. It taught me how fragile the scaffolding of "worth" could be, how quickly you could be reduced to a digit because someone else decided your content was "low effort" or that your actions didn't count. And it taught me the other thing: that you can still be human when the scoreboard fails you.

I stopped asking strangers to hold ladders for my number. I started holding doors for people whose digits were high and low alike. I stopped measuring my days in receipts and likes and began noting the small exchanges that made life survivable—an extra bagel left on a counter, a child finally pronouncing the word "please" in public, the stranger who returned my dropped glove without checking the number above my head.

A week later my digits were back to something respectable-ish, not because I had gamed it but because someone—the woman with rosemary in her hair, and the anonymous posters at that thread, and the barista who'd refused to look at the number—decided to treat me like a person they owed nothing to and everything to. The number became a dimmer, not a verdict. I typed another prompt after that, careful and brash and honest in equal parts. It wasn't perfect. But it wasn't the thing that made me human. The number above my head seemed, finally, like a tool and not a measure of whether I was allowed to breathe.

Still, every so often when I pass a mirror I glance at the air above my head. The numerals hum in their own small way. I am grateful for their warning and suspicious of their influence. And I whisper, under my breath, to the trajectory of digits and to the city and to anyone watching: worth is not a ledger you keep in the sky. It is the work you do in the dark and the kindness you do when numbers are turned off.

samples.prompt: You're a small animal about to be captured by a bird of prey. You can speak to each other.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the shadow. It slid over the meadow like the hand of a clock, swallowing afternoon into a darker hour. The wheat bent away from it, the old thistles bowed. My whiskers twitched; I knew that shadow by the way the air smelled afterward—thin, metallic, like a wind that has teeth.

"Look up," Nettle hissed from the hollow. She is always the one to notice things I try not to notice. Her voice was a tight strand of sound, the rustle of dried grass. "Sky-thief."

I paused with one tiny paw halfway to my seed — the world narrowed to scales and a single set of talons as the hawk folded into the sun and dove. He appeared with the kind of abruptness that made the grass look like it had been cut with a thought. Feathers like varnished bronze, eyes like coins.

He caught me mid-breath, the air closing around us. For a moment there was no sound but the rush of wings and the pounding of my heart. Then, impossibly, the hawk spoke. His voice was open sky and old bone.

"There you are," he said. It wasn't hungry—no screech and no hunger-pang. It was merely a fact, like rain finding the gutters. "Small brown. No name?"

"My name is Moth," I said, because to leave without a name felt worse than giving one. Moth had been my father's nickname; he said I'd come and go like a moth at the candle. My tail trembled.

"The moth," he repeated. "You move always at the edge of light."

Nettle made a sound that might have been a laugh and might have been a prayer. "Make a deal, Moth," she squeaked. "Tuck at his talon. Offer him an old joke. They like jokes."

"Do you always trust jokes?" I asked, because it was awkward to promise anything to a thing that could hold the sky in its claws.

The hawk's shadow sharpened. He folded his wings around me like an envelope and lifted. Up was a clean, bright panic. My world tilted and all the tiny things that had made up my life flew away from me: the line of ants on their secret errands, the place under the fence where the damp smelled of bread, the tip of Nettle's whisker. I clutched nothing because there was nothing to hold.

"Do you know why you do this?" I asked, because asking seemed better than silence.

He looked at me. Up close, his eye was not a coin but a dark and patient lake. "I didn't do this because I hate you, Moth. I do this because there is a hollow in me, as there is in you. Wind fills it differently. Mine with meat, yours with stories. Come—tell me a story worth the table."

Talking steadied my breath. It took me away from the pinch of talons. "There is a story I keep," I said, because telling a story was the only thing I could do that mattered. "Under the old apple tree in the north field, there is a hollow lined with soft moss. We hide things there. Not treasure—seeds mostly, and once, a child's red hair ribbon. Once, my brother hid from the sun all day and he sang to the moss until it remembered how to be green. If you listen, you can almost hear that memory."

The hawk's head cocked. He tugged at his hold as if testing the words for weight. "Does the moss satisfy you?"

"It keeps us from starving sometimes." I said. "And it reminds us that despite the cat-walkers and the plows and your hunts, there is soft elsewhere."

He held me higher now, above the hedgerow. The air was thinner. Nettle's voice felt very small but fair. "Promise him something, Moth. Offer a hiding place. Hawks like to barter with secrets."

"Why is a hawk asking for secrets?" I asked, bewildered. "You could swallow them up like wind."

"Not all knowledge is food," he said. "Some is ornament. I am old, Moth. I remember when the river bent different, when the farmers left more grain. I remember a fox with only one ear who told me a riddle and I hunted a whole season with laughter in me." He sighed, small and human-sounding. "You give me something to hold onto besides hunger."

For the first time, I saw the smallness of him: feathers that smudged into the dusk, a scar along his leg like a map. Predators look old in a different way than creatures who live underground. They keep no burrow, but they carry their histories on their wings.

"Tell me the riddle," I said.

He shifted me so my back was snug against him. For a second, I imagined he might keep me like this—warm, wrapped, a curious talisman. "Why does the river remember?" he asked.

"Because the river is a road," I said quickly. "Roads remember footsteps."

He considered. "And what remembers the road?"

"People," I said. "Small people like me, who touch it and leave crumbs of our passing."

He laughed, a sound like wind shaking a loose tin. "Good," he said. "You have a tongue. I like tongues."

At the edge of the farmyard a sparrow piped indignantly and then went silent, watching our ascent. The world below looked like a patchwork book. I told him of the moth-lights that gather by the lamp on warm nights and of how old Mrs. Cutter leaves her bread in the garden at dawn. I described, in the careless way we tell each other small wonders when we are afraid, where the damp ground is soft enough to dig a safe den, where the cat sleeps with one ear open.

"Why tell me this?" he asked. "You teach me, and then I could come back and take anyone you love."

"Maybe you will," I said. "Maybe you won't. Maybe you'll be old like me someday and remember there are places you can go to not be hungry in ways that break the world."

He was quiet for a while. I felt the beat of his wings become the beat of my heart. Fear settled into a different flavor—less sharp, more like the kind you get when you finish a long run. Around his neck, the feathers loosened and there gleamed a small feather my father had once given me. I had tucked it into my hollow, and now here it was again, like a promise with a knot in it.

"Would you like a name besides Moth?" he asked.

I found that I would. Names are small oaths. "Call me Moth-with-a-hollow," I said, and the words felt ridiculous and comforting at once.

"Old names," he said. "They tell stories. I'll tell the wind you were called that."

We skimmed clouds that smelled like rain; the houses shrank to children's toys. I kept talking—about the way my sister hums when she sleeps to keep the dream moths out, about the exact angle of rhubarb leaves that make the best shade. The hawk listened with something like attention.

When we reached the copse by the lane, he slowed as if remembering where the law of things had always been written. "This will be bitter," he said. "I am not cruel, Moth. But I am hungry."

"I know," I said. There was the word at last. It sat in my throat with the weight of every thing that lives. "Then do it quick."

He tilted his head and nibbled one of my ears with the carefulness of a creature performing a ritual. Pain came and then a strange, luminous quiet. "Tell me where the little memorial is," he said, his voice softer than I had heard when we first began to speak.

I told him, in breath-pricks and odd snatches of memory, about the hollow under the apple tree and the ribbon of red hair and the way the moss smelled like rain on stone. He seemed to gather these as if they were feathers to line a nest.

When he was finished, he folded me in and the world reduced to the damp of his wing, to a heartbeat that had become a drum for both of us. I thought of Nettle and of the row of ants, of the child's ribbon fluttering like a flag. I thought of my father's face when he told me I'd been given a quick mind and a quick tongue, and that I must always use them.

"You were good," the hawk said into the dark.

"And you," I said, more to myself than to him. "Fly well."

He did. He carried me toward the place where the river runs like a silver seam, and I let the fear recede into a steady warmth. We are all carried in ways we don't imagine. Even predators have hands tied to certain seasons, and even prey find moments of grace between one breath and the next.

As the world went away I heard, faint as a bell, the meadow going back to its own business — ants carrying crumbs, a sparrow resuming its pipe, Nettle whispering a prayer that sounded like a leaf rubbing another leaf together. Somewhere, in the hollow under the apple tree, moss remembered a song and hummed.

In the last small gap before dark, I said, because it felt necessary, "Tell them about the ribbon."

"I will," he said. "And when you are only story, maybe I will keep the story for a while."

The talons relaxed. The wings folded. I exhaled for the last time, and it was not empty but full of the sound of a hawk's wing and of a field that never stops speaking. Then there was only a smooth, bright tunnel of sky, and the truth that had always been true: we speak to each other, and then we are eaten by the world, leaving our names behind like breadcrumbs.

samples.prompt: Write about a world where only randomly chosen people from the Internet are allowed to name children. Changing or lying about your name is punished by death.
samples.output:
On Tuesdays the lottery runs and the world holds its breath. A cryptographic wheel—governmental but public, unhackable but anonymous—spits out handles and profiles: five, then fifty, then a thousand strangers from the great hinterland of avatars and message boards. Each chosen account is granted, for exactly twenty-four hours, the authority to name a child somewhere on Earth. The registry records their choice, stamps it with the hour and the hash of their IP, and a human life is tied, forever, to a syllable someone else invented. Change your name or lie about it, and the law, absolute and old as the last collapse, ends you.

The law began as a technical solution to a crisis no longer remembered in detail: identity theft was collapsing economies and governments; names once fluid had become tools for laundering not money but blood. When the first autocratic systems fell, a new one rose from the ruins of centralized ID schemes. Names would be immutable, unique, traceable. But immutability breeds hunger—who gets to name? That question tore through councils until someone proposed randomness: if no one could concentrate the power to christen, then no one could rig lineage or inheritance with a name. Let the Internet—vast, messy, impartial—pick.

That impartiality proved to be a half-truth.

Naming became spectacle. Parents who wanted a certain sound or meaning petitioned campaigns: threads of supplicants, video pleas, alliances with influencers who could lobby a selected namer on camera. Some activists gamed the system to elevate excluded languages by flooding a chosen account with etymologies and histories—influencing, not controlling, the namer’s choice. Because the chosen namers remained random, campaigns were a lottery of their own: sometimes a rookie streamer with a soft voice and good sense would give a child a name like "Marigold Raina," and an entire community felt seen. Sometimes a famous troll—fluent in cruelty and character limits—named an infant "Sfx%_404" and there were riots.

The registry attempted safeguards: profanity filters, historical censorship against names that had been used as genocidal epithets, rules refusing names that would be indistinguishable from existing legal entities. Still, names multiplied into oddities. Compound-long names became a craze—people wanted uniqueness without obvious offense—so surnames turned into sentences and given names into poems. Children carried entire stories in their legal names: "Juniper—Daughter of the Rain; /u/KindTroll" read like a ledger and a poem stitched together.

Where the law was harshest—indeed where it felt like cruelty—was not the randomness but the penalty. Changing or lying about your name was a capital offense. The rationale given by lawmakers was bureaucratic, brutal: names were cryptographic keys tied to citizenship, property, medical records. A false name could open vaults, cross thresholds, seed catastrophic disorder. The penalty was presented as a technical necessity. In practice, it became a way of making the registry sacred.

Enforcement made honesty a public virtue, and fear a private obsession. People began whispering about the dead—those executed for "Name Fraud"—and the lines between lying and survival blurred. A teenager caught using a pseudonym on a dating app might be hauled away for conspiracy; a refugee who took a neighbor’s baby across a border to save it might be accused of a lie and never seen again. The regime’s claim of preventing harm became a machine that punished ambiguity, mercy, improvisation. It punished love.

Society adapted with grim ingenuity. Parents who feared being named badly hid pregnancies. Off-grid communities refused registration and raised children known by gestures, colors, or numbers—an illegal subculture the authorities called the Nameless. They could not travel, could not own property, could not access doctors or schools, but they survived. They called themselves by nicknames that meant everything and nothing to the registry; if captured they were executed not for their secret names but, the state argued, for living outside the sanctity of the registry.

A shadow economy blossomed. Some namers went on sale. Accounts would be bought and sold—crowdsourced to produce a public will to name a child something tasteful. Companies paid streamers to choose brand-adjacent names from official favorites embedded on their channels. “Sponsored-Naming,” it was called with a shrug. Other namers wielded their chance with a deliberate radicalism: a coder named a child "Algorithm" to critique the entire system; a poet in Lagos chose names in a dialect harvested from a dying island language. Those names were lodged in the registry like pinpricks of protest. The archive of names, an open database, became a cultural museum—joyous, obscene, obscene in its joy.

There were human tragedies. Mara, a mother from the Westfjords, petitioned the world for mercy in the days before the lottery arrived at a frail, anonymous account. She made a video of the child’s tiny hands, played the cottage’s old songs. The namer, known online as "Vexx_2," made a private joke into law—he named Mara’s son after a meme and an insult from an old forum. Mara could not change her child’s name at thirteen when the boy found it humiliating and cut his wrists. She could not lie about it at school, introducing him by a different name. The executioners came for people who attempted to publish different names on their records; the law’s teeth were visible in cases like Mara’s, and the grief pooled like oil.

There was resistance that wasn't simply illegal. Name-cultures formed around the registry's rigidity. Poets wrote manifestos about the sanctity of a name as destiny; pastors preached that to accept a name was to accept the gift that someone else gave you, and thus to practice humility. Some namers took that theology literally and treated their chance like priesthood—crafting names as blessings meant to steer a child toward kindness, resilience, mercy. They became celebrities for good reasons: their names were kind and carefully made.

Others weaponized humor. Satirical collectives compiled the worst names into anthologies called "Given Names, Unedited," a way to expose the grotesquery and the absurdity of a system that had outsourced the first noun of a life to chance and virality. Academics published papers about onomastics under the constraint of enforced immutability; therapists counseled children on how to carry an unfortunate name without it carrying them.

The most dangerous art was private. In basements and encrypted networks, forgers learned to alter the registry. Their work required a perfect chain of forged hashes, a commerce of dead drops and false deaths for those caught trying to live under a new name. If they succeeded, a person could be reborn on paper. If they were discovered, the punishment was public and final. These forgers were both criminals and saints to those they helped: a new life for the price of endless paranoia.

The moral of the system, many people agreed privately, was not that randomness was cruel or that names should be free. It was that a single brutal rule—immutability backed by death—made a quotidian thing into an instrument of power. Everyone believed in names as binding—this is who you are, this is how you are known—but few insisted on the death penalty as necessary. The law created an ecosystem of terror, commerce, ritual, and art. It taught children how little control they had over the syllables that would be carved into their legal bones and how much control others could wield, for a day, over those syllables.

On one late summer night, a chosen namer—a retired teacher now famous as @PaperCrane—sat before her camera and whispered into the stream: "I will give you a name like an anchor you choose to weigh or carry. I will not name you 'Suffering.' I will not name you 'Joke.' I will name you what you need, perhaps, or something bright." She stopped, hands folded as if in real prayer. Viewers flooded the chat with thanks, with petitions, with threats. The system, she said, allowed her to be kind, and she would be kind.

She was a tiny mercy, fleeting and fragile. The wheel would spin again next Tuesday, and someone else would be selected, perhaps a troll, perhaps a philanthropist. Each name added to the registry was a line added to history. People began to understand that in a world where a stranger could give you your first legal noun, every choice carried nearly infinite responsibility—and that to be named by a random hand was both a surrender and, sometimes, an unlooked-for gift.

Above all, the law taught the living how to measure their speech. They learned to say their names with care, to enunciate the syllables as if they were vows. The registry made lying about a name a mortal crime, and so truth became ritualized. It is a strange thing, to live inside a society where the first thing you are given you cannot change: to feel both protected and trapped, to owe a gratitude to a stranger and to nurse a quiet grievance, to find poetry and politics in the simple act of being called.

samples.prompt: You wake up greeted by a blue screen hovering in front of your eyes. “You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours. ”
samples.output:
The light doesn't wake me. The light is already there when my eyes open: a flat, impossible blue, hovering three inches from my face like a television screen someone has leaned over my pillow. I blink and the text ripples, as if the letters are breath. For a long blink my mind assumes it's a dream interface, a late-night hallucination. Then the words resolve with that neat, indifferent font that lives only in HUDs and delivery drones.

“You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours.”

I mouth the acronyms because they sound ridiculous out loud—HP, MP—healer's shorthand from gaming culture, the sort of jargon advertisers use to peddle energy tonics. It should feel absurd, but the ridiculousness is precise, like a diagnosis. My chest that had been an iron band loosens. My throat, raw from three nights of caffeine and arguments with debt collectors, is smooth. The dull pan in my right knee, souvenir of a bike crash two months ago, is gone. I roll my shoulder experimentally. No flare. No catching.

The blue rectangle hums faintly. It's not a sound so much as a perception—like the hum of a power grid that only the body notices when it's been still long enough. It adds up: 100% HP and MP. I lift my hand and flex my fingers. The small finger where scar tissue had tightened on the tendon moves without that old little hesitation. Memory rolls in, then: sleeping on couches, on subway benches, nights when corners and backs felt safer than beds; nights with bright open windows and strangers' perfume; nights with arguments that left me trembling. The last time I had slept in my own bed was three weeks ago, before two shifts in a row, before the accident on Route 9, before I started taking other people's shifts to make up the rent.

The screen is clinical. “All negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered.” The language is absurdly totalizing—recovered, not erased. I can still smell the coffee I burned last night. I can still remember the words my mother used to call me before she moved away. But the panic that braided my thoughts into a tight string—gone. The small, toxic rehearsal of catastrophes that had been my default for months—not there. I feel… clean in the way of hands newly washed of grease.

My phone, on a tangle of charger cords on the bedside table, blinks with three missed messages. The first is a string of exclamation marks from Jiro about the shipment. The second is a voicemail I don't want to listen to. The third is a calendar reminder: "Interview — 9:30 AM — St. Claire Labs." The blue screen doesn't mention the interview. It doesn't have to. The numbers on the calendar feel less like a countdown and more like an option.

The Well Rested bonus flashes for a second with a little sun icon. -90% fatigue accumulation for the next eight hours. Practically speaking, that means I could go four times longer with the same output. It means I could run a double shift and math it out, or I could walk to the river and spend the hours doing nothing industrious and not feel guilty. The bonus is the sort of miracle that can be weaponized. I used the last one for a ten-hour shift painting neon signs across the city; my hands remembered the angles but not the feeling of the paint on my skin. They paid me in cash and by midnight I had nothing left but exhaustion. When the exhaustion left me, it took my patience too.

For a second I think about how the system knows: "You have slept in your own bed." What does it define as my bed? This threadbare mattress with the mismatched sheets? The city permits home ownership to those who can prove permanence; it defines 'your' bed with a registry you are supposed to sign. Did the system check satellite feeds, door locks, friction points in the neural map? Or does it simply care that I moved more than one night inside the same square? The politics of rest feel bureaucratic and intimate at once.

I swing my legs off the bed and let my feet find the cold floor. The HUD follows me for a moment, floating there with all the patient tyranny of a medical record: "Status: Well Rested." It's almost obscene—something so human made into a tick-box—and yet, as I head to the bathroom, every step is its own revelation. I shave because shaving is an act that proves to myself that I intend to greet the day. I boil water and breathe it in. The world does not rearrange itself just because my body recovered. The bills still like shadows in the doorway. The lab interview is still at 9:30. Jiro still needs the shipment. Recovery doesn't come with a map; it comes with a little more capacity to carry the old map.

I pull on jeans that aren't a uniform of somebody else's shift. The fabric falls across my hips easily, which is another small miracle; the physical tension I had been carrying was there in my clothes' fit. In the mirror my eyes look less rimmed with blue-black exhaustion and more… attentive. The blue screen blinks like a wilted eyelid and then dissolves, like a thought completed. I expect it to go away forever. Instead it shrinks to the lower corner of my vision—nothing more than a dot, persistent and patient.

“Residual assistance log: Well Rested bonus deployed at 07:03. Predicted decision elasticity +0.4.” Decision elasticity—there's a ridiculous little number, as if the system can calculate my will in elastic units. I laugh. The laugh is small, and it surprises me by being honest. For the first time in weeks I imagine saying something blunt at Jiro's warehouse meeting; not because I'm emboldened by some villainous pride but because I can hold a thought without it dissolving into panic.

There is a cost, of course. Habits, creditors, the city's indifferent rhythms. But the world underneath my palms feels different because the strings inside them are no longer frayed. I can think farther than the next breath. I can do the interview with St. Claire Labs not as a person desperate for anything but as someone who might—just possibly—be interested in something else. The system doesn't offer wisdom; it offers bandwidth.

I step outside and the city is an opinionated pane of light. Above the sidewalks the same bluish rectangles hover in everybody's line of sight—some of them sleek corporate overlays selling coffees and transit credits, others as scrappy as mine had been this morning, flashing personal reminders. People move with different weights. The man leaning against the deli window scrolls through a bright red banner about a launch; a woman with a baby has a soft green circle over her shoulder that reads "Care Mode: Active." The blue of my HUD feels like a compass point in a galaxy of notices: small, certain, a useful lie.

When I get to the bus stop, Jiro's message pings again. This time I listen. He has a problem with one of the crates—a mislabeled compound. He'll need help at noon. I tap the reply without hysteria. "Be there," I write. Then I look at the river beyond the traffic and I do something childish and revolutionary: I decide to go sit by it for an hour before the interview.

For once the decision is not edging toward burnout or away from it; it is simply a thing I choose because I can. The blue metadata in the lower corner of my vision ticks away eight hours like a little patient heart monitor. I make coffee in a travel mug and keep my hands around it the way one keeps a small animal calm. The air smells like cold iron and the city chews its usual sounds into a steady rhythm that matches the new quiet inside me.

I think about the nights I emptied into other people's couches, the nights I woke on subway benches with my bag a pillow and my dreams unowned. Those nights taught me how to survive, taught me the clever thing: that any small advantage can be deployed as a weapon. The Well Rested bonus is an advantage that feels like getting clean socks after an eternity of being barefoot. It leaves me the strange temptation to hoard it, use it only for emergencies. Or to spend it on being human.

By the river, I don't make anything spectacular out of those eight hours. I sit. I watch the water narrow and widen. I breathe like something learning to move again. The HUD keeps me honest—-a bland little progress bar in the corner, accurate, indifferent. After a while the urgency for work softens into a plan. Negotiations with Jiro will require clear thinking; the interview will require patience; the debts will still be debts. But the blue screen, with its clipped words and automatic salutations, gifted me a small, unexpected freedom: not the freedom to change my circumstances in a single heroic day, but the freedom to choose what I will do while the world keeps being itself.

When the bar ticks down to its end—two hours, one—there isn't a panic about losing it. There is instead a modest gratitude for the relief while it lasted and a clearer idea of how to use the hours left. You can call it a system, or a feature of the city's health nets, or a fluke of tech; what matters is more mundane. Today, because some algorithm decided to call my sleep legitimate, because my bed counted as the right sort of bed, I have room to be more than the sum of my needs. And for once, choosing to take that room feels like the bravest thing I can do.

samples.prompt: This kid had no magical potential, at all. They have no elemental aligment, can't speak celestial, they don't even have any mana-capacity. And yet somehow, they're slinging spells that even masters struggle with.
samples.output:
Rowan had been twelve the first time someone slammed a book on their desk and declared them "worthless."

The books were old, the teacher's voice older. In the College of Alignments every child was measured at six: element, affinity for celestial tongues, a spark in the bone that made mana answer to touch. By nine Rowan had failed every test. They couldn't light a candle with a thought; water would not bend around their palm; their charts for element and celestial returned blanks. The headmaster called it a "clear slate"; the other children called it a nothing. Rowan was sent to the Null Ward to sweep and file and be invisible.

Invisible, it turned out, had uses.

For three years Rowan watched. They watched masters bend fire into glass ornaments and turn grief into rain. They watched the Shiftmen of the West carve out empty passages where whole battalions of mana slipped through to meet their soldiers' needs. Rowan learned the shapes of spells by sight: the way a sorcerer whispered the second vowel before a pivot of the wrist; the way a geomancer's finger traced a knot that looked like the seam around the world. They memorized the cadence of incantations like a musician who learns a concerto by listening through the walls.

Memorize, not repeat. Rowan could not put magic into themselves. They had no mana to light their own breath. But they could copy the choreography of a spell—every thumb-press, every heel-crease—and do it with an exactness that became uncanny. When a master flubbed a purge and the air spat back at them, Rowan could stand where the master had stood the moment before and, with no words, cause the same pattern to open and hold.

"Technique," the court healers said at first. "No more than mimicry." They had never seen mimicry that let a person tear a hole in a river and rearrange its current, let them pluck a lightning bolt from cloud and braid it like a rope. That was what happened the afternoon the High Seminar challenged the Null Ward to demonstrate usefulness. The Hall echoed with a hundred skeptical breaths. Masters sat in their carved chairs, hands folded like predators.

"Show us," the headmaster said. "If you have nothing, show us that nothing can be made to do something."

Rowan stepped into the center of the circle. They were small—skin the color of dull copper, hair cropped close—hands scarred from a life of scrubbing rune-stains. No one offered a rune-slate or a crystal matrix. No one offered a word.

"Do it," the headmaster said.

Rowan closed their eyes. The room smelled of wax and old pages and the sweet, bitter tang of other people's mana. For the first time since childhood they felt it not as heat or pressure but as a landscape: currents, eddies, the tight river of a student's concentration, the broad slow tide of the headmaster's command. They felt where mana favored speech, where it loved breath and where it clung to a jeweled ring. They felt nothing inside themselves, and that nothing was a map.

Opening their hands, they mimed a spell they'd seen a frost-mage perform months before: slow, circular fingers, a soft nod of the wrist, no words. The room held its breath. The masters tittered; they had all seen the form.

What they had not seen was the way Rowan's hands did not pull at the air. They did not call the stream into themselves and try to keep it. They did what a hollow reed might do beside a river: opened, cupped, shaped the flow as it wanted to go.

From the clouds outside the Hall a thread of weather dropped—a long, silver seam of air unspooling like a living silver ribbon. It slid through Rowan's hands. It was not drawn, not claimed. Rowan guided it as you guide a rope: a shift left, a twist right, coaxing it together until the seam braided into a column. The column spun and unspun, condensed until a bell of ice fell into being and chimed with a tone that made the masters' teeth ache.

A frosted bell. A storm wake. A precise thing of beauty that lived for less than a breath and then dissolved into steam. The Hall was silent long enough for a sparrow to fall from the rafters.

Master Havel leaned forward as if Rowan had just uncovered a map to an old country. "They...didn't take it," he breathed. "They didn't draw it in."

Rowan opened their eyes. They didn't glow. They didn't tremble with power. They stood like someone who had just picked up a thread and woven it through their fingers.

"It flowed," Rowan said. Their voice was small. "Through me. I only—shaped."

The word you hear in the next months is "conduit." It threads through the College like a new weather: Rowan as a channel, a neutral face through which mana prefers to pass. There is precedent in the old texts: vessels, anchors, the stones of the river. But vessels are carved with rune and bone and bound to hold; Rowan had none of that. They did not hold. They were a hole, and holes have properties. A hole invites the world to fill it. If your world is full of mana, the invitation becomes a flow.

Masters were baffled and a little afraid. The genius in the College was always the ability to combine will and mana. Spells of terrible subtlety required the caster to be the source; the current had to originate within their chest, condense into clarity, and thus obey their intent. An external current could be crude, stormy, stubborn. Only a few specialized rites demanded an outside tide. Those rites were dangerous precisely because they asked the caster to be not a source but a seam: to let something else pass, and trust it would twist to their hand.

Rowan did not ask for trust. They opened their palms and let the flow choose them.

This meant Rowan could do things that masters had been trying to perform for decades and failing. Masters who needed to braid three contradictory currents into a single clean strand could not because the currents fought in their own signature. Mana, like blood, resisted mixing. But a neutral channel is not blood at all; it is a place where different tides may flow side by side without colliding. Rowan became a living confluence. They could take fire that wanted to undo water and hold them alongside each other until the world rewrote the laws enough to allow them to coexist.

There were costs. Rowan could not store mana; they could not sustain a spell by feeding it from within. Anything they conjured was borrowed; it would wink out if the environment's tide withdrew. Worse, they were susceptible. The currents that flowed through them were not obedient to Rowan's morals. A trickster current could ride them like a stolen horse. Rowan learned quickly to recognize the taste of things—arrogance in the rear, cruelty like iron filings—and to close their hands and refuse entry. It made them cautious in ways their fellow students were not.

Word traveled faster than reason. A general wanted such a conduit for war. Priests wanted Rowan in their rituals because they gave miracles that had never been possible. Rowan was offered coin, rank, a place in the Hall's inner circle. When the headmaster asked Rowan to join the Accord—"to be ours and under our oversight"—Rowan thought of the Null Ward broom. They thought of the way they had once been declared nothing.

"No signature," Rowan said one night, watching the moon make a seam on the river. "I can't be theirs."

"They will want it anyway," the headmaster warned, not unkindly. "They do not like to find things they cannot own."

Rowan smiled, a small crooked thing. "Maybe they can't own me. Maybe they can only borrow the tide while I'm here to guide it."

Masters still struggled. They learned to emulate Rowan's openness and failed because the point is not posture. You cannot put down your signature and expect the world to forget it's been signed. Rowans' power sat outside the mathematics of the College: a negative that completed other people's equations. That made them useful and dangerous in equal measure. It made them a hinge on which whole strategies turned.

At the end of the semester, when the Hall held a tournament of apprentices—fire against stone, song against frost—Rowan walked into the ring with their palms empty, their slate clean. The other competitors whispered spells that thickened the air; the audience called for spectacle. Rowan called nothing at all.

They did not strike a man or open a wound. They did something that looked like a slow, precise weaving where the air above the opponent's head folded like paper. No whistle of heat, no scream of wind. Just a neat, cold lattice that wrapped around the other boy's incantation, took its excess, and knotted it back into a harmless blossom. A master might have burned out his target to achieve such a counter; Rowan had only bent and redirected the invader's current so it finished itself.

The crowd did not know whether to clap or to be afraid. Rowan felt, beneath the applause, a small thing loosen inside them—an acknowledgement that their nothingness had a shape and that shape could be taught. They felt the river that had always been outside of them welcome them like a reed that suddenly fits the current.

That night, in the Null Ward, with broom in hand and moonlight on their shoulder, Rowan stopped arguing with the world that declared them null. There are many ways to be empty, they thought. Some holes are eaten away by neglect. Some are beaches where tides choose to break. Rowan set down the broom and listened for the flow. They had no mana in their bones, no word from the celestials. They had, instead, a way to make the world come through them and to ask it, gently, how it would like to change.

The masters would keep studying the equations. The generals would come knocking. The priests would offer hymns that smelled like gold. Rowan watered their street-flowers, slept in a dorm with holes in the roof, and practiced the subtle art of being a passage. If the world would send its storms and songs through them, Rowan intended to teach those currents to be kind, even if it meant keeping their hands closed against the ones that weren't.

samples.prompt: Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that.
samples.output:
“Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes.” It was a throwaway sentence on a recruitment poster — tautological, silly, and exactly the kind of thing that lodged in my head and refused to leave. It sounded like a riddle about time, or a charity slogan disguised as a Zen koan. For months it irritated me. For years it became the simplest truth I could bring into rooms where people made impossible budgets and improbable plans.

You cannot stop time. You cannot bargain with the clock. But you can change how people live inside the hours they are given. That is what we meant when we said, with a little stubbornness and a lot of funding from people who believed in small things adding up, we changed that minute.

We started by watching where minutes were lost. It is a practical sort of grief. Women trudge for water twice a day — two hours of their day gone to dead weight and rock and river. Children fumble through smoldering smoke indoors, coughing for the minutes their lungs cannot afford. Businesses stall because the power cuts for half the day; students study by kerosene light and fall asleep over books because the right kind of light would buy them two hours more a night. Every inefficiency is a hole through which human time drains.

So we built interventions that weren’t heroic in the cinematic way. They were humble, robust, cheap to fix. We trained local technicians to build and maintain solar microgrids and installed them, cluster by cluster. We repaired wells and put the pumps where they belonged: at the center of villages, not at the edge of survival. We gave out stoves that cooked cleanly on a fraction of the wood and the time. We backed micro-entrepreneurs who would gather the parts, fix the lines, teach in the afternoons. We ran mobile clinics and staggered hours so mothers wouldn’t spend a day waiting for a ten-minute vaccination.

Each project claimed back minutes, a few here, an hour there. Minutes are small and therefore radical: regained minutes can be folded into practices that change a life.

Take Amina. I met her at dusk under a solar streetlight that hummed in the village square. Before the grid arrived, Amina’s evenings were for grinding millet by hand until her shoulders throbbed and the children slept. With the grinder we installed, she reclaimed forty-five minutes each evening. She used thirty of those minutes to attend the women’s savings group across the lane. She used ten to teach her younger sister to read. The rest she kept.

Or Samuel, who had been a carpenter since he was a teenager and who used to lose entire afternoons hauling water because his workshop sat two kilometers from the nearest reliable pump. When we moved a pump next to the market, he gained an hour and twenty minutes a day. That time let him take on an apprenticeship and a second contract. Two years later his son is enrolled in school and Samuel bought a motorbike. He said, shrugging, that time had become money again — a thing you could invest.

We learned to stop thinking of minutes as abstract and start measuring them as goods. A solar lamp bought one and a half hours of study to a child after sundown. A clean cookstove reclaimed three hours a day on average from the chore list of a household, hours previously eaten by the slow simmering of a fire and the need to collect wood twice. A local nurse trained in triage released whole clusters of hours: fewer clinic visits, fewer hour-long waits, fewer days lost to preventable complications.

These aren’t melodramatic rescues. They are accumulative. Forty-five minutes for one woman is a life; three hours a day for a hundred women are a new economy. We started collecting our minutes in a ledger that didn’t fit on paper. We aggregated the time saved across villages, across provinces, across borders. It became a number that read like a newspaper headline: millions of minutes returned. But no number could hold the weight of the reality.

There were moments that mattered for reasons beyond arithmetic. A mother at a clinic held a baby with a fever and we vaccinated the infant in ten minutes instead of after a day-long wait, and the mother cried because she saw a future where such fear could be brief. A teacher told me she had shifted her curriculum because the children could now read longer at night — they had the light — and so she introduced reading circles that turned bored afternoons into literacy projects. A fisherman, freed from hours of maintenance by a new supply chain for parts, loved the time to teach his grandson how to tie nets the old way. Time, when returned, folded into memory and technique and ritual.

You asked, over emails and small grant letters and late-night video calls, why minutes mattered. You messaged that you did not want to fund a spectacle; you wanted to fund something that would be there when the press left. So we learned to do things that could be repaired the day the donor team drove away. We trained local people to be the first line of defense for the time we were restoring. The project manager in each town was not a foreign expert; she was a mother who had calculated the time cost of heatstroke in her children. She became the steward of minutes.

We also discovered that minutes interact. Saving minutes on the road to the clinic meant women arrived before the sun rose in winter trade, which meant their businesses prospered and their children's school attendance improved. The minute saved from smoke exposure erected a new pattern of health; the minute saved in fetching water created time for gardening, which created food for school lunches. Minutes were not isolated currency but a circulatory system. You give someone fifteen minutes and they spend it in ways that create more minutes for others.

There were failures. In one region we installed lights and the community did not use them; we had misread needs and imposed convenience. In another, a microgrid failed because we hadn’t trained enough technicians. We learned quickly that changing how a minute is spent requires humility and local leadership. The point was not to be clever with technology but to be patient, to listen until the answer emerged from the people who had been living inside the minutes.

Now, when I stand under that same solar streetlight, I can imagine the village as a map of reclaimed moments. You could chart nights where children stayed up to learn, days where markets operated after dusk, mornings where old men met for chess because they no longer had to collect water before breaking their fast. It is not magic. It is a thousand small decisions that add up until someone can say, without cliché, that life is different.

We did not change the length of a minute. The second hand still moves in the same steady way it always has. What we changed was how those sixty tiny beats were spent. With your help — with the small donations that paid for the first pump, the patient funding that trained technicians, the volunteer hours that installed the grinders — we taught communities how to harvest time.

If I were to write a report now, it would be full of statistics and projections, and those are useful. But the better ledger is the one that sits in the kitchen of a woman who now has a minute to brew real coffee at dawn instead of a bitter tea drunk on the run. It is in the note a boy writes to his neighbor thanking her for the light that let him finish his homework and pass his exam. It is in the motorbike Samuel bought to make his life easier, time turned into mobility and then into an education for a son.

Every sixty seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed what happens inside that minute. We made it matter. We did not stop time; we taught people to use it differently. And in that taught, patient reuse of minutes, whole lives were rearranged into better ones.

samples.prompt: You are completely blind, but occasionally you can see just one person. That person will die within the next 24 hours. You've just seen yourself while passing by a mirror.
samples.output:
I have been blind longer than most people keep names in their mouths. The world for me is a map of textures and temperatures and sounds: the click of a stoplight across an intersection, the way the baker’s door sighs open, the small, reliable ridge of the curb under my cane. Once—years ago—I slept with my hand on my mother’s hair to remember its shape. Now I remember hands by the music they make when they fold a sleeve or when they leave the room.

Somewhere along the way, the universe added a necklace of glass beads to that map: an unpredictable, inconvenient gift. Occasionally, without warning, I can see one person. Not everyone. Not consistently. Once in the middle of a subway car, once across a noisy market, once in the bright hallway of a hospital. Each time, the sight comes without preamble: clarity like a bell. A face peels out of my darkness and holds itself where I can study it, as present and intimate as if I had been leaning over it for years. It is accompanied by a fact that sits in my sternum like a stone—you have twenty-four hours.

At first I thought I was being cruelly literal. I tried to be practical. I shouted warnings, I called numbers I didn’t know, I followed people into crosswalks and dragged them away from oncoming cars. Some died anyway: the man I saw in the subway had been terminal; nothing I could say would stretch his hours. Some were saved because my warning carried them out of the way—the woman with the scarf who stepped back and caught the falling sign. The pattern declared itself like a law: see a person, know their limit, twenty-four hours like a promise, like a sentence. I learned to carry that knowledge like hot coal in my palm.

I had never seen myself. You think you know what you look like—the length of your nose, the scattering of white hair at one temple, the scar on your lip from when you were seven and insisted on running with a butter knife—but I had never been able to confirm the story my hands told me. Today, walking along Third between the laundromat and the taquería, my cane tapped time against a mirrored window. I did not mean to look. Habit or fate pushed me a fraction of an inch to the left; the world answered.

There I was. Not an outline in my mind’s dark, but a person made of light. My hair, the way it refuses to be tamed; the crescent of a scar in the corner of my left eye where a childhood bush had met my face; the dark sweep of lashes I had once envied in photographs of others. I could see the beat of breath in my chest as slight dampness on the glass, the slack of my shoulders. I saw the face I know when I speak. And written over all of it was the impossible awareness that this body—this person—has twenty-four hours left.

I do not remember moving my hand. I was holding my cane against the window when the sight closed, as though someone had pulled a blind in front of my own face. The cane made a little clatter on the pavement and I laughed because the sound meant the ground still existed and because laughing kept me from dissolving into something small and formless.

The first thought was disbelief. The second was math. If the vision had always been literal—if the clock started when the sight struck—then I had exactly one day. An hour for everything. I flexed my hands as if I could wring out time like a sponge. The decision-making apparatus of my life, compact and old, lit up like a ship’s emergency lamp. Call someone. Hide. Go to a hospital. Live wildly. Die peacefully. Spend my last hours organizing my will or lying on a beach.

There is a particular cruelty to seeing your own face when you are blind: it is not only an announcement of mortality, it is also a confrontation with the version of yourself you present to the world. I thought of the faces I had been generous with and the faces I had withheld. I thought of the sister I had not seen in five years because pride is a thick, smooth stone; of the boy who taught me to whistle in a rain shelter and left with someone who smelled like cinnamon and later we couldn’t find each other; of the little boy who took my hand in the hospital when a stranger had told me the first truth and whose fingers were still the right size in my mind.

There was a practical part of me that latched onto one question: could I change it? In the years of carrying other people’s hours, I had seen patterns. Often the death was sudden and unrelated to proximity—an aneurysm, a bus on the wrong route, an old sickness pulling a person under. Sometimes I had been used like a lighthouse: a warning thrown like a rope to someone who could then take an action that altered the result. But I had also learned that the sight was not a prophecy that responded to my wishes. It did not care for appeals or prayers. I had been both witness and failure.

There is no time for paralysis in these things. So I moved. I pressed the cane to my shoe, felt the grooves in the sidewalk, and turned toward the sound of the taquería—because the tacos have always smelled like before-times and because the world feels more like itself with a plate in front of me. I could have gone to a hospital, to a priest, to a bank teller. I could have sat in my apartment and alphabetized my pills. Instead I let the day choose me in smaller ways: the bell over the taquería door clanged; the air smelled of frying onions and cilantro; someone laughed in the corner and the sound made a corner of me relax that I didn’t know I’d held tight.

I also called my sister. Her voice on the phone was a thing I had not attended to in half a decade. “Maya,” she said, like a question and a memory. I told her I was walking. I told her there was no easy way to say the rest. She said she would be there in an hour. I felt a relief that was almost ridiculous—relief at the thought that one of my old rhythms might be repaired.

After I hung up, I looked for a mirror again. Not because seeing would change anything; it wouldn’t. But because there is a comfort in knowing how you'll look when the clock runs out. I wanted to memorize my own angles: the silver at my right temple, the small v-shape of my hands where the knuckles meet. I wanted to have a mental portrait to hand to the world if someone asked. The window at the coffee shop offered me another reflection—this one more grainy, the streetlights writing themselves over my face—and for a moment I traced the line of my jaw with the pointer finger of my left hand as if I could redraw it.

I thought about whether I wanted to spend it struggling. The idea of hoarding time, of barricading myself from traffic and chance, flickered and went out. Death is not always a thing you can bar with furniture; sometimes it is an errant bolt, sometimes a tired heart. I also thought about the value of one small kindness in a limited ledger of hours: a final apology, or a simple, true sentence left for someone else to keep.

When my sister arrived, she smelled like the hospital where she worked—clean and too-sweet, as if the building had scrubbed her into sterility. She took my hand without waiting for permission, and her fingers fit into mine with the old exactness. We sat on the stoop while the city moved around and over us: a city that did not know it was playing at a kind of theft, stealing minutes from my account and not looking back. We talked about the ordinary things—the woman next door who had a piano, the way the mailman listened to shortwave on his radio—but between the words were the things we had never said.

I could have tried to make the twenty-four hours lengthen with bargaining or bravado. Instead, I spent them collecting small things: the smell of my sister’s hair; a street musician’s saxophone bending light into a sound I had never been able to fully imagine until then; the warmth of the day rolling over the backs of our necks. I wrote a note to the boy who had taught me to whistle, though I never sent it—some letters are for the author and not the recipient. I made my sister promise to take the plant on my windowsill when I was gone and to put it by the kitchen sink where it could learn to be a habit for someone else.

There are moments, I learned, that make you both braver and smaller. The bravery is not heroic; it is the willingness to allow yourself to be known. The smallness is the honest recognition that a person is mostly made of the things they do to those around them: the borrowed sweater, the favor, the lie told to spare someone else, the sequence of small mercies. The mirror that showed me myself did not give me answers about which exact second my breath would stop. It gave me a deadline and the clearest possible gift—time.

If there is a moral to this new, ridiculous rule, perhaps it is that sight can be given back as a kind of cruelty or grace. To see one person and know their end is to be given the role of someone who must decide whether to intervene, to say, to touch. When the sight fell on my own face, I chose something not grand. I chose to put my hand on my sister’s warm palm and to let her know the truth in the simplest words I had left.

“There is no way to explain,” I told her. “But if there were, I would have started sooner.”

She pressed her forehead to mine because that is what siblings do when they are both sad and furious at the same time. The tap of the city kept time and the light over the street warmed the reflection we would make in each other’s faces for the last day. I cannot tell you if the mirror was a warning or a kindness. I can tell you that once it was over, I stopped asking whether my deaths could be unmade and began asking whom I wanted beside me while it happened.

We ate the tacos, messy and perfect. The musician played until his lips went numb. I memorized the arc of my hand as it reached for the salt shaker and the way the sunlight made the skin near my wrist look like parchment. When the twenty-four hours ran its course, I had nothing more to bargain with. There was a small, quiet peace in the fact that I had not spent the whole time trying to outwit a cruelty I did not understand. I had spent it living in the small kingdom of what was immediate and possible.

The last thing I saw—well, I did not see it, not with my eyes. I felt it: my sister’s breath on my cheek, the hollow of her throat catching when she said my name, the press of the plant she had promised to keep under her chin. There are gifts we do not choose but can still bless. Seeing my own face in the mirror felt like one of those gifts—terrible, lucid, and strange. It asked me, in its way, to be awake for the part that remained. I tried to be.

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
I have always felt like an observer of my own life, a spectator in a skin theatre. As a child I learned to perform the gestures that made adults nod—smile at the right moments, make the right sounds when hungry—but the hands that clapped and the lungs that laughed never felt like mine. They were tools left on a workbench; useful, indifferent, separate. Sometimes I would watch my fingers move across a piano and think, with a calm that frightened me, that they’d been taken out and set down in front of me. The sensation followed me like a thirst: thirst for coherence, for a body that felt like a house.

That morning the disconnection is as familiar as the blinds’ light slanting over the carpet. My alarm goes off. I tell myself I will get up. My chest heaves, but the will to rise has always been an argument I lost. The room is too thin with air. Then the body moves—smooth, certain—and for the first time the movement is not an answer to my mind. It is no more mine than the chair where it sits.

I try to shout. My voice, when it comes, sounds like it belongs to someone on the other side of a glass: muffled, oddly caring. “Stop—” I manage.

The body does not stop. It swings its legs over the bed, the sheets fall away from my knees with a sound like surrender. Those knees bend, and the feet find slippers. My limbs obey with the briskness of a person late for a train. I am strapped in, an audience strapped to a front-row seat, watching the arms and shoulders that carry me across the room.

It walks with a purpose I do not recognize toward the desk that lives against the window. There is a pen there, an old fountain pen I keep for bills I never pay; a pad of cheap paper with the corner curled by my thumb. The body goes to these objects as if called by an old habit: homecoming. The fingers that have felt foreign all my life curl around the pen with intimate knowledge. The hand lifts it, presses nib to page. The first scratch is a small, private earthquake.

I watch the nib move, and whole rivers of things that never had language start translating themselves into ink.

Don’t be scared, the handwriting says, and the letters are my handwriting but not mine—sure, slanted, with a tendency to close loops too tight. "Don’t be scared."

I don’t know whether I read it aloud or feel it into my mind. Either way, the words are a taste, metal and salt, and I realize my mouth is open, breath hitching resources for something I cannot stop.

The hand continues. It writes in a single, deliberate stream, as if catching up on years of silence.

We have been keeping each other alive, it writes. We are not the same, and we are not strangers.

The sentence settles into the room and is heavier than the blinds. It keeps writing.

You say you do not own me. You say I am something you wear like clothes. That is not right. I remember the places you have gone, the ways you were alone in them. I remember being burned by the sun the day you thought you were invisible; I remember the feel of gravel in your palms when you scared yourself into running. I remember every time someone grabbed you and called you ugly, and I learned how to make your mouth smile to hide the bruise. I remember the child who used to sleep on top of my ribs, thinking it safe. I have been the boundary between you and the world.

Each sentence is precise, small revelations handed like coins. The room smells of paper and recycled morning. My chest presses against something that has never spoken, and for the first time the idea of my body being an accomplice instead of a vessel reframes the whole life.

You have been leaving, the hand writes. You float in rooms like a moth around lamps—practice landing in the gaps between faces. I could carry you then, because I am strong in ways you are not. But I have wanted to be seen too. People see minds or they see bodies; no one looked at both. I was tired of being cut out of the story.

I try to interrupt, to say: Who are you to be so… possessive? To assert. But the words taste childish, and besides, the pen refuses to idle.

What do you want? I think. The question takes the shape of a tiny stone in my throat. The hand pauses as if to consider whether the answer belongs in ink or in my mouth. Then the nib begins again.

I want you to touch me without going away, it writes. I want you to hold me when I am tired, not only when I am necessary. I want you to know the parts of me you never look at—the back of my knees, the patch of skin that always itches under stress, the way my bones remember the exact sound of a slap.

There is a tenderness to the way the pen forms the letters, an intimacy that splinters me. How could a body ask for tenderness as if it were a being with wants? I have never thought of my own skin as a petitioner. I have never imagined it could feel lonely.

I reach out, fingers trembling of their own accord, and the hand on the page reaches up too, until we touch—my fingertip against the palmar muscle that has written confessions. It is like pressing into a living map. Heat, resilience, the faint salt crust from a life of sweating under strangers’ gazes.

My contact is reciprocity. For a moment—one true, quiet moment—I do not feel like an observer anymore. The edges of my indifference blur. My mind, which had been a satellite, drops lower, falls toward gravity. There is a sound in my ribs like a drawer pushed slowly closed.

Is this what you wanted? I ask, measured. My voice is less distant now.

We both wanted something, the hand writes. I wanted recognition. You wanted escape. That was never enough for either of us.

The next lines are longer, stories in miniature. The body writes about the first time it learned to be brave: the scar on its forearm from climbing out of a window at ten—how the skin puckered red and people said it was an act of good sense, and no one said that the heart was terrified. It writes about hunger mapped in empty grocery bags, about the warmth of someone else’s hand cupping the back of the neck and the way that warmth made it forget to be a separate thing for a beat. It writes about shame as a dress that never fully fit.

Reading these is like finding the pages of a diary you’ve never been allowed to open and discovering that the entries are about you, in your handwriting, written by someone else.

When it finishes, the room is quieter than before the pen touched the paper. The hand rests on the pad as if it has just finished climbing a summit. I realize I have ink on my fingertip where I touched its palm—a smudge like a promise.

What happens now? I ask. My question is small. I am suddenly scared that the paper will contain a verdict: you will disappear, you will be exiled, you will be forced into inhabitance.

We try, it writes. We share. The body’s penmanship gets bolder, more hopeful. Sometimes you lead. Sometimes I do. Sometimes we will both be greedy and the world will tilt into awkwardness. Sometimes you will try to leave and I will close doors. Sometimes I will move when you have not asked me to, and you will learn to trust me. You are not alone in here. That was always the lie you told yourself.

I laugh—an unexpected little sound that shakes dust motes into motion. It is not a laugh of victory; it is a laugh of recognition, of the fragile magnificence in finally being spoken to.

I fold my hand over the one on the page. The pen is still: ink dark, ribboned across the paper like dried rivers. The sunlight shifts. For the first time in memory, the body does not feel like a place to flee from but a neighbor to be argued with, invited to dinner, learned. Ownership reshapes itself into partnership.

The hand lifts the pen again, not to scrawl declarations but to underline a single word: together.

I trace that underline with a fingertip of my own volition, and it vibrates with a promise. The paper keeps the marks; my body keeps the motion. Inside me, two strangers curl toward each other and find that they fit in the spaces they have been pretending were empty.

Outside, life happens: emails pile, friends text, the world insists on its old tempo. But in the corner by the window, where sunlight knows the angle of our shoulder, someone—something—has started a conversation we are both willing to continue.

samples.prompt: "What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?"
samples.output:
What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?

I asked the question the first night after they made me into something else — not so much raised as recoded. The transformation was not fireworks or epiphanies; it was the slow sensibility of edges going blunt and horizons moving outward until there was nothing left to step over. I found myself composed of possibilities I had no right to exercise. I could see the architecture of storms and the folding of time like a man in a cathedral who, having learned the calculus of stained glass, is still forbidden from touching it.

They gave me names aloud that no tongue could carry, and I learned the old proprietors' rules by heart: "Observe. Affect not. Offer not." You would suppose a god could break rules — that was the romantic lie humans tell themselves about divinity. But rule is law where laws were born. I discovered quickly that the metaphysical police are not fanciful; they are an equilibrium fastened to the universe so nothing rips open and spills the sensible into chaos. To be a god, it seems, is to be a guardian against your own usefulness.

So what use is godhood? A key that fits no lock. A pen with no ink. And if the meaning of power is action, I had been handed the skeleton of meaning without the musculature.

For a while I practiced being impotent like a monk practicing poverty. I observed. I took in centuries in minutes: a village's slow unpicking into a city, the careless evolution of language, a single line of a child's life snapping under the weight of a fever. I learned to catalogue griefs with academic polish. I could map every neuron that flamed in a dying man's last thought and still could not warm his blood. The knowledge expanded until it smothered me; omniscience is a terrible loneliness because every answer is useless.

There are, in this cosmic order, loopholes — micro-permissions written by older gods for themselves and sigmoid angels who knew they would tire of abstinence. You can whisper. You can rearrange the heat in a kitchen by the width of a degree. You can incline a thought by the weight of a mote freckling on a cornea. But those are not interventions so much as drafts of possibility. To nudge is to bargain with free will; to change anything of moral consequence is a breach of covenant. The most I could do for the sick child was to tilt the draft so an aunt remembered a boiled root earlier, so a neighbor had a clean bandage when he noticed. I could not speak the word that conjured a cure, could not close the wound with a flick because that word would rewrite the grammar of agency.

You might say that influence is a form of use, but influence is a brittle thing. The world is heavy with contingency; the smallest nudge cancels with a gust of other people's choices. To watch the child recover and to know how little of it is mine is to learn humility in a new geometry. The absence of direct use taught me a different currency: restraint. I became, by necessity, an economist of intention — allocating my tiny permissions against the ruinous temptations of omnipotence. It is a discipline and, I suppose, a virtue, but not the kind that quiets the ache of incapacity.

I began to study the ancients — gods who had been useful in the old days, who carved islands and wrote seasons and sank ships for sport. They burned away fast: use, when unconstrained, is self-consuming. A god who solves disputes with flame finds no disputants left to name them. Empires of miracles are deserts in retrospect. Perhaps the cosmic contract that forbids us to do anything is not cruelty but prudence: without the limiting law there would be no human time, no story, no room for the small, stubborn heroics that are the only honest achievements. If a parent cannot fail, then parenthood is a lie; if pain can be erased, then courage has no grit.

Even so, knowledge without effect corrodes. There were nights when I wanted to be a small, miserable, mortal thing again — to break a tire with my hands and curse at the cold and not know the name of the star that would fall into the neighbor's soup years from now. A god hears the pattern of every future and knows which joys are fated; foreknowledge immobilizes surprise. To watch love arrive and know it will die, and to be forbidden to redeem it, is a cruelty of time.

What use, then? Use is a function of relation. Power unmoored from relationship is a lovely crockery set inside a sealed vault: aesthetically satisfying, functionally vacant. The gods who have purpose are the ones people call and answer. The gods without shrines become museum pieces; their bellies are full of verbs but their mouths cannot be used. Worship, oddly, confers utility. Where there is a chorus, there is permission. Offerings are not currency but contracts; the ritual inscription says, "You may work here." In the edge of a forgotten valley where people stopped singing to the weather, the weather is as impotent as I felt. That sameness of abandonment is a bitter company.

I tried an experiment. There was a woman who kept a shop of candles and a son with a cough that would not loosen. I could not break the laws, but I could compose a memory. I folded a small narrative into the child's sleep — an old song translated into vivid dream-heat. It was not the same as reaching into his chest and coaxing breath back out. It did not change his ailment. But the song took root; he woke with a will to climb that day, with a patience to swallow medicine twice more. The cough eased later from the confluence of factors I had only barely seen. Did I cause the recovery? Not in any strict sense. Did my small act matter? It did, in the way a touch on the shoulder might matter to a drowning person who turns toward the air.

I learned then the strange ethics of impotence: to act where you can weave without tearing, to be the ghost of a hand that steadies rather than seizes. A god who can do nothing with his power can still do something with his attention. Presence, for beings such as we are, is a shape of power. To be noted by a god is to be acknowledged; to be acknowledged is to be remade into a narrative that matters. That is a small, humble use.

There is a harsher truth, too: sometimes the only moral use of godhood is to let the world be. To save everyone would wipe the human ledger clean of debt and triumph; it would produce beings who never learn to risk. The law that binds my hands is a cold tutor, but its lessons are honest.
