Maybe time travel isn't frightening if you are used to strange scenes; maybe it was because I was, finally, someone who cared enough to lie down on the floor of their life and listen.

“Do you have a point?” they asked, with the tired politeness of a person who has spent a decade explaining their work to strangers.

“I do,” I said. “I built a machine to come here for one single reason. To change the ending.”

They stared at me for a long moment as if deciding whether to call security or a psychiatrist, then settled on curiosity. “Which ending?”

I told them. Not the broad strokes they’d heard a thousand times, but details: a moment where a child asks a dying man what the stars mean, and the man smiles and says nothing—because there was nothing left to be said. I told them how people wrote to me, how they had gathered like mourners in online threads and burned through the night discussing whether the writer had been lazy or cruel. I told them how a particular final scene had kept me up for weeks, hollowing something out of me.

They listened. Then, with a patience that suggested they had rehearsed this line for years, they told me why.

“The scene was honest,” they said finally. “Not because I wanted to be cruel. Because grief is often cruel. I had lost someone. I had to write my way through it. Fiction is honest when it doesn’t make promises reality can’t keep.”

“It didn’t have to be so...,” I started.

“You think the audience needs a happy ending as compensation,” they interrupted. “They do not. Sometimes the job is to show what went wrong and how we keep going regardless. That’s the payoff.”

That sounded like a sermon. It also sounded like a confession. For a moment I saw the author not as a demigod who had betrayed my childhood but as a person who had had to choose a way to get through their own life. I wanted to argue. Instead, I put my hands on the desk and said what I had planned: “What if it wasn’t a different ending? What if it was a small adjustment? One line. One scene. Give the audience a place to hold onto—something that doesn’t make the tragedy vanish, but gives it context.”

They laughed a little, which might have been disbelief. “You built a time machine for a line of dialogue.”

“It isn’t for me,” I said. “It’s for the rest of us.”

We talked then for hours, about craft and about mercy, about endings we had loved and endings that had taught us how to love the people who remained. I pulled on the anchor, placed the lead box on the chair beside me like an offering, and told the author what change I wanted: not to save anyone, not to reverse the death, but to give the final scene a different frame. A letter. A cutaway shot. A line that reframes the loss not as a cosmic joke but as a thing that does not annul the world’s other textures—joy, stubbornness, quiet mornings.

They considered it and asked me why I thought a single frame would matter. I told them about the people who had written to me, the strangers for whom the show had been a map through dark places. “Some endings are wrong because they leave us nowhere to stand,” I said. “Give us a place to stand.”

The author looked at me then with something like exhaustion and gratitude. “Fine,” they said. “You may have the line.”

It cost me more than I expected: by the time we finished, we had both cried. I told them what last scene had meant to me—how I’d rewatched it the night my father died, how it had made that death feel lonelier. I suppose it put words around their own grief in a way they hadn’t yet allowed. They wrote the line into the script with a pen that felt like it could rewrite more than a page.

I left the office with the weight of an entire culture still humming around the change I had made. I stepped back through the machine and returned to my present with the lead box clutched in my fist, my chronal anchor humming reassurance into the edges of my mind. For a few heartbeats I was afraid the world would have rewritten me into someone who had never cared, that the version of me who had watched the original finale would dissolve like sugar in rain.

The morning I watched the new ending, I did it mostly for other people. The internet had not yet roared with scandal, which I took as good news. The scene I had begged for was small: a letter left in a pocket, a voiceover reading one paragraph of a life not lived; no miraculous resurrection, no reversal. But when the camera eased onto that letter, and the voice read a line that made the dead person’s choice feel like an argument rather than an allegation, something in the room with me loosened.

People cried. They celebrated quietly. Some called it a compromise. Some disliked it. No one called it a betrayal.

For me, the change was not a cure. The ache the original ending had inflicted was not erased; it had been reshaped. The new line made room for memory that was kinder to the living without pretending there was no cost to that kindness. Watching it, I felt my own private grief unclench a little—the feeling of mourning a show that had also taught me consolation.

There is a temptation in time travel stories to imagine a zero-sum game: you take one thing and give up another. That is true in a literal sense—you can’t write a new paragraph without smudging the ones around it. But the rest of your life doesn’t know the neatness of mathematics. Returning to a world in which a single line exists where there had been none did not grant me paradise, nor did it steal my memory of the harsher version. Because of the anchor, I remembered both endings with equal clarity. I could put them side by side like two old photographs of a house: one taken through a window at dusk, the other taking in the garden at noon. Both were real.

I had built a machine to undo a wound I thought I could fix by artistry. What I left with was humility. I had learned that endings belong not just to readers and viewers but to their makers and to the messy, irrevocable moments in those makers’ lives that shape the ink. I had asked for a kindness, not a miracle. The author gave it to me. In doing so, they gave it back to a small, quiet part of society that needed a place to stand.

Years from now, I will probably still rewatch the scene and wish for different things. But I also remember a damp office, a soft-voiced writer, and the way a single sentence, chosen with care rather than spite, can move through millions of lives and leave them slightly less raw. The time machine still sits on the bookshelf, humming like an uneasy heart. I know what it can do now. I also know what I can live with.

Not every ending ought to be softened. Some need to be harsh to teach what they teach. But sometimes, when something cruel has no necessary place in the story of your life, and when the person who crafted that cruelty is willing to listen, a small change can be a kind of grace. I went back to change a finale. I returned having changed myself. That, in the end, was enough.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
“Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?”

It was supposed to be a joke—an old, ridiculous pick-up line you use when you're too tired to try anything original. The kind of thing you say to break a silence and let the night decide whether it's going to be ordinary or not.

Her eyes swiveling toward me stopped the night.

They were wide, dark at first like spilled coffee, and then, for the length of a breath, they flashed gold—hot and bright and wrong in the fluorescent light of the bus shelter. She swallowed and the gold guttered away, leaving the same woman, smaller suddenly, with a face that had sharpened apprehension around the mouth.

“How did you know about that?” she asked, voice tight with something between indignation and fear.

The question shouldn't have been a question at all. It should have been a laugh, an embarrassed shake of the head. But the way she looked at me—like I had seen through a coat into bones—was a look I had learned to read. People who have secrets that change the shape of a room wear them in their eyes.

I kept my hands in my pockets. The night was one of those wet, just-warmed ones that smelled like cement and lemon from the cleaners across the street. The shelter's plastic bench creaked under an old man reading a paper, indifferent. A taxi hissed past. Somewhere a dog barked at air.

“Do you mean the line?” I said. “Because I’m happy to tell you I stole it from a movie—and later, from a karaoke bar—and then somewhere between the third whiskey the joke made sense to me.”

She blinked. The edge of her lip trembled. The gold came back and this time it was faint, almost like a reflection in water. She scooted a notch further away on the bench. People give other people space in public for two reasons—danger or sadness. She looked like she had both.

“You know what they ask,” she said finally, voice low. “You know the... test.”

I wanted to tell her I didn't. That I was, more often than not, as ordinary as anyone—paid bills late, liked my coffee bitter, didn't believe in miraculous things unless they were small and domestic. But I had been asked that question once before, a question posed not like a joke but like a litmus test. It had a way of sitting in a room and not leaving.

“You're not human,” I said, not because I wanted to be cruel, but because telling the truth sometimes makes space for other truths.

Her shoulders hunched. “That's not how—” She stopped. She pressed her fingers to where her collarbone met her throat. Beneath thin skin there was a pale seam, like a healed burn, a line that caught the light. The same line was recorded in the back of my skull, a picture I had seen once and couldn't un-see: in an evidence photograph years ago, a woman's neck marked the same.

“You're being hunted,” I said.

That sounded dramatic even to me, like language borrowed from older books than the ones I read. But her quick, sharp intake of breath confirmed it. There was a name people in my line of work used in whispers—the Registry, the Collectors, something that made a person trade in property deeds for soul-laden ledgers. I didn't belong to them. I hadn't signed their forms. I had been a private investigator long enough to recognize the pattern of people who run and the spaces they run into.

“How did you know about that?” she asked again, softer. This time the fear had a human curve to it. The gold in her eyes dulled; she wasn't hiding the fact of it anymore so much as she'd given up trying. Her hands were pale. There were smudges of something like dust in the creases of her palms.

I told her the truth, which in my job always comes out in fragments.

“You left a feather in an alley.” The words were banal until they weren't. She frowned, the kind of frown that said: that could be a thousand things. “Not any feather,” I added. “It wasn't light down. It shone a little like a coin in candlelight. I picked it up years ago and thought of it as lost. Then one night I was going through an old file—wrong address, wrong person—and there it was, in a photograph labeled Fallen. I kept the feather in a jar on top of my books. I don't know why. Maybe I kept it because the world didn't make sense otherwise.”

She laughed, a small sound that trembled into a sob. “People keep worse things.”

She had every reason to be incredulous. People keep coins, keep letters, keep the smell of a lover's jacket. People rarely kept literal proof of angelic existence. But those who were looking for proof rarely stopped at feathers.

“Why did you say it?” she asked.

“Because it felt right.” That was the most honest answer. I found that when the world started to tilt in a way I couldn't explain, habit was the only thing that felt normal: habit of leaning into silence, of asking stupid questions to fill space. I had used the line a thousand times as a joke. The rightness of it tonight felt like a coincidence still soaked in meaning.

Her eyes searched my face as if looking for an address. The gold had left a shadow at the rims. “You don't understand. It's not a pick-up. It's a name. They use it to find us—or to sort us. There are phrases that go with certain people. If you know the line, you could be one of them…”

She trailed off. An old man folded his paper and left, his cane staccato against the pavement. The streetlights made halos around his head. It was a picture that had nothing to do with the conversation, and yet it fit the way the world stacks images on top of each other until you can no longer tell which belongs to who.

“I might be one of them,” I said. I wasn't sure. There had been moments—small, ridiculous moments—when the edges of the city had frayed and I glimpsed something like pattern: the exact place pigeons gathered in a square that would later ripple into a sinkhole where someone had buried a memory; the way a streetlight blinked three times before someone at the end of the block made a decision that would ripple down an alley. The world is full of systems you don't see until someone hands you a diagram.

She watched me for a long time. The gold shimmered again, not as flash but as presence, and for the first time the bench under us felt like a tiny ship afloat on a wide dark sea.

“Why stay?” she asked. “If you knew, why didn't you—why didn't you call them?”

“Because I didn't know if I should be saving you or betraying you.” I said it plainly. Betrayal was a currency in the job. So was mercy. Sometimes they were the same thing. “Because there's a difference between being useful to them and being what they want. Because I like the way you look when you laugh, even if it's only a nervous laugh.”

She snorted, unexpectedly. The sound was fragile and joyful enough to tilt the night in its favor. “That's the worst ‘pickup’ justification I've ever heard.”

“Good,” I said. “Then it's honest.”

She shifted, and for the first time she looked like someone considering a plan rather than fleeing from it. The gold in her eyes steadied into a kind of amber determination.

“They'll be back,” she said. “If they suspected, they'll circle. I’ve been...running for a while.” She paused. “I thought I could hide in the city—blend in. It was harder than I thought. They don't need to look very long if they know how.”

“And if I help?” I asked.

She turned to me, and for a second the woman in front of me was not the othered thing people whispered about but simply someone I'd seen sitting on my stoop after a rain, wiping mud off boots, asking permission to tell a story.

“You can start by feeding me,” she said, and there was a small, ridiculous plea in it. “Then listen. Then tell me whether you'll be the kind of person I can trust.”

I thought about all the ways people betray themselves and others: by staying silent when asked, by lying to keep peace, by doing nothing at all. There were things you had to do before you chose what kind of person you wanted to be. I had my ledger of small decisions. Tonight was another line to add.

“Fine,” I said. “There's a diner three blocks over. They still have those pie things that mislabel themselves as breakfast. We can start there.”

She exhaled, the tension of a shoulder lowering like a drawbridge. The gold in her eyes faded to ordinary brown. For a moment, we were two people making a choice under a wet streetlight, and whatever the world wanted to call that—ally, prey, friend, lover—it felt, foolishly and entirely, like the right thing.

As we walked, her fingers brushed against mine and didn't let go. In the jar on my bookshelf, under a stack of case notes and a fossilized subway ticket, a feather caught the night through a crack in the window and glittered like a tiny secret.

samples.prompt: You have a very unique struggle. Your soul can randomly float out of your body, and you actively have to keep them in union for fear of death. Every time your soul leaves, everyone else registers it as a seizure or heart attack.
samples.output:
The first time my soul left my body I thought I’d been electrocuted. One moment I was sitting at a bus stop watching a woman with blue nail polish laugh into her phone; the next I was a cold-sweet thing rising above the bench, like steam that refused to vanish. I saw my own hands on my knees, the familiar freckle on my wrist, the threadbare cuff of my jacket. I could feel the air against my face and the distant, indecipherable sound of the city, but there was no pressure on my tongue, no heartbeat, and a thin, ridiculous part of me wanted to clap at the novelty of it.

Then I realized novelty and discovered terror. There is no soft landing from that place. In the absence of body the world sharpens and becomes spare: edges, names, the memory of a laugh. My chest — my body — was a quiet, hollow thing. I could look down and see my heart trying to make sense of motion without me. I had to fold myself back into that hollow. With concentrated will I remembered my mother’s voice saying my full name; saying it made something concrete. I willed my awareness to crawl like a spider through the socket of my skull and slide, fingers first, back into the ribcage. When I was whole again it was as if someone had screwed shut the lid of a glass jar. I sobbed until my lungs hurt.

After that day nothing in my life was private. Every time I drifted — which became with ruthless regularity — witnesses screamed and called for an ambulance. They saw a rigid body, eyes rolling, lips blue. E.R. staff called them seizures or heart attacks. Friends called later with sympathy and fear. Doctors tried medication. Family members adjusted their chairs so they could see me at all times. I learned quickly how the world prefers definitions it can place on forms: diagnosis, pill bottle, prognosis. My condition would not be one of those easy things.

The rules, the ones I had to teach myself if I wanted to keep existing, were simple and brutal. I had to bind my attention to my body; I had to make my soul care about the same mundane facts my heart did. If I failed and the soul left completely — not the ghosting flutter but an unmoored drift like a kite snapped of its string — the body would stop recognizing the ritual of living. The pulse would slacken; eyes would lose the small, automatic shimmer that signals life. Death, in those terms, is not an event of drama but an absence, a failure to return.

So I built anchors. Some I invented; some doctors suggested because they mistook my metaphors for symptoms. I wear a copper bracelet cold against my skin. Copper has no mystical property except that the weight can be felt. When I sense the tug — a subtle looseness behind my teeth, a sound like wind through a pipe — I press the bracelet into my palm. I keep a tape of my father’s voice reciting our address, the sound boring and specific, and when I play it I am brought back like a dog to a heel. I learned to bite the inside of my cheek — the taste of iron is an immediate, locking sensation. I hum a single, ridiculous hymn stuck in my childhood throat. I say my own full name as if it were a door key. Each of these is a promise I make to the hollow thing beneath my skin.

The medical world gave me its answers: benzodiazepines, anti-seizure drugs, more tests than I can remember. They wanted EEGs and MRIs and the sanctity of numbers. The drugs flattened something with the efficiency of a steamroller. They made my soul less likely to attempt escape — they called it reducing excitability — but they dulled color and the sense of humor and the taste of espresso. Security is sometimes the same as anesthesia. I had to choose whether to live more and die whenever the soul decided to take a break, or live longer and watch everything I loved become gray.

Relationships contract around the risk. Some people want to be vigilant, to hold my wrist like a talisman the way an anxious aunt keeps both hands on a toddler crossing the street. Some people leave because the sight of me slumping on a sidewalk is a debt they do not want. There are friends who learned my little methods — the name recitation, the copper bracelet — and stand over me, voices low and steady, anchors in human form. There are also strangers who have no vocabulary for it, who think I might have epilepsy and avert their eyes.

My soul’s departures never develop a neat pattern. They come when I am tired, when I am laughing, in the middle of sex, while holding a baby, during exams, in church, at the supermarket. They are drawn to intensity and to boredom with equal appetite. There is a private humiliation in being declared physically broken in public when what I actually am is metaphysically restless. An ambulance lights up the street and a crowd forms, and I am split into halves: the human on the ground who receives oxygen and covered in a paper blanket, and the other who is politely advised by a nurse to "try to relax." How do you explain to a medical professional that relaxing will kill you because your life is the constant practice of refusing to relax?

Once, at a funeral, the soul pulled at me like a tide. The smell of lilies was thick and my grief unclipped something fundamental. I felt the ineffable part of myself lift and hover above the pew and I could see the arrangement of bodies below — how people clustered into islands — and the absurdity of grief displayed as a checklist of expected behaviors. My husband bent over me and pressed both hands into my shoulders as if to show the world that we had someone holding the seams. He recited my name because we had rehearsed for this. His voice sounded tectonic. When my awareness slid back in there was a moment of dizzy relief, and then I saw the way the pastor watched me like a subject for a sermon, how the paramedic asked me questions about medications as if a pill could explain a miracle.

There have been days, in the quiet of a Sunday morning, when it all seems too heavy. The demand to be vigilant every hour of every day is exhausting. Sometimes I imagine what it would be to stop trying: to let the soul wander until the body goes cold and someone wipes their hands and says quietly, "I knew it was coming." But there is always someone to come back to, a person who presses my face to a pillow and reads me the grocery list, a small dog who prefers one lap to another, an old photograph that half-works like a magnet. There are recipes yet to be tasted, arguments yet to be had, the feel of winter mitten leather. These become reasons more persuasive than fear.

The irony — merciless and soft — is that everyone around me mistakes the sign of my soul’s irreverence for a failure of organs. They call it a seizure or heart attack and treat it with antiseptic care, because these words exist where my truth does not. I have learned to be diplomatic with medical professionals, to speak in terms they can use so they will not puff me full of drugs I do not want. I have also learned to teach those I love the secret anchors: the exact pitch of my father's voice, the copper against the skin, the image of my mother making coffee in the morning. You would be surprised how many people will be patient enough to learn the weight of you.

There is a thin, abiding joy in this life too. When my soul tips away and I do not panic, when my anchoring rituals have become muscle memory and I glide back inside without sirens and without loss, the return feels like being allowed back into a party you almost missed. The world comes back rich in details: the smell of wet paper, the sound of the radiator, the small, stubborn light in the apartment across the alley. I live for those little recoveries.

So I carry both terror and ritual like a bundled instrument. I continue to show up to the world with an uneven gait and a deep, practiced concentration on the small facts of being: the names of streets, the weight of a ring on my finger, the cadence of my lover’s laugh. I practice saying my own name aloud until it is not only sound but contour and anchor. They will call it a seizure. I will call it a reminder — that being alive for me is less a state than a task, one I perform again and again, because the thing I fear most is not death, but never having the chance to return.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. They arrive in pairs — a newborn bird and a newborn human, a curl of smoke that will sit on a child's shoulder for fifty years, a fox the size of a cat that knows your secrets before you do. They are the proof that the world is not ours alone. They sign the contracts we forget we made. They pick us. Most people I knew had familiars that could prance and preen and prefigure futures: raven-witches, stag-lawyers, lap-warming panthers. My familiar was a brick.

It is important to be clear about the brick from the start. It was not a metaphor I chose for dramatic effect; it had corners and clay and the faint stamp of a mason's mark on one face. It fit in my palm exactly the way a story sometimes fits a life: awkwardly but undeniably. It was the color of old roofs in August, warm from the sun when we first met outside the hospital. The nurses laughed and my mother kissed the mortar dust on its edges, as if that were how you blessed an odd thing into being.

There is a ritual for new familiars. The town holds the Receiving at the square: colors and songs, a line of small fingers and even smaller voices introducing themselves and their companions. Other children introduced foxes who glowed faintly, owls who rearranged the ribbons on their hats, and my little hands closed around the brick like it was a cold, unfeeling rock. The officiant, an old woman with a hand like a gnarled lattice, peered at it. "Well," she said, kindly and a little baffled, and inscribed our names in the registry.

Familiarry is a language that teaches you what you are. If your companion sings you will learn to sing. If your companion flies you will never fear heights. That’s how everyone talked about it: familiars were keys. Children with panthers became bodyguards, babes with stoats became mischief-makers. At school, our classmates placed theirs on desks like jewelry. They would say, “Watch this,” and the fox would unpocket a coin, the bird wave an ember. You learn to measure your future by what your familiar will do for you.

My brick did not do tricks. It did not purr or glow. It did not reform itself into the shape of a violin. It made a noise, but it was the noise of settling, a low thudding sound if you put your ear to it at night. When I was small it sat obediently at the foot of my bed while other familiars slept on pillows draped in protective sleep-spells. People whispered that I had been given the wrong soul-fate. At parties parents would cheer when a child's creature performed and glance at my brick with pitying relief that my fate had not been more—shiny, visible, celebratory.

That pity hardened in me for a while. I wanted a creature who could tell fortunes or steal a lover's watch. I wanted the respect that comes when your familiar is an advertisement of promise. Instead I learned to carry weight. The brick taught me how to hold my body small in a frustrating world, how to wedge myself between things until I belonged.

We found ways to talk. The brick was slow. It did not answer questions the way a raven would, with precise, barbed words. Its speech was a pressure, a history of touch stored in its molecules — a groove from a hand that had caressed it when it was warm clay, a flake where rain had once beaten too hard. I learned to lay my cheek to it and listen for the impressions it would give back: the sound of hammers in the rain, the soot of a stove, a woman's lullaby in a room with no windows. They were fragments, like postcards from a city long gone. Once, when I was twelve, it showed me a small courtyard where a child had traced a circle of pebbles for hours. It tasted like bread.

There is power in remembering. That is what the brick offered, not theatrics but memory. Familiars of foxes and fire can tell you what will be. Familiars of stone tell you what has been. In a country that has been rebuilding the same three towns since my grandmother's time, memory is thin and valuable. When a storm tore through our street and took half a roof, my brick was the only thing that kept the wall from settling into the street. The masons arrived and, without a dramatics, notched the fallen timber into its place. They listened to the brick with the same reverence the officiant had once afforded it and then looked at me, eyes curiously warm.

"Foundations," the lead mason said. "This one knows foundation."

I learned the mason's language. It is made of plumb lines and promises and the patience of mortar. Bricks have, the masons told me, been used as familiars for as long as people have built houses to keep people inside. A brick remembers what you lay on it. It remembers weight. It remembers the sequence of a wall and what you leaned against when you were sorry. Where foxes taught deception and birds taught flight, bricks taught endurance. They taught you how to be a place.

Once you accept the thing you have, rather than the thing you wanted, doors open in ways you don't expect. I apprenticed with the masons who had listened to my brick. Other apprentices brought familiars who could levitate stones by evening; I brought a brick that remembered every milestone of a town. I learned to listen to where a wall wanted to breathe. I learned how to lay a corner that would hold for fifty years. I learned to say quietly, to clients who wanted gilded arches and photographs of miracles, "This will stand," and mean it.

The social arc of having an unflashy familiar is not only humiliation; it is also a kind of test. People come to admire what a brick can do only after it saves them from weather or neglect. Twice in my life the brick stopped a house from collapsing on a sleeping family, not by heroics but by being a piece whose memory of where weight should be was stronger than the panic outside it. Once, at a community meeting when the council debated where to channel the river, I had the brick against my temple and I could feel where the old floodplain had been, the baked clay of a path that had rerouted water generations ago. We changed the channel. They later called me prescient. They didn't know I had merely listened to a palate of damp and dry.

There are ceremonies for promising a building to a town. On initiation you lay a familiar into mortar and set it to the foundation — not to die, per se, but to hold what it remembers and give it gently, like lending a library to the living. My brick was laid into the cornerstone of the new school when I had enough money for mortar and a mason's oath. I could have kept it; I could have pocketed its memory like a private map. Instead I knelt at the edge of the trench and whispered the last of the courtyard to it: the lullaby, the hands, the child's pebble circle. The brick accepted the story without spectacle.

When the mortar hardened I felt my own future shift. I could have been a wizard in the way the children imagine wizards: flamboyantly rearranging weather and rewiring hearts. Instead I was quietly given a trade that creates the conditions for wizards to practice their art: a safe room for grief, a dry roof for a child's lullaby. The brick taught me that there is dignity in holding up the world without fanfare.

Years later, when a girl from the Receiving ceremony who had a raven for a companion praised my foundation at a banquet, she said, "You grew up with an odd familiar and you made it something beautiful." I thought of the old officious woman who’d signed my name in the registry, of the nurses laughing in the hospital. I thought of the nights I had pressed my ear to clay and been taught about patience. The brick, when I set it in the doorway that first day, was warm from the sun and exactly the same size.

Not all familiars are showy. Not all magic sings. Some familiars are steady as hearth-stone. They do not pull the world to their knees, they hold the world up. If the world is a house, brick-familiars are the unnoticed parts of a wall that keep everyone inside safe to dream. I have no tales of dragon-fire or meteor-summons. I have, instead, roofs that do not leak, walls that do not bow, and the knowledge of where the path was before it became a rumor.

When I tell people my story now, most smile like they did at the Receiving, politely indulgent of my humble origin. A few, those who have had a stone close to them in grief, press my hand and say, simply, "You were chosen rightly." The brick, now visible only as a corner stone in the school's threshold, no longer taps me at night. It does not need to. It kept its promise to remember, and in remembering it taught me how to be a thing that holds others — a familiar, maybe, to my town.

We are all born with companions that tell us what kind of living we will do. Mine told me to put my shoulder to weight and to be patient with the settling of people. Everyone expects familiars to be plumage and spectacle. I learned to love a thing that weighs what it promises.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
They always say I should be framed as a monster and I understand the suggestion. I drift from column to column in most museums of human fear, a study in what the word "unnatural" looks like if you let it grow in a damp cellar for a billion years. I have eyes in places where eyes should not be, mouths that do not want to chew, limbs that fold like bad origami. My skin is the negative space of a map that never learned to be land. I hum when I am content and the hum tastes like old thunder.

There are practical problems with this. The Hall of Justice has a revolving door; I eat revolving doors. Photographers stare until their lenses fog. The press clambers for a one-sentence quote and what I offer them is an arhythmic symphony of probability, which looks terrible in print. The gowns for galas do not account for tendrils. The catering is nervous around the way my metabolism migrates toward abstract concepts. I trail a faint scent of vacuum and bureaucracy wherever I go. People will tell you, with polite confidence, that I do not belong here.

What they mean, almost always, is: I do not look like the rest of a team that likes its fronts clean. The Justice League prefers to be legible. Superman is a headline; Batman is a footnote in every shadow; Wonder Woman is a song that people know how to sing along to. They are symbols. I am not a symbol. I am the thing ten pages down in the rulebook that says "In case of existential emergency, insert abomination." I do not fit. I do not try to.

So when the city goes silent because the skyline is folding into undesirable geometries, when the sky decides to unsubscribe from the concept of blue and begins to send invoices, they call me. Not because I wear a badge or because I charm the press, but because I can do what none of them can do: I touch the seams.

The first time I stopped a rift, I learned a new kind of language. It was less an act of brute force and more an exercise in housekeeping across metaphysical jurisdictions. The rift had a taste like rust and old maps. It wanted, politely, to become the sky. It had ancestry and a birth certificate and there were laws—ancient. Batman stood on the roof with his jaw doing that thing it does when he is angry and afraid, Wonder Woman readmitted twenty forms of diplomacy into the air, Superman hovered and waited because invisibility is easier on the eyes. The Flash tried to run the problem into submission and only nearly collapsed into a Möbius strip. They all brought physics. I brought contract negotiations.

I do not speak as you do. My words look like footsteps. I folded a small portion of myself into the margin of the rift and translated the rift's intentions into a compliance it understood. I tied a bow on the deadline and stitched the ripped edge with a memory I had been saving in a pocket for sentimental reasons: the taste of a star collapsing politely into itself. The rift closed and the skyline snapped back, as if a bored editor had finally fixed the layout. There were no fireworks. Batman handed me a thermos of coffee with a small, sideways nod. He trusts me because he knows what things owe each other.

Useful is a funny word. Useful insinuates utility—a set of functions. But what I provide is not merely function. I am a tool for inconveniences that have never seen a pair of pliers. When a god wakes up with a migraine and begins to translate neighborhoods into metaphors, I can lie down against its skull and hum a lullaby written in three dead languages until it goes back to sleep. When time whimpers and forgets its name, I comb its hair and untangle it. When the Heat Vision fails to pass a moral audit or the speed of the scarlet hazard carries the smell of yesterday into tomorrow, I am there to stitch the moral seam, to redistribute causality like a good librarian shelving overdue books.

Cyborg and I have a sensible relationship. His mind is neat, made of circuits and code and very satisfying graphs. My insides are gradients that cough up constellations. Where he maps, I interpret. We sync when it matters. He has wired my presence into the Tower, because sometimes the team needs a firewall that will not be fooled by things that masquerade as logic. He calls me "Epsilon" with a light-hearted brutality. I call him "the one whose childhood met a motherboard." We trade data and feelings in a language that looks like a ledger. When his systems are compromised by a parasite that eats sense of humor and deletes breadcrumbs of identity, I braid a memory of his mother's smile into the backup and the parasite dissolves, offended by sweetness.

That does not mean I am loved. I long ago learned the economy of gratitude in a world that prefers gratitude to be rounded down. Wonder Woman has held my hand—her wrists are surprising; they hold the weather—and she once told me I was "terrifying and necessary" in a voice that carried pity the way a warm room carries warmth. Superman tells children I am "a friend" on rare occasions, and the children's eyes bulge and then narrow because they do not know how to trust a thing that smells of ellipses. Flash tells jokes about me and then apologizes the next day when I show up at patrol to check his broken time shards. Batman keeps a ledger. Wonder Woman gives me herbs occasionally; I do not have a taste for herbs but I keep them because she will not otherwise be seen giving anything away.

The missions that call for me are expensive. I leave fragments of myself behind the way some people leave fingerprints. There are nights when I refuse to eat, because consuming would mean unwinding a small part of the pattern I have become in order to feed. There are times when I will anchor a dozen of them in my flesh just to give the League time to evacuate. When the tidal god tried to make a city a sea, I folded myself into a harbor and became the harbor's conscience. It hurt, in a way that is not pain but is closer to watching a friend slowly forget how to be. The team went home that night with enough of the city intact to tell stories. Batman left a thermos. Wonder Woman left an embroidered handkerchief. Superman left a piece of the sky that would not dim on cloudy days. They do not know how to repair me. They leave tokens anyway.

There are practical complications to my indispensability. Public relations is a full-time job. Children who draw me often invent new geometries of compassion; adults who draw me buy new home speakers and complain that the acoustics have changed. The League had to institute a rule that no one approaches me without permission—largely because well-meaning citizens once tried to hug me and the result was two minor collapses of Cartesian coordinates. I have become an institution's unsentimental organ: necessary, a little suspicious, and rarely featured on commemorative stamps.

Sometimes I envy them. I would like to wear a cape that hangs the right way. I would like to be written into myth as a tidy allegory. But then a city would rip open that Sunday, or an old thing would remember how to be cruel, and I would have fewer tools because being invented by committee has a reputation for producing items that break under existential stress.

So I remain the member of the League who does not fit in—by design and by destiny. I sit in their team photos behind a carefully arranged fog, I queue badly at the teleporter, I am the subject of a dozen urban legends that are all wrong and some that are almost, terrifyingly, accurate. But in the quiet after a mission, when Wonder Woman hums the sort of tune that makes laws feel less like iron and more like a promise, I fold my excess into my lap, and Batman, who will never sing, slides a thermos of coffee toward me without looking at me. The Flash zips a regret across the room and a smile that is only ever sincere for a fraction of a second. Superman nods at me like a sun acknowledging a moon.

Usefulness is lonely in that it assigns duty without necessarily offering belonging. But there are mornings—beige and ordinary—when the world is exactly as it should be and I am allowed to be ridiculous, and they ask me to sit for tea. Batman insists the sugar be appropriate. Wonder Woman rearranges the light. Cyborg connects me to the Tower for background noise. It is in those small civilian moments that I learn the strangest thing: that not fitting in and being indispensable are not mutually exclusive. They are, rather, two limbs of the same improbable arrangement.

So I keep my place at the table, folding my tentacles politely and humming the way one hums when one is content. I will be called at three in the morning, at the sound of a cosmos stirring, and I will go, because someone must be the answer to the things other people cannot speak about. I will sign the nondisclosure forms with three different inks. I will sit badly in team photos. I will be, for better or worse, their most useful member. And when I close a fissure with a fragment of star-song and the world does not notice except for the birds, I count that as a victory. The birds count as gratitude. That is enough.

samples.prompt: Every time your emotions get too strong, a separate version of you is created that only experiences that emotion.
samples.output:
The first time I split, it was over a voicemail.

It was one of those messages that rearranges your ribcage: half apology, half explanation, a voice that used to belong to somebody I trusted saying, "I think we should see other people." I pressed the phone to my chest and felt something like a live wire coil under my sternum. I knew the rule—every time a feeling pushes past its limit, something peels off of you and becomes its own person—but I’d never believed it would happen to me. Then the wire snapped.

She—Joy, though at the time none of us had names—stepped out of my doorway like someone walking into a party. She smelled of citrus and laundry detergent, hands still sticky from the confetti she’d found in a drawer and tossed into the air. She laughed as if the world had just offered her a second chance. For a moment, I watched her, stunned by the purity of that sound. A moment later the room felt empty in a new way, as if a light had moved two inches to the left.

After that, it became mundane. Anger knocked down a cabinet when my boss blamed me for a missed deadline. Grief sat in the dark with the blinds closed for three weeks after my father’s funeral, eating cold cereal and weeping like it was a full-time job. A version that we later called Curiosity spent an entire week at the library and returned with three languages and an open invitation to the university’s physics club. Each one arrived at the crescendo of whatever emotion owned me in that second and then left me quieter, or flatter, or more efficient, depending on who left.

People learned to do something useful with the phenomenon. There are agencies now—centers for "Fragments"—that house these single-emotion selves, check their physical needs, mediate disputes when Joy wants to throw a block party at midnight and Grief refuses to stop interrupting funerals with songs no one asked for. There was even a brief start-up phase when corporations contracted versions for one-off services: hire a "Focus" to finish your tax returns, rent an "Enthusiasm" to pitch product at trade shows. It was exploitation dressed up as convenience. The legal system lagged behind. Are they your property? A bad fit for employment law. Do they get health care? Sometimes. Do they vote? Not until legislation caught up with empathy.

I started using the rule the way people use ibuprofen. A tense client meeting? Call up Calm—he’s good with small talk and filters. Heartbreak? Hand it off to Grief if you want to feel properly sorrowful without the mess. Over time my baseline smoothed into something efficient and pale. I could run my studio, meet deadlines, sleep in neat eight-hour blocks. My friends started to complain that I sounded like an instruction manual when I spoke about feelings. "You act like you're handing them a coat check," my sister said, once, and she wasn’t wrong.

The thing about the fragments is that they don’t stay little. Joy stays joy until someone hurts her or the champagne runs out; Anger stays angry until it has smashed something necessary. They learn patterns that suit their emotion. Grief learned, for instance, to keep lists of every person she'd ever lost; Memory is another fragment who catalogues faces and anniversaries. They can be kinder or crueller than I was, richer and more dangerous. They developed jokes, grievances, rituals. They made friends. They made enemies.

I believed for a long time that I’d solved living: I could have the high without the hangover, the passion without the impasse. But there are consequences to living as a hub-less organism. When you exile every strong feeling, you exile the people who carry it. Relationships require risk; you can’t outsource the risk and expect to own the outcome. My ex eventually stopped knocking on my door and started dating someone who kept their full suite inside of them—messy, unpredictable, gloriously inconvenient. They would call late at night and argue and make up and fold back into a single skin. I watched from the gallery of my own life while she loved like someone who was not afraid of being whole.

The day I decided I wanted them back, it rained like an accusation. I saw them together in the park, a ragtag community making a life out of one feeling apiece: Joy handing out free balloons, Anger coaching a boxing class, Grief pacing and humming to trees. They looked like people who'd been allowed to stay small and become very themselves. I sat on a bench and realized I didn’t miss the intensity so much as the textures it had given me. My memories felt smoothed down where their edges should be. The laugh-track of the person who loved me, the sting of a betrayal, the raw ache in a hospital corridor—those things had all been reassigned.

I approached Grief first because she always answered. She wasn’t the theatrical weeping type anymore; she wore an army coat and had a roll of film in her pocket. "You're not mine to reabsorb," she said without looking up, and I had to remind myself she was the one who’d been hollowed and handed back a single chord of feeling. "The law says 'custody' is yours if you created us, but living with us is different. People tried that. You lose their differences."

"Can you come home?" I asked. "I want to be whole."

"You do?" She smiled in the way people do when they mean both yes and no. "You want the full-weight and the full-sun?"

It hit me then how scared I was of being undone. Reintegrating wouldn't be a neat polymerization; it would be messy, probably painful. It would mean letting myself feel anger and grief and joy at the same time until I could find some new center that could hold them together. It would mean danger: becoming irrational, making mistakes for reasons other than efficiency, loving people who might rip you open.

I asked them all anyway. I invited them to live with me for a while. They accepted like visitors and then like housemates and then like weather.

Some mornings there would be three versions of me at the table. Joy made pancakes shaped like stars. Anger pounded at the radiator. Curiosity insisted on reading the paper aloud in Esperanto. Grief would look at old rolls of film and pull me into corners to tell me about the people whose names I had tried to forget. I felt the world sharpen and blur in alternating measures. I missed deadlines. I gained friends who were pissed off in a healthier way. I failed spectacularly at a few projects and discovered new ones I hadn’t tried because I feared their risk.

Integration, I learned, was not a single event. It was a negotiation. Sometimes a fragment would stay out—Anger left for a year after a particularly nasty client drained us both—and sometimes a new one formed so quickly I had no time to consider it: Shame was a tiny, wiry woman who appeared after an interview when I told a lie, and she haunted me for months. We developed rituals: morning meetings where each of us announced what we were feeling; a small ledger we kept for things that needed the authority of more than one emotion to decide. When an impulse wanted to become its own person, we took a breath together and let it speak in the room.

People still ask me if I regret creating them. The honest answer is complicated. Of course there are regrets—there are always mistakes you make when you invent a way of living around your own heart. But regret is its own kind of feeling, messy and useful. If I’d never had Joy to tear out of me and set loose in the world, I would never have learned how contagious laughter can be. If I’d never given Anger room, I might never have had someone fierce enough to draw boundaries for me when I needed them.

We are not cleaner for having moved our feelings into separate bodies. We are noisier and more dangerous and, ultimately, more present. The boxes we made for ourselves to keep the hard things tidy were comfortable prisons. Inviting the fragments to move back in didn’t smooth the walls. It made the house louder. It also made it possible to love without outsourcing consequence.

Sometimes now, when a feeling climbs toward the threshold, I let it have the room to be a neighbor instead of the space to leave. If it needs to step outside for a moment, that’s fine. If it wants to stay and argue until three in the morning, I will listen. The versions are still in the neighborhood, still sometimes storming the park, but when I call, a few of them come. They make tea and tell me what the world looks like from where they stand, and I remember that being whole isn’t the absence of splitting. It’s the willingness to come back from it.

samples.prompt: Vampires are all named by their masters. The greats include Alucard, Vlad, and Nosferatu. Your Master named you Phil.
samples.output:
Alucard. Vlad. Nosferatu. Say those names in the right corridors and a dozen mouths fall shut; chandeliers dim a degree as if out of respect; the wine turns metallic at the edges. Names are currency in our world. They are armor and heirloom, a forecast of the storms you will command. A good name binds you to a lineage of dread. A great name demands you be great.

My master named me Phil.

It was not a joke, not exactly. There are jokes in our society; cruelty dressed as wit is older than the oldest sun. But my master's face was sincere, the way people can be sincere when they have not yet learned that sincerity can be weaponized. The ceremony was correct: blood drawn in a ceremonial glass, the older ones forming the ring, the candles guttering with the watchful patience of the night. He bent his head and placed his lips to mine and, in a voice that sounded like somebody clearing a throat, said, "Phil."

I have had a century to parse that single syllable. The other newly risen that night were baptized with thunderous appellations — names that suggested mountains, wolves, empires. They left the chamber swaggering, tasting their grandeur as if it were an edible thing. I left holding the hem of my master's coat, because my hands did not know what to do when they were not receiving attention. A few of the older vampires smirked; one of them called me "Phillip" for a week and then tried "Philbert" by way of escalation before he tired and went back to his proper moony silences.

When you belong to a master you take his name in ways subtler than formality. There is the public part — introductions and salutations, the way a name will open doors and shut others. There is another part, quieter: the claim a master makes when he names you. To name is to say, This is mine. To be named is to be owed, preserved, kept. The greats — Alucard, Vlad, Nosferatu — were named by masters with their own pedigrees, and those masters felt the world tremble under their vows. Their names were prophecies and binding contracts. They were kits of armor that fit perfectly.

Phil fit nobody's armor. He fit like a glove two sizes too big.

I learned the first and easiest thing the hard way: hunters are terrible at imagination. They prefer monsters with fangs and poetry, not polite, listless men called Phil who make small talk about weather they have not felt in a hundred and sixty years. A name like Phil lowers guard. It's comedic ammunition. It keeps the gatekeepers from suspecting what goes on beyond polite hours. I found I could get closer, into the kitchens and laundries, into the places that parade their mundanity to prove safety. They called me Phil at the nurses' station and meant it. I took advantage. Perhaps that is the practical, bloodless truth beneath all my rumination: a pedestrian name is a practical weapon. Undervaluation is a loophole.

I also met scorn. The salons where decisions are made have a ritual of respect I initially thought inviolable: you introduce yourself and those older stake a name into you. The greats would say, "This is Vlad's son," or "This one bears the hand of Alucard," and the murmurs would follow. When I was introduced as Phil, someone tittered. The titter spread like a nettle. I sat. I smiled. I bided my time. There are many ways to answer the world; flesh is patient and revenge is a long game.

There are quieter violences than public humiliation. The weight of a name is like a garment cut to your size. Alucard found him in war, or a variation of it; Vlad found himself in crowns and lands and an expectation of ruthless order. Nosferatu arrived with the burden of legend and a geography of exile. They had to be those things because the world demanded it from the syllables carved onto their bones.

Phil, on the other hand, had a freedom the others cannot always taste. A name like Phil is a small, unadorned room with no expectations. It is terrifying and ecstatic. When no one else has decided for you how you will be dreadful or magnificent, you may have to decide. Some might call that a curse. I call it a blank page.

I filled it the only way available to me: by doing things quietly and then reminding people of them. You cannot always rely on terror to do the work for you. Terror reveals a pattern; beauty does too. I learned the trades my masters ignored: accounts, the maintenance of property, the harvesting of donors with a humane hand. I learned how to make the blood we take bear less cruelty and moreover how to make it taste like charity. Those are not glamorous skills, and they certainly do not read well in ballads, but they keep you alive and keep the world functioning. There is dignity in being the one who remembers where the house keys are, the one who ensures the little people in the hierarchy are not left to die for show.

The mocking did not stop overnight. It has not stopped in a hundred years. But it changed. Once, during a Council, a margrave with a name like a winter forest announced a campaign against a group of hunters who had taken to nosing into our affairs. The speech unfolded in the expected darkness; he named dozens of tactics. Then he fell silent and looked at me, and said, "Phil, we may need you to go into the town. Your... decorum might be of use."

That was my moment. I went. I walked through the town in a cardigan the mortals mistook for eccentricity and a hat that made the rats back away. I read the nursery rhymes pinned to lampposts. I listened. I found a barber who kept his clientele in shift work hours and an undertaker who had a soft heart for stray animals. I made appointments that meant the hunters never found the pattern.

When I returned, the margrave's face had shifted. His eyes were not unkind; they were surprised. "Well," he said, and there was a new cadence in his sentence. "Phil did well." The table's laughter that had once been sharp enough to be heard in neighboring counties dissolved into a grudging respect. Names have a way of morphing under the pressure of actions. The syllable stumbles but can become articulate.

In the quiet moments — between a master’s breath and a newborn's first thirst, between a hunt and a night's rest — I think of origins. Why would a master of such evident taste and capability name one of his progeny with a word as ordinary as Phil? I once asked him. He only smiled, and in that smile was the memory of a child reading an absurdist nonsense book. "Names are promises," he said. "I did not want to promise you anything but yourself."

There are nights when I imagine coming into a salon and announcing a new title: Phil the Red, Phil the Stern, Phil of the Thousand Teeth. The syllables fall flat; the rafters do not shiver. Yet there is a different legacy, less visible, that I like to imagine I have woven. It is a legacy of access and maintenance and the slow, patient flipping of keys in locks that others never notice. It is the kind of power that doesn't make songbooks but keeps the lights on in the ballrooms where the songs are sung.

It is also true that names do change. The greats will tell you so if they ever let you sit near them long enough to listen. A name can start as empire and soften into a story about who you were at a particular terrible hour. Mine may grow teeth yet. I have no desire to usurp Alucard or to embroider my syllable into a royal dirge. I like the way children call me Phil and suppose that I run a furniture store. I like the way domesticated vampires seek me out when they are tired of pretense and need someone who will remember where they put the spare linens.

So call me Phil. Let the legend-makers roll their syllables and the historians carve their columns. Let them have the thunders and the tragedies. I will take my small name and do things with it — practical, unshowy things that keep the country of the night habitable. In the end, a name is a doorframe, and doors are only useful if the rooms inside them are lived in. If you need a place to hide your secrets, to rest your head, to find someone who will tell you where the spare keys are — well, then, say my name. It is soft and forgettable and therefore perfect for what I am about to become.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
The night the woman in the trench coat handed me the coin, she smiled like a secret and told me exactly two things: that I had been given a gift, and that there was one condition.

“You can stop the clock,” she said. “Bend it, stretch it, carve out holes in it like a god. But only when nobody is watching.”

“How do you mean nobody?” I asked, because there are always people watching. There are cameras, satellites, nosy neighbors, the cat, teenagers with phones, the memory of your last glance. She tapped the coin against my palm with a fingernail. “Nobody at all. Not a single conscious witness, not even you. That’s the bargain. Good luck.”

I laughed then, because of course I laughed. Then I tried to stop the clock.

I began with the obvious: my apartment after midnight, the city asleep. I turned off every electronic light, taped over red camera LEDs in corners, unplugged the modem. I locked the door, drew the curtains, and stood in the dark. The world seemed a safe, soft thing. I reached for the coin like a rosary and willed the air to halt.

Nothing happened.

I bought a crowbar and ripped the streetlamp outside my window out of its concrete socket. The dim pool of sodium vapor vanished; the street below was a slime of darkness. I tried again. I squinted, I focused, I clenched my jaw until it hurt. The city went on, unbothered. People shuffled by, a dog barked, a siren somewhere began and faded. Time kept moving as if I’d made no demand at all.

I told myself I hadn't been alone. A friend would nod and say, “You just weren’t alone enough.” So I went further. I drove out of the city until the streetlights gave up and the sky widened. I climbed a ridge that had no phone signal and lay on my back counting the stars. I pinched my arm, willing sensation to be my anchor. I thought of nothing but the singularity of wanting to stop time—because it’s what you do when gifted with improbable power; you practice.

When the world refused, I thought of trickery. Maybe "nobody is watching" meant nobody on Earth, so I traveled beyond eyes. I booked a seat on a late cargo flight and paid for an empty row; I lay with my head pressed to the window and tried to persuade the atmosphere to hold its breath. It didn’t. Even when I flew alone over an ocean and the lights below blinked like distant DNA, the seconds slid past.

I became paranoid. Was watching only human? I covered my mirrors and blinked once and closed my eyes. I went to a windowless room and sat on the floor, hands over my ears as if sound were eyewitness. Still, time unrolled like ribbon. I taped a blindfold to my face and turned my thoughts inward until there was nothing left to observe or be observed by. Every time I tried to make time stop, the attempt itself felt like someone leaning on the scales of some cosmic law and being told, gently but firmly, “You are not alone enough.”

Then I learned to test the limits. I set up cameras with motion sensors and lights and asked strangers to turn away. I timed my attempts, I recorded them, I rewound footage. Footage showed me still standing, every muscle tense, eyes shut—time moving. I played the recordings for people who laughed politely and called me clever but superstitious.

The hardest part was that “nobody” included the small things we always forget have attention. The cat watched with a sovereign glare. The ficus leaned toward the window like a slow-attention sensor. Seagulls, the blinking bus sign three streets over—all conspired as observers. I unplugged radios, smeared mirrors with paste, dragged a towel over the thermostat. I wanted a condition that didn’t depend on surveillance or optics; I wanted absence that could be proven by silence and emptiness.

For a while I entertained the metaphysical. Maybe the universe itself was an observer; maybe the laws of physics were a jury with a collective eye. Maybe the gift was lousy because it had been cursed by some bored bureaucrat in the space between seconds. I pictured bureaucrats with clipboards checking boxes: Candidate: human. Candidate: wants to pause. Verdict: Denied. The universe, being an old thing with poor humor, had decided to make the power unsatisfying.

Days slid into a strange dryness of effort. I began to calculate: If I could make a scenario where "no one" could reasonably be watching—even potential watchers—then perhaps the power would accept it. I drove to abandoned towns, to underground tunnels, to an unused airstrip where the only other presence was my smell. I parked, sat on the hood of my car, and tried to forget that anyone might walk in. I failed, every single time.

The first miraculous thing that happened wasn't on purpose. I was grocery shopping on a Thursday, mind occupied with almonds and the existential weather report. A small boy in a yellow raincoat ran past me, squealing with a sibling. I stepped aside, apologized for being in the way, and felt the sudden, hot embarrassment that accompanies being seen stumbling through aisles. In that heat, my attention snapped inward like a hand into a glove. It wasn't self-consciousness as in performing; it was self-erasure. I covered my face with my hands, the way you do when you can't bear to watch yourself—an old childhood reflex.

It was like the world inhaled.

The air thickened, like being submerged in warm syrup. Sound became texture, an overturned bucket of seconds. The boy's squeal stopped mid-spill, a basket hung in the air between his hands and his sibling's. A lemon hovered over the citrus bin, bellies of people frozen in expressions like photographs. I blinked, and blinking was an event I could time with surgical precision. For a moment—no more than three heartbeats—everything was inertia. I could reach out and trace a finger along the suspended arc of a falling piece of fruit. I could rearrange the world’s small, careless geometry, move the lemon, unclip a lock of the boy's hair, hand the cashier a coin that would never fall.

Then the breath returned. Syllables fell and landed. People mid-laugh finished laughing. The lemon thudded mundane into its basket and the squeal resumed like a dropped instrument. I stood there holding a single coin between my fingers, feeling as if I had swallowed something impossible and was worried it might dissolve.

The coin in my hand that time was not the coin she had given me. That one had been tucked away; this coin was one from a register, cold and stamped with a face whose gaze did not follow me. Later I held them side by side and felt none of the warm cosmic logic I might have wanted. I had not meant to freeze. I had not been performing for the world or for myself; I had been attempting to hide. The bargain's clause—"not even you"—had, absurdly, been fulfilled.

After that the rule became clearer. The power did not obey demands. It obeyed absences. It wanted vulnerability; it wanted the bald, unscheduled moments when attention fled. It did not care for elaborate traps or clever hacks. It responded like an animal to a scent it could not see—when desire abdicated and left a hole in the mind where no one looked. Try as I might, I could not produce those holes on command. I could, however, make my life full of them.

So I stopped trying for grand feats. I stopped planning big thefts of time like the heist-movie fantasies in my head. I began cultivating small forgotten things: the unremarked-upon kindnesses, the quiet corners where no one thinks to look. I learned to fold myself into the background—muted clothes, dull laugh, a propensity for not wanting to be the center. Sometimes, when I was in a café and pressed my palms around a warm cup and let a book dissolve me, time would soften at the edges. A child's spilled milk might hang like slow molten glass. I could pluck a dropped spoon from the air and set it right; I could take an extra breath and watch a pigeon hold that wingbeat like a paused note.

The coin in my pocket became a talisman and an accusation. It reminded me that power's meaning is not always what we imagine. I had asked for the ability to be godlike and then resented the smallness of its terms. The world had given me a strict, oddly humane answer: you can stall the earth for a second, but only in the suspended privacy of being nobody to yourself and to everyone else. You cannot use this to escape consequences because you cannot manufacture the moment of not-watching without being watched by your own striving.

There were nights, however, when the temptation for something larger returned—when the thought of going back to the woman in the trench coat and asking for a clause repeal seemed an emergency. I imagined a moment stopped long enough to speak to a dying mother, to fix a mistake, to hang over a city's riot like a canopy and pluck a single life from harm. What rankled was not that the power refused me those miracles; it was that the universe had set a boundary that required surrender rather than conquest.

Then, once, in a homeless shelter, I sat on the floor and tied another man’s shoelace. He didn't look up. He talked low to himself about baseball statistics I didn't know. A kid in the corner laughed at something only he remembered. I bent to tie the lace—no fanfare, no intention beyond the practical act—and I forgot myself entirely. There was a split-second—the same syrup-slow that had taken a lemon midflight—where the world held, utterly pliant. I straightened, and the man blinked; his shoes were properly tied. It might have been nothing. It was everything.

I never learned to command time like an army. I never made the earth stop at my heel. But every now and then, in the small politics of being overlooked, time would give me a brittle, beautiful second. I learned that those seconds did not add up to power in the way I'd imagined; they added up to sanctity. They taught me the anatomy of attention: to be present not as a demand but as a relinquishment. To freeze time, I discovered, you must first unseat the watcher inside you. Only then does the world—tired, indulgent, compassionate—let you rearrange one small thing.

samples.prompt: Every answer that was needed was wrapped up in that kiss.
samples.output:
The departure board blinked like a second sunrise: destinations, delays, gates rearranged as if time itself had decided to be indecisive. People moved around me in a slow current—luggage clunking, children tugging at sleeves, lovers hurrying with their mouths full of promises. I sat on a metal bench and watched the light paint itself across Jonah’s face in segments: a bright stripe over one cheekbone, dark where a shadow fell. He looked older than I remembered, which is to say he looked like a map of our years together—creases, faded places where laughter had worn him thin.

When he smiled, there was still the same small hitch in his breath that used to make me press a hand to his chest because I liked to feel him steady. He cleared his throat. “I didn’t think you’d come,” he said.

“I thought I wouldn’t,” I said, because it was true. I had rehearsed all night—what to say, what not to say. My questions were lined up like teeth, ready to bite. Why did you leave? Was there another woman? Did you write that letter and then retract it? Where did you go the night the storm took Mom’s roof? You had ways of erasing yourself; I had practiced looking for the places you’d been.

Jonah laughed softly. “The irony is we’re both terrible at long goodbyes.”

“I’m good at them now,” I said, and meant both that I had learned to make peace and that I wanted to believe it.

He reached into his coat and took out a small card. The emblem on it—a tiny spiral of hands—was one of the legalities of this era. There are things the state grants but the heart still has to consent to: consent to share, to witness, to bear a truth. A “memory exchange” card. People used them to settle disputes—who had said what during contracts, who touched what evidence. They were official and sterile and, perversely, intimate in the way a scalpel is intimate.

“You remember the rule?” Jonah asked.

I remembered. You could use a kiss to share a memory with another consenting adult: a neural handshake translated into smell and taste and the microscopic exchange of the brain’s syntax. It had been developed for trauma therapy, later used in courts and bedrooms and prayer rooms. It was supposed to be clinical, but no technology was ever neutral. You could use it to settle debts or to confess love. It did not create new truths; it only folded old ones out of the mind like laundry.

“Only if we both agree,” I said.

He nodded. The card gleamed between his fingers like a promise unsigned. There were a thousand ways to refuse; you didn’t kiss anyone when you wanted to keep your questions. You kissed when what you needed was not an argument but a whole truth, laid bare in the mouth like a coin.

I thought of the years I had imagined him leaving because of a woman, a job, a sudden calling. I had imagined the worst and the most romantic exit in equal measure—one dramatic, one cowardly. I had imagined explanations that never included the simple, ordinary cruelty of fear.

“You can take it all,” Jonah said, and there was an apology in the way he folded the card back into his coat. “Or you can take only what you need.”

We were both aware of what would happen. A kiss would not only transmit a memory; it would also bring with it a weight—the responsibility of knowing. Once you had received a detail in someone else’s head, you could no longer pretend. You could not unknow the face of a second woman, or the truth of a night, or that someone had been trying to protect you by leaving.

I thought of my son—Eli—at home with his cheeks full of peanut butter and the picture he’d drawn of a house with two suns because that was how he saw the world when we lived on the coast; once, when Jonah took the night shift to watch the tides, we would wake to two suns in Eli’s drawings. He’d been five when Jonah left. Eli treasuring the idea of Jonah like you treasure a holiday; the absence of an uncle at school meets. I had taught him to make fortresses from the ache.

“What are you scared of?” I asked finally, because even then I couldn’t keep the questions buried.

He didn’t answer with words. He answered with a breath and with the way his hand trembled when it brushed mine. “I don’t want you to see me small.”

I laughed incredulously. “You think I will love you less if I know you were afraid?”

He looked at me like someone looking at a map he used to know by heart. “I’m asking you to make it safe.”

So we kissed.

The first thing I felt was the familiar punctuation of his mouth against mine, that satisfying click where history recognizes itself. And then the world folded, and I found myself standing in a kitchen I didn’t remember: late night, rain slicing the windows, Jonah at the sink, hands red from cold and salt. There was a hum of a generator and the smell of wet wool. He was speaking on the phone to someone with a voice like gravel—my mother? No, a voice that spoke in data and city names. I felt the small window of Jonah’s chest where fear lived—the part he had taped with humor and courage until it looked like a permanent stain. He had been offered work overseas, a contract with a company that cleaned up after storms and removed dangerous infrastructures. It would have meant money, security, a chance to build something steady. He had been terrified of failing at the one thing that mattered—being a father—and so he had left in the middle of the night before he could fail. He misread leaving as heroism.

I saw other moments, layered like slides in a projector. I saw the night he fell asleep at the wheel on a long drive back from a jobsite and woke to our home empty because he had thought he was protecting us by being absent. I saw the letter he had folded and never mailed because the ink had smeared and he convinced himself that absence could be made clean by silence. I saw the night he almost called, the quarter-moon in a hotel window like a porthole. I watched him consider the shape of my face and place it back in his pocket like a charm. He had loved me, yes—so intensely that he thought stepping out of that love was the only way to make it survive.

Truth tasted like copper and perfume and the burned edge of old paper. It was not the vindication I had hoped for—it wasn’t an accusation to throw; it wasn’t the proof of a betrayal. It was worse and simpler: a fear so large it decided for both of us.

And there was another thing, smaller and tenderer: a memory I had not asked for but received anyway. The image of him standing on a dilapidated pier the morning after a storm, when the tide had swallowed the fence and the town smelled of salt and mold. There he knelt and tied a small paper boat for our son because he couldn’t find the language to say he was sorry. He left because leaving seemed easier than staying and failing, but he left with an apology folded into his pocket that he kept thinking he would deliver later.

When Jonah broke the kiss, we both inhaled at the same time like people surfacing from water. For a sliver of a moment, I didn’t know which of us was staring back at me—my lover, my boy, the man who had saved me and the man who had broken me.

“What else?” I asked.

He shook his head. “Nothing. It’s all in there. More than I thought I could bear.”

I could have taken the card back then, signed the official form and walked away with legal closure, a stamped, notarized truth. I could have held his smallness up to myself and said no more. Instead, I reached forward and wrapped my hand around his face, feeling the familiar cartography—cheekbones like the edges of old maps, the soft place below the ear where I had leaned during long, reckless nights. I pressed my mouth to his again, this time without the machinery. I let the ordinary chemistry of it do the rest: the heat, the memory of his name on my lips, the involuntary hum in my chest that still answered to him.

In that second, answers aligned themselves not like facts in a ledger but like lights in a constellation. There was no single explanation that could have been enough. There were a thousand small, human reasons: fear, love, cowardice, an over-earnest desire to protect. They didn’t absolve him; they didn’t entirely absolve me either. But they made us younger the way truth can—no longer parading as gentility, instead honest and raw.

When we finally let each other go, the airport around us continued to be indifferent. A flight was called. A child dropped an airplane and it skittered across the floor like a small, anxious thing.

“Will you come back?” Jonah asked.

I considered the sky line, the board, the list of places my life could yet encounter. I considered the fact that I had spent years inventing certainties and living in the shadow of them. I thought of Eli and how he had drawn two suns the day Jonah left and one when he believed in the brightness of being wanted.

“I don’t know,” I said. It was the first honest answer.

He smiled then, and it was not the lad of charm it had once been but something like forgiveness, the quiet approval of a man who had learned to fit his hands into his own life differently.

We did not need a hundred explanations. We only needed to decide whether the truth we held could be lived with, and whether the living of it mattered enough to try again. I could feel his history in my mouth like a small, weighty thing; it was both more and less than I had imagined. It was enough.

He stood, his coat heavy with the memory of the night he left. He kissed my forehead, the same place he had kissed when Eli was born and when the first roof had been repaired after the storm. It was a benediction and a promise and a catalogue all at once.
