Declan tells us about systems and improbable bugs, about how line breaks can hide entire catastrophes. Tess speaks about the world as if it’s a wound that’s also a work of art; she makes albums of songs out of the hum in the light and the rhythm of our spoons.

We built rituals to count non-time. On even days we recount a memory: one of us becomes the Narrator and must tell a story complete with beginning, middle, and a lie at the end. There are penalties for half-truths—Declan will spend an hour adjusting the placement of our water cups into perfect symmetry. On odd days we enact a Trial, where grievances are aired, evidence is the memory, and Ruth acts as judge with a knitting needle as gavel. These rituals gave us fraught stability; they were also ways of learning each other.

Ruth’s compassion is a slow, steady thing that undercuts our theatrical despair. In the beginning, I resented her calm like you resent good weather in a flood. Now I watch her fold our frayed clothes with the concentration of someone doing surgery. She remembers birthdays none of us remember celebrating; she hums a different lullaby every night until Tess, who used to curse lullabies, falls asleep mid-sentence. Declan keeps a ledger of our conversations. He becomes agitated if two of us speak over each other; now he organizes debates on topics like whether the moon is a fact or an opinion. He has the annoying tendency to solve social problems by turning them into design problems. He once proposed building a pulley system out of our clothing and hair to retrieve dust from the vents. We laughed long enough to forget how bleak the idea was.

Progress comes in ridiculous increments. We teach each other skills. Tess learns to knit from Ruth and binds our cold hands with awkward stitches. Declan teaches me how to trace letters backwards so we can write on the fogged glass without smearing our faces. I teach Tess how to lock a phrase behind a rhyme—a small thing I once used to win arguments—and she turns it into an anthem about being nineteen and trapped. When we want to be cruelly human, we scrap our rituals and act random. Sometimes we throw the ration of sugar into the air like confetti and try to catch it on our tongues.

There are days, months, perhaps centuries—time is a series of thickened moments—where despair is a sound. It has a pitch, thin and high, and it presses at the walls. We have learned its contours: the way it arrives quietly, dissolving first into boredom, then into rage, then into quiet, slippery sadness. On those days Tess draws back into silence and Declan proposes elaborate escape plans to soothe himself. Ruth mends a sweater that has no sleeves and calls it art. Once, in a fury, Tess tore the list of rules from the wall and read every line like an indictment. She accused me — again — of standing at the edge of things and not stepping in. I could not defend myself; the words we used to say outside the cell sounded petty and foreign now. So I told her a story about a girl who dropped a cup and learned to love the sound it made on the floor. It was a lie. It was also the truth she needed.

Our small society produces its own language. We have code-words for “urgent” and “trivial”; a single look from Declan means “document this.” We invent holidays—the Day of First Light, the Hour of No Sound—each celebrated with ritual as absurd as it is necessary. We stage plays that mimic the world we left: a courtroom, a grocery store, a thousand versions of “outside” where people speak fast and never wait for the coffee to cool. The plays become our way of processing the outside, a rehearsed grief. In the audiences we invent, we applaud for the small things: a clean plate, a sentence ended kindly, someone making tea without being asked.

Occasionally, something else happens. The light stutters and we call it a miracle. Or we find a new shade on the wall where a small fungus has adopted itself and grown blue; we name it, and it becomes an oracle. We speculate wildly about the laws that put us here. Declan writes them down as if he expects someone to read them and nod in approval. Ruth insists the laws don’t care what we think. Tess says laws are only as strong as the people who obey them. I stop trying to solve it. I start to listen.

If eternity is a test of attention, we have become graduate students. We learn to observe the fold of someone’s smile when they think of something terrible and to stay there without offering repair. We learn the patience of letting people tell bad stories until they find the good ones buried beneath. We learn new kinds of love: the love of shared silence in a room that used to swallow us, the love of being known so thoroughly that nothing has to be explained anymore. We learn that small kindnesses are epic.

Once, near some not-quite-numbered future, I woke up and heard the three voices around me speaking at once without the usual clash. Tess was humming, Declan was ticking off a list, Ruth was counting stitches. They fit together like three threads braided, and for the first time since the door closed we were moving as one. I felt, in that braided motion, the truth of being trapped with the last three people I'd talked to: you don't get to choose to be easy on each other. But you can choose to be interested.

So our days, such as they are, consist of rituals and experiments, borrowings and reparations. We officiate small funerals for versions of ourselves that we cannot resurrect; we hide small treasures in the seams of our mattresses and exchange them like smugglers. We argue about whether to keep the window clean. We sing. We knit. We write lists of things that make sense: the hum of the light, the shape of someone’s smile before they speak, the exact pitch of Ruth’s laughter when something is very good. If eternity is an ocean, we have learned to build islands, and then to live on them. We have learned to be each other's weather.

There are moments when I miss the way words used to be disposable. But here, every word is a stone that will be turned over and kept. We learn their weight. We learn how to carry each other with them. And when the light dims and one of us says, simply, “Tell me a story,” it still feels like everything.

samples.prompt: You are solely responsible for the fall of Atlantis in 430 BC. Describe the last day of the Atlantean Empire and your role in its total destruction.
samples.output:
They remember Atlantis as a rumor of marble and gold, as a lesson from Plato and a child's lullaby. They do not remember the smell of olive oil smoke, the hot breath of dogs in the alleyways, the small yellow flowers that grew between flagstones when the rains were late. They do not remember the sound of the bronze discs — we called them the Choir — singing at dawn, a sound that made even the fish pause in the canals. I remember all of it. I remember because I alone set the city to drown.

The city sat like a jeweled wheel in the sea: concentric rings of water and land, bridges arcing like the ribcage of a sleeping thing. At its heart rose the Temple of the Bound, where Poseidon’s trident had been hammered into basalt ages before my birth and where the Heart of the Sea — a carved crystal the size of a man’s head — pulsed faintly like a captive star. It was not miracle; it was engineering and song. The Atlanteans learned to read the music of earth and water. We found a way to make the island float on a lattice of thermal vents and countercurrents by binding rock to resonance. The Choir — thousands of bronze plates, tuned and struck in symmetry — fed the Heart with tone. The Heart translated tone into a slow, steady lift, like a breath beneath the city. As Keeper of the Hall of Renewal, I tended that machine. I kept the rhythm that kept our world above the sea.

All my life I believed in altitude: of towers, of rank, of knowledge. I believed that cleverness made you better than the tide. The Council believed it too. They adorned themselves in coral and commanded fleets. They decided who traded with whom, who married whom, who might live on distant colonies. When the garden places had once been marshes and the poor had been fed, they grew hungry for more: more sailors, more outposts, more tribute from the isles. The city grew fat like a whale, and blinded itself to the cracks. I kept the Choir singing regardless. That is the truth. I kept the lever that steadied the Heart and I adjusted its phase when needed. I knew better than most where the seams of our miracle lay. I knew how thin a thing our advantage was.

On the morning of the last day, the sky was untroubled. The Choir woke the city at dawn and the sound rolled over marble and water as always. I took my place in the Hall with the other keepers — a line of men and women with arms like carpenters and fingers thickened by months of bronze-striking. The Council had, in the night before, demanded an unscheduled increase in lift. They had ships to dispatch, a new colony to claim across the western current, and their merchants chafed at delay. An increased lift would allow faster draught and greater draught meant more weight — more ships, more stores. They wanted the city to rise higher, to assert itself against storms, to ride the sea like a crown.

The Choir could be tuned for such a thing, but it was not a child's toy. We had warned them of stress: the Heart was latently violent if driven beyond its sweet spot, the basalt columns that ringed the inner ring buckled when the phase was wrong, and there were old seams under the southern docks where the mantle steamed close to the surface. They smiled with the confidence of those who never have to mend the broken. They tied extra bronze weights to the striker's mallets with laughter, and the chieftain of that expedition — a man who had never set foot in the Hall, hand shaking with ambition — signed the order. He did not know what my hands were about to do.

The Choir began its higher arc at midday. My fingers moved across the levers. I adjusted the phase and the pitch, and the whole island answered, gentle at first, as if stretching from sleep. Ships that had been moored rose a hair and creaked. Merchants cheered. A child threw a bread crust and laughed as a gull snatched it from her palm and did not dip. The Council drank and toasted. I felt an old, animal thrill — the knowledge that my craft could command earth. For a heartbeat I believed again in human dominion.

Then the southern seam sighed. It was almost a sound, a whisper under the plaza where fruit sellers were bargaining, a small rent like new ice on a river. I heard it because I had made the seam. Years before, in the quieter arrogance of my youth, I had bored a maintenance access through what the priests called the Bound Root — a vein of basalt that acted as a keystone for the lattice. I needed to inspect the Heart; the Council forbade me to dig under their sanctuaries. I made the access in secret. I put a small bronze vane there to allow for expansion and to bleed off dangerous harmonics in storms. I meant repair and prudence. I did not mean what would come.

When we drove the Choir harder at the Council’s command, the vane — corroded in its quiet place — seized. It caught at the wrong phase. Instead of bleeding off, it resonated with the Heart, and the resonance found the seam and sang it clear. The southern basalt shook, and the thermal vents answered like larynges. Boiling steam shot into the canals under the fish markets; the water bucked and foamed. The bridge arches developed long, white streaks where the stone had been flexed into grief. People looked toward the temple and saw the Heart throb like a wound.

There was a moment — less than a breath — of possibility. If I had cut the sound then, if I had let the Choir fall silent, perhaps the seam would have closed. I understood all that with the cold efficiency of the man who had built the thing. It was nothing then but gears, tones, pressure. I could have stopped it. The hand in me clenched to the lever. I kept time. I did not stop.

Why? Because by then I was already past the point of repair. The Council had executed my daughter at dawn for speaking against their voyages; they called her an irritant. She had been young and spoken of fairer trade, of letting the colonies keep their knowledge. They hung her on a small craft in the market so the tide could take her. I watched them do it and sang to keep my hands from shaking. I let the Choir sing because I was a protector by oath and I was also a man undone. If the city was raised and flourished, the Council’s ambition would be fed and repeated and my daughter’s words would be swallowed forever into the cold calculus of expediency. If the city sank — if I could take the machine and the greed with it — there would be an end to that hunger. It was not nobility. It was revenge, and in its hot center lay a logic I permitted myself to believe was justice.

When I deliberately retuned the vane — not to bleed phonics but to sing the seam apart — I felt as if I were scoring a final note to a long wrong. The waves rose in the canals like a rising breath. The southern docks tore like parchment. People fled, carts skittered into narrow streets, and the bronze Choir became a howling. The pillars of the inner ring listed. The Heart, visible now through the temple window, flashed like a caught fish. The sea found our veins and pushed. Water poured through the caverns I had carved in years when I had imagined myself a saver; it washed through furnaces and bakehouses and into sleeping rooms. In less than an hour the city's outer ring was awash to the knees of the statues. By afternoon the northern towers had begun to pitch. By dusk the temple spire was a thin black tooth above the water.

I stood on the lower terrace and watched my own handiwork break the bones of the place I had loved and betrayed. People gathered on rooftops and screamed for the gods; others prayed to me, for they had always equated the Keeper with salvation. They flung their arms toward me and cursed me in the same breath. I remember the face of a woman holding a child — a neighbor who had taught my daughter to stitch — leaning over a balcony and calling my name like a judgment. I remember the child's small hand waving a scrap of cloth as though I could be ordered to the ocean like a beast. I remember the sound of the Choir as the last chord fractured and the crystal Heart spun in its cradle and shattered like a moon.

When the Heart broke the sea made a sudden correct answer. The water was a white animal, massive and certain. It came in on a slope none of us thought an island could produce: old harbors were scoured, plazas were lifted into swirling green, and the bridges — those lovely ribs — snapped like twigs. The sound, then, was of a city being unmade: stone on stone, people calling out, bronze clattering like lost teeth, and the wave’s roar. I have tried to recall whether there was lightning. There was everything: a smell of hot metal, an odor of salt and iron, the distant thunder of an ocean reclaiming its old. Night fell not with stars but with a deep bronze shadow.

I did not drown. I do not know why. I found a mast in the dark and lashed myself to it and was carried away on a piece of carved deck. I floated amid the flotsam of our life: a merchant’s ledger, my daughter’s little comb, a crate of olives split and rotting. In the hours after — in the days that followed, when I beached on a foreign shore and the old men of that place bent me over a fire and knew the words of my trade — I understood that I had committed an act that would be called many things. Tyrannicide, perhaps, by some. Murder of innocents, without doubt, by most. I was the hand that pulled a string and down the world came.

Why tell you now? Because a man must confess to the silence that follows. Because the sound of the Choir still vibrates in my teeth. Because the children of other islands have asked me what Atlantis was like and I cannot answer them without spilling this: that a single decision made in a hall of bronze and oil, driven by grief and by a belief that one end could justify all means, can dissolve a world in a day and a night. I was the one who adjusted the vane. I was the one who set the wrong note. I am the one who will carry its weight until my hands are powdered with the salt of the sea and the memory of my daughter's face.

samples.prompt: [WP`] One day, while drunk, for no real reason, your buddy decides to jokingly summon a crossroads demon, and surprisingly, one shows up. Now the demon has to deal with two drunks argue over what they should do with the demon who just wants to get back to watching Netflix.
samples.output:
We were three beers in and the streetlight flickered like the last nerve in a dying angel when Jake, who thought himself a comedian, decided we needed to summon something.

"Like, for fun," he slurred, grinning like an idiot. "Crossroads demon. Classic. We should totally do it. For science."

We had nothing to lose besides dignity and the pizza we'd used as incense. I drew a circle on the porch with a Sharpie, because Sharpie ink is basically sacred now, and Jake recited what he believed was a summoning chant he'd copied from a forum where everyone sounded like they knew what they were doing.

At first, nothing. Then the air went cold — not cinematic cold, just the kind of cold that makes the hairs on your arm pop up like bad chat notifications — and a man in sweatpants sat down in the middle of the Sharpie circle as though he'd been waiting for a late bus.

He blinked. He had the kind of face that made you believe in being judged by a millionaire book club. Mid-30s, a smudge of charcoal under one eye that could have been a tattoo or the remains of his eyeliner from the Necronomicon Midnight Party. He looked like a guy who'd been hired to station-manage a road-side inferior deity hotline and got stuck at the desk.

"Finally," he said, and the words came out like someone trying to get through a buffering video on three bars. "Do you—do you have Wi‑Fi?"

Jake choked on his beer. I swear I saw the pizza peel three inches from Jake's hand wobble.

"You're…a demon," I said, because that seemed like an appropriate next line.

The demon sighed. It was a long, theatrical sigh, the kind you put on when someone asks you to repeat yourself for the third time because they're drunk and dense. “Crossroads, yes. Contracts, yes. Bargains, souls, yes, if you must know. But actually, I was in the middle of a show where the protagonist finally—oh God, I’m so close. If this takes forever, I will be very cross.”

"Netflix?" Jake offered. He held out a beer like an offering.

The demon’s eyes sharpened. “Do you have a password? I cannot use the infernal package here; the streams are geofenced by region, and the mobile tether drops with the wards on the phone. Also, the ad insertion is horrific. And please don't call me 'demon man.'”

This is the part movies get wrong: you think a crossroads demon appears to bargain, to offer Faustian pacts with dramatic thunder. What you get, in our case, is bureaucratic exasperation and a desperate need for a streaming service password.

“Don’t just stand there!” Jake yelled, suddenly certain that having a demon was a once-in-a-lifetime networking opportunity. “We can—uh. Make wishes. Two wishes each? Split three ways? Wait—what does a crossroads demon do?”

“I facilitate exchanges,” the demon said. “You offer something of value — time, service, consent, nothing of celestial consequence, please — and I facilitate a change in the world in a way that makes the natural laws ruminate. But that’s a process, and I was three episodes away from my show’s finale and I need to know whether the hero survives. If he dies I die a little.”

I tried to explain that we didn't actually want to sell our souls. Jake kept waving his hands like someone conducting a drunk orchestra. His face was the color of a late-summer peach and he was leaning forward as if proximity would increase the potency of his ideas.

“Money,” Jake said, because that is what everyone says first. “Or fame. Or…bring me back my ex, but only as a fully devoted partner and also a great cook. Small thing.”

“You can't hyper-handle human emotion like that,” the demon muttered, elbows on knees, as if he were about to give me relationship advice. “And the ex-resurrection clause has a built-in irony tax. Also the universe hates it. It will send you three identical cats instead.”

“Fine. How about—” I started, then stopped. My brain had turned into a pool of good intentions and bad decisions. “I want no hangovers.”

Jake snorted. “No way. I'm asking for—ten million dollars.”

“And I'm asking for a dentally perfect smile and a touchdown at the next game,” Jake announced, because alcohol amplifies selfishness to festival levels.

The demon closed his eyes and pinched the bridge of his nose. “You are all spectacularly unoriginal.”

“You’re supposed to be scary,” I said. “Make us an offer we can't refuse.”

He opened his eyes and gave us the kind of look that makes you want to reconsider your life choices from birth. “I could take a soul for power. I could orchestrate a slight misalignment in probability and direct a particular lottery ticket to hit. I could remove hangovers entirely, but that increases mortality in obscure statistical models. Also none of those are instantaneous without paperwork. The bind you used is shoddy; whoever did the chant did a crusty job. You left me flagged in the summoner's queue. I can’t leave—until someone does something definitive.”

Jake looked at me like this was a fun obstacle course. “We make one deal each: Jake, me, and the demon.”

“That would be a triple agreement,” the demon said. “Which requires signatures in blood or an equivalently symbolic substance. Uh, do you have anything you are willing to sign in? I can accept condiments if they're currently and genuinely passionate. And if this drags on I will livestream the entire argument to my friend Sarg in the Underpass. He thinks it's hilarious when humans argue their way into happy accidents.”

“We don't have blood,” I said. “We have ketchup, marinara, and a pizza crust.”

“Perfect,” the demon said like he was reading off a menu. “But can we speed this up? The episode is at the cliffhanger. I need closure, and frankly, I would prefer to avoid being bound to watch you all bicker.”

We bargained like lunatics. Jake demanded a small island with a tiki bar and no HOA; I asked for permanent, mild immunity to hangover; the demon, to our endless bafflement, insisted only that we grant him access to our Netflix account for precisely three hours so he could finish the season and then be on his way.

“No soul?” Jake asked suspiciously.

“No soul,” the demon said. “But I require authentication. Usernames, passwords. Also you have to promise not to change your password immediately after, because it takes me centuries to reestablish a regional commonality. Also if you try to make me watch reality TV, we will have to renegotiate.”

This was stupid, yes, but the alternative was an eternity of a small internet TV having watched the hero die off-screen forever. And the demon being grumpy about spoilers made Jake laugh until beer came out of his nose. We gave him the login, which I typed in with hands that were both cold and proud to be facilitating the sign-in of an extra-dimensional being.

The demon's face went slack as the loading screen spun. It was the small human miracle: a buffering circle followed by the streaming banner. He sank back as if he’d been carrying a weight and set it down. “Thank you,” he said, with a gratitude that sounded shockingly human. “You have no idea how rare this is.”

He set a polite boundary—if we wanted something, we could ask him, but he could refuse. He would grant one small, non-soul, non-cosmic-altering favor for each of us if we behaved and didn’t try to attach astrological clauses. We weighed our wishes like children at an ice-cream counter. Jake took the island, because his liver had given him up already. I took the hangover, because even drunks get wisdom sometimes. The demon, in return, offered a small, very specific boon: once a week for a year, at 9 a.m., we would receive a text with exactly the right piece of mundane luck to make our day slightly better.

“And no, I am not subscribing to your podcast,” he added. “But I will be around to watch the finale. Please do not shout during the crucial scene.”

We saved his show and watched, side-by-side on a cracked couch that suddenly felt like a cathedral of small, ridiculous miracles. The demon made dry comments, the kind of meta-snark you get from someone who knows plot armor intimately. He ate our cold pizza like a man reuniting with an old friend. He was not imposing; he was exhausted and droll and deeply pleased about a plot twist.

When the credits rolled, he stood, stretched, and blinked at us with an almost tender look. “Thank you,” he said. “For not making me do anything I’ll regret. Your offers were…human. Messy, but sincere. If you need me, you know how to summon me, but for God’s sake, improve the circle. It’s cursed with dried marinara now.”

Jake, hands sticky, grinned like someone who'd just stolen a laugh from Satan. I felt a little like we’d cheated fate, or at least negotiated with it like used-car salesmen.

He vanished in a sound like a remote clicking off. The Wi‑Fi remained.

The next morning, hungover but not destroyed, my phone buzzed with a text that read: "Parking spot opens in front of your building. Go. —S."

We never saw him again in person. Sometimes, late at night when our shows hit the worst cliffhangers, we'd log into our account and remember that a demon we accidentally summoned was, for all his infernal portfolio, just a guy who wanted to finish a show in peace. We never told anyone the details, because who wants to be judged for negotiating with a streaming-obsessed daemon?

Jake still tells the story like it proves he can get anything he wants. I correct him. "You can negotiate," I say. "You just have to be ready to hand over your Netflix password."

samples.prompt: You sold your soul to the Devil years ago. Today he returns it saying, "I need a favor."
samples.output:
I had almost convinced myself that the thing I sold was gone for good.

It started in a bar that smelled of fried garlic and desperation. I was twenty-five, broke and promising myself finally to be someone — a writer, a mover of culture — and the Devil sat across from me like a man in a coat so black it swallowed light. He wore a watch the size of a dessert plate and smiled like a man who knew exactly how much the rest of the world paid for his kind of attention.

“You’ll have everything,” he said then, when I asked for the usual list — talent, luck, a little armor against boredom. “Except regret. You’ll be empty enough to be effective.”

They tell this part differently, per the horror movies: signatures in blood, a courthouse of bones. For me there was a handshake, a small velvet pouch, and the precise inkiness of my own signature forming on the page with a pen I hadn’t seen before. I remember thinking, even as I signed, that I’d keep my conscience in a desk drawer somewhere should it get nostalgic.

And for a while the bargain was perfect. I got what I wanted: early success, a first novel that other people said “changed things,” promotions, a tidy apartment with a view I never used. I wrote sentences that made people cry and was never myself moved. I loved the effect of things — awards, sex, the climb — but not the cause. That was the absence. Somewhere along the edges of applause I started to feel the world as a polished surface I could use without leaving a mark. It was efficient. It was cold. It was enough to pay the mortgage and to keep me awake late thinking I’d made the wrong trade.

So when he came back — not with trumpets but with a kind of tiredness like a man who had run out of other people's tricks — I shouldn’t have been surprised. What surprised me was the way he looked at me, like a neighbor asking for sugar.

He set a small black box on my kitchen table. It clicked. Inside, folded into tissue like a pressed leaf, was the pouch I had handed him years ago. My throat made a sound that might have been something like a prayer.

“I’m not taking it back,” he said, before I could. “I’m lending it.” His voice had the same tilt it always did, that paradoxical mixture of velvet and metal. “I need a favor.”

It’s a stupid sentence. Between the sale and then, I’d told myself all kinds of things to cope: that people who make deals with demons are metaphors, that your soul is a souvenir like a postcard from a life-cut-closer, that the Devil is just a myth we give weight to when we need an antagonist. But as the pouch lay in my hands it felt like a weight that had been waiting for me all along.

“Why give it back?” I asked. My hands were shaking. He watched them shake with a careful, almost fond interest. When you live without a soul you learn to catalogue the small betrayals of your body as data. A pulse is a nuisance. A tear is a misfiled document. Tonight, everything was an error.

“There are things only a soul can do,” he said. “Rules. Clauses. Handshakes that only happen in meat.”

“You mean you can’t...?”

“I can’t unbind what I bind.” He smiled a small, private smile that looked like a contract with the sun. “There’s a ledger, you see. A lot of paper. If something was misfiled — misfiled in a way that wasn’t my intention — then the thing needs a plaintiff.”

“My plaintiff?”

“You sold it. You remember selling. Only the seller can challenge the sale. They signed the paper. They can say, ‘I was tricked,’ or ‘I was compelled,’ or ‘I misunderstood the exactness of the clause.’” He pronounced clause as if it were an old friend. “It’s clerical, not cosmic. They like things tidy.” He tapped the face of the table. “I need an error corrected.”

I waited for the catch. There is always a catch with people who wear black coats and have watches like suns.

He met my eyes. For the first time I saw not performance but hunger, not power but exhaustion. It made me suspicious in a way that had nothing to do with infernal pacts and everything to do with the human capacity for tiredness.

“Whose soul?” I asked.

“Her name is Mara,” he said. “She sold to me three months ago, at a traffic light in Queens. She thought it was a prank. She thought she was buying time away from debt collectors with a guy who looked like a television host. The paper said all the right things. The ink said the right things. One clerk filed it as ‘final.’ The other clerk, apparently, misread ‘permanent relinquishment’ as ‘temporary lease.’” He shrugged. “Now she has no job and two small children and a medical bill and the wrong kind of grief. She needs a reversal.”

There’s a part of the tale you learn quickly where the Devil’s charm is practiced, its edges rubbed smooth by centuries of use. He sells heartbreak like candy; this was the script I expected. Sympathy. A tearful anecdote about a single mother. A moral pretense that would coerce me by the only human thing left for me to feel: guilt.

But the Devil’s argument wasn’t emotional. It was legal. He wanted me to stand down at an iron-clerked hearing and sign a paper that would—by virtue of authorship and an old rule I had never known I still had lawfully inside me—call the contract into question. The administration of Hell required human signatures for reversals because humans were, in their small and infuriating ways, unpredictably binding.

“Why me?” I asked.

“Because you sold.” He smiled; not the theatrical smile now, but one I recognized from league tables and award ceremonies. Familiar. “I’m not suited to courtroom theatrics. I tried once and they fined me for contempt. Humans react poorly to brimstone in briefs.”

There it was: a bureaucrat with a cape. The Devil who had once whispered in alleys and painted city skylines red had been reduced, in this telling, to a clerk asking for a witness. And in that moment, I did an unexpected thing: I laughed.

Not an incredulous laugh, not yet. It came out as a small, disbelieving bark. “You want me to—what—prove I was tricked? I’m supposed to say to a judge, ‘Yes, I sold my soul. I remember signing. I thought it was a good idea at the time but now I regret it?’”

“You can say whatever you want.” He folded his long fingers on the table. “You’re free now. That’s the point. Don’t squander it speaking like a saint.”

Free. The word landed with the lightness of a coin in an abyss. He had returned my possession like a man who took back an errant umbrella to borrow an umbrella, and in the same motion asked for a favor that felt like more debt.

They tell you the Devil doesn’t do favors. They’re wrong. He does favors because favors are useful; they create dependence. They create stories. He offered me a choice that felt like a clean line on a map: help a woman and perhaps begin to stitch small holes in a life you helped hollow out, or refuse and step away with my pouch full of everything that was mine once and the knowledge that I had helped make a world that could refine empathy into a product.

I could have made the practical choice. I could have pocketed the sack, taken back the empty lightness of my life, and continued to write sentences that moved people without myself being moved. I could have told myself that correcting one bureaucratic oversight in Hell would not become a trend.

Instead I placed the pouch on the table and felt something odd and small and warm bloom in my chest. The sensation had been called many things in the years I had studied loneliness: nostalgia, acid reflux, a good marketing tactic. Now it felt like something more like a muscle that remembered being used.

“All right,” I said. “I’ll do it.”

He smiled then, fully, a thing that rearranged the kitchen light as though a curtain had been pulled. “You were always romantic,” he said.

“I was pragmatic,” I corrected. “And don’t call me that.”

“You’ll go down,” he said. “You’ll sign the petition. You’ll speak with a judge who hates metaphors and clerks who love schedules. It will be boring, and it will be triumphant. And when you’re finished, if the petition is granted, Mara will have a chance to get back what she lost.”

“And if it isn’t?”

He shrugged. “Then you get your soul back. Perhaps we shall call that a consolation prize.”

It’s funny how the life you’ve built without a thing grows fragile the moment you know it can be returned. I thought of the first book — the pages that had made strangers cry — and then of the night my sister called from a hospital three years ago and I’d told her I would come but didn’t. I thought of the emptiness as an instrument, sharpened for efficiency, that had been given back to me for this small stubborn act of advocacy.

I took the pouch and, for the first time in a long while, I felt my hands tremble because something inside me wanted what those hands had long ago sold: to be moved, to risk regret, to give a damn without calculating the profit.

“Tell me where to sign,” I said.

The Devil gave me a folded sheet of paper, the kind of thing you fill out in triplicate, and for a moment I wanted to ask whether there would be crowns or whispering, whether the courtroom had an antechamber of bone. Instead I went to the bathroom and looked at myself in the mirror — the same jawline, the same tired eyes — and put the pouch under my shirt, against my chest.

“You might want to look alive in there,” he called as I left.

“I’ll try,” I said.

“Try is a good start,” he said. “I need that favor, you see, not because I’m incapable of doing my own mistakes, but because I’m tired of being the villain. Sometimes you have to ask someone you hurt to help you become the man you never were.”

The irony of taking help from the man who had designed my emptiness prickled, but something in me — perhaps the thin, newly warmed thing the old merchants call conscience — leaned into it. We walked out together under a blue sky that looked, for the first time in years, like a place that had room for more than one purpose.

I sold my soul years ago for a career and a comfort. Tonight, because the Devil needed a favor, I got it back long enough to decide whether to give it away again. The favor, I realized as we hailed a cab, was not a favor for him at all. It was a favor for me.

samples.prompt: There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.
samples.output:
There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.

I counted the steps under my breath—one, two, three—and tried not to imagine that the beast would count back. The hum that had followed us from the beach had the steady assurance of a machine and the uncertain lilt of a living thing: a bass-note vibration that made a blind moth hum against my teeth. As I moved into the shadow of the thing’s lips—slick, membraned curtains half-slitted to reveal the cavern within—the sound became a mouthful of silence. Sound, like light, can be swallowed. The world narrowed to the soft slap of my boots on the ridged gum, the old rasp of cartilage, a distant slosh of water deep inside that exhaled scent and warmth.

They called it a beast because it moved and ate and hummed the way beasts do, but the words we had for it were human conveniences: the Mouth, the Dragon of Vell, the Old Thing. It had been sleeping for as long as anyone could remember, its body a low hill by our fishing inlet, its breath the warm currents that allowed sea-kelp to grow short and sweet. Once in a generation it opened its maw to swallow the moon, or a ship, or a servant sent to replace the light in its throat. My grandmother used to tell me the story of the last Keeper—how he walked the beast’s gums and came away blinking and laughing and hollow-eyed, forever braided to the creature’s rhythm. She left me a coin and a warning. "Do not let it make you its voice," she would say. "Be the one who listens."

I kept the coin in my fist now and let it press into my palm as if that would anchor me. The beast’s front teeth were columns, each mottled with barnacle-growth, fungoid filaments waving like pale tongues. Between them the mouth opened into an amphitheater of mucous and rill. The lightstone—the small, prismatic seed of light we kept in a net to ward the inlet—nestled beyond, lodged in the beast’s palate like a pearl stuck in a throat. Without that light, the village’s fishing nets would show only as dark teeth in the fog; without light, the boys would only know night, and the gulls would turn away.

I had promised. There are debts a body makes for hunger that a soul keeps for pride; this was both. My hands smelled of tar and last night’s smoke and a fear older than my knees. I had brought rope and a dagger and a pocket of salt. If legend held, salt made the beast cough; if legend lied, salt made me ordinary.

The inside of the mouth was not the savage, maw-like place my mother’s stories promised. It was a cathedral that had been swallowed whole. Shadows pooled in the folds like oil, and across the vaulted palate a thin film of phosphorescent fungus crawled in lazy braids. Each braid pulsed once, twice—breathlike—and the pulses were the memory of the hum I had been chasing. As I moved forward the fungus rearranged its light in slow, indifferent patterns; it did not brighten at my approach, nor did it scream.

I craned my head to see the lightstone—a finger’s width of glass suspended by a web of mucus and tissue, giving off the calm, cool glow of a moon ripe and small. It rested in a nest of calcified ridges, rimed with salt. Around it, small things clustered: eggs the size of my fist, nacreous and quivering; a skein of transparent larvae that fluttered like folded maps when the beast adjusted its jaw. The sight struck me like an accusation. A warmth spread under the coin in my palm that had nothing to do with the beast’s breath.

I had expected the lightstone to be a thing to pluck, heavy and stubborn, resulting in a loud complaint and a chase. I had not expected it to be, in its sleepy cradle, a heart-beat for these small lives. The idea of taking it—of breaking apart the web and dangling it from my neck as proof—suddenly morphed into tearing a bird of its nest.

Behind me, the hum diminished to a memory. Inside the beast the world went on breathing in slow, oceanic lulls. I watched an egg vibrate and remembered the children in the village who used to watch the beasts go to sleep and imagine the stars were being made. There are economies in the world that are not coin-based—one being the exchange of safety for light—and for the first time, I felt the arithmetic tilt.

"One step at a time," I whispered, but the whisper was for my hands, not for the beast. I unhooked the rope looped on my shoulder and set the coil on the glistening palatal ridge. The rope was coarse and smelled of flax and gull-feathers; a small knot was my only plan. If the beast woke, I would climb, or fall, or be swallowed, and none of those options were particularly attractive. But standing beneath the lightstone, seeing the slight chest-breath of a larva beneath the pearl-light, I could not bring the coin to my lips.

A movement shifted in the darkness beyond the glow. Not the lazy, giant muscle of the beast, but something with a will. A small head protruded—cartilaginous eyes rimmed with the thin black of someone who had not yet catalogued the horizon. It had the face of a child made from sea-silk and salt; its mouth opened in a tiny, expectant O.

My knife trembled in my fingers. I could take a slice at the web, break the lightstone loose, and run with a prize. The coin in my palm grew hot, then cold; I let it fall, watching it wink on the palate like a swallowed star, and I said aloud the only prayer I knew, one my grandmother used to sing when storms came close: "We are borrowing the night."

The larva watched me with an intelligence that flinched and returned. It was not fear, exactly; curiosity edged its stare like a blade being honed. I thought of the children who would need the light tonight to pull their nets, and the wife who would cry if the nets came up empty. I thought of my mother’s hands, thin as driftwood, and the way she would lay a hand on my cheek and say, "You will always owe something." Owing something is a human condition; sometimes it is only possible to be kind when one is broke.

So I did something small and dishonest: I took my pocket of salt and let a few granules fall upon the web. The salt hissed quietly, a sound like a distant bell, and the web contracted. The fungus around the lightstone flared to a bright, keening blue and then dimmed as if remembering itself. The larva made a sound—a tiny, squealless note—and tucked its head into the shell of its egg.

I eased my knife under the lightstone’s edge and nudged. The nest resisted, but not violently; there was a give, a slow decanting. The stone slid free, and for a breathless instant it lay in my palm like the moon on a boy’s fist. Its light was warmer than I had imagined, and inside it a tiny spool of motion uncoiled. The beast inhaled—not a roar, but an enormous, placid curiosity—and with that breath came the scent of kelp and wet fur and a thousand small, bright memories.

I did not run. Greed is a compulsion that needs to be sated immediately; generosity is a muscle that requires intention. I could have clutched the stone and fled down the slick of the beast’s jaw, but the larva in the nest uncoiled and nudged its egg, and the motion made my chest ache in a way that made the village’s empty nets look like a poor trade for a living breath.

So I did what neither coin nor pride would have predicted. I broke the lightstone—not with a clean, triumphant smash but with a slow pressure that let it give itself up. Glass splintered; light spilled into the web like milk into black tea, and the cave filled with a gentle, spreading luminescence that wrapped the eggs in a cradle of warmth. The larva made a small, satisfied sound and curled tighter. Tiny motes—old lumens, fragments of other nights—floated up like confetti and settled over the beast’s palate.

There was a choice at the edge of every theft: take and leave darkness, or give back light and walk away with nothing to show. My hands were empty when I climbed back over the teeth and stepped onto the wet sand. The rope looped from my shoulder felt like an apology. Behind me, the beast sighed, and the hum returned, thicker now, braided with a contentment I had not expected it to accept from me.

When I reached the top of the dune, the village was a smear of lanterns. A child laughed somewhere; the sound was small enough to fit in a pocket. The coin in my pocket had been made useless by a salt mark and a gentle pressure; what it bought no longer mattered.

People ask later what I felt walking away: terror, triumph, shame. The truth was simpler. I felt, for the first time, that my own heart had matched the pace of something older than our reckoning and learned to keep time without taking the drum. The beast would wake tomorrow as beasts do, full of indifference and appetite. It might move that night; it might turn and roll and eat a boat or two. But the eggs in its palate would be warm, and some new thing would fight a first hour in a mouth that had refused me as thief and accepted me as one small, strange mercy.

At the edge of the inlet I stopped and looked back. The beast’s mouth was a soft, closed line. In its throat a faint, blue smear pulsed like a secret. I pressed my palms together and, for no audience but the wind, mouthed the old words my grandmother always said when she put out the lights: "We are borrowing the night."

samples.prompt: : You are missing an eye, and hate being asked about the eyepatch. There's nothing you like less than having to explain the story of how a single acorn once saved your life.
samples.output:
People ask about the eyepatch the way other people ask the time: casually, from a place of convenience rather than curiosity. It's on my face like punctuation, something to mark a sentence that other people insist on finishing for me. "What happened?" they say, like I am a trick question. There are three answers they want.

The first is the short, flashy one that gets applause at bars: "An acorn saved my life." It fits on a napkin, it has a laugh line, and it makes strangers lean in. The second is the longer, theatrical version, told when audiences require drama — explosions, valor, the kind of catastrophic heroics that let listeners doff their caps vicariously. The third is the truth, which is neither neat nor glamorous and which people rarely, if ever, want to hear because it makes them uncomfortable. They want myth. I hate when people want myth.

I hate being asked about the eyepatch because the acorn story reduces the rest of me to a gag. There is a lifetime of small, messy grief behind the patch — the surgeon's voice over me in a fluorescent room, the first time my hand reached up and came away slick and warm, the way sunlight turned sideways into a slice of loneliness — and all of it dissolves into a punchline when someone says, "An acorn? Come on." The acorn story is a coin flip: it wins the table, and I lose language for myself.

Still. The question comes so often I have learned to tell the story in a way that satisfies without giving away the parts I don't want retold. So yes: an acorn saved my life. Here it is, in the version I force myself to repeat when I can't be bothered with the long, sullen truth.

We were moving along the north edge of the ridge, me and two other couriers — the kind of job where you walked the worst parts of the map because someone had to. The leaves were dead-sounding underfoot. It had been raining the night before and the ground smelled like wet leather. My helmet had a dent in the rim from an earlier fall; someone had scribbled "LUCKY" on a piece of duct tape and stuck it to the inside because there is always someone who thinks a joke will make things calmer.

We were crouched, same rhythm of breath, when the world changed pitch: a twig to the left, a rustle, a shadow that shouldn't have been there. In the trees above, some idiot had climbed a tree stand for a better angle; they'd been waiting on us a long while, I guess. The first bullet tore a hole in the air beside my head and the taste of metal came hot and immediate.

I hadn't been looking up. I'd been watching the ground, counting steps. But the universe has a perverse sense of comedy. An acorn, nothing more than a gloss of brown, dropped from the crown of the oak directly above me. It hit the rim of my helmet with such soft, absurd violence that it caused my chin to dip a fraction of an inch. A fraction of an inch is all you need.

The shot that would have hit the top of my skull instead nicked the orbital bone and took the eye. The force came in a white blossom of light and then a hollowness behind my teeth. For a heartbeat I thought I had been stunned — that the swelling noise would be replaced by order — but the world rearranged itself into the shape of blood and the face of one of the other couriers shouting my name. The shooter abandoned the stand, their silhouette already receding like a shadow that knows it has done wrong and gets away.

That is how the acorn "saved my life." Without the acorn, the trajectory is clean and merciless. With the acorn, there is a damage that allows you to still breathe and to have a future that is not a hospital bed with bedsheets tucked too tightly. I am alive in a way that is embarrassing to admit: alive because of a meteorological fluke of gravity on a Sunday morning.

People hear that and they want the neat lesson — fate, luck, the universe's sense of irony. They want to hold that magic up and say: see? Life has a sense of humor; look how small things can be big. The joke is on us, the acorn says. They tell me "what are the odds?" as if odds are comforting. They ask about bone luck and mythic signs. They rarely ask how the surgery felt or how the mirror felt the first time I saw the void where a perfectly good human eye should be. They don't want to know about nightmares that smell like wet oak and gunpowder, or the afternoons when my hand, doing the thing it has always done without thinking, reaches up to my face and feels the leather strap and remembers.

Sometimes people laugh and ask if I have named the acorn. These are the gentle ones, the people who mean no harm. "No," I tell them. "I didn't plant it." Sometimes they want to touch the patch, an invasive little pat on the head that I've learned to flinch from. Hands hover and retreat. Someone always says, "It could be worse," in a voice meant to prop me up. They all miss the point: worse cannot be measured in stories like this. Worse is the small, steady grinding loss of not being able to perceive half the world you used to. Worse is learning that the face you gave to mirrors for years is now a sign and that other people's curiosity will always be a ledger you never consented to.

And yet the acorn story is true, and I tell it because it's the easiest way to end an interrogation. I tell it in bars when I want to be left alone. I tell it in elevators and at parties because some lines deserve to be paid for and I am done paying otherwise. Sometimes I add the bit about the dent in the helmet, the duct tape, the shout of my friend. People laugh. They exchange glances. The novelty fades. The conversation moves on.

There are days when the patch feels heavier than the actual eye ever did. There are little violences: a waiter leaning down to speak when it's not necessary, an old woman on the bus crossing herself the way people do when they see a wound they do not know how to name. There are more benign moments, too — kindnesses from strangers who, upon hearing the story, will go out of their way to make sure the world is softer for you. They hold doors and make small adjustments that add up to something resembling care. If I'm being honest, I have learned to take those as gifts when they come without strings.

Sometimes, late and alone, I tell the true story to myself in the long form, the one that resists tidy punchlines. I tell it without the acorn as an afterthought, because the acorn that fell was infuriatingly random and, in the end, unworthy as an explanation for what living with a loss really looks like. The acorn was small, and the universe loves small things, but the aftermath is a slow geometry of rehabilitation: doctors, new habits, the way people look at you as if they're deciding whether to love you, fear you, or simply be entertained.

If you ask me what happened and you mean it — really mean it, like you're prepared to listen to the parts that don't have a quip attached — I'll tell you the whole thing: how stupidly mundane most of it was, how I had to relearn the way to thread a needle and how counting stairs became a little ceremony. I'll tell you about the nights I stared at the ceiling and the hours I quietly hated the oak tree that had conspired with gravity. I'll tell you that that acorn didn't choose me; it was a tiny projectile without malice, and the world did not spare me out of benevolence.

But if you are the sort of person who only wants the headline — the anecdote to drop into cocktail chatter — then I will tell you the acorn story. It will make you smile or laugh with an elegant curl of irony, and you will put it away in your mental pocket like a charm. I know you'll take it with you because I pick up other people's stories the same way. I will, for your sake, deliver the pithy version with neat timing and not detail the blood.

Do I resent you for it? A little. Because every time the acorn becomes the whole, a part of me disappears again. Because it is easier to make a life out of a joke than to live in the slow, awkward work of survival. Because sometimes I want to lay down my patch and say, "There is more to me than your punchline." But then I remember that the acorn did what it did: random, absurd, miraculous in a way that makes you laugh when you don't know how else to respond to the fact of being here. So I put the patch back on, and I tell the story, and I leave a little space for the truth that follows, which is not a story at all but a life.

samples.prompt: Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.
samples.output:
Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirmed it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.

He kept the list on a narrow strip of vellum that smelled faintly of smoke and old books. Most days it was crowded, a cramped alphabet of ends: infants with their bright futures, cartographers and kings, stray dogs and dying stars. Sometimes the names were written in iron script, sometimes in the fragile hand of a child—each name a knot on a net he wore as a mantle. Today the knot was a single, audacious loop: GOD, lettered in ink that did not dry.

He looked at it the way a person might look at a locked door. All his life—however long lifetimes counted to him—Death had taken the world at its rate. He had been taught the rules when the world was still new: extract, escort, close. Gods had been on other lists once, the rare errant demigod who had borrowed time, or the angry pantheon struck down by a rival. But the notion of harvesting that which named the cosmos itself had been a question asked only in idle half-jests among the shadows: could the maker be unmade? Is there a final accounting for the final account-keeper?

He felt, oddly, like a child being told he could touch a storm.

He rose from his chair, the floorboards of his office sighing with the sound of small galaxies spinning off the edge of a map. His scythe hung on a peg by the door, polished by years of routine so that it reflected everything and nothing. Today, for the first time, his hand hesitated on the haft.

When he arrived, the world around God was nothing like the descriptions in prayerbooks and cautionary tales. There were no thunderheads, no choir of cherubic bureaucrats. There was a small garden, improbably ordinary, ruff of grass at the edge of a salt sea. God sat on a stone bench with hands folded, the kind of hands that tell of work done: callused, soft, a map of everything made. God was wearing a sweater that had seen better winters and a pair of patched jeans. There was a half-drunk mug of something steaming, and a stack of papers that, upon closer inspection, were the drafts of rules, edits and crossings-out in every language.

God turned as Death approached. His eyes were a fatigue that had somehow become human: not the hard, blazing omniscience of scripture, but the warm, raw sorrow of someone who had been up a very long time and finally, at last, decided sleep was necessary.

“You’re early,” God said. His voice was like an old bell, slightly out of tune.

Death smiled. Smiled was a word people used for faces that resembled their own, and his face, when he afforded it one, had been carved from the dusk between breaths. “Not earlier than you asked for,” he replied. “You were put down for this morning.”

God looked at his hands. “I did not put myself down, exactly.” He shrugged. “It happened in a way I suppose you’d understand: a decision, a surrender, a binding. It felt like taking off a cloak I had worn too long. It felt like…” He searched for a word the way old men search for coins in couch cushions. “Like finishing a book I’d never thought I would outlive.”

Death crouched, unwinding the usual rituals from his sleeves like a man taking tools out of a drawer. There were formalities even for the gods: seals to break, immunities to note. But as he examined the signatures threading through the margins of the drafts, something lighter than bureaucratic triumph warmed him—something like pity and, faintly, like gratitude.

“Why?” Death asked. The question was not curiosity for his ledger—it was quieter, a human question: why would something that could sing a world into being choose to be silent?

God laughed, a sound full of things that had been both created and forgiven. “Because I was tired. Because the songs began to sound like repetition. Because I noticed the small joy was not in commanding, but in seeing how the small things arranged themselves on their own.” He gestured to the sea, to the gulls arguing over a crab. “I also think,” he added, looking out at the horizon, “that if I stayed, no one would be allowed to be small. Belief is a crowd that can become a prison. Perhaps I wanted to see what happened when the crowd dispersed.”

“But you are the crowd,” Death said, because in the ledger’s ink that felt like truth. “You are what keeps the geometry of meaning.”

“And maybe I’m tired of geometry.” God’s smile was sudden, like a break in the clouds that had learned to be tender. “Take me, then. Not as a punishment, not as conquest. Take me as mercy. Take me as you would a tired horse, a worn instrument. We both do a job. Let me stop.”

Death’s hand, which had been steady for an eternity, shook once. It was an image of mortality no one anticipated: the Reaper’s tremor. “If I take you,” he said, the ledger’s single syllable echoing against the sea, “what becomes of the rest?”

God folded the papers into a small neat pile and nudged them toward Death. “The rest will have to keep organizing itself as it always did, with or without my notes. The fields will be left to the farmers, the storms to the weather, love to futility and ferment. Some things will make themselves up. Some will fail gloriously. That is the point.”

There was a long silence. If Death had been made of more than the patient components of endings, perhaps he would have feared that silence. Instead, he felt a fierce, tender thing well up: recognition. Gods had taught him language, but God himself taught him what it meant to be tired. Death, who had never rested on purpose, who had never allowed himself to be excused, felt something like permission offered to him across the table.

He performed the rites because that is what he did. He lifted the scythe—no longer a terrifying crescent, but a simple tool, as domestic as a bread knife in that light—and touched the edge to God’s palm. The sound that rose was not an ending-bell but a book closing in a quiet room. For a moment, there was a loop of white, like a new moon, and the mug steamed a little more fiercely.

When God folded, he did it like a man going to sleep: hands to his chest, a small exhalation, the long, steady fall of someone catching up after a marathon. Death supported him; he had supported countless beings across thresholds, and his kindness had become the only generosity he'd ever been paid to practice. He felt, astonishingly, a heat in his ribs that was not coldness but an ember of something else—compassion, perhaps, or the beginning of pity.

“You will be cared for,” Death said, because he had learned the cadence of consolation.

“You will be cared for,” God echoed, and for a suspended beat their roles reversed in a private, sacred joke: both caretakers, both relinquishing.

The taking did not cause the sky to fall. Nobody who had been watching from far corners of the universe collapsed into belief-fueled chaos. What happened, instead, was smaller and stranger and perhaps truer: the voice in the wind saying this must be the will of God paused and listened to itself. People lowered their heads and other people did not. Some said a new theology; others lit candles with the same old hands. The constellations kept their courses, though a few of them seemed to shimmy, as if checking a seam.

Back at his office, Death put the vellum back in the ledger and underlined the single name with an almost tender stroke. He closed the book and sat a very long time, feeling the universe continue, resuming its ordinary, miraculous, stubborn business. For once his list would be less crowded in his mind: an absence had its own outline now.

He had always wondered if it were possible, and now he knew. It had been possible because even the infinite could be exhausted; because being omniscient had never precluded being lonely; because mortals and gods alike were devices for making meaning, and devices eventually wear out. He had harvested the maker and had not become the maker in return; he had merely become, for a time, the keeper of a secret gentler than fear.

Outside, a gull cawed over a tidepool. Somewhere, a child laughed at a joke that had nothing to do with omnipotence. Death collected the scythe, smoothed his cloak, and turned the page. The net he wore was lighter for the space God had left, and he felt—unexpectedly, like a small promise—that endings could sometimes be beginnings disguised in old clothes. He had taken the name God from the list; the world continued to call itself into being without it. And in the quiet after, Death kept his hand over his chest, feeling the echo as if it were someone else's heartbeat, learning the shape of a rest he had never before been permitted.

samples.prompt: She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.
samples.output:
She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.

It was not the dark itself that calmed her—dark had teeth and the city at its most honest still bit—but the way night folded around mistakes and kept them from being read. The streetlamps threw forgiving halos that made every face a continuous shadow; the shops shuttered and the adverts went mute. In the hours when most of the world took inventory and cast judgment, she could become something softer: a woman without receipts, without witnesses, without a home address on a ledger.

Her apartment was a small harbor for nocturnals. Curtains the color of bruises blocked the last scraps of afternoon. A single lamp glowed like a watchful moth. On the table lay trivialities that had been arranged to look like the life she had not chosen—an idle teacup, a stack of unpaid bills bent into sharp corners. She kept the radio tuned to late-night frequencies, voices rubbed gravely against one another like two people trying on accents until neither sounded like the original.

She fashioned her evenings into a ritual. She walked the river when it was black and oily and anonymous, the water holding her reflection until she blinked. She traded whispers with other night-workers—the cleaner who hummed hymns to fluorescent lights, the taxi driver who spoke in the tired grammar of confessions. At an all-night café, she sat beneath a poster of a sleeping moon and stitched camouflage into the invisible fabric of her life, mending gloves and hearts with the same thread.

The fear of the day was not a thing that had come overnight. It was layered—years thick—an architecture of small violences. The first dawn she remembered was raw and heaving, sunlight like a spotlight on the moment she had cracked. She had been younger then, limber with convictions, and daylight had unspooled those convictions like an old rope. Names were called, doors unlatched, obligations slapped down hard as court papers. People she loved had told her, with the casual cruelty of the certain, that there would be consequences. The sun, in their mouths, became a tribunal.

After that, she learned that daylight had allies. Paper loved daylight, and with paper came signatures and deadlines and social workers in sensible shoes who punctured the sanctuary of night with clipboards. The sun exposed wiring behind her polite face—debts, identities, the small thefts she had committed against herself to survive. It broadcast the footnotes of her life into a clear font where anyone could read them.

It was a practical fear too. In daylight the city pulsed with traffic cameras and HR representatives, with men in good coats who preferred to do their work in the light because light made things official. Night offered wiggle room—anonymity, yes, but also time. If she could delay long enough, if she could wrap herself in midnight and reroute her obligations around sleeping people, perhaps she might outrun the accounts that were due or the names that had to be given.

But mostly it was shame. Shame sat reef-like under her ribs and grew coral, ugly with the passage of years. She had made choices—she had let go, she had turned away—and the day was a cartographer. Sunlight rendered the map of her life in bright, precise lines and pointed to the parts she had preferred to smudge with a thumb. At night she could paint over them.

People simplistic about courage would have called her cowardice. They would not have seen the small, cunning courage it took to exist in the seams of time, the way she learned to make long, impossible feints. The world that demanded neat histories offered no clemency for muddled truths. Her sin—if it could be called that—was not singular; it had been a dozen omissions, some with teeth, some with gentleness. She had remarried her silence the way other people married men. It was a quiet, binding thing.

On the solstice, when the night stretched its longest and she held it like a mantle, something unscheduled arrived. There was a sound she did not expect: a knock, not the tentative rapping of dealers or drunkards but the hollow certainty of someone who had practiced arrival, as if the knock had worked its way into muscle memory. It was still before dawn, the sky a slow bruise. The time when the night still believed it might continue.

She stood at the door and counted her breathing. The knocks came again, three, then three, organized and obscene in their civility. Her hands were committed to their own rehearsal: they smoothed the dress of sleep from her lap, wiped away a phantom of sweat. The radio kept a low hum in the background as if to underline the normalness of the world she was refusing.

When she opened it, she expected a messenger with paperwork or the polite, bright face of a neighbor with a casserole. Instead she saw a child—no, not a child, a woman who had the pelvic sway of someone who had slept in too many chairs, who had laughed too soon at the wrong jokes. There was something about her face that arrested the breath: the slope of the ear, the shadow by her lip, an old scar softened by time. The woman carried a box tied with string, and her eyes were partly a mirror and partly a sun trying to warm him away.

"Are you Lila?" the woman said. The voice lived in a more forgiving register than the day. It had the remnant of an accent that had been ironed flat by necessity.

Lila's knees felt like the bottom of a well. She had not seen that voice in years, in the kind of years that rearranged furniture in the heart. She had rehearsed answers to papers and men and judgment, not this.

"I used to be," she said then, and it sounded like an admission and a refusal at once.

The woman smiled as if that were the exact truth she had hoped for. "They said you'd moved many times," she told Lila, "that you liked the night. I brought soup."

It was ridiculous how physical forgiveness could be. The sight of the box, the commonness of soup, the woman’s relaxed shoulders—they all conspired to make the night around Lila's chest feel suddenly porous. The shadow-armor she had worn felt too heavy, a medieval contraption no longer needed because the threat it had been forged for was gone or had softened into age.

"Why now?" Lila asked, though the question thinned like breath.

"Because I've been tracing maps," the woman said. "Because I grew up with a name like a stone in my mouth and I wanted to know if there was a mother attached to it." She stepped closer, placed the box on the threshold. The string cracked quietly.

Names were fragile things. Daylight loved them—neat categories, neat closures. Night loved the forgetting of them, the way a thing could be left unnamed and therefore uncharged. The woman—no, her daughter—lifted her hands as if offering a truce.

"I don't want anything from you," she said. "No judges. No all the reasons you kept yourself away. I only want to sit with you before the world says anything."

In the newness of that offer, something enormous and perilous rose up, a kind of hunger disguised as relief. Lila had imagined that her nights had been a kind of generosity toward others—that by hiding she had spared them pain. But now she saw a different kind of selfishness: she had been hoarding the darkness, an isolation that kept the soft things inside from dissolving into people's lives where they might be changed, shared, and perhaps, in a way only day could render, healed.

She thought of every dawn she had missed, of children's schoolplays she had not attended, of apologies she had never learned to pronounce. She thought of the men with clipboards and the long lists of reasons that had kept her under the coverlet. She thought of small mercies—soup on a porch, a lit cigarette shared between nervous fingers—and how the world had grown new skin around them.

She invited the woman in. They set the box on the table. The lamp threw a small sun of its own and the radio, as if embarrassed, went quiet. The woman, whose name was Mara, peeled back the string and the paper and set out bowls of soup that smelled of old summers: tomatoes, basil, the faintest curl of garlic. They ate in the peculiar intimacy that exists between two people who have practiced absence and now practice presence like a foreign language.

When dawn came, it bent the curtains with muted hands. Light spilled across the floor and painted everything in verdicts. Lila felt the old fear rise, the reflexive desire to slam the shutters, to pull the night back over their heads like a stern parent. But Mara was laughing at some private joke, the sound small and bell-clear. Across the table, her daughter—Mara's daughter—said nothing. She was too young for explanations; she only watched the light with the open-eyed fascination of someone for whom the world still promised straightforward things.

"Leave it," Lila said to the curtains, and her voice surprised her. It was not a command to the light but to herself.

Daylight touched the bowls, warmed the teacup, settled on the edges of their shoulders and did what daylight does: it revealed, yes, but it also made witnesses of the ordinary things. The ceiling fan hummed its tired hymn. Outside, the city woke and the day began to catalogue its inhabitants. The world would continue to name and to judge. Documents would be served at noon, and officials would collect signatures in the afternoon, and the street would, inexorably, present its list of debts.

But in the breakfast-room, under that thin, new sun, Lila found that the future could be met not as an indictment but as a conversation. She had held onto the night for fear of being seen, of being made accountable by an uncompromising light. She had clung to it as others cling to a wound. Now, at last, the day was not the tribunal she had feared. It was the place where stories could be set down and traded, where names could be spoken aloud without being used for punishment, where the small, ordinary act of sharing soup could render absolution into something plausible.

She did not know if forgiveness would come in full or in fragments, or whether the world outside would be gentler for having witnessed her. But she let the curtains fall open all the same and felt, with a cautious and growing surprise, that the sun did not always come bearing only judgment. Sometimes it brought a harvest that could be gathered: faces, voices, the possibility that the past could be asked to sit down and be spoken to over something hot and sweet and simple.

She held onto the night for as long as she needed. Then, finally, she let it go.

samples.prompt: A pill is invented which eliminates the need for sleep. It has one side effect.
samples.output:
The pill came in a white vial the size of a fingernail, wrapped in a pamphlet with a glossy logo and a slogan that read, simply: More life. No sleep. It is astonishing how a single sentence can rearrange priorities. Suddenly there were two kinds of people in my city: the sleepless and the sleepers.

On television they showed businessmen walking past sunlit cafés at three in the morning, their faces sharp, their eyes bright, conducting deals in hour-long blocks that used to belong to dreams. Students opened books at two a.m. and closed them at dawn with no weariness. Emergency rooms ran uninterrupted. Concert tours shrank by days, factories lost the dead hours. Productivity curves bent upwards like statements that didn’t lie anymore.

I took the pill on a Tuesday, because my daughter was turning twelve on Friday and I wanted to write something that would make her laugh, not just a text I would scribble half-asleep. The clinic asked me to sign forms, to acknowledge that, besides the obvious—continuous wakefulness, altered circadian rhythms—there was a single side effect, clearly printed and circled in black ink: the permanent removal of forgetting.

They explained it like a statistic. Night is not only rest; it is pruning. Synapses we never reuse are softened, small humiliations dissolve overnight like sugar in tea. Forgetting is a sculptor’s chisel; it discards the unnecessary so that memory can keep making room for the important. The pill prevented that pruning. You would retain everything your mind ever recorded, from the taste of a childhood orange to the precise tone of a barista’s disappointment when you interrupted her.

I laughed at first, because grief has a way of making odd things sound like bargains. Imagine, they said, never misplacing your keys, never blanking an important face. Imagine anniversaries that remain anniversaries, not loose threads you have to be reminded of. Imagine—my daughter is twelve—her every laugh captured, never to be simplified into an orphaned feeling I could retrieve only with the help of photographs.

The promise was intoxicating. That first week I wrote so much my fingers ached. I stopped small arguments in their tracks, because I remembered every time I had been unfair. I could recite every line of my grandmother’s favorite recipe; the cadence of my father’s cough came back like an echo. The world sharpened into detail. Night no longer pressed me into oblivion; each hour I spent awake fed into a reservoir that refused to leak.

But memory is not a series of tidy files. It is an accumulation, with the same inevitability as barnacles on a hull. The first unpleasantness came as a scrape. I remembered, with painful clarity, the way a roommate mocked my travel-stained shoes at twenty-three. Ordinarily, that would be a marginal note in the ledger of self. Now it played back—tone, cadence, smirk—until it had weight. Then other slights came up, then injuries, then faces I had tried to put away. The small cruelties of strangers, the clumsy betrayals of lovers, the banality of long afternoons I would previously have let dissolve—none of it dissolved anymore.

You learn—the hard way—that forgetting is not defective mind but mercy. At three a.m., after the third time I lay awake replaying a moment in a restaurant when a man had said something racist to a woman my friend was with, I realized my head had become an archive that treated everything with the equal reverence of evidence. There was no hierarchy; every hurt was a headline. The pill had made me omniscient about my own life and ridiculously poor at living it.

Society adapted in all the fiendishly human ways you would expect. Lawsuits bloomed: people sued to extract old promises, old slights, old claims. Contracts were drawn with clauses about "memorial testimony"—you could legally bind someone to the contents of their eternal recall. Couples began recording arguments to cross-check later, because memory’s infallibility was used as a cudgel: if you remembered something, it was incontrovertible. Therapists turned into archivists, trained not only to unpack trauma but to build curatorship into minds. There were “forgetting clinics” that offered illegal erasure—chemistry that burned like greed—and religious sects that denied the pill on metaphysical grounds. People who wanted to forget, children mostly, were often the ones who could not take it. For them forgetting was not a bug but a gift.

There were wonders. Witnesses could testify to crimes with unshakeable certainty. Lost languages resurfaced because the last speakers could never let a syllable fall silent. My daughter, who resisted the pill at first, relented. She liked knowing every first of everything: first friends, first heartbreaks, first successes. At school she could revise her homework at two in the morning and still remember the diagrams by morning. She loved, as children do, that her memory was a treasure chest with no leak.

But wonder has a cost. People who had taken the pill often spoke of "memory weight." There is a vocabulary for grief and burden that formalizes it—"affective loading," "cognitive saturation"—but the sensation is immediate. It is like having a backpack of stones you cannot take off. If you are lucky, the stones are angels—hugs, kisses, the exact cough that tells you someone is nearby. If you are unlucky, the stones are the slights and cruelties handed to you without an opportunity to forget.
