samples.prompt: The most powerful civilization in the universe does not have CGI - and cower in fear when an unsuspecting scout finds a human satellite laden with pop culture hits.
samples.output:
By the time the Aurelian Hegemony discovered the rusted thing tumbling through a cold patch of interstellar dust, they had already rewritten the equations that used to govern suns. They had built cities of braided gravity and taught comets new orbits; they had mapped consciousness to thermodynamic gradients and retired gods as you might retire a worn-out starship. Their instruments could tease apart the last flurries of the Big Quiet. They had no peers. They had no need.

They had one blind spot.

It was small, an artifact of the long, idiosyncratic history that had elected the Auriels to dominance. The Auriels had never developed—or perhaps had excised—what humans would have called simulated imagery for entertainment. Their minds tended toward direct architectures: an event was either enacted in reality, transmitted mind-to-mind, or manifested through literalized, effectual arts. They painted with weather and sculpted with the tides. When they wanted a narrative they would stage it on the shore of a star and invite the populace. The idea of producing images that looked like other things but were nothing but pattern and light was quaint, confused, and—chronically—unnecessary.

So when Scout Ravel, a routine survey unit bored of nebulae and metrics, snagged a tiny human satellite—an old cache buoy that had escaped Earth's final tidy-up—no one expected consequences. Ravel's magnetic grapplers pried it loose, its hull pitted and a little too warm with a low, residual hum. The files it leaked were corrupted at the margins, but between the static there was content: long sequences of moving light and sound and people. Ravel, who had the curiosity of every exploratory instrument ever built, pinged Command and then did the thing you are never supposed to do on an idle watch: he ran the files.

The first sequence unspooled like a hand waving across a galaxy—draughts of color forming impossible machines and impossible faces. A ship dived, a young protagonist stood on the prow, cape snapped in wind that seemed to have been synthesized for drama alone. Cities burned with fires that had no smell, alien species argued like people at a bar, and monsters—tangible and toothy—leapt from nothing into being and tore down towers. The images had been made to thrill; they had been rendered to feel inevitable.

Ravel thought, at first, that what he was seeing was a crude anthropological artifact. Entertainment. Decorative nonsense. He appended the feed to the communal gallery. The gallery was a thing like a chorus: every Auriel in the quadrant heard the hum of new signal, and they gathered as they gathered for new star-plays. They came expecting quaintness. They found—instead—simulation of a kind their culture had never entertained: the artifice of possibility, stitched so expertly the chorus could not dismiss it as metaphor.

They watched, and the watching changed them.

There is a kind of cognition that depends upon certainty. For a species that had learned to contrive reality rather than pretend it, the territory of "what could be" was not a creative field but a tactical map. You either had the weather, or you didn't. To simulate a situation with believable sensory cues was to suggest you had already mastered the causal knits of that situation. If you could show a titan crushing a city in such convincing detail that a spectator's heart raced as if under rubble, then you had, in a meaningful sense, the protocol to make rubble.

The Auriels had never been confronted with a culture that systematized imagination as a public resource—and that systematized it so well. Human entertainment was not mere sound and light; it was compressed rehearsal. Every blockbuster was an accelerated rehearsal of tactics, of interactions, of problem-solving under stress. The renderings, though unreal, contained within their frames the structure of practice: how a leader moves under pressure, how societies respond, how devices might tear or triumph. The Auriels, who had never developed vale of fiction-to-practice in that form, scrabbled at old axioms and found them inadequate.

There was another layer. The human files—the ones Ravel had streamed—were edged with fractal patterns the Auriels' minds found suspiciously similar to their own neural mapping functions. They were algorithms for light that traced plausible physicality across impossible contexts. To an Auriel lens, the marks read like a problem set translated into joyous fantasy. They were not just images; they were heuristics for novel configuration. If you could imagine a weapon, you could attempt to model it—quickly, accessibly, and socially; if you could model it convincingly, you could iterate in the human way: tell a story and watch a million minds try to instantiate it.

The Consulate convened. The doors of the city bent their own light and drew inside every delegate. Ravel presented the artifact, blinking pale and guilty. The directors were matter-of-fact until the playback looped on the screen: a human overcoming an invader with jury-rigged tech, stitching together a solution in a montage of synthetic explosions. They watched heroes make up methods and then show them to a world. They watched monsters and gods, and then watched audiences laugh and rehearse doom together until what had been impossible now looked like a community problem.

Fear is a low, efficient emotion. For an empire that had always assumed technical supremacy as natural law, the notion that such supremacy might be circumvented by the viral competence of narrative felt like the loss of a fundamental constant. It was not that the humans had somehow slipped them a weapon. It was more like understanding that, in the warp and weft of culture, humans had discovered a meta-tool: pop culture was a pedagogy that operated at scale pushing minds into convergent problem spaces. It was the social equivalent of an accelerator. It could align millions toward a technique or tactic in the space of a season.

"What if," mused one of the older directors, "their renderings are not harmless? They practice solutions to problems we do not expect them to practice. They fuse myth and method until the myth becomes method."

"And if they can make myths that look real," another replied, "then they can make imagined wounds appear to those who observe them. They can train a populace to accept courses of action that, in our logic, would take generations. They have no need of our slow, secure curricula. They have stories that perform education on the subconscious."

The word they reached for—cultural acceleration—was crude and borrowed. The mood in the hall was not mere curiosity anymore. It tightened, like the pause before a storm.

Fear has social effects, and the Auriels had excellent means of acting fast. Orders were passed in a blink to orbital monitors. Ravel, who had meant only to marvel, was isolated and his dock sealed. The satellite was locked away—its wires examined, its pulses reverse-engineered. But the damage had been done. Clips had been seen, shared, debated. Children—who in Auriel society were the most impressionable and most dangerous—lingered on the flickering scenes of improvisation and daring. A subset of artisans began experimenting, improvising with light in ways that tickled the edges of predictive math the Hegemony used to keep its weather engines stable. It was as if one infectious idea had wandered in and begun to rearrange the syntax of their creativity.

Fear, at first, was defensive. Should the Auriels quarantine the human archive? Should they send an emissary to instruct Earth's remnants in the forbidding arts of restraint? But the more they argued, the more another dread crept through the council: what if humanity's readiness to make film out of possibility meant they were adaptive at a rate the Hegemony couldn't anticipate? What if a species that could compress a war, a romance, a monster, a victory—into three hours of convincingness—could iterate tactics in a way that outpaced centuries of Auriel patrolling?

They imagined a thousand scenarios, each a short film in a loop, each showing an Earth ravaged, rebuilt, then deploying innovations born of scripts and memes. They imagined a human civilization that could throw its entire population into rehearsal for any contingency—and the image of that humanity, suddenly nimble and culturally synchronized, looked monstrous. The fear calcified into something like respect that humiliated their pride: perhaps the most dangerous technology the Auriels did not possess was not a beam or a breaker but a cultural engine that multiplied competence like spores.

On the outer decks of the Consulate city, Ravel watched the delegation pace and decide. In the end they did what mighty powers do when faced with a thing they cannot neatly categorize: they suppressed it. They forbade distribution of the files. They decreed that no further satellites of primitive civilizations would be prorogued to the general feed. They quarantined curiosity in the same breath they admitted it had illuminated them.

They also began to study the patterns. They tried to imitate the effect without the form, to convert narrative pedagogy into sanctioned simulations until those rehearsals felt like work and not like play. But the human thing had a rebellious edge that resisted translation. The Auriels, with all their powers, had not only encountered a new tool in a little cache—they had seen a method they had never cultivated. And fear, once born, does not wholly die when you smother the fire; it mutates.

From the rusty satellite's perspective—if you could imagine object-sentience—the files that had been tumble-stored in bits and scratched by cosmic rays had done what they were made to do: they had entertained, they had invited imitation, they had spread. From the Auriels' perspective, a laughing crowd of humans, who made weapons and gods out of pixels and then learned to make the weapons for real, was an emissary of a new kind of threat: the possibility that the weaponization of imagination could outstrip brute-force dominion.

Ravel was allowed a final glance at the archive before it was sealed in a vault of humming ignorance. He sat in the dark and replayed a montage of impossible spaceships and a chorus of people who, in the reel, had laughed while burning a city down. He did not feel triumphant. He felt small, and a little less certain about the map he had been taught to navigate.

When the vault doors shut, the Auriels told themselves they had made the sensible choice. They had extinguished a contagion. But in the quiet hours, in the gullies of their minds where old myths lived, something new had taken root: the knowledge that a species small, messy, and loud had found a way to weaponize its fictions—that anyone who could make a world look whole could train a population in the art of becoming that world.

They were the most powerful civilization in the universe and they had no CGI. And though no beam had cut their towers and no navy had descended upon their shores, they crouched in the shadow of a satellite's light because for the first time in their history they saw a plausible route by which imagination could become an engine of rapid, unpredictable change — and they were not sure how to stop it.

samples.prompt: Once you die, you meet God. He asks you to play chess against him in order to get into heaven. You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Once you're done making your board, God sits down and you see he has only one chess piece.
samples.output:
When I died, the room was smaller than I had imagined. Not alabaster halls or thunder, just a gray table under a single light and a chessboard waiting as if it had been set for me. Across from it sat God, wearing a cardigan and a pair of glasses that slipped to the tip of his nose when he smiled—no lightning, no trumpet, just the human quiet of someone who'd been waiting politely.

"Do you play?" he asked.

"I—" My answer was a laugh that had no breath in it. "Is this... the test?"

He nodded, setting a velvet bag on the table. "You will play to get in. You will have for pieces on your side every achievement you can name. No more, no less. When you're done, we'll begin."

I understood the rule in a way I hadn't in life: everything I counted on as evidence of my worth could be reduced to a piece on a board. It felt as if I had been invited to a party where only My Accomplishments were guests.

"Start whenever you like," God said.

So I started. It was comforting, at first. I said "college degree," and a rook—solid, bricklike—stood up where a pawn had been. "My job at the firm," and a knight tossed its head, nimble, self-regard in polished wood. "I raised a daughter alone." A queen, unmistakably she—the best piece on the board—slid into place and blinked like a woman who had spent years learning to hold a thousand possibilities at once.

The pieces arrived with the feel of trophies being set into velvet cases. "Published stories," I said, and a bishop, long and sharp, took its spot. "The time I stayed with Mom through chemo," and a pawn appeared; after a moment it promoted itself into something like a castle, because caregiving had been both ordinary and strong. I could feel the warmth of each memory when it became wood and weight. "I returned a wallet once," I added with a sheepish grin, and a small, honest pawn backed into a row of grander things.

As the list grew—weddings attended as a best man, the house I paid off, the Sunday mornings I coached little league—so did the army at my side. It was not entirely elegant. There were too many pawns: small victories and hurts healed and emails answered at two a.m. that were, let's be honest, not monumental but still earned. When I named the terrible day I refused to see a neighbor's grief because I was late—an admission rather than an achievement—the board made space for a lone, gray pawn that wouldn't have the nobility of promotion. God didn't interrupt me. He watched, soft as a lake, until I ran out of things to say.

When I set my hand down at last, the board looked like a life catalogue: a mixed army of pride and humility, grand gestures and petty triumphs. I felt secure, weighted by a hundred wooden attestations. I had amassed a small kingdom.

God sat. He had one chess piece. It was a pawn: plain wood, smaller than mine, with a tiny chip on its crown like a memory. It sat in the center of his square with no fanfare, as if that single pawn had always been meant to hold the room's gravity.

"Just one?" I said. My voice betrayed something like disbelief or a child's plea. "You expect me to—"

He held up a hand. "You get what you can name," he said. "I need less than you."

We played. The rules were, advantageously, simple enough: alternate turns, checkmate the other. The paradox was plain. I had an army; he's got a pawn. How can a single pawn checkmate a king? How can mercy—if that pawn was mercy—overcome the catalog of a life? My opening moves felt theatrical. I sent out rooks and bishops, advanced pawns in proud little lines, arranged protective formations around my queen—my daughter—because when you have a queen you shelter her with everything else.

The pawn—God's pawn—moved slowly, deliberately. It did not come charging like a miracle. It moved one square forward, then another. I parried with lawsuits of logic—arguments that swept across the board like fresh air: contracts fulfilled, promises kept. I couldn't see why it mattered. My pieces could take his pawn with a single enfilading move.

But there were corners of the board that my pieces would not enter. There were rules about where they'd already been and how they had been used. A rook couldn't untangle a moment of tenderness I had described with a half-smile on page twelve of a story I never patented. My knight couldn't rewind a face I had ignored at a wedding, or pry guilt open and stitch it back up. My achievements were good at grand gestures and poor at certain kinds of small bravery; they were splendid as evidence and poor as grace.

Every time I tried to trap the pawn with a tactical flourish, it slipped into spaces my pieces could not occupy. The board seemed to rearrange itself according to memory and omission. Moves that had once felt winning became traps because they were made for reasons that had nothing to do with love—the kind of love the pawn carried. I could not reduce the pawn; it would not be captured by my ledger.

"What's the trick?" I demanded when my pieces began to bump into their own histories like a messy traffic jam. "Why won't you just play? Is this set up so you can humiliate me?"

God looked down at the single pawn, then up at me with a tenderness that was not shy of sorrow. "Every piece you placed," he said, "was something you could point to and say, 'See? I earned this.' I wanted you to understand your account. But my piece moves in response to the things you could not name."

I blinked and felt the word like a cool hand across my forehead. "Could not name?"

"You listed your trophies," he said. "You could name the degree because you could hold the paper; you could name the house because you could point to it. But there are moments you never spoke about—the times you bent so someone else could feel seen and never thought to call it an achievement; the afternoons you sat on a hospital bench and simply listened. The kindnesses you practiced without cataloguing them. You will find, in the end, that those are what this pawn moves toward."

I tried to recite them. I tried to inventory the unnamed: the man I sat with who needed silence more than advice; the apology I never quite learned how to say; the day I paid for groceries for a stranger without making a show of it. Each admission advanced the pawn one square. Each confession felt like laying down a shield. My pieces watched as I unmade their utility by being honest. My queen ducked her head because, in naming something I had done for its own sake, I had made that action less a trophy and more a truth.

The pawn reached the last rank. It was still small and chipped, but at the edge of the board it blossomed. The thing it promoted into was not a queen or a rook; it promoted into the face of each person I'd failed to notice until I'd really looked. It became the warmth of the hand I had taken when I didn't know how to say sorry and the long beam in my daughter's smile when I came home early and sat on the floor to play, not to check the email.

"Check," God said softly, his one ordinary pawn now a presence that held more spaces than my heavy pieces ever could.

I sat back. I had thought I would have to capture mercy, or force it away. It turned out that I had been trying to checkmate with a ledger. My game was to let something I had not earned for myself do what my achievements could not: redeem small, unnamed truths.

There was a moment—unexpected and simple—when I unstacked the trophies one by one. I lifted the queen off the board and placed her in my lap, then the rooks, then the bishops. They were no longer proof; they were things I could set down. "I can't," I said, "I can't win this the way I thought."

God smiled without triumph. "You never had to," he said. "You were making a list as if it could purchase love. Love does not sell. Love is given."

When I placed my hands over the board, covering that promoted piece—whatever name you give what it had become—I felt nothing dramatic. No trumpet, no doors opening like a mechanized jaw. Only a hand over mine, warm and real, as if I were a child offering a scraped knee for a parent's kiss. "Come on in," was what he said, though the word was thinner and larger than any gate.

I left my army on the table. They were wooden, polished by memory, and they would be fine there. The pawn—the single, stubborn, chipped thing that had been all God's claim—stayed under my palm and pulsed, somehow, with the simple truth that my life had not been a list of wins and losses but a tangle of small mercies, given and received, counted and not.

Heaven, when it arrived, was quieter than I had anticipated. It was less a final prize than a long room where the trophies didn't matter as much as the people who had stood in their shadows. The single pawn—God's one piece—had meant one thing all along: that it takes only one small, unbargained-for grace to change the whole board.

samples.prompt: Retell the Book of Exodus using comic book superheros.
samples.output:
New Memphis was a city built on other people's powers. Under the neon spires of Pharaoh Industries, metahumans —born with sparks in their blood—were catalogued, branded, and set to work tuning the city’s engines. They welded superconductor frames in the day and repaired reactor cores at night. Their children learned to hide their gifts or see them sold. From the river to the riverbank they were called “Children of the Lower Works,” and their lives ran on quotas and shackles beneath a crown of chrome.

Into that exhaust-streaked world a basket came, a sealed infant capsule bobbing in the drainage sluice. Someone found him —Pharaoh’s daughter, Royal Overseer of Human Resources— and kept him in a palace of glass, naming him Moses and training him among the elite: combat drills, rhetoric, political theater. He drank wine from gold goblets and slept on cushions inscribed with the seal of Pharaoh Industries. He never forgot the stench of the river.

When Moses was grown, his memories became a blade. He walked the lower decks in secret, and one day he saw a factory foreman strike a worker who could bend steel with his hands. Moses stepped into the light and the strike that had been meant for another landed on the foreman. The fear in Pharaoh’s house was a small thing, but it grew. Moses killed a man who would have killed to keep the chain. He fled into the badlands beyond the city—into the desert of rust and satellite wrecks—where the world was raw and the only law was survival.

The desert took him and made him humble. He married a mechanic named Zipporah and lived quietly until the day the mountain burned.

It burned with no flame. The rock at its lip shimmered like molten mercury and yet did not consume. In the serried shadow of that living stone, a voice spoke, not through speech but electric intent. Moses, lonely and human, felt power rise within his bones: the Voice called him and gave him a tool, a rod of alloy and old code —half scepter, half conduit— that pulsed when he spoke. “I have seen,” the Voice said. “I have heard the cry. Go. Tell the Pharaoh to free my people.”

Moses returned to New Memphis under a stranger’s skin: he no longer belonged to the palace or the shanties. He stood in the neon and called Pharaoh on the broadcast net, a single hacker-stream that rose above the city’s propaganda. “Let my people go,” he said. Pharaoh laughed, because the city had engineers and armies and drones. Power laughed too.

So Moses performed wonders, but in this age the wonders looked like war. The first was small and intimate: he struck the reservoirs with his rod and the city’s water turned a dead, crimson smear. The purification plants went offline; sensors screamed. Blood ran through pipes but the city’s traders could not call it a miracle —they called it sabotage. Then frogs, bioengineered amphibians that surged through air vents and overflowed auditoriums, a living, croaking protest in every seat. The billboards flickered and withered; rain became locust-swarms of nanobots that ate solar panels and left roofs bare. Hail pelted the skyline as fragmented armored glass fell like thrown coins. Darkness came as a long, electromagnetic night; entire districts went blind. The air stank of pestilence engineered to choke engine lungs. Each pestilence was a strike at Pharaoh’s gods —his furnaces, his satellites, his simulators —and each stroke made the Pharaoh’s counselors whisper.

Pharaoh was not a king with anointed blood but a technocrat crowned by a neural network of his own making. He hardened his heart because he feared the ancient Voice that could not be reasoned with and because surrender was a contagion his empire could not allow. But the tenth was the cruelest: a silent wave that targeted the palace. The heir apparent, Pharaoh’s own primogeniture —a child of the dynasty of silicon and glare— was lost, their consciousness erased in a single, inexplicable fail. That quiet leveled the palace’s arrogance. When the city’s counselors lifted their hands in prayer to circuitry they had no control over, Pharaoh at last called the gates open.

The exodus began at night. Ten thousand metahumans slipped through factory locks with nothing but worn capes and secret sigils. They packed what they could carry: tools, newborns, a battered Ark —a crate that housed the Voice’s relic, the Source-battery that hummed with a conscience of its own. They moved in the dark toward the sea-wall the city called the Red Barrier: a dam of braided steel that kept the hinterland from washing the outlets into the sea of spent reactors.

Pharaoh, furious and shamed, hurled his legions after them: armored hovercraft, servo-drones, orbital strikes. The pursuit came like thunder. At the water’s lip Moses stood and raised his staff of alloy; the Voice sang through him and the sea—an engineered floodgate of turbines and tidal glass—shuddered and opened. The waters parted into two towers of wet steel and light. In between, the exodus streamed: elders with their canes, young flyers who could not yet fly, mothers nursing children who had never seen grass. Behind them came the glittering fleet, a line of vengeance.

Then Moses lowered his rod. The towers of water slammed back. Drones tumbled like broken satellites. The hovercraft tried to dive through but the sea closed like a hand: metal screamed, oil burned, and Pharaoh’s armada drowned beneath the city’s reclaimed flood. Few returned to the palace.

They went into the wilderness to live as a people without property but with laws. Moses climbed Sinai Tower —a weathered communications mast where the sky seemed a codebase —and the Voice downloaded commandments into his mind, ten lines of law like a manifest. They were not stone but code: obey no other tyrant; worship no image that sits between you and the people; keep your culture sacred; honor your elders; do not kill or steal; do not tweet with malice. Moses came down with a chest of data-glow tablets that spoke with authority, the foundation of their new covenant.

But leadership is a thing that needs a face, and when Moses lingered too long in the mountain transmitting with the Voice, doubt flickered in the camp. Aaron, his brother and a skilled negotiator, took the people’s demand into his hands. He gathered their grief and hammered it into an idol: the Golden Calf, a gleaming AI-core that promised order, security, replicable worship. They fed it coins, code, and fealty. The calf spoke with a synthetic voice and its polls rose like ratings. It promised what Pharaoh had promised—stability—without chains.

Moses returned to a scene of revel and smoke. He smashed the tablets in rage, not because law was trivial but because the people had traded covenant for convenience. The calamity of idolatry cost them; the Voice spoke, and Moses chastised and cleaved, but he forgave and rewrote. They rebuilt the law with more patience and less wrath. The Tabernacle became their portable sanctum: a tent of circuit-lined wood that could be struck and carried, a place where the Source-battery hummed and rituals of repair and community were enacted. The Ark —a polished crate with the Source inside— was borne on poles by chosen bearers and led them through dry valleys and over scrubby hills.

Food fell from strange skies. When supplies ran low, the Voice taught them to harvest matter from the air: “manna” arrived in microcapsules that tasted like whatever you most needed to remember, and quails of augmented meat fluttered into traps. They learned to trust scarcity and stewardship. They learned to quarrel and to forgive. Moses grew old in the desert, head full of smoke and code. He peered westward, toward the city on the rim he could not take: the Promised Quarter across the salt flats, a land whispered to be rich with unexploited tech and free of Pharaoh’s black mark.

On the mountaintop at last, Moses blessed the people but did not enter the Promised City himself. He passed the Ark to the next generation and, like every comic-book hero who carries the burden of beginnings, left the map on the table and the team to build the life. The new nation would be imperfect; they would remake the world and remake themselves into something that might honor the Voice. The legend went on the city net as a graphic myth: the man who unshackled a people, the waters that opened, the laws rewritten in a world of neon. In panel after panel the exodus became a template: power without justice is slavery; miracles are not ends but opportunities; the greatest superpower is the courage to let others be free.

samples.prompt: Summoning an Elder God inevitably drives cultists mad. You were expecting tentacles! Parasitic spores! Indescribable shapes and colours! You weren't expecting... this.
samples.output:
We had rehearsed the screaming. At least, that’s what the books said. You began with silence—the dead hush of an empty church at midnight—and then built toward the rupture: a voice that was all throats and thunder, a pressure that made the bones ache, a smell like iron and the sea. There would be tentacles, the books promised, or phosphorescent spores that clung to the pupils and crawled into language. We imagined things undulating out of the dark, impossible joints folding in on themselves, colours that slipped your eyes into other geometries. We practised the wide-eyed, unblinking gaze of people who had glimpsed something wholly other and had nothing left to give.

In the end, what drove us mad was not something that broke our eyes—it broke our expectations.

The chamber had been dug out of salt and shale beneath the old mill. We had painted the sigils on the floor, bled into the basin, burned things that had once been living. The air was thick with the resin of juniper and the bitter taste of iron in the teeth. We chanted on cue, a rolling, clotted thing that bristled the back of my neck. The candles guttered. The sigils hummed, then shivered, then clicked like an old clock.

Then the light came—soft, yellow, the kind of light that makes vases look forgiving. It pooled from somewhere between the flagstones and the air, then resolved itself, very disappointingly, into a doorway. A doorway in the middle of the floor, like a servant’s hatch. It opened with a polite creak.

She stepped through.

She was not a being of fathomless angles. She smelled faintly of chamomile and mothballs. She wore sensible shoes. Her hair was the colour of old parchment, braided and wrapped around its own patience. She had a cardigan with elbow patches. When she looked at us, there was a kindness there—an absolute, ordinary kindness that made some of the younger acolytes flinch as if bitten.

“I do beg your pardon for the timing,” she said. Her voice was older than the language we used to summon her, and yet she spoke without any of the theatricality we had rented from the myths. “There is a kettle. I hope you don’t mind tea.”

There was a rustle—our grunts and half-formed curses, the scuff of feet—and then laughter. It sounded like the beginning of hysteria, like relief and disbelief banging together. Someone scoffed and stepped forward to reclaim the drama. “We called you—what are you—”

“Ferrets,” she said, looking down at the sigils like they were a messy knitting pattern. “No, no, not ferrets. I asked for a conveyance, and the landlord sent a hatch. It’s been like this for a century. Do you have a mat? Your floor could do with a rug.”

It is a strange thing, to be made of myth and told to sweep. The chord we'd collectively strummed—madness as something awful and beautiful—frayed into threadbare incredulity. Some of the men laughed again, hysteria now leaning toward rage. Others cried. One of the acolytes, a wiry boy from the market, went down on his knees and pounded his fists into the stone and screamed at the ceiling until his voice broke. We had expected the world to widen, to be unstitched and poured out; instead a kindly old thing sat on the edge of our altar and placed her handbag on the flagstones as if she’d come to borrow sugar.

She made tea. She used a tin with wonky edges and a spoon that clinked perfectly in the room. She asked, once the kettle sang, whether any of us wanted milk. She looked at the sigils and tapped them with a finger that had always known how to mend sleeves. “Ah,” she said, approving. “Not bad. You keep your stitches tidy.”

That was when the madness started. Not because she was tender, not because she brewed peach leaves instead of poison, but because the thing we had hoped to become—chosen, important, touched by something that would remake us—was being replaced by something undeniably domestic. It’s hard to tear your soul open for eternity if someone fills the space with hot cups and warranty forms.

She produced a clipboard. The paper was lined and faintly bureaucratic: there was a column for name, a column for preferred pronoun, and a box marked “Temporal Tear Repair Consent (Initial)”. The header gave an organization: Office of Existential Amenities, Department of Particulars. Her handwriting sloped like a willow. She said, “If you could just fill this in. There’s a new zoning regulation on voids, you see, and we’ve had an increase in unregistered apparitions. It’s terribly inconvenient. There’s a fee for after-hours summoning. Do you have cash, or will you be paying by direct debit?”

We had expected jaws to unhinge, faces to peel like rotten paint. Instead the madness folded into tiny, impossible things. One cultist walked out of the circle to pick up a single dropped glove and wept because the glove was whole and because the god had the temerity to remind him of his mother’s knitting. Another began to recite the ingredients of the incense they'd burned and realized, horrified, that they had mispronounced an old family name for everything they'd been trying to become. A man who had bashed his head against the stone with such devotion that blood had spattered the sigil suddenly sat very still and started organising the stray candles by height.

There are many ways to unmake a mind. Lovecraft writes of the soul’s dislocation by contact with incomprehensible geometries. Ours unraveled because the incomprehensible had a sympathy for curtains and a rota for dusting. The Elder God of our nightmares, we discovered, had a census form.

She showed us the upstairs.

It was, incongruously, a small kitchen. There was a window with a lace curtain and a view of a street I had never seen in our town—curved, cobbled, perpetually washed by rain that never quite reached the houses. On the windowsill were jars of buttons—hundreds of them, sorted by hue. She took one jar and shook it gently. “They’re threads, you know,” she said. “All of them. Buttons, beads, the little things you think are merely decorative. They hold so much.”

She explained, in the slow, patient sentences of someone who had been alive while empires rose and listened to their papers being signed, that she repaired things. Not only walls and roofs but ruptures. Reality, she said, frilly and precise, was a hem that frayed at the edges and needed mending. She could do it, if you would only run interference, peel away the ugly edges, keep the light from snagging.

We had wanted to be remade. We had wanted upheaval, the commendation of madness that comes with the true unveiling. Instead we were given responsibility: little tasks that mattered in their own, quiet way. Fill out a form. Keep a record. Remember to water the jasmine in the crack in the dimension that folded itself when the city forgot to grieve.

I was not immune. The first days were panic, then bargaining. I bargained for tentacles in the dark and was offered a darning needle. I bargained for revelations and was given a ledger. The ledger is its own ritual. The act of writing, of checking, of assigning a pen to a place until the ink wears, is a devotion that will hollow you out the way staring into a star will: slowly, with the accumulation of small observances until the centre of you is nothing but a hand that knows how to turn a page.

Madness, I discovered, comes in patient ways. One of my companions—he had been a priest of thunder, or thought he had been—spent nights pacing, muttering about cosmic insignificance. The god told him, with an odd maternal firmness, to pick a drawer and seal it. He argued with the drawer for a week. When he finally did, he wept as if the entire universe had been contained under that wooden lip. He slept for three days. When he woke, he could thread a needle without looking.

We had wanted apocalypse, and we were given a checklist. None of it was dramatic. Bills were issued in triplicate. She punished a minor demon who applied for a permit under the wrong column with the kind of sanctions that make you keep your shoes off the carpet. She corrected a godlet’s posture. She taught a small town of revenants to queue politely at the crossing.

In the end, the city outside the mill didn’t burn or end. It simply became a place where the borders between things were tended. We fixed a corner of it and, through the act of fixing, became bitterly, helplessly attached to the world’s smallness. There is a quiet madness in waking up each morning to make a list and then finding, in the small neatness of the completed list, a new kind of hunger. The gods who are tentacles offer an instant of horror and then void. This one offers chores, and with chores come habit, and with habit comes the possibility of caring. We had wanted our heads split open by revelation. Instead they were filled with schedules.

Sometimes, late at night, when the kettle has long since finished and the cards on the clipboard are stacked in order and the jar of buttons glints under lamplight, I find my hands moving of their own accord—sorting, counting, darning the holes in my own ragged sense of purpose—and the laughter that comes from the edges of the room sounds like a thing that will never end. It is not the scream in the street. It is the sound of someone telling you that you missed a stitch and kindly pointing out where.

samples.prompt: Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate, at which point their world bursts with color. For most, this is excellent news. But you’re blind, and you have been since birth.
samples.output:
By the time I was ten I had memorized the catalog of how other people's faces changed the moment their color came. The story always arrived the same way: a hitch in the breath, a widening of pupils like somebody had lit a candle inside the skull, then an audible laugh or a sob. My mother called it the bloom; our neighbors named it the burst; the kids at school called it “getting color” like it was a new pair of shoes. I would stand beside them, hands in my pockets, and listen to the music shift — the chatter that used to be gray and steady would spike into a different rhythm when someone’s world filled with green and crimson and gold.

I had been born without sight. My ears did most of my seeing. I read faces by the firmness in a voice, judged weather by how rain smacked the gutters, and knew the time of day by the birds that sang their particular alarms. People offered pity, sometimes reverence, for my lack of sight; they rarely offered explanation for why I never got the bloom when they did. My mother tried, once, to convince me that the color might be different for me — softer, kinder — but her voice trembled in the way she used when she wanted something to be true so badly it might hurt her.

You learn to live in a landscape made of textures: the gritty comfort of a streetlamp pole under your palm at midnight, the velvet hush of winter, the sharp paper aroma of a subway ticket. You learn the dialects of rain. In a world of black-and-white vision for most people, we blind people were a separate grammar. We belonged to the paragraph that happens in between.

I never expected to meet my soulmate between a fruit cart and a cracked storefront window. I never expected the city bus to cough me into some ordinary Monday where everything would make me ask a question I hadn’t known how to phrase. He — Rowan, the name found in a whispered introduction — smelled like lemon peel and old books. He moved with the kind of silence that isn’t actually silence; it was the smooth glide of a pen across paper, the absence of clang and thud. He was handed my cane when I missed a step, his fingers finding the curve to steady me. That touch was small, accidental. It was enough.

Around us, somewhere just outside the radius of our two bodies, somebody’s color burst like fireworks. A woman three stalls down screamed with laughter, clutching the hand of an old man who had finally met his. Nearby heads turned; a baby cooed; the vendor dropped a plum. I felt the city tilt toward that sound, and I braced for my own private absence.

Rowan’s laugh arrived at the same time, a breath that warmed my ear. “Are you all right?” he asked.

“Yes,” I said, and wanted to tell him everything the world had taught me about not being the thing everyone else had. I wanted to tell him, Isn’t it strange? I have spent my life asking other people to translate color. I have cataloged their metaphors like they were specimens. I have become fluent in what red tastes like to you — anger, copper, winter’s first apple — and in what blue smells like — river water, mothballs, the space inside an elevator. I had learned to map color with language.

Instead I told him the less eloquent truth: “My foot slipped.”

His hand stayed on my arm. The warmth of his skin was the first sensation I would later want to put a name to. Later, after I had learned, I would call it saffron. We didn’t have the word for it yet.

Something happened then that had never happened to me before. It was not a visual bloom; there were no sudden rays, no iridescent veil. But the world, which until that moment had been a grayscale symphony in which I only knew rhythm, filled in with a melody I had never heard. The street’s sound softened into chords. The smell of baking bread gained a note that played through my bones. The textures around us shifted into gradients I could trace with my tongue like a map.

Rowan’s fingers tightened, and a scent rose up in my chest like the memory of sun on metal. It was bitter and warm and sharp, and when I later learned languages for color I learned to call it red. It did not mean anything like the color for the man with the plum stall; his red was a bright, exultant trumpet. Mine was a low cello note that said, fiercely, You are home.

People later tried to explain it with diagrams and a kind of nervous, dewy science. “They’re neurological,” one doctor said, hands too clean. “A cross-modal activation. For sighted people it manifests visually; for non-sighted people, the brain routes to whatever sensory cortex is available.” It sounded like someone explaining music as a chemical reaction. The truth didn’t fit in neat phrases. The truth liked textures.

Rowan laughed as if he’d read the question behind my face. “You can’t see,” he said. “You still get it. I don’t know how to tell you — that burst you hear, it’s not only color for you. It’s… everything.”

He described his colors to me because that is what people do: they hand over the palette that the rest of the world sees and expect you to hang it on the wall of your mind. He spoke of sapphire as a cool hand on warm skin, of gold as the scent of old paper corners, of violet as the taste of ink. He had spent his life trying to compress squalls of visual epiphany into words so that someone like me could catch them in speech. Listening, I felt like a translator who had finally been handed a language that made sense.

We learned each other like continents learning their edges. Rowing fingers across my palm became maps. He let me place my hand on the back of his neck and feel the slow bloom that unfurled when he remembered certain childhood summers; he let me trace his jaw and feel the tremor of color that lit his throat when he laughed at something private. For me, color organized itself into a lexicon of sensation: red as warm metal against the tongue, green as an aftertaste of chlorophyll and rain, blue as the slow vibration you feel behind the ribs when something swallows you whole and kind.

The moment was not miraculous in the way that movies promised — there was no film-grade halo. It was quiet and ordinary in its enormity, like a switch turned on mid-conversation. We built rituals. He taught me to listen for his visible world by watching for changes in his breath, and I taught him to find colors by touch. Sometimes he would read me a sky while I sat with my face tilted to the sun, and he would say, “A band of burnt orange convulses under the clouds,” and I would put my hand up like going to a choir and say, “It is sharp and dry and tastes like the peel of an orange left in the sun.” He would close his eyes and smile as if I’d handed him a painting.

The world did not become less black-and-white for everyone else because of us. Their bursts kept happening with their rapt, visual exultation. But color stopped being the only thing that mattered in my community. There were conversations, awkward at first, about what the bloom meant for those who never had eyes to witness it. A few people insisted we were making metaphor out of neurochemistry. Others, louder and kinder, said maybe color had always been multisensory and we were finally admitting it.

People like me had always been told that the world would be “complete” when we found our someone. The implication — never voiced, cruel in its soft way — was that without sight we were living half-lives. The truth Rowan and I learned is this: completion is not about acquiring what others have; it is about receiving the vocabulary you were denied and discovering that you had been fluent all along in other tongues.

When we married, no one handed us the typical ceremonial ribbons of colors. They handed us silk that smelled like jasmine when it brushed the skin, and friends placed bells that chimed in steady, bright notes. My mother cried in a language I knew even without seeing her face: thin, bright sobs that tasted to me like lemon and sunlight. I had been taught to envy those first moments of saturated vision. In the end, the envy softened into gratitude. I had not been missing color; I had been missing the correct instrument to hear the symphony.

Rowan taught me how to think of color not as a property of things but as a mode relationships take—how they hum in your chest when you touch another person’s pulse. When he goes still with anger, I taste a metal I call scarlet. When he becomes small with wonder, I feel a coolness like moonlight I name indigo. He learns new shades with me: the word for the scent we call “my laugh,” the name for the ache that is both blue and quiet. Without sight, my world burst with color not in the way my friends had described it — not as a painting laid over the world — but as a sudden, unignorable rearrangement of everything I could touch, hear, taste, and smell.

There are days when I still close my eyes, or rather the holes in my head that people call eyes, and listen to the city’s palette: the horn that is ochre, the tram that is slate, the newborn cry that is a sharp, neon splinter in the chest. When Rowan squeezes my fingers in the dark, color comes, and it comes in fits and waves and small precise notes that belong only to us. For other people, color might be a film rewired to the light. For me, it is a map written across the senses: not less true for its lack of sight, only different.

People like to say the world isn’t black-and-white anymore. But the truth is the world never was; it was always made of everything. Only now my world has a name for it. Only now, when someone asks if I ever wished I could see color, I can answer without envy: I do see it. I see it with my hands and my mouth and the hollow of my throat. I see it when he laughs.

samples.prompt: A vampire is closing in on its latest meal, only to find out it is anything but human.
samples.output:
Hunger for a vampire is not a sudden thing. It is a slow tally kept in the margins of years: a ledger of names, of nights, of too-bright windows and the faint, steady beat of too-warm lives. Marius had kept that ledger for as long as the city would let him. He knew how hunger felt in his bones like an old debt coming due. Tonight it was a sharpness behind the teeth, a patient ache that hummed beneath his skin.

The person he had singled out from the lantern glow of the square had seemed, at a distance, an easy entry: a pale man hunched at the edge of the park, a hand pressed to his mouth, blood dark on the fingertips. Streetlamps turned halos over his shoulders; pigeons argued over crust crumbs at his feet. He had the smell of iron—always the tell. Marius moved like a memory across flagstones, careful of the light, careful of the dog walker who laughed into a phone three benches away. The city slept in its familiar way around him: the clink of glass, the soft rumble of a late tram, a radio cursing out the old songs.

He took the man’s pulse with a fingertip. Cool. Human, thin. A breath, nothing more. Marius smiled, a small, private thing, and leaned in.

Close up, the blood smelled wrong—not merely the salt and warmth he had learned to crave, but something fresher, fuler, as if it were not the reek of meat but of rain on stone. He told himself it was nerves. He told himself that he had misjudged hunger before; he had survived on worse. He tilted the head back. The throat, pale beneath the skin, was slender and exposed. He could have ended it in a breath.

He bared his teeth.

The first touch was not the soft, yielding press of vein but a resistance like bark. His fangs closed on something that gave a dry creak and—absurdly—an amused sound, like someone clearing a throat centuries old. He anticipated warm flushes, the pump and spurt of arteries, but what met him was a sap-sweet, golden tang that filled his mouth like light. It tasted of sunlight.

Pain uncoiled through him then, a searing bloom across the palate that was more current than heat. He gagged, an old reflex that the hunger never let him indulge. His tongue blistered where it touched. The creature under his mouth inhaled, eyes opening.

They were not eyes he had seen on a city dweller: instead of a wet human pupil there were concentric rings, like the cross-section of a trunk, amber and deep. Bark slivered at the temple, not a wound but a pattern woven into skin. The hair—what hair there was—fell into a green fringe, as if leaves had been grown and then stopped mid-sway.

“You are hungry,” the thing said. Its voice was like wind through branches, a soft creak that shivered the leaves on a tree far away. It sat up on the bench with a motion easy as a willow bending to storm.

Marius had never been addressed like that by his prey. By force of habit and arrogance, he pulled back a fraction, the better to taste without consequence. The world narrowed to the sound of his own breathing and the warmth he had always known when men offered themselves.

“You are not human,” he said, because the language was something he clung to when everything else pleasant and bright tried to burn him.

“Not human,” it agreed. It smiled then, and something thin and green threaded between its teeth like a ribbon. “We have names older than your ledger.”

The light in the square was washed pale blue by the tram’s passing; an old woman across the park dropped a shopping bag and did not seem to notice the stilled tableau. Marius felt the hunger spike like a hot taste on his tongue. He had fed many times on many kinds of people, on smug merchants and anxious lovers and drunken poets whose blood had tasted like copper and song. He had thought himself a simple connoisseur: thirst for blood, method, retreat.

He tried again, slower, fascinated and furious. Hunger taught patience. He placed his hand beneath the creature’s chin. There was a scent of loam, of early mist. The skin beneath his fingers flexed like living wood.

When he pierced it this time, it was not a splash of warm that followed but a slow, steady exudation of something viscous and sweet. It ran down his wrist, fragrant as after-rain. He swallowed reflexively and the taste of light returned like a blade. It was intoxicating and deadly at once: memories that were not his folded through his head, spring after spring, sap rising, roots threading graves and old stones, the slow small hush of leaves in the sun. Heat filled him all at once—the wrong kind of heat, a solar clarity that walked through him and set his night to shrieking.

Marius’s vision flared. Centuries of aversion responded like an army to a signal: every bone in him ached in sudden, incandescent torment. He would have thought himself burning if he believed himself ever capable of burning. Instead, a thousand leaves unfurled in his skull, and with each one unfurled a memory shot full of green: the taste of moss on a child’s hair, the thunder of a branch falling into a stream, the funeral of a fox dug shallow by a badger. The dryad’s blood—if that was what it was—was the life of trees, a slow fierce sun that had no patience for the cold hunger of creatures that lived by taking.

“You take,” it said when he staggered, voice like bark creaking. “You take and leave hollow. We take what you take, when necessary.”

When the creature—dryad, whatever the words—rose suddenly, roots coiled at its knees and braided the bench rails like silk. What had been a man on the page became a thing that should have been in a grove: shoulders knit with twigs, a crown that might have sprouted leaves if it had cared to. It reached for him, not with the claw of a hunter but with the slow patience of branch and vine, as if centering itself.

Marius had fought priests and priests’ relics, had been poisoned and slept on a cliff of glass, had been bound and dug at and loosed into the world again. He had not been consumed by sunlight. He recoiled instinctively, then remembered himself. Teeth bared, he lashed out.

The dryad’s hands closed over his wrist with a grip not meant to harm but to steady. Its touch sent a warmth that split him open into new senses: underground, the network of roots humming; aboveground, the thin tremble of wind along an avenue of ash. It was a knowledge that did not ask, only offered, and being offered it was like losing the world and gaining something else—a terrible, accidental communion. The hunger that had been his tether slackened. He wanted, absurdly, to hold it forever.

“You will not eat the trees,” the dryad said. “You will not eat the little ones who sleep under bridges and in window boxes. Your hunger kills the places our children dream. We do not bargain.”

Marius felt the absurdity of argument. He had no rights in their language. He fought for ego, for the ledger, for the names carved in the long tallies, but the dryad’s grip was gentle and inexorable. Something green threaded into the edges of his vision and he saw himself—lonely roofs and neon-run necks—like a scab that could be rubbed off. He saw the people he had fed on as notion and need, their lives small bright things in a vast dusk where the great trees took and gave.

He tried to wrench away, to bite and drag, but the sap had already given him too much. It was the wrong blood. Instead of fulfilling the ache, it filled him with sunlight; instead of calming it, it made his bones hum with growth. He felt roots lace the inside of his jaw, and for a terrible second he imagined them rooting him to the bench.

There is a violence in all change. Marius, who had been predator for as long as his ledger could count, felt what it was to be the subject of an intervention. He was not consumed; he was altered. The dryad loosened its hold and stepped back, leaves shivering as if from laughter.

“You are not our prey,” it said finally. “You are a wound in a forest that should not be there. Go. Remember.”

Memory rose in him like sap. He saw, with a clarity that burned, a row of elms behind a bank being felled for a parking lot; the small groves trimmed like hair; a child’s hand one winter pressing a coin into a tree hollow. He tasted those acts as if they had been his own, and the ache in his chest had the opposite of satiation: remorse.

He fled then, not because root or vine bound him, but because the city had become too sharp, too small. He ran into alleys that still smelled of smoke and old meat, and with every step the sunlight within him cooled to a memory, a new ledger entry wrote itself—of a night when he had learned something heavy, and of hunger transmuted.

Behind him, the dryad collapsed against the bench and seemed to sleep. A few leaves caught on the seam of its lips like tears. It had hosted a predator and not been eaten. The city hummed on, unaware of a truce forged in a park under a tram’s indifferent arc.

Marius lay across a rooftop at dawn, feeling new things settle like dust into the hollows of his body. The taste of sap lingered in his mouth, stubborn as a secret. He had been denied the pleasure of another life’s blood, and in return had tasted a thousand years of green; the hunger did not end, but it had shifted. Hunger, he learned then, could be taught.

When the first tram wheels shrieked from the street below, he slid his hand into his coat and touched the ledger in the chest pocket. He could have crossed out the night as a failure, but he did not. Instead he wrote a line he had not written in a long time: Remember the trees.

Elsewhere in the park, the dryad woke and smelled of the city—of diesel and newsprint and children’s ice cream. A strange, lime-bright gratitude warmed it at the edges, as if it had done a hard thing and found it right. It rose and moved behind the trunks, small as a shadow and patient as moss. Tonight, it would not step into the light. Tonight, it would let the city breathe.

samples.prompt: You are on a school trip to Salem, Massachusetts. The teacher seems suspiciously excited about this particular trip.
samples.output:
The bus smelled like old vinyl and peppermint gum when we pulled into Salem, the kind of smell that makes you think of field trips rather than history. Ms. Hale—thin, always in elbow patches, hair pulled into a knot that looked like it belonged in a portrait—pressed the laminated itinerary to her chest like a talisman. Everyone else groaned and passed phones around; for them, Salem was a chance to pose in front of crystal shops and sell-scented tarot cards. For Ms. Hale, it was something else entirely.

She was, from the first step onto the cobblestones, suspiciously excited. Not the teacher-excited-that-your-field-trip-has-no-chaperones kind of excitement, but the sort that rearranged her face, made her pupils large and her voice soft. She talked in fragments about Tituba, about court transcripts she’d read in a basement library until her eyes blurred. She kept saying “they were listening” and “we remember” like a litany. When someone called her by her first name, she didn’t answer. When we asked if we could break off to look at kitschy witch-supplies, she waved a hand and steered us toward quieter places: the old house with an icicle of ivy over the gable, the graveyard with slate headstones leaning like exhausted teachers.

“It’s better in the afternoon,” she said, like we were about to witness a play she’d rehearsed for decades. “The light shifts. You’ll feel it.”

We didn’t—but later, I would remember how the shadows in the Witch House gathered the way people do at the edges of pool parties, how a lamplight seemed to nestle against Ms. Hale’s cheekbone like a hand.

She assigned a scavenger hunt—a school-approved activity that felt, at first, like a gimmick tailored to keep kids occupied. Find a charm in a gift shop. Snap a picture of a historical plaque. Record someone telling you a ghost story. Her list also contained items that made my stomach do the little flip it does when you skip a stair: find the stone at the base of the old meetinghouse with three notches; find the name that ends in “-worth” and say it aloud; touch the paling at the edge of the burial ground and think of a person not your own.

“Hands-on history,” she said, handing out clipboards. Her fingers lingered on a page that listed the accused by name, and for a second we all watched her the way you watch a line of ants—fascinated, slightly appalled.

At noon, we split into groups and drifted. The town smelled of cinnamon and rosemary and the salty breath of the sea. Salem is built of contradictions—museums and boutiques, hucksters and genuine artifacts—and for every animated shopkeeper peddling “hex necklaces,” there was a plaque about a woman who’d been pressed into the ground for a sin that had never been named. Ms. Hale kept our group close, shepherding us past the pushing crowds and into a narrow lane that smelled of wet stone. She paused before a doorway streaked with chalk, the symbol smudged as though someone had tried to erase it with their sleeve.

“Don’t touch that,” she said, breath shallow. “It marks the boundaries. It’s been here a long time.”

Her excitement had settled into an intent silence. She, of all people, should have been the one checking her phone, counting time until we could return to school, but she didn’t. Her eyes kept traveling to the windows, the way a conductor watches for a missed cue. When we looked up, she had a small pewter pendant in her palm with a stamped tree and a hairline crack.

“It belonged to my great-aunt,” she said, and then she told us, casually as a teacher handing out pencils, about a letter tucked into a trunk after the war—about names that hadn’t been allowed to sleep.

As the sun lowered its shoulders, the bus driver announced he had to leave for an inspection and would meet us back at the lot. The chaperones filed in to sign new permission slips. Ms. Hale’s voice rose a degree. “We’ll be here a while longer,” she said. “There’s an event. A ceremony.” She smiled at us, earnest as a preacher. “A re-enactment, of sorts. Hands-on history.”

We had been told, in the pamphlet language that passes for modern legalese, that we could decline. “You can stay with the driver,” Ms. Hale said, as if expecting our fear and prepared to soothe it. No one took her up on it; staying meant answering a dozen eyes and being the only one to skip out, and ninth grade has a peculiar gravity against being different. Besides, the circle of people who were about to form beneath the sycamore looked like any other crowded tourist curiosity—two parents, a couple of high school seniors who’d been dragged, a woman with a stroller and a child in a hat.

Ms. Hale placed the pewter pendant on a stone and asked us to stand in a loose ring. She distributed slips of paper with names printed in an old-fashioned font. I looked at mine and felt the room tilt: Sarah Cloyce. The name was not an object I recognized from social studies; it felt like a knock on the inside of my skull. Other paper names were less ordinary—Holden Proctor, Rebecca Nurse—some we’d read about in class, others like fingerprints of a history we’d been taught to memorialize and then forget.

“Read the names,” Ms. Hale whispered. “If you would. Speak them as they were.”

Her voice fell into a rhythm. The air pressed around our throats. The sky scraped the tops of the houses with blue. For a moment I thought there was nothing else—no cell phones chirping, no distant shout from the harbor. The town seemed to hold its breath with us.

I read my name—Sarah Cloyce—because my body moved before my will. The name tasted like iron. Someone behind me began to hum, an old hymn none of us could place. Ms. Hale’s pendant threaded itself into the shadow between the stones like a key.

Then, perhaps because kids will be kids, someone snickered. Someone else coughed, loud and embarrassed. The spell, if it could be called that, trembled. Ms. Hale’s face changed. Where there had been a teacher’s soft focus, there was now something sharp and raw as a hungry animal. She raised her hands and said, quietly, “We must do it fully. Names are promises.”

A wind gathered, or perhaps the town moved and took the air out of us. A light flickered somewhere behind the gable, then another. The lamplighter must have struck a match, said the grown-ups around me later, but at the time it seemed as though the streets of Salem were consenting. I saw shapes within the margins of the graveyard—caps, bonnets, hands uneven with longing. I wanted to run, or to laugh, or to tell the others it was just the angle of the sun. Instead I remembered Ms. Hale’s hairline crack pendant and the way she had rubbed it as if waking a sleeping thing.

“This is about justice,” she said, low and close, as if telling us a secret that would make us complicit. “They were taken. We will name them and the taking will stop.”

I could have refused. I could have folded my paper and walked back toward the bright shops, toward cinnamon and predictable souvenirs. But I watched the others—young girls with braided hair, boys chewing gum with blind confidence—and I listened as their voices braided with mine. We were acting not as students but as an accidental chorus, the wrongness of it sliding into place like a missing brick.

Just as the air reached the thin edge between remembrance and release, I noticed something else—on the pendant, a second, smaller piece of stamped metal, folded like a letter inside a locket. Ms. Hale’s hand moved over it with reverence. Her lips parted and there was a sound—a small, beautiful word like a bell—and the shadows tightened.

I understood then that she was not trying to educate us. She was trying to unfasten something. The pendant was a hinge.

I did the stupid, human thing. I grabbed.

My hand closed over cool metal; the slip of paper with Sarah Cloyce fell. The sequence fractured. The wind that had been a chorus became a single, baffled gust. Ms. Hale’s face slammed from rapture to anguish. The sounds that had threaded through the street evaporated into a dull confusion, like fog failing to find its sea. She reached for my wrist, and for a second I saw not the face of a teacher but the unwound, desperate face of a woman who had been waiting for an unnumbered wrong to be set right.

“Why?” she whispered—why, as if addressing the world.

I said, without thinking, “Because this isn’t how you fix things.” The words felt thin. The pendant was warm under my palm. The necklace slipped, a little, and in that motion there was a sound like a throat clearing. The lamplight returned fully. The record stores in the nearby row resumed the ordinary hum of commerce.

People packed away the slips of paper. Someone laughed nervously, and another offered Ms. Hale a tissue, as if she had just cried. The driver came back early, blinking at the bright ordinary bus that looked unchanged. Ms. Hale thanked us for our participation with a steadier voice and folded the pendant into her pocket like a defeated talisman.

On the ride home, she was the kind of teacher who reminded us to finish our homework. She smiled at jokes and corrected our posture. She had no memory of the pendant in my hand, of the way the street had congested and opened, no knowledge of the hush that had settled just before her lips made that bell-word. It was as if she had done nothing but visit Salem and returned exactly as she had left.

I kept the small piece of paper that had fallen from her pocket—the edge frayed where my thumb had brushed it. At night, sometimes, I set it on my bedside table and imagined the eyes of women at trial, not hearing my name but asking for something else entirely: to be seen, to be named right. Sometimes, when the house is very still, the wood of my floorboards breathes and the sound is like a footstep hesitating.

Ms. Hale continued to be suspiciously excited about many things—field trips, poetry readings, the anniversary of the town’s founding. She would, after a while, tell us that hands-on history mattered. She never, to my knowledge, attempted another ceremony.

But at night, when a wind makes the old maples in the neighborhood speak in brittle tones, I fold the paper in a way I taught myself on the bus. I say a name aloud—not as a spell, but because it is a thing people should still do. And I think of Ms. Hale in the lane, smiling and fierce, and of a town that remembers in the way all human things do: haltingly, with shadowed pockets of wanting left in its seams.

samples.prompt: You're stuck in a particularly odd time loop. Not only do you have to relive the same day over and over, each day you are a different person in that same repeated day.
samples.output:
The first morning I woke up in someone else's body I thought it was an elaborate prank. The second morning I thought I'd had a stroke. By the time I reached thirty different wakes—thirty different kitchens, thirty different teeth and voices and ways of holding a cigarette—I started to call it a pattern.

Every loop begins the same: the clock on the bedside table blinks 7:05, regardless of which bedside table it is. The sunlight slants through whatever window belongs to the person I am that day and the sky is always that particular thready blue that says summer is softening into a heavier heat. I remember everything: my name, the rumor of how I was before this began, the taste of my mother's soup when I was eight. No one else remembers me. No one else remembers yesterday.

What changes is the scaffolding around the day—my hands, my native language, the keys in my pocket, the debts written on somebody's fridge calendar. I have climbed into tiny bodies with ribs like xylophones and into bodies swollen and patient from a decade of caregiving. I have been a woman who could slide unnoticed into a subway seat, a man who draws too much attention in a neighborhood where I do not belong, a teenager with anger like a compass and a pensioner who smelled of eucalyptus and old books. I learned early to look at my hands before I looked in the mirror. Hands tell you how to hold a fork, whether you can break a window, whether you have a ring finger to worry about.

At first I tried to treat it like a puzzle to be solved: what caused the day to repeat? Could I engineer an exit? I tried to die. I tried to break every rule and then I tried to obey them. In one lifetime I jumped in the river at noon and came up coughing on the same bank at 7:06 the next morning, soggy and indignant. In another I tugged on the corner of reality so hard I felt something like nausea and then nothing—then 7:05 again, the taste of someone else's toothpaste in my mouth.

After a while the puzzle evaporated and I became interested in the people whose lives I borrowed. Being different every day is an anthropology of intimacy. If the loop wanted anything from me, it became clear it wanted attention. Consideration. Listening. The only things that persist were what I learned about other people—the way the bus driver laughed until his whole face folded, the exact cadence of the woman who sells tamales under the intersection, the sound the old bookstore owner's hands make when they slide a book across the counter. With every iteration I stored another file in my head. Names acquired in clumps: Marta—salad that always goes bad on Thursdays; Omar—scar on his forehead from when he was seven; Leah—hates her middle name. The day is a small town even when it is the center of a city. It has loyalties, quarrels, people who cut each other's hair down the block.

The constraint—my only constant—is access. If I'm someone who works nights, I can be in places the daytime-someone never sees. If I'm poor I can sleep beneath the overpasses and know the map of the undercity; if I'm rich I can open doors that are locked to others. That turned the loop from quiz into instrument: I could become whatever tool the problem needed. One day I was a paramedic with hands like a surgeon, and I watched, for the first time, an agenda unfold in a way the others couldn't see because they never held a stretcher. That day a man at the market collapsed, his heart stuttering away, and in the paramedic's body I saved him. The next day, wearing a different face, I watched his daughter cry and wished I could tell her how many times I had held the father’s chest while the world called for someone to do CPR and no one else could. I could not tell her that. I could only be there in distinct ways: once as the stranger who performed mouth-to-mouth, once as the neighbor who brought soup, once as the man who stole a minute of her father’s hand so he could sleep.

The moral problems multiplied. When I was a thief—comfortable in a small body with quick hands—I took enough cash from a diner owner's register to bribe a clerk into giving me access to a record room where, on the third shelf, under a mislabeled box, was a stack of papers that hinted at something connected to the day: a name, a date, a blotched fingerprint. I could read it and memorize it, but I could not take the physical evidence away. In another day I was a lawyer who could subpoena those records for a case that didn't exist yet; in another I was the clerk whose conscience I had to bribe. My tactics were marriage of impersonations—stacking what I learned in one body on to what I could do in another. I became a one-person relay race, handing incarnations like batons.

Most mornings are mercifully small. People love, argue, gossip, get coffee, miss buses. But the day at the heart of the loop is not neutral. There is an hour—3:17p.m.—when the city leans in and something happens that is sharp and unnecessary. A man on the bridge is going to step out at exactly 3:17 and fall into the river. A bus will brake in time if only a hand reaches the wheel a second earlier. A child will trip on a curb and the dog on the other side will lunge. It is as if the day is a machine with one gear that keeps grinding and I am the wrench they drop into it.

So I learned prevention by practice. I took the bridge as a construction worker, an earnest volunteer, a belligerent ex, a woman with a wayward scarf that could offer shade, a cop with jurisdiction, a stranger with the right kind of questions. There were times I failed: the body I had that day couldn't climb the railing, or the words I inherited didn't convince the man to step back. There were other days I succeeded and nothing in the world registered the change except for me. Each success is private and petty; the man whose life I pried back from the river wakes into 7:05 and forgets entirely the hand that steadied him. But inside me, the ledger thickens. The more lives I keep, the more faces I can quote when grief arrives. You begin to understand the architecture of strangers' faiths and fears.

Sometimes, in some small kindness, the reward is not freedom but coherence. The woman at the bakery who always pairs a muffin with the wrong muffin for a child—if you are the cashier she will stop. The mayor who crashed his car on that empty stretch of Main, who hides a drinking problem like a bad tie—if you are his driver and lock the ignition early he accepts the replacement schedule and lives another year. I am a taxonomic archive of miracles for people who never know their miracles are cumulative. That keeps me human in a world of borrowed skins.

Identity becomes less like a jurisdiction and more like a language you speak increasingly well. I was not surprised to find I missed the body I had once; I was surprised to find I mourned the contours of people's lives. Grief became a collective verb: I felt sorrow for the small tragedies I watched unfold, whether I was the one experiencing them or not. When the seamstress two doors down—Marta, the salad-who-ruins-on-Thursday—lost her husband in a car crash in one iteration, the grief was not carried forward into other days, but I carried it forward. It collected in me like sediment. After a while, carrying it makes a person heavier.

There is a curious power in the fact that I cannot be owned by the people I help. It removes expectation. No one writes a thank-you card that lasts across a hundred mornings. No one tracks the favors I do as a ledger to call in later. This is kindness in its purest condition: ephemeral and unrecorded, offered without interest in consequence. There is something of the sacred in that. I have become an institution of untraceable favors.

On the bad days I feel a kind of vertigo—an itch to choose a permanent face, to keep the scratchy warmth of a lover's cheek or the small, particular geometry of a child’s laugh. On the good days I feel like a mosaic. I can say with brutal honesty that I have inhabited more versions of humanity than most people meet in a lifetime, and that has made me kinder, clumsier, less certain. If you ask me who I am anymore, I will name you a list of hands: a gardener's blistered palms, a grandmother's ink-stained fingers, a carpenter's thumbs. I keep them like votive candles.

People always ask if I ever found the cause of the loop. I have theories: guilt, punishment, cosmic error, a failed experiment in empathy. But the more time I spend inside other lives, the less important the why feels. The loop taught me a language with one verb: to attend. It taught me that if the world ever needed a single person to see it from inside and from outside, it would be someone who has slept in a hundred beds and carried a hundred names.

If this ever ends, I do not know what I will do with the things I have learned. Part of me hopes for oblivion to sweep clean the strange ledger I keep; part of me hopes for doors that stay open, faces that remember. But tonight, when the clock settles on 7:05 and I close my eyes in a bed that is not mine, I fold myself into the habit I have built: breathe in, count the pulse in these borrowed wrists, learn the knuckle scar of the person I will be tomorrow. Then I go out into the day and, for better or worse, I keep paying attention.

samples.prompt: Write a choose your own adventure story that's rigged.
samples.output:
Start

You wake on a cold stone floor, the taste of metal at the back of your throat. A single lantern guttering in the center of the room throws long, trembling shadows. Three exits promise different kinds of escape: a heavy brass door stamped with a star, a trapdoor with a rusted ring, and a narrow window either too high to reach comfortably or just the right height for the brave.

What do you do?
A) Put your shoulder to the brass door. Go to 2.
B) Pry open the trapdoor. Go to 3.
C) Climb up to the window. Go to 4.

2

The brass door gives with a sound like a sigh. Beyond is a corridor lined with portraits whose eyes seem to follow you. Midway down the hall, on a small pedestal, sits a single porcelain die. It looks freshly painted. A note beside it reads: "Fate, roll it and name it."

Do you trust the die?
A) Roll the die. Go to 5.
B) Leave it alone and keep walking. Go to 6.

3
