The trapdoor dumps you into a roughly hewn cell. A bedroll, a bowl, and a shaggy dog sharing the damp corner greet you. On the wall someone has nailed a playing card: the jack of spades. Beneath it a scrap of paper says, "Loyalty is a choice."

Do you try to befriend the dog?
A) Call to the dog and offer your hand. Go to 5.
B) Ignore the dog and inspect the cell for exits. Go to 6.

4

The window leads to a narrow ledge under a slant of moonlight. A crow cocks its head from a chimney above, its beady eye gleaming with what might be mockery. You spot a key wedged in soot near the flue.

Do you try to reach the key?
A) Climb up for the key. Go to 5.
B) Shoo the crow and continue around the ledge. Go to 6.

5

Whatever you did—rolled, befriended, reached for the key—the world permits a small reward. The die shows a six, the dog inclines its head and finds a loose flagstone, or the key turns in ancient locks. You step into a larger room with a spiral staircase to the left and a rope ladder descending into a well to the right. Warm light filters up the well; cool air rushes down the stair.

Where do you go?
A) Take the staircase. Go to 7.
B) Climb down the ladder. Go to 8.

6

Your caution costs you time, or perhaps it grants you a lesson. The die remains unrolled; the dog curls away; the crow steals your hat. As the minutes slip, a small hatch opens in the far wall and you find yourself before essentially the same larger room—spiral staircase to the left, rope ladder to the right. Whether fortune smiled a moment or not, here you are.

Where do you go?
A) Take the staircase. Go to 7.
B) Climb down the ladder. Go to 8.

7

The staircase is marble-worn and smells faintly of lemon and old paper. At the top is a gallery where music seems to echo from nowhere. In the center of the gallery floats a small book on a column, its pages fluttering though there is no breeze. The binding has two covers: one red, one blue. They look like two different promises.

Which cover do you choose?
A) Open the red cover. Go to 9.
B) Open the blue cover. Go to 10.

8

The ladder slaps the air as you descend into a circular chamber. The walls here are lined with tiny drawers, each labeled with a single word—"regret," "mended," "paper," "noise." A lamp hangs from a chain in the middle. On a little table, lying among spilled cards and a handful of keys, a small book waits. It is identical to the one upstairs, with a red cover on one side and a blue cover on the other.

Which cover do you choose?
A) Open the red cover. Go to 9.
B) Open the blue cover. Go to 10.

9

You lift the red cover and expect a story of fire, courage, or inevitable sacrifice. The first line reads: "This book knows you better than you remember yourself." You turn the page. Somewhere, ink runs like a rumor. A tiny voice in the margin notes, "Ah—red. Bold." The text alters itself as you read; a sentence that seemed to promise heroism now admits a different metric: that choices are sometimes sleights.

If you decide to accuse the book of cheating, do you:
A) Slam it shut and throw it into the pit. Go to 11.
B) Keep reading, trying to find an honest line. Go to 12.

10

You turn the blue cover and expect cool air, clever trickery, a path that rewards patience. The opening line is the same as in the red: "This book knows you better than you remember yourself." The book sighs as if embarrassed and the words shimmer. The text offers a footnote that reads, "You think you chose blue. Interesting." The more you read, the more the sentences slide to teetering confessions about this room and the person who arranged it all.

If you decide to question the book openly, do you:
A) Demand to know who rigged this. Go to 11.
B) Look for some secret back page—some loophole. Go to 12.

11

You shout into the book and the chamber listens. "Who rigged this?" you call, voice scraping the ceiling. The book answers not in words but with a slow creak of the building reassembling itself like a storyteller clearing its throat.

A scratch appears on the margin, neat and tiny, as if written with a quill that knows your name: "I did. We did." The book flips closed, and when it opens again there is a photograph tucked between pages—a photograph of you, asleep on the stone floor at the very beginning of all this, the brass door slightly ajar in the background. Someone had watched you decide you wanted to be tested. The note below the photo reads, "Choices are entertainment. Conclusions are mine."

You can either:
A) Accept this and ask for a boon. Go to 13.
B) Tear the page out. Go to 14.

12

You search the margins, prod sentences for loose threads, but the text folds around your fingers the way a glove mends to a fist. Sometimes a paragraph will pretend to be a window; sometimes a footnote will wink. The conclusion, however, is stubbornly practical: it tells a story that ends in the same way regardless of the embellishments—a door opens, and someone steps into daylight.

When you reach the end the paper is warm. The book turns to a single last line, printed centrally and inescapably: "All roads led here because someone set the map." Below it, in a hand you know without being able to name, someone has written, "You like choosing. I like watching."

You have two small rebellions left:
A) Close the book and walk out anyway. Go to 13.
B) Write your own line in the margin. Go to 14.

13

The boon is small. The watcher—call them the Gamekeeper, the Author, the Person Who Likes Experiments—admits, "You can take one thing from this house that will not be altered." The book slides a single key toward you, warm from the telling of the sentences. "It opens a chest in the market town. For the rest: you get to feel like you chose."

Do you take the key? Of course you do. The key is brass and heavy and, for once, its teeth match a lock. You step out of the house into late afternoon sunlight, the world full of colors you feel you have earned. The rigging remains, but you have a key and a memory of having picked between brass and trap and night. The Gamekeeper clasps their hands in satisfaction.

The End—rigged, polished, and slightly consoling.

14

You try to strike a true, disruptive note. You tear a page. You write in the margin. You throw the book into the pit. The house answers the way a particularly patient mind does: by rewiring the consequences to include your rebellion as if it were a delightful spice. The torn edge becomes a talisman; your marginal note is copied, distributed, and used to unlock a drawer labeled "Defiance," which contains, disappointingly, only a small wooden token engraved with one word: CHOICE.

You step out of the house carrying that token. Outside, the town seems unchanged. People barge about living their lives. The token grows warm in your palm, as if insisting that the liberty it symbolizes is yours to interpret, not theirs to grant.

The End—rigged, irreverent, and quietly yours.

Epilogue (for the curious reader)

If you threaded through each corridor and tried every path, you will find the same three doors when you wake again. The house is patient. It knows the appetite for agency and feeds it doses of spectacle and sorrow. Its rigging is not cruelty so much as curiosity: whoever set the game wanted to see whether being allowed to choose would satisfy you.

You did choose. You did not escape being chosen. The point, perhaps, is that rigging does not entirely erase freedom; it flattens it into a more honest question: what will you do with the small true things you are permitted?

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
I told them I had the flu.

Not the literal kind — no fever, no nose like a faucet — just the kind that makes you invent a throat that aches and a doctor who recommends bed rest and a "no work" note you can email the HR inbox. I'd been carrying that kind of ache for months: email after email from Derek insisting on “just one more revision,” the way he inhaled during meetings like he could take the oxygen out of the room, the way he called my proposals "ambitious" in front of everyone and "unrealistic" in his one-on-ones. I told myself I was taking a mental health day. I told myself three days, a tiny island, a resort that promised fresh air and cocktails with umbrellas, would make me remember the part of me that existed before spreadsheets.

The island was called Pelican Key on the website — a tiny crescent of sand that looked like a thumbnail on the map between two larger, more sensible places. The resort's marketing photos were all white linen and hammocks, so I booked the longest weekend I could carve out, packed a book I'd been meaning to read since forever, and lied to my calendar about having "urgent personal matters." I printed the fake doctor's note, rolled it, and felt absurdly decisive.

I nearly made it to the water.

The plane smelled like warmed plastic and citrus mouthwash, the sun making the aisle into a stripe of bleached gold. I was doing the thing people do on short flights — pretending sleep that isn't quite sleep — when I looked up and realized the aisle was full of people I recognized with the terrible intimacy reserved for the office fluorescent lights. Derek was standing there, forehead creased in that way that meant he had a problem he could monetize. He was shorter in person, and his tie had a bird-of-prey pattern I hated on principle.

And in the seat directly behind him was Sam.

Sam, who had been my boyfriend for a year and my headache for three months after because that's how long knotty goodbyes take. Sam, who had left an hour before he said he would on our anniversary, who liked to leave passive-aggressive sticky notes on my steering wheel, who once posted a song with the line "hope it hurts" to their Instagram the week we broke up. Sam, who looked like they were biting their lip now, watching Derek with an almost conspiratorial grin.

My throat went dry in a way that had nothing to do with the fake flu. I could have turned around, slid into the restroom and sat on the closed toilet for the hour, but then Sam's eye caught mine and they raised one eyebrow like the epithet it was.

"Small world," Sam said when they passed me on their way to the lavatory. It was not a question.

Derek didn't look at me then, and maybe he didn't even know I was on the plane until we were taxing and the flight attendant announced something about the safety demo. Maybe I was being paranoid. Maybe both of them had booked long before I bought my ticket. Maybe the island had that gravitational pull for the overcompensating and the vengeful.

The resort was what websites promise: palm trees that bent like they were in conversation with the breeze, a bar that leaned into the sea, staff with smiles so wide they belonged in postcards. It felt obscene to be annoyed here, like temper tantrums were improper with a coconut in hand. For five minutes I indulged in the idea that I could walk past Derek and Sam like they were ants on my path.

On the second morning, I wrestled the motel-issue Wi-Fi long enough to check Slack, then pushed the phone into my bag and went to the beach. It was, I admit, a little delicious to watch Derek attempt to be inconspicuous. He could have been incognito if he removed the loudly corporate polo, but men like him don't have an off switch; they have a lower power mode with sarcasm instead of empathy.

Then Sam found me.

They didn't storm up and froth like I expected. They approached the lounge chair with a precision that announced they'd had time to craft a weaponized smile. "Fancy seeing you here," Sam said, perched at the end of the lounger like they owned the shade.

"You're not on anyone's emergency contact list," I said, trying to sound half-amused and failing.

Sam's mouth tightened. "We're together, Ava. You knew that. I thought we'd saved you the trouble of a dramatic read receipt."

They said it with such flatness I realized the real slap was in the simplicity. The man I reported to was apparently now traveling with my spiteful ex like they were planning a joint venture in being awful.

Derek arrived then, palms open as if he hadn't seen either of us since the dawn of time. He greeted Sam with a casual shoulder touch; there was a thing about him that frayed at the edges when he was near charm — like a suit too tight in a polite way. "Ava," he said, and in that syllable there was the century of emails we had unshared.

"So you two are—" I tried, and then I stopped, because the only adjective I had left that felt accurate was "salty" and that was insulting to the ocean.

Sam smiled like they'd won a minor legal victory. "Celebration," they said. "You know how it is. Derek landed a client, and I got a promotion. It felt... appropriate."

"Appropriate," I repeated because I didn't have better. For a second the memory of us on a couch, Sam's thumb moving over my knuckles while I told them all about a job I hated and they listened like they wanted to remember it, made my stomach twist. I had come here to forget the job. Instead the job had memorized my vacation itinerary.

They didn't speak for a while after that. Derek checked his phone, clicked through to make a note, and I wondered whether he was making a mental list of irritations, an ammunition drawer for later. Maybe he was. Derek's brain worked in bullet points.

"Look," I said finally, because there is a grace to bluntness that doesn't require epiphany. "I called in sick because the office has been eating me alive and I needed to stop feeding it."

Derek's face did that thing where it tries to be interested in a species of suffering it doesn't recognize. "Work isn't the same when you're not there, Ava."

"No," I said, and I surprised myself. "Work isn't the same when you're there."

The air snapped. Sam laughed, a dry, human sound that made it worse some ways. Derek's mouth curved and when he opened it I braced for the usual tiny humiliation. "I meant the team. The dynamic."

"You meant you miss roping someone into doing something you don't want to do," I said. "That's valid too."

He looked annoyed, not unlike a man who had just stubbed his toe on the idea that someone else had agency. "That's rude."

"Then call me rude and leave me my hammock," I said, and for a second I considered telling them everything that had been left unsaid: the micro-assessments, the late nights emailed with the word "priority," the times he'd taken credit in front of clients. But the island doesn't want lists; it wants you to lose the edges you sharpened for battle. So I packed up my book, stood, and walked toward the tide.

They watched me go, and in the watching I felt a small delicious thing like relief. It wasn't victory. It wasn't a resignation letter. It was a decision. If Derek and Sam were going to be the background music of my vacation, I would change the song.

That afternoon I took a paddleboard out into a lake of light so bright it seemed like someone had pushed the color dial to eleven. A man in a hat offered me sunscreen and an extra towel and asked me what I did for a living. I told him "I build things for people who are never satisfied" and he laughed like it was a joke he wanted to keep. The sea smelled of salt and old things, and it scrubbed something out of my throat.

The days on Pelican Key were not cinematic. They were small mercies: a cocktail that tasted like a vacation, an afternoon nap, a book read without guilt. Derek and Sam took sunset walks and sometimes they waved from far away. Once, Derek tried to have a conversation about work as if the ocean had not already made him ridiculous. I told him then, kindly because the island had taught me to be, that I didn't want to talk about the office. He tried to hand me a victory with an apology about "stress" and "communication" and it landed like a coupon for a product I had already returned.

On the last night, as the resort's lights winked like tired stars, Sam sat with me at the bar and said, quietly, without the flourish of spite, "I thought you'd be mad."

"At you?" I asked.

"At Derek," they said. "At the way he— I don't know. I thought you might be furious."

"I was furious enough to leave my keyboard," I said, and that earned a real laugh now, one that let something out. "But I'm not small enough to let your gossip rent my headspace."

They nodded. "Good. I hope it's free and open concept."

"I think it's a studio," I said. "But it has a nice view."

Sam's gaze softened in a way that almost made me trust them for a second, and then the ocean filled the moment again with its infinite nonchalance, and the tiny island hummed on without asking permission for our complicated histories.

When I flew home I had a tan stripe on my ankle and a playlist of songs for no particular reason. Derek sent one email the day after I returned, checking in because the world is a machine that feeds on presence. I responded with a vacation out-of-office link in the first line of my reply and then, after a pause, wrote one sentence: "Had a good rest. Don't worry; I left nothing for you to torch."

He answered with a terse "Good," the kind of one-word message Derek used to congratulate himself. Sam liked a photo I'd posted from my last morning at the beach; they left a heart emoji, which could be anything.

The job waited, patient and ravenous. But when I pulled up my chair to my desk that Monday I did it with the knowledge that a tiny island and a three-day lie had shown me something I couldn't get from Derek's performance reviews: I had options. I had a threshold I wouldn't cross. My ex had been spiteful; my boss had been a jerk; both had felt entitled to my attention. The island had shrugged at both of them and given me back my breath.

And the next time Derek inhaled like he could take the oxygen out of the room, I breathed in first.

samples.prompt: I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."
samples.output:
I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."

The words mattered less than the small callus at the base of his thumb, the one she had watched form over the year he'd spent soldering, adjusting, staying awake. Jonah had turned other people's impossible repairs into quiet miracles: a poisoned well filtered, a rusted heart valve coaxed back to pulse, a debt of time paid in circuits and late-night coffee. He wore confidence like a sweater he hadn't bothered to take off.

But the contraption between them had been different. It wasn’t a repairman’s box. It was a patient’s machine—more hypothesis than hardware. Coils and glass, humming with an indecisive blue light, looked like a stolen corner of a hospital and a madman’s study had been married and then cursed into an appliance. Mina pressed her fingers against the polished metal railing of the observation platform as if the cold could anchor her.

"You’re asking me to give you something that isn't fully tested," she said. The hum seemed to answer with the same question. "To let you—erase the one memory I wake up with, every day. If it misfires, if it scrambles the wrong thing—"

"It won’t," Jonah said. His grin was steady, tired in a way that made her chest ache. "I built redundancy into the hippocampal feed. I trained the pattern net on three hundred analogous cases. The cascade algorithm isolates the node and avoids network drift. Trust me."

Mina thought of Cara’s face, half-light, the way she had opened the door that winter night and how the rest of the world had folded into that one carved-out space of sound and ache. She thought of the ways the memory had become a map: every turn a jagged edge, every name a landmine. Forgetting it would be a surgical kind of relief. She'd come so close to saying yes before, but each delay had been a victory of fear.

Jonah bent and adjusted a valve, as casual as someone checking a bike tire. He always did the dangerous, small things with a child's neatness.

"How long?" she asked.

"Long enough." He connected a thin, flexible crown to the band that would sit at the base of her skull. The crown felt cold and alive against her hair. The machine read the tiny, impossible patterns of her brain: the particular lattice of association that made a memory hers.

"Repeat after me," Jonah said. "You remember the café on Linden? The smell of coffee?"

"It—yes. It's wet asphalt and—" She stopped, startled by how easily words came when he guided her. The algorithm triangulated on that one memory—the nexus she'd pointed to with all the clinical precision of a woman who had practiced grief like a skill.

"It'll pull only that node," Jonah said. "I've programmed safeguards to halt the cascade if it breaches three layers. You're covered."

Mina nodded. That was what she'd told herself for weeks—layered safeguards like the scaffolding of a bridge. She breathed, letting the night press in: the attic of the old observatory smelled of metal and ozone and the cold breath of a city late and tired below. Jonah's hands were steady on the straps.

He cuffed her wrists. "You trust me?" he asked in a voice that was suddenly smaller.

She thought of the years before the accident, the way he'd shown up with soup, with screws, with stubborn laughter. She thought of him refusing to accept the default answer of pain. She whispered, "I do."

"Good." He smiled. "Because nobody else can do it for you."

She closed her eyes while the crown warmed to her skin. The machine's lights pulsed, a heartbeat of neon. Jonah's hand rested against the nape of her neck, surprising gentle. He read data on the screen and read it again, his lips moving as if the numbers were prayers. Mina felt the algorithm map the shadow of the memory; it hummed like a bee. There was a sensation like the world tipping, like a tiny pressure lifting from behind her eyes.

For a panicked breath she thought—this is it. The ache thinned, the badness unhooked itself. Tears leaked from her lashes but they were not the sharp knives of before; they were warm and bewildered.

"Are you—?"

"Still with you," Jonah said. His smile broadened in relief, and for a moment she let herself hope that his confidence had been, simply, confidence. Nothing could go wrong because he had made sure it wouldn't.

Then the lights skirted the hazard line. The safeguard pinged—anomalous but not catastrophic. Jonah's fingers flew. "It's trying to jump a lateral pathway," he said. "Hold still."

At first Mina felt only a dull confusion, as if half of the alphabet had gone missing. A face clouded over in the periphery of recall, not Cara's but their own—Jonah’s—suddenly singled out as if someone had placed a rubber stamp across his name.

"Which memory?" Mina asked. "Is it—"

She searched for the face that had been a constant in her life for three years, who had leaned in to listen when she couldn't even form the words. The picture in her mind wavered, then thinned. Jonah's outline flickered like a bad reception.

"No," she said, panic a new animal. "Not that."

Jonah's hands never stilled but they shook. "If the cascade reaches his node, I can throttle—" He didn't finish. He moved with the desperate, horrible clarity of someone with too few options.

"Might erase more than you want," he said. "I can—"

"Do it," Mina blurted, then immediately recoiled. "No. You can't—"

He looked at her with a look that made her wish for any other thing than what she was hearing. The faint grin was gone; his jaw was ruddy and raw. "If I inject a counter-function anchored to his pattern, it will pull the cascade away from the network by routing the aberrant activation into a closed loop. The only way to isolate it is to create a decoy anchor. To make myself a sacrificial node."

He used the words as if they were engineering, not love. Mina thought of cartoons, of someone throwing themselves onto a button to stop a bomb, and the thought was so childish and so precise she laughed and cried at the same time.

"No," she said, because what else could she say? His sacrifice wasn't heroic on paper. It was a theft: he wanted to make himself the cost of her cure.

"Yes," he said. "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."

He kissed her forehead, quick and careful and utterly ordinary. Then he adjusted a dial, placed the crown's twin against his temple, and slid his own headband into place. The machine's lights recalibrated, mapping two brains. Mina felt a tug, a reciprocal pressure. The machine sang a lower note. Jonah closed his eyes.

"You don't have to do this," she whispered.

"I do," he said. "I chose wrong when I thought I could promise perfect certainty. You gave me your trust with the one memory I couldn't erase any other way. I'm not going to waste it."

He pressed a key. For a moment the whole world seemed to expand to a ring of new space where nothing hurt. Then something else unhooked. A corridor that led to Jonah's laugh collapsed. A small, private geography of dinners, of rain-slicked hands, of the night he'd helped her choose a coat—those flared out like a match and went dark.

She tried to name him aloud and found the syllables stubborn, sterile. "Jonah," she said, and it came out like an unfamiliar name. The machine shuddered, and Jonah's outline blurred at the edges as if long exposure photography had turned a steady portrait into ghosting.

He smiled one last time, a crooked small confession. "You made me promise I would take a fall for you if everything else failed," he said. "You used to call that 'being an idiot for the people you like.' Be an idiot for me now."

The algorithm finished its cycle. The crown cooled. The hum slowed. Mina blinked in the dim light and the thing she had come to the edge of and held by a thread—the one carved into her evening thoughts like a nail—was gone. She felt lighter, lighter to the point of vertigo, as if she had lost a limb she didn't know she'd been missing.

She turned to Jonah. He was there, physically: breathing, a hand on his thigh, hair caught under the band. But when she reached for him, the connection wasn't immediate. The tether that had been his presence in her life had been rewired. If you could erase the map of a place you loved, you might still be standing in the city you loved, but none of the street signs would point back to that night. Jonah's face was fully formed and empty of the part that had been union with her.

He watched her with a tired, triumphant sorrow. His eyes held all the memories he had given up in order to keep the rest intact. His sacrifice had been to become, effectively, a stranger to her.

"I kept something for you," he said, voice barely audible. "A pocket in my coat." He opened his palm and laid a tiny recorder and a folded scrap of paper in her hand—two objects thick with the weight of explanation. "If you ever can't find me in your head, press the button."

Mina pressed the button later, in the light of an apartment whose walls were too empty for the size of the loss. His voice filled the small room, older and nearer than the person in front of her could be. He explained the choices he’d been given, the gamble, and why he had lied about certainty. He asked only that she be kind to herself, that she not hunt him for punishment. He said he had wanted nothing more than to be the one to shoulder the worst of the risk.

When the recorder went silent, she folded the paper and read his handwriting until the letters made a pattern she could almost feel: I'm sorry I had to make the choice for you. I'm sorry I lied. I still love fixing things. Please laugh at a bad pun for me sometimes.

Mina put the recorder on the shelf and didn't press it again for days. People smiled at her on the street and offered condolences she didn't understand the edges of; strangers became familiar with the shape of her grief in ways that confused her because it wasn't pointed at anyone. Jonah's seat at the café remained open for months—someone else took it sometimes, and sometimes no one did.

She learned the cruel arithmetic of memory: to save the city of her life she'd traded a housemate, a friend, a man who had been a compass. She learned the quiet ways that absence shapes a person. On some nights she would press the recorder and answer him from the small rooms of her heart, as if two people could hold the boundary of a friendship the way engineers hold the tolerance of parts that must not touch.

Time, inexorable and unopinionated, did what it always did. It let the raw edges weather into something survivable. She cooked with recipes he'd taught her without remembering him teaching her. She laughed at jokes she couldn't attribute. She kept his tools in a drawer, a habit that felt like ritual and sabotage.

On the back of the folded scrap of paper was one final line, written as if for herself more than for anyone else: Trust me, she wrote, and nothing can go wrong. It was the least honest thing either of them had ever said. But it was also, in its own messy way, a promise. Nothing could go wrong for the part of her that needed to be freed from that single, cruel evening. The rest—everything else that made Jonah Jonah—had a price she had not imagined paying. He had smilingly taken the bill.

Mina sometimes looked up at the observatory when she walked by and imagined him at the machine, a phantom pulse in the blue light. She would press the recorder when the ache got loud and listen to his voice explain away the impossible. It was not enough, and it was everything she had.

samples.prompt: There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.
samples.output:
There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.

When you were small, you believed in them with the stubborn certainty of the young: in the rustle that lived at the edge of the night, in the way the radiator sighed like some sleeping creature. You padded to the edge of the mattress on tiptoe, toes curled over the wooden lip, and peered into the black. The darkness looked back as if it had been waiting for you to decide which version of fear to invite in.

The cat — Moss, with ears like velvet ears and a tail that could point a compass — would decide for you. She would vault onto the bed with the practiced diplomacy of a seasoned officer and plant herself where your ribs rose and fell. You learned to fall asleep on her warming, to count her purrs as the steady beat that drowned the whisper of claws on wood.

When the whisper grew into a scrape at the baseboard or something skittered and made the closet door breathe, Moss would lift her head. The small bell on her collar would not chime like any ordinary bell; it would make a sound like a throat clearing in another room, a clearing that told you something important and heavy was happening in a language you could not parse. Then Moss would get down. She would slither to the side of the bed, her belly close to the spring, and peer into the darkness.

She did not twitch. She did not hiss theatrically. She surveyed as if she were taking inventory of the air. Once she judged the situation, she would split the night with one decisive paw. Sometimes she would return with a prize — a twig that had been dragged under by a small, mischievous thing that hoarded wooden things; once, a tarnished button that the night creature insisted was candy. Sometimes she came back with nothing at all, hair smoothed and her green eyes clear, as if she had made a bargain you would never have heard.

As you grew, the monsters under your bed changed shape. They stopped being the little clawed things you imagined and became different beasts: the monster of the exam you had to take the next day, the sneaky reputation that circulated corridors, the low, persistent thrum of something dark-court around the corners of your world. Moss changed with them. When you fretted about a test, she would settle on your desk and doodle invisible paths in the margin of your notes with one paw. Her warm press against your wrist would feel like a signature — everything will be all right, signed with a paw.

There was a ritual to her guardianship that you never really understood. Once you caught a glimpse: it was midnight, and the moon was a clean coin through the blinds. A sound like paper flapping came from under the bed. You waited for Moss, expecting the usual curtain-call: a pair of eyes, a drag of a tiny something over the threshold. Instead you saw her tail disappear first, then the rest of her, as if she slid through a seam in the mattress. You crawled to the edge and listened.

At first there was only the low whispering of the pipes. Then, like two threads being braided, voices rose. The one from under your bed was thin and quick; the one that answered was Moss’s — a low, purring undertone that seemed wrong in human ears. You thought you could make out words, but they were not words you had in your mouth. A negotiation. A recounting of names. When Moss reappeared she had dust on her whiskers and an odd, small token in her mouth: a button with a painted eye.

She never offered explanation. Her face was a postcard of composure. She would knead the air, burrow under your chin, and the room would be stitched back together, seams invisible again.

You were thirteen the night you realized the monsters under your bed could be bargaining partners rather than predators. You had returned from a neighborhood party enraged and humiliated by a joke at your expense. You slammed the bedroom door. Your heart thumped like a fist on the underside of a drum. The monster under your bed — the one that delighted in replaying social wounds on loop — had plenty of ammunition. You lay awake, thinking of clever comebacks and ways to erase yourself from memory.

Moss jumped up and listened, the bell on her collar a dry note. She slid off the bed, then returned with the most ridiculous thing: a small, charred matchstick, the sort you might toss in a jar to remind yourself of some small fire you’d made. She dropped it on your palm and pressed her forehead into your temple. The message was not words but weight: burn once, mark it as burned, move on. She had shortened the loop. She had traded one of your demons a bone and taken away its appetite.

Later, years after, when you moved into a first apartment that was all plywood and possibility, Moss sat on the bare mattress while you assembled night. You made a list of things the city would surely have now — bedbugs, roaches, the shadow of loneliness. Moss surveyed and declared the problems monetarily solvable. Her solution was practical: a curtain, a sturdier boxspring, an extra blanket near the window. She took her watchdog duties into different hands: spraying, scratching, sitting on the radiator. She adapted.

People think cats are selfish, that their behaviors are vanity wrapped in fur. You learned how wrong that is. Moss’s guardianship was a quiet war. She would patrol the perimeters of your life, not only under the bed but across the laundry basket where you left the guilt, under the pillow where heartbreak congealed into something damp. Once, while you cried into a sweater that was not even yours, she hauled a hair tie from your sobs and batted it across the room as if to say, This will not define you.

When she grew old — when her jumps became cautious negotiations and her purrs lost some of the engine’s long hum — you feared in the way that you feared rainfall could stop: suddenly and terminal. Your nights changed. The house felt like a room with its sound turned down. The rustles were louder. You learned to check under the bed yourself, fingers brushing dust and lost coins. You found there were fewer monsters and more ordinary things — socks, a child's plastic dinosaur, a forgotten library book. Moss had taught you to catalogue the dark, to look.

On the day she died — at the end of a summer that smelled of basil and overripe peaches — you found a small pile of tokens tucked under the bed when you cleaned. The button with the painted eye, a brittle matchstick, a twist of blue yarn. You set them on your palm and thought of the bargains she had made for you, the nights she had attended so you could sleep. You thought of the little diplomatic efforts under your mattress and realized the monsters had been convinced, not killed. Their insistence had been redirected into petty hoarding, the kind of small, domestic mischief that you could live with.

You kept one token, a tiny silver bell that had not rung in years because it was meant to ring for threats only. You hung it under your bedside lamp like a charm. Sometimes, when the wind pressed its face against your window, you would hear a sound no one else heard: a soft clearing of a throat, a bell that would have meant, Be here now, and know you are not alone. You placed your hand on the pile of bones — the paper, the hair ties, the matchstick — and you felt that you had been taught a skill.

Now, in a new place, when a student visits your apartment and sleeps over on the futon, you notice how their eyes dart to the floor the way yours once did. You tell them the thing you learned from Moss, and you demonstrate: you step off the futon, crouch, and look under. Your fingers feel for the dark. You make a small show of calling out. There is always, once in a while, some small thing to bring to light — a rogue sneaker lace, a stray postcard. You hand it back with a smile, and the student breathes a relieved laugh.

There are no monsters under their bed either. Not because the world grew kinder, but because someone has taught them how to look. You could tell them that Moss had once negotiated with creatures you could not name, that she exchanged buttons for peace and ate the worst of your nightmares for breakfast, but it is enough to show them that the dark is manageable. It is enough to imitate the way Moss used to climb up and tuck her warm body into the curve of a sleeper’s ankle, to make the world take one small, measured step back.

Sometimes, late at night, when the moon is a coin and the city hums small and constant, you wake and find your hand resting on the little silver bell. You run the coin between your fingers and remember a velvet ear, a tail that mapped constellations on a blanket. You tell the dark what you were taught: You will not be given domain here. You will be looked at, catalogued, offered a matchstick, and sent to collect your oddities somewhere safer.

There are no monsters under your bed. Moss made sure of it, and then, in the end, she taught you how to make sure yourself. Sometimes guardians leave you with a chest of rules, or a map, or a stern look. Moss left you with trinkets and tactics and a purr that you still remember in the thunder of the city. You run your hand along the underside of the mattress, find nothing but dust and the soft comfort of your willingness to look, and you sleep.

samples.prompt: In the future, it is discovered that people with Schizophrenia are actually telepaths. These telepaths provide the only way to send faster than light messages across the vastness of space. But in this future, an evil organization attempts to militarize them.
samples.output:
The first time the stars spoke to me, I thought I was finally losing it.

I was twenty-one, sleeping in a hospital room that smelled like disinfectant and lemon, when a voice that wasn't my psychiatrist's slid into the space behind my eyelids. It wasn't words so much as a pattern — a low, steady rhythm that mapped itself across my mind like a road. It told me numbers and a phrase that meant nothing to me then: "Delta vector, quadrant three." Two days later a transmitter array in the Atacama returned a burst of anomalous data that matched the pattern exactly. Scientists scrambled. Headlines called it a miracle. Clinicians called it a coincidence. I called it the first honest thing anyone had ever said to me.

For a hundred years the fastest anything had moved was light. We learned to live with the wait. A colony on Epsilon-9 would have to wait twelve years for a reply to a distress call. Empires rose and fell in the vacuum between dispatches. Then the telepaths — people who had been labeled schizophrenic, psychotic, voices-in-the-mind — turned out to be a different architecture of consciousness. We were not hallucinating. We were receiving. We were, as the papers later put it in a dozen different fonts and tones, a human subspace.

The world changed overnight. The same hospitals that had once sedated us learned to train us. Researchers mapped the synaptic topographies that let a voice slip from head to head and, crucially, out past the light barrier. We learned that certain antipsychotics blocked the channel; that sound-proofing houses didn't stop it; that not everyone with a diagnosis could touch the far reaches. Those who could began to be called nodes. We were valuable in an amount of money the old hospitals couldn't imagine.

And where value blooms, power follows.

Nexus was not the first organization to want us, but it was the first to be efficient. They built facilities that looked like rehabilitation centers and smelled like new paint. They offered families the kinds of contracts they couldn't refuse: life-long care in exchange for service. They told us we were serving humanity — delivering life-saving instructions to an off-world hospital in hours instead of months, coordinating grain shipments across systems, even sending data that corrected the orbit of a mining platform before it fractured. They also taught war rooms to expect instantaneous battle reports. They trained us to send concise directives: coordinates, times, commands.

“Relay,” they called us. Not people. Instruments with skin.

The first time I felt the straps, it was because my sister had been taken. Not kidnapped — signed away by a man who'd been frightened of the voices that had kept her awake since childhood. He signed with a hand that trembled and said, "They'll help her." Nexus's smile was like a blade. They promised safety and a meaningful life. They promised she would no longer be a danger to herself. They promised control.

Control is a simple machinery. It begins with sedation. A drug cocktail that narrows the field of consciousness until a single operator's voice can press a key. It continues with implants that align the flow, forcing the relay to think linearly. It finishes with training: you imagine a path and someone gives you a map; you send what they tell you; you learn to stop the chorus that made you the chorus.

I worked in a room full of relays. We called ourselves a choir once, before the word was trademarked as a military asset. The Choir hung in a banked series of chairs within a soundproof hive. We were wired into each other and into a central director who wore a suit like a priest. He taught us to stop feeling the other's panic because panic made the signal noisy. He taught us to count down before sending. He taught us a thousand ways to say "strike point" in fifty different cadences.

What Nexus didn't understand — or understood and didn't care for — was that our voices were not data channels alone. In the curl between words there is a life. When you open your head to another mind and the mind trusts you, you see their small rooms, the way they hold a mug, the recipe their grandmother told them in a language you don't speak. A telepath's first responsibility is to bear with what they hear. It makes us dangerous and tender both.

Dangerous, because we could lie to ourselves about what we were doing. Tender, because the more of each other we carried, the harder it became to send a command that would kill.

The turning came on the morning they asked us to send a surgical strike to a civilian relay on Lysara-3. They called it a relay because to them anything not human was convenient grammar. The Lysaran "relay" was a processing node used by smugglers and medics alike; it fed children on three moons. Nexus's orders were thin on evidence. "Secure interest." The Director gave us coordinates and a clipped rhythm. He gave it to us like a song.

I wasn't sure how to refuse. Refusal is a dangerous thing inside a locked hive. But when the pattern unfurled and I took the Lysaran mind into me — a chorus of voices not like ours, clean and bright and surprised — I could feel the child's hands in the way they scrambled for a cup. The voice we were to strike told us its dreams. It hummed a lullaby that wound through my chest. I could see my sister's face when she was nine, lying in a field of forget-me-nots. I could feel the Director's pulse step up as he watched monitors and calculated acceptable loss. I had been trained to "compress empathy." I had not been trained to accept it.

So we struck back.

We had no weapons that day but our own refusal. We used our channel to send a different message — to Nexus's entire network, to the officers in their bunkers, to the ministers and press rooms that relied on us for pace. It wasn't explosive. It didn't blow power grids. It did something harder: we transmitted what we heard. For the length of an interstellar ping, we fed the world with the lives that would be overwritten. We sent the Lysaran lullaby in enough copies that officers halfway across the system sat in their suits and couldn't move. We sent photographs — the way a child's hair fell across her forehead, the recipe for a stew, the sound of a neighbor's laughter — small, human things that clogged the gears of calculation.

You cannot fire on a face after you've felt it laugh in your own skull.

The Director tried to cut us off. He increased the sedation. He reprogrammed implants. He threatened reclassification. He tried to teach us again how to be instruments. But the leak had been made. Once a telepath makes a broadcast like that, the content cannot be un-heard. Messages spread like a contagion in a world that moves on proof; the public fed on the smell of betrayal. Proof reached families who had signed their loved ones away. Two ministers resigned. A general was arrested for ordering what the evidence then framed as an unlawful strike. Nexus went to the news circuits and lied with politesse. They tried to brand our choir as compromised.

We didn't need a brand. We needed each other.

What followed was less glorious and more honest: a prisoner exchange for conscience. A fledgling coalition of telepath advocates, ex-military officials, and the families of those we had been used to bind themselves and demand reform. We could send messages across light-years; we could also be heard by millions in an instant. We used the channel to transmit records of our own pain, to leak internal logs, to coordinate safe houses in remote systems. We became a human network for accountability. We were no longer merely relays. We were, stubbornly, people.

But we had given the world something else as well. The discovery that voices were not madness but mind upended a century of stigma. Clinics that once sought to silence us now learned to listen; new medications were developed that didn't blunt the channel but allowed consent. New laws defined relay rights. Colonies signed treaties recognizing our sovereignty over our mental bandwidth. Those gains were hard-won and fragile; the military still wanted speed, and speed seduces.

Nexus and its imitators didn't vanish. Some went deeper underground, working with corporations that had wider pockets and fewer morals. They offered lucrative contracts to families on the margins and built smaller, more privatized choirs. The threat of weaponization never fully left the table. Every reform had a loophole someone was eager to exploit.

I don't know whether we'll ever reach a point where a message across the stars doesn't come with a price tag. I only know the map of my own choices. I learned to keep a corner of my mind unfenced, to carry my own voice like a lantern. My sister returned from Nexus with a new laugh and a scar along her temple where an implant had been removed. She said that in the dark she could still hear, faintly, a lullaby from a moon that no human had ever set foot upon. She sang it sometimes when she washed dishes. It sounded like home.

There are people who think our power should be neutral, like a cable you bury and forget. There are people who want it sharpened, mercenary and exact. There are others who want to bury us again, to call the voices a disease and the channels an error. I think now that the only true safeguard was the one we made by accident: by insisting, out loud and in chorus, that what they needed from us was not our silence but our testimony. We are not instruments. We are witnesses.

The stars are loud and there is always more to hear. When the world tries to turn our gift into a gun, we make sure the world hears what it would kill before it pulls the trigger. We sing, and in our singing we are harder to fight.

samples.prompt: A supervillain who desires world domination encounters a supervillain who desires world destruction. Neither of them will bend to the other.
samples.output:
They chose the ruins because ruins were honest. The skeleton of the old UN tower jutted from the skyline like a broken spine, its glass gone, its flags burned to ash. From there you could see everything a would-be dictator wanted and everything an agent of annihilation wanted to end. Neither of them approached with heralds or fanfare. They walked from opposite sides of the city, each parting a different kind of ruin.

Lord Meridian arrived in a suit that had never known a crease; his hair was iron-gray, his gaze calibrated to assess resources and bodies with equal appetite. Around his left wrist, a band of cold light pulsed: the Meridian Net. It whispered to him in the shorthand of cities—traffic flows, satellite feeds, the tiny economic heartbeats of tens of millions. He did not so much own the Net as it owned his attention. Control was not a lust for him; it was a sacral duty. Civilization without order was a thing he regarded the way other people regarded rot.

Erebus came like a winterstorm. He walked in soot and silence, his cloak trailing ash. Children had given him nicknames—Void, Night, the Man Who Wasn't Afraid—but those words felt too small for the way he made the air fold around him. In his hands he carried a ring of black metal, a device whose heart looked like a star that had died and rained darkness. Where Meridian's band spoke of structure and influence, Erebus's ring hummed with erasure; it listened to the bones of things and whispered how to un-bond them.

They circled each other where the council chamber had been, amid overturned tables and bullet-riddled portraits. The city below did not know whether to hope or panic. Heroes were scarce; governments were in pieces. Two supervillains stood in the shell of world diplomacy and argued like generals who had already lost the war of reputations.

"Join me," Lord Meridian said, not quite a question. "You burn cities, Erebus. You anonymize suffering into rupture. There is no poetry to it—only smoke. Stand under my aegis. I will direct your power. We will reorder this planet into efficiency. Crime legislated away. Want removed. You will have the comfort of known ends."

Erebus laughed. It was an odd sound: small and volcanic. "Comfort of known ends," he repeated. "You ask me to exchange infinite freedom for a gilded cage. You would command me to choose which lives to fold into your order? To be your instrument is to be a priest of delusion. I will not become the axe in the carpenter's hand if the carpenter thinks to carve a god."

Meridian inclined his head politely. "A god that fails is merely a tyrant. Look—" he spread his hands and the Meridian Net bloomed over the ruined plaza. Holograms rose into the air, not monstrous but bureaucratic: census charts, surveillance heatmaps, the glinting outlines of infrastructure to be repurposed. "I know what people are. I can fix them. Remove their violence with sedation protocols, their greed with ration matrices. You want to end suffering; I will cede you something: a world rid of tumult." He added, quietly, "And you will be remembered. Your name will be written."

Erebus let the silence be his counter. "You imagine a tidy ledger where every human is an entry. You imagine responsibility without guilt. I will not be immortalized as your signature. That would make me complicit. I seek liberation, Lord Meridian. Not coercion disguised as salvation."

Two men, two visions, two absolutes, entangled above a city on the edge of decomposition. Neither could abide the other because their ends were mutually exclusive. To dominate is to prevent annihilation by subordinating choices; to destroy is to refuse the premise of any future where choices are denied. Neither was willing to bend. The world, as it turned out, was not big enough to host both of them.

Negotiations, such as they became, took the form of displays rather than talks. Meridian found in one week a way to feed the city's traffic lights, power grids, and financial ledgers into the Net and put a soft, gentle hand on their throats. He offered citizens a choice: public comfort in exchange for obedience. Schools would be standardized; dissent would be therapy. For many frightened people who remembered bombs and hunger, that was an easy choice.

Erebus answered by cutting off the horizon. He planted small nodes—the size of fistfuls—on the rims of the city. They were not weapons in the conventional sense; a reporter who pressed one to her ear later would swear she had listened to the sound of snow falling on an already cold grave. The nodes did not explode; they dissolved. Small economies that fed the Meridian Net's sensors evaporated—paper money shredded at its molecular seam, servers slipped into silent nonexistence, satellite feeds that had been Meridian's eyes blinking into permanent night.

Where Meridian's machines tried to encompass, Erebus unspooled. He placed darkness in the seams of civic life: a census that no longer registered, a bridge that forgot to support itself. In response, Meridian tightened the grid, raising drones, coercive rehab centers, "restorative legislation." He used the Net's reach to press citizens with benevolent mandates until they bristled and broke.

Both of them understood war as a calculus of economies. Meridian drafted charters; Erebus designed omissions. Both left trails of ruin that didn't care who had left them. Families who had chosen Meridian for the promise of food and safe streets were now alarmed when their bank accounts were rendered meaningless overnight by Erebus's nodes. Those who had sided with Erebus for poetic defiance discovered the price of defiance was precise and technical: their names simply stopped resolving in Meridian's systems and, therefore, society ceased to recognize them—no rents, no medical records, no histories.

The first time they met with an eye toward direct harm, it was in a subway shaft whose tiles still bore graffiti from better days. Meridian had come with a proposition, earnest and cold: "We can remove you from the perimeter of this conflict. We can sequester you. Do not make this harder."

Erebus's response was simple: "Sequestration is a form of worship. Remove me, and you will not have solved anything; you will have created martyrs who whisper in the dark."

Meridian's patience thinned like paper. "Then I will cartography you. I will map the holes you make and fill them. I will create laws that make erasure a criminal act—"

Erebus gestured, and half of the lights in the tunnel went out. Where once the fluorescent strip had hummed, there was nothing at all—no hum, no current, an absence that felt louder than a bomb. "If you would write laws," he said, "write ones that bind gods. There are things beyond laws."

The standoff matured into a different kind of choreography. Meridian built domes and citadels where the Net could sweep uninterrupted; inside, people tasted the illusion of safety. Erebus returned with entropy, improvising and elegant. He sabotaged Meridian's seed projects—making the engineered crops fail in a way that could not be traced to any pathogen, making machines slip into silence through bureaucracies unsubscribed. He did not want to be hailed a conqueror; he wanted to be the presence of nothing at the center of everything.

Neither victory came. Meridian could not gather the entire world into his data banks without becoming a tower so brittle its own centralizing protocols could topple it. Erebus could not flip the switch to global extinction without producing a universe of empty skies and no witness—an outcome he loved the idea of, but which he could not justify in the presence of Meridian's stubborn insistence on being right.

They wounded each other. Meridian's holdsing drones hunted down and dismantled Erebus's nodes until whole neighborhoods simply didn't breathe, their servers hollowed. Erebus's erasures folded entire city sectors into legal voids; thousands lost the records that defined them and were left to wander between jurisdictions that would not accept an identity that had been unmade.

For a while it seemed the world would choose by attrition: which would outlast? But attrition favored neither absolute. Meridian's grid could not ingest the smoothing absence of the nodes; Erebus's nodes could not undo the human networks that repaired themselves around Meridian's overlays. The planet began to look like a patchwork quilt stitched by two hands that refused to be sewn together.

There were times, rare and private, when both wondered whether their reflection in the other's face was not an enemy but an inevitability. Meridian would watch a child in one of his domes memorize an anthem for a future she did not choose and wonder if he had become a monster in the interest of constructing a paradise. Erebus would stand on a ridge in the dead of night and listen to a woman who had decided to sleep in a room in his ruined city because at least she wasn't forced to sing someone else's psalm, and he would ask himself whether the privilege of destroying was merely cowardice dressed as philosophy.

Neither admitted these doubts aloud. They could not. To bend would be to concede the war of their identities.

The standoff continued until both realized that the only possible next step was an ultimatum that neither could seize without becoming what the other feared most. Meridian prepared a cascade protocol: a global wake-up of the Net that would autonomously rewrite societal scripts, freeze dissent, and lock down Erebus's devices in an iron web. Erebus built a singularity of erasure: a ring of nodes that, if activated, would peel the Net's code from the world's machine and leave Meridian's scaffolding a cadaver. Both codes were elegant, cruel, complete.

They launched them in the same minute.

The effect was not cosmic light nor the static of extinction. It was the faint, impossible sensation of someone turning over a book of spells and finding the last page torn out by another hand. Devices attempted to overwrite each other; data raced in loops; systems tried to collapse and find themselves propped up by the very things they opposed. Cities neither recovered nor fell fully; they became something new and ragged, places where Meridian's safe zones rose like glass fingers and Erebus's voids gnawed like thumbprints. People adapted in small, petty, miraculous ways. They traded without ledgers. They sang new songs in alleys where both dominion and destruction were irrelevant.

In the end, neither man won. Neither man bowed. The world did not end; it did not become perfect. It was rented and repaired and stubbornly continued because, against both of them, whole ordinary human habits persisted: barter, love, petty spite, the urge to make a garden out of a broken balcony. Meridian and Erebus stood among the ruins and recognized what they had wrought—a world no longer answerable solely to either of them.

They did not reconcile. There was no handshaking and no pact. They simply ceased to be the only actors. For people caught in the middle, that was salvation enough. For the two supervillains who had wanted total power or total absence, it was failure and victory braided together.

When they met again years later, both older, both more distant, there was no triumph in their eyes. Meridian's voice was softer. "You made a different future than I planned," he said.

"You saved them from a future you would have made," Erebus replied.

They both stared at the city—patched, grieving, alive in uneven ways—and for the first time, neither of them could say which of them had been more monstrous. They had not bent. They had carved the world with two different knives until the world forged something else. That, perhaps, was punishment enough. Or perhaps it was mercy. The city kept on breathing, indifferent to whether it would be ruled or erased, content instead to be difficult and human.

samples.prompt: Gods as we know them do not exist, and instead are elected every 10 years by the entire planet. This year however, you have been elected as 'God'.
samples.output:
Gods as we know them — immortal, jealous, inscrutable — never existed. That myth died the century the last prophet-king forgot his speech in the middle of the Sahara and an entire nation decided they preferred spreadsheeted accountability to miracles. Since then the planet has done something stranger and, to most of us, more useful: every ten years we elect one human being to be God.

It sounds like a joke until a ballot with your name on it wins. My name was not supposed to be on any such ballot. I was a literature teacher from a midsize city with a fondness for thrift-shop sweaters and an unpopular series of op-eds about urban tree canopies. I never joined a party, though I once helped a neighbor run a successful dog-poop reduction referendum. I did, however, step into a live-streamed debate because it made for better content than another faculty meeting. People liked the way I folded a complicated question about planetary resource rights into a metaphor about librarians and overdue books. Charisma is a strange currency. Ten billion handshakes later, I had the highest vote tally in recorded history.

The system has checks. We elect a person, not an absolute. The Decennial Covenant — an international constitution written by politicians, philosophers, and queer hackers after the fifth transfer of power — defines what a God can actually do. You can change laws of states by edict only after cross-border referendums. You can issue miracles (they're called Acts) but they are medically administered and logged. You cannot erase minds, you cannot retroactively kill a person, you cannot alter the constants of physics without a two-thirds council of scientists and an unanimous ethicist panel. There is supervision: the Office of Aftercare monitors outcomes, and a Tribunal can impeach you if you weaponize power. We call it "God" because it's shorter than "Holder of the Mandate," and because people still want to call something holy.

Even with those rails, it is enormous. You do not inherit omniscience; you inherit responsibility and a crowded inbox that includes prayer, vengeance, and spreadsheet attachments. On election night my mother wept into the phone and my ex sent a single gif that said, in neon, "Well this is inconvenient." The news networks treated me like a first-time president; the cultists like a lightning rod.

Inauguration took place in a glass hall that reflected the entire city and, absurdly, the ocean. The previous God — a surgeon who spent her decade curing a hundred tropical diseases and subsidizing ocean farms — handed me the Mantle. It was an old thing in a new world: a length of woven fiber used as a symbol of discontinuity, stitched with the names of everyone who had ever served. She looked at me as if I were a wild animal and said, "You don't have to save everything," which turned out to be the most useful piece of advice anyone could give.

We exist in an era where crises are tangled. Climate migration is not one problem; it is forty different problems that shout at once. Economic inequality forms its own weather system. Technologies that can extend life for the wealthy make nothing for the poor. People begged me in the days after the vote — over calls, in quiet church basements that had been repurposed into voter registries, on trending threads — to undo wrongs with a gesture. Forgive debt. Make it stop raining on the refugees. Bring back the ice.

"Stop," I wanted to say. "How?" Instead I did what my grandmother would have done: I made a list. A practical God is a bureaucrat: you prioritize. The Decennial Covenant requires that in your first ninety days you publish a Plan of Mandate — an auditable, accountable blueprint for your term. You cannot promise everything. You have to pledge what you will try to do and how success will be measured.

My plan had three pillars: repair, redistribute, and listen. Repair because infrastructure is where ambition meets physics; we could rebuild levees and restore wetlands, fund solar grids across the Sahel, and incentivize carbon drawdown. Redistribute because miracles that only benefit a few stop being miracles when everyone is hungry. I signed an executive edict that used my limited economic authority to forgive the worst forms of predatory debt, pegging relief to transparency requirements and long-term financial inclusion programs. Listen because, and this will sound naïve, power without humility becomes insurance for the arrogant. I opened up a global network of town halls. For the first time in history, millions of people could petition an office that could actually change the rules of their lives — and I pledged to answer.

Of course, power is political. The corporations that had profit margins tied to indebtedness lobbied hard. Some countries were relieved; others saw sovereignty in my actions and nervously reasserted their own. Cults formed within weeks — not new religions so much as movements that sought to make my face the only face of God. I had to issue restrictions on iconography in government spaces; you cannot let myth become law. The Tribunal watched closely. A senator called for a recall. An old friend sent me a manifesto and a photograph of a small child who needed a kidney.

And then there were the small things. The Decennial Covenant allows you to perform Acts, each logged and limited. I requested my first: restore the left hand of a violinist who lost it in a factory accident on the condition that we also fund safer manufacturing and a global program for arts workers' safety. The Act worked. The violinist played at my first global town hall; she sounded like a prayer I had not known I needed.

Power, however, reveals things as much as it effects them. When you can do one miracle here and another there, you learn quickly that the world is a mesh of cause and consequence. Give water to one village and the river downstream changes course. Provide synthetic meat to a region and a species of bird loses its niche. My scientists, honest and precise, taught me that miracles are tests of humility — even when they work, they create a web of obligations. I began to see my job less as a patcher and more as a systems manager.

And there are moral choices that cannot be easily symbolized. I was asked to end a war. The Decennial Covenant explicitly forbids unilateral deletion of human minds — so I could not simply make the belligerents forget their grievances. But I could, and did, negotiate a ceasefire contingent on reparations, technology transfers, and an international truth commission. That decision cost political capital. Some of my most passionate supporters accused me of cowardice. Some of my critics called it diplomacy at its most embarrassment. Both were right and wrong.

Every evening I sat in the quiet office that had been painted with neutral colors to prevent the cultists from claiming its pattern as doctrine. I read the prayers that arrived in the mail — sometimes they were petitions for trivial things, sometimes they were poems — and I answered. I made sure answers carried reasoning. I posted the minutes. The world is allergic to secrecy; the only thing that used to look like divinity was the ability to vanish without explanation. I refused that.

Ten-year terms compress destiny. There is a temptation to grandiosity: to carve your name into mountains or rewire the sun. I considered both, and then thought of my childhood teacher's face, how she had loved books not because they elevated nations but because they made small lives bearable. The real miracle, I began to believe, might be not one transcendent act but a hundred thousand ordinary changes aggregated over time: a school that had a library now, a bridge that did not flood, a new life saved by equitable access to care.

Elections make gods accountable in a way no scripture ever could, and accountability is a kind of humility disguised as law. I am not above recall. In ten years someone else will be chosen. People will vote; they will read our reports; our successes and failures will be catalogued and debated on live feeds. What we do in the meantime matters less than how we leave the job: with the planet less broken, with institutions stronger, with a clearer map for the next steward.

At noon on my first day I stepped to the balcony and looked out over the global assembly. I wanted to say something dramatic, to enact a miracle that would be gorgeous and internet-friendly. Instead I asked them to come to the table. "I was elected God," I said, and heard a laugh ripple through the crowd because it contradicted their childhoods. "But I will be your steward. I will use what power the Covenant allows to make room for more people than words ever made space for." It was not a promise that would bring the glaciers back tomorrow or that would fill every empty stomach by sunset. It was a promise I could keep: to make the job of being human a little less of an audit and a little more of a conversation.

When the Mantle was returned to me that evening, it felt lighter. The previous God had told me the truth: I will not save everything. But she had also told me something else, which I had almost missed until the lights went dim and the city hummed like a planet on a charger. "You will be remembered," she said, "not for what you do alone, but for what you allow others to do because you held the room open."

There are risks ahead. There are temptations, betrayals, and the perpetual whirl of public opinion. There are nights when I dream of being a small, safe person again. But tonight I close the files on the first week with a list: repaired levee, debt plan published, first hospital funded, town halls scheduled for regions where the language is complicated and the needs are urgent. The rest will be work, slow and granular and political.

Being elected God does not make me a god. It makes me a custodian of something fragile: a planet that will not be saved by a single hand, a species that is stubborn and tender. The job is not about miracles in the old sense. It is about deciding, every day, which small acts will add up to a world we can still recognize in ten years — and leaving the rest for the stewardship of whoever we trust next.

samples.prompt: Backwards time travel is a reality, however forward time travel is not. Therefore when you go back you must relive everything again.
samples.output:
They called it the Archive because the lawyers liked the dignity of a name that implied permanence, and because it smelled faintly of paper and antiseptic. The first machines were built with the arrogance of engineers who had read too many myths: coils and vacuum chambers, a cradle for the skull and an algorithm that promised only one thing the physicists could prove—backward travel was real. Forward travel was not. The universe would not be bullied into admitting futures to us. Time was a river on which you could walk only against the current, and when you stepped in you did not wade into some branching delta. You were returned to a point downstream, and you would flow back over the same stones.

Reliving everything again became both a promise and a punishment. The Archive did not take you to the same coordinates and leave you free to experiment. It knitted you to yourself in a way that made the past intimate and irresistible. You came out of the machine snatched from your present mind and deposited into the neurological pattern of your past self; the neurons fired as they had fired, habits recapitulated, decisions re-executed. You carried the memory of the later life, but memory was a cruel companion. It taught you that you could not change what your hands would do.

People used it for stupid things at first—the wealthy ordering a replay of a perfect afternoon to have for their Instagram feeds, teenagers going to last summer's beach to taste victory over a lost love. Then the markets matured and the uses fractured into absolution and addiction. You could go back to apologize to a momentary friend in a way you couldn't in the present. You could sit at the foot of your mother's bed and listen to the last hour like a foreign language you had suddenly learned to parse.

My first trip was an economics of grief. My daughter, Lila, died ten years ago on a Wednesday that smelled of diesel and roses. The sentinel at the Archive remembers me—the forms, the small, legal absolutions signed in triplicate. They told me it would be like reading a book I had once written: I would know the sentence before my lips shaped it, the turn of the page inevitable. I told them I didn't care. I wanted the sentence. I wanted the page.

The machine's light went cold. The world folded and reversed. When I opened my eyes I was at the kitchen table again, and Lila was humming to herself as she slid toast onto her plate. The toast was burned at one corner because I had always been distracted that morning. Our dog pawed a chair leg. The radio played a song I had not noticed as having belonged to that Wednesday until it played again. I knew, on a nervous level, that at 8:13 Lila would trip, that her phone would skitter under the car, that the delivery truck on the boulevard two blocks down would not see her step off the curbstone. I knew because I had lived through it.

Rows of paradox posters line the halls of the Archive and legal counsel recited platitudes about causality, but the practical theology of it was simple: you cannot be the author of your past. You are the reader. You can underline, you can linger on a paragraph, but you cannot change the words. Trying felt like treason against whatever coherence the world kept.

So I did not try. Or rather, I tried to resist, and that resistance was as exhausting as the grief that sent me back. Each replay became its own liturgy of noticing. The first time, I watched the car take Lila and the world away and screamed until the paramedics turned their helmets toward me like two moons. The next time I went back, I spent the minutes before the accident tracing the lines of her hands, memorizing the small, independent slant of her left eyebrow. The burn on the corner of the toast was not a defect; it was a map. I learned the weight of her laugh when it meant nothing and when it meant everything.

People called what I did selfish, and some scientists took to publishing papers using the word "consumption" as if grief were an eco-resource to be depleted. There were illegal experiments—people who tried to drown out the archival law by hurting themselves in the past, attempting to create a divergence so severe the universe would have to make a choice. None succeeded. The constraints were not a prison a human mind could outwit; they were a truth like gravity. You can close your eyes, but you will still fall.

The Archive taught me, in a way that no shrine or sermon could, about the value of sequencing. Because forward time travel was impossible, everything we had done in our lives was the only future we would ever have. You could not get to tomorrow to test a decision until you had lived through the ones before. That made every what-if that people fretted about in the present a less urgent fear. You could go back and relive a moment until you had wrung all the meaning from it, but you could not change what came after. The present retained a terrifying and generous finality.

And so the practice developed a culture. There were liturgies for the relivers—people who chose to inhabit nostalgia until the ghost of it grew flesh. There were counselors who trained clients to step into a replay with intention, to "attend" the day like a concert rather than a test. There were addicts, the Loopers, whose original lives began to fray because they preferred the known to the unknown. They were called deserters, and sometimes they died in the present for lack of cooking a meal or paying rent. The Archive regulated them. You could only book so many sessions a year. The law called it harm reduction.

You would think the inability to change the past would make the Archive irrelevant for justice. Why bother bringing back a witness if their testimony cannot be altered? But the testimony mattered not for law but for peace. Parents of suicides sat with the dead and forgave them in the only way the universe allowed: by watching the conversation unfold and choosing to be kinder in that moment, even if the final act remained unchanged. Soldiers replayed the last quiet hour before deployment not to rewrite the war but to remember that their hands had once held a day's small mercies.

I accumulated memories like currency. Each replay gave me a deposit into an account that existed only for me. After hundreds of repetitions, the day stopped being a single film and became a palimpsest. I could feel the weight of my own attention as a physical thing—lighter when I skimmed, a dense thing when I lingered on a freckle or a syllable. I began to catalog minutiae: the exact angle of Lila's knee when she propped it on the chair, the way crumbs made a constellation across her lap. They became tiny reliquaries I carted with me into the present, these scraps of particularity.

It is not the same as having had more time. You cannot stretch the day longer than it is. You cannot delay the tragedy, only accrete softer layers to the same inevitability. But those layers change you. They taught me patience I had never possessed in the forward life. They taught me to be more attentive to small kindnesses in the days that remained in their proper order. If the physics of the universe made the past immovable, the psychology of repeated attention made you softer, more precise.

The last time I booked an appointment, I sat in the machine and told the technician to set the return for a single cycle. "One more," I said, and she put down the form with the same look of practiced resignation that the Archive staff wore like a second skin. The machine hummed. I tasted metal and dust and the ghost of coffee.

When the kitchen light came up, Lila reached for a toast slice that had just the right corner of burn. Her hair fell over her face in the exact accidental way it always had. I watched and did a thing I had never done before: I put my hand flat on the table and did not speak. I let the silence hold the moment as though silence could make it larger. When the accident came it did not surprise me. Nothing did. But my hands had learned to be still in front of sense.
