Back in the present, the Archive's staff walked me down the steps with the sort of mechanical warmth they practiced on funerals. "We limit repeats for that very reason," the woman at the desk said, more gently than she usually handled clients, as if she had once been a Looper herself. The law had done its work. My bank of memories was not endless. You pay for every revisit with the coin of your remaining years.

I left the Archive that day and walked down streets that were stubbornly forward-moving. Children on bikes cut across crosswalks with a reckless future. A man laughed on a park bench and did not know his laugh would be the same next Tuesday. The impossibility of going forward made the world singularly precious; you could not go back to relive the smell of a winter market after the season had passed. You had to live it now, poorly and unprepared, as all human beings are forced to do.

People still argue about whether the Archive is a mercy or a vice. Philosophers scribble treatises, and counselors draw up contracts. For me, the machine was both. It let me hold Lila again until the fingers of memory were callused with knowing. It taught me that some sentences in our lives are closed and that the only agency we have is how we attend to them. If the past must be relived, then the act of reliving becomes a craft. You do not change the ending; you change whether you have been present enough to be changed by it.

On the subway home that afternoon I smelled diesel and roses passing the same station where the Archive's street curved. I closed my eyes and let the movement of the train be a second kind of river. I could not step into a future I had not yet earned, but I could, finally, take the next step forward, however small, with a heart that had been pared by repetition down to a finer instrument for the present.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
They call it the nightshiver, a name that tastes of fear and the rustle of leaves. When the Holocene died—when oceans warmed and forests collapsed and ninety-eight percent of familiar life folded into the fossil record—evolution did not stop. It rearranged itself around the new openness. Cities became canyons. Suburbs turned to thickets. Empty niches that had been occupied by dozens of species for millennia lay bare. Food webs rewove themselves, and one of the patterns to emerge was a simple, bitter truth: humans were predictable.

From that predictability a niche opened. Animals that could learn to read schedules and mimic voices, that could manipulate doors and set snares, found a new currency of calories in the bodies of men and women who still stepped into the world at dawn. Packs formed, and tool use spread through populations like a rumor. Of all of them the nightshiver became a legend because it combined several advantages: speed and patience, hands that could pry and hold, a brain that learned quickly and remembered the shape of a street as well as the smell of a child's shirt.

Nobody can agree on its ancestor. The old naturalists argued from bones—fused wrist joints, a curled pedal phalanx—they suggested procyonid stock, raccoon-like dextrous forepaws taken to an extreme. Others swore at the ghosts of feral dogs, pointing to its pack instincts and long-distance endurance. Whatever its origin, the nightshiver is an evolved thing, not a ghoul. It is an animal as precise as a lockpick.

Imagine it in the ruins: the coat a salt-and-ash collage, the muzzle narrow, eyes an odd pale that glows faintly like a wet coin when you catch light. Its forepaws are manicured and clever; they unsnap buckles, lift latches, fold fabric with a practiced delicacy. A membrane deep in the retina tunes to the thin heat signature of a sleeping human; its hearing catches the subharmonic of a child's breathing through a boarded window. Most striking is its face: not just expression but mimicry. It can flatten lips and tilt its head to mimic the curious gape of a lost dog. You lean toward such a plaintive sound, because long before the extinction people had taught dogs to answer calls. The nightshiver learned to use that lesson.

They hunt in small bands—six to a dozen—using roles as specific as fishermen’s. Scouts climb the skeletons of streetlights; stalkers keep to the alleys; lure-keepers learn human cadence and experiment with toys and torn shirts. They cache human things like trophies and bait: bright curtains to reflect moonlight, a doll's mitten weighted with pebbles to mimic the sound of a moving child. They do not simply ambush. They engineer situations in which people become their own traps. A pack will cut a footpath through the overgrown subway and leave a trail of damp towels trailing like a promise. Mothers follow towels. Children run toward the sound of a voice crying for "mama." When the space narrows, the hunt becomes clean.

It is said that nightshivers have an oral tradition. Skills are taught in the den, during long winter hours, through demonstration and the slow, patient copying of gestures. Pups learn to peel back a rusted door, to set a loop of vine at ankle height, to lay out scents in a pattern that signals safety—then to suddenly break it. Senior animals show them how to take what humans leave unattended: a cup of soaking clothes that smells of milk and sugar, a pot of soup cooling on a stoop. In that sense they are cultures: local dialects grow between packs. The city-dwellers will invent different lures from the hill-packs and the river-packs. Some specialize in mimicry and child calls; others in the brutal method of flushing people into clutches.

I met them once in the dusk after the rain, when everything smelled of wet concrete and tin. My group had been taking water from the reservoir at the south wall and the slow pulley noise of our pump had probably been the equivalent of a dinner bell. I had been sent to bring our boy back from the pit gardens—children were fast apprentices and thinks to be watched—and I walked with the slung bag of seeds at my hip thinking not of predators but of the delighted crackle when the boy's pockets grew heavy with beans.

There was cotton at my feet when I turned the corner, one glove folded like a handless prayer. That should have been chance. Instead, there was a single, wrong dog-cry from the shadow beyond the overturned bus, the timbre almost, but not quite, a child's wavering call for "mama." I felt the hair at my nape rise. You learn the small differences: the wrong rhythm, the absence of a creak in the timbre that a real child makes when it's been played outside too long. I should have gone back the other way. Instead, curiosity—stubborn, human—was as dangerous as always.

Out among the bushes a pair of yellow eyes ticked, and things moved like soft machines. Two nightshivers, all elbows and teeth, slipped between broken playground equipment. They did not charge. One sat upright on its haunches and lifted its head, that canine approximation of a child in confusion. The sound it made hit my ear like a dropped plate. It was wrong enough that for a second my heart stuttered not in fear but in sick comprehension. The animal held its gaze like an actor gauging a response.

I had a slingshot. I could have fired. I knew others had died when they were hunkered, hands steady on a weapon, and the pack turned the bodies faster than anyone could count. The nightshivers don't waste energy with prolonged chases. They set up a narrative—a lost child, an injured dog—and wait for the human to set the prop. Then the hunters take it from behind.

The pair advanced, and I ran because gear and ritual make us run. I hit the boy's cart on the rocky slope and the little cart toppled, beans everywhere, and for a half-breath all of us—myself, the boy, the other scavengers—were focused on scooping up small red seeds as if that could restore the world. Then their signal flared: a low, rolling bark that sounded at twice pitch; the city-pack answered with three replies like bells.

They came like shadow rivers. One launched itself from the stoop, paw catching my ankle with a clamp that was practiced and merciless. Pain exploded, but more present was the understanding of design. The nightshiver bites and shakes to induce collapse, not to devour at once. It wanted me small and manageable. It wanted me easily carried or dragged. Around us the pack administered a quickness to ritual: a strip of cloth seized from the cart, the boy shoved toward a gutter, a snarl to break formed resistance. Someone—an older woman, a neighbor with a crowbar—met them with a swinging beam, and that was when the myth broke. The nightshivers are cunning and patient, but not invincible. The beam hit one of them between the eyes and it staggered. The pack broke. They retreated into the gutters like a rumor sudden as it had come.

We patched and made lists and burned what could not be eaten. We told the children a different story that night, about the way shadows choose the softest places to bite. We began, as survivors have always done, to change our habits: the pump was worked on at different times each day so the bell-rhythm could not be learned; curtains were braided with bitter herbs so their scent would be repellent; sentries were posted at the edges of playgrounds with tin clackers the way coastal peoples used to rattle to keep seabirds off the nets. We learned to leave decoys for the nightshivers to practice on—rouge-rag dolls stuffed with stones—so that the predators would waste their learning on false leads.

It is tempting to romanticize the nightshiver, to call it noble for being so adapted. But it is simply well-fit. Evolution has trimmed it to the razor edge where human predictability is now a sustenance strategy. The creature's success has changed how we live: we hide, we vary, we teach our children to make no noises that could be learned into a lullaby. Our best people study them like any other predator—tracking patterns, charting dialects, cataloguing which packs use mimicry and which use ambush. We make maps with crosshatched warnings: do not forage in the creek at full moon, do not answer cries from the east. We have become the species that reads a map with trembling fingers.

The nightshiver's triumph is, in a way, an indictment. For millennia humans were the architects, the engineers of niches; in the wake of their designs, another animal took engineering as its project. It has become brilliant at reading our scripts and ripping out their pages. We live now in a world where the apex position is no guarantee and the cost of predictability is no less than a life. Each packed den in the rubble holds not only a kill but a collection of human objects—a braider, a button, a child's shoe—objects they do not eat but save. They are trophies, and they are tools, and they are proof that the earth has room for cruel, clever things.

samples.prompt: A werewolf considers biting a dying person to keep them alive.
samples.output:
They had left the curtains cracked so the moon could see him. It was a kindness of the hospital — or cowardice — that the fluorescent glare was kept away from the bed where she lay. Moonlight carved a pale coin on the sheets and lit the fine hairs along her jaw. Somewhere beyond the window a siren faded and was swallowed by midnight traffic. Inside, the only sound that belonged to her was the slow, skeletal clack of the ventilator, and the occasional, ridiculous beep that told them she was not quite gone.

I could smell everything: the antiseptic, the sweet chemical of morphine on her breath, the copper of the blood that had pooled and clotted beneath the bandage. I could smell the breath of the nurse waiting politely by the door. My own heartbeat thudded in my ears like a second pulse, louder than their machines. When the moon pulled across the floor, a small animal inside me woke and shook itself.

I have bitten before. I have taken flesh and left the mark of the things that both give and take. The lore is simple in hunters' bars and in the mouths of frightened old women: a bite will save you from certain death. Turned, the body knits, the fever flees, the skeleton grows dense, the blood runs different and more quickly; the heart refuses to stop. For that reason alone, the bite is a kind of miracle and a kind of murder.

She turned her head toward me with an effort that made me see bone through paper skin. Her eyes were clouded with the delirium of morphine, and she reached out with a hand that felt like wind.

"Dad," she whispered. It wasn't a child voice anymore; the accident had made a hundred small deaths of the woman I'd taught to ride a bicycle and cook eggs. "Don't leave me."

The beast behind my teeth answered before I could put language to it: yes. Yes. Bury my teeth in her throat and watch the wound close from the inside; feel the swell of life like a tide coming back. Keep you forever. Make you claw at the world and never go away.

I had been given a choice, once, though I hadn't known it. I had woken in the mud next to a body and a man I did not recognize who cursed my name and chewed my wrist until the taste of iron had sewn us both together. When the fever died in me, I came back with a hunger I had to learn to keep fenced, and a loneliness the size of a field. The man who bit me loved me in his way — his hands had done what every story says, out of pity and fear — but he had stolen the last of a life I might have lived without him. There had never been consent. There had never been apology.

I remember that first month as if it were a place I had left but which still had my letters. The moon read me like a map. I woke shaking with desires that were not mine and then, after, with grief for the body that had been taken and what it had been allowed to become. The curse is not uniform. Some of us keep our minds. Some of us are better at the long slow work of teaching the animal to sit when asked. But none of us escapes the subtraction: nights given, nights taken; friends lost; children who grow into strangers who do not understand why their father cannot stay late.

The nurse cleared her throat and made some small, professional sound that said she thought I should step away. I did not move. The moonlight braided through the fine hair on my arms and for a moment I considered the mechanics: it was the wolf's maw that sealed the bond; a human bite rarely did the thing. To make the miracle I would have to become the night itself, to lower the shutter of my will and let the old, hungry thing rise. If I allowed it to happen, would the animal obey? Would it understand that this bite was not a hunt but a gift? Would it be kinder than the man who had stolen me?

I imagined, with a clarity that made the blood behind my teeth ache, the way the wound would knit. I imagined the slow bright burn that would take the ache from her chest, the stuttered heart restarting like a clock being wound. I imagined teaching her the things I had learned with such cost. I imagined showing her the boundaries and the tracks, the ways to carry the wolf inside like a plough rather than a storm. I imagined refusing to let the hunters find her. I imagined nights of training, of hiding and whispering, of holding her while the moon tugged and rebuilding what had been broken.

Then I imagined other things.

I imagined the small cruelty of children who did not know her, of lovers who would not come near, of the way her laughter might change. I imagined pain, the animal's urgent compass pointing to things the human mind would never sanction. I imagined the hunter's rope and the townsfolk with pitchforks, and the grief of parents who would not understand that I had made a decision to free her from one death by damning her to another kind. I imagined her hands, used to gripping crayons, gripping a blade. I imagined the slow erosion of everything I had wanted for her that was not the foxing and the throb beneath the skin.

There is a monstrous selfishness to the thought as well. To offer her this life is, in part, to offer her my company. I am less frightened of the future with a wolf at my side than of the house falling silent. The beast inside me likes the sound of that: hands to feed it and wrists to keep. But I am not a coin she can spend on my comforts. The truth of it sits on my chest like a stone.

"Dad," she said again, quieter. "Please."

Consent cracks the world into two. There are a few cases where it is asked for, explicit and whole, a person choosing immortality and danger with eyes wide open. Those requests happen in different rooms and in different times, not in the narrow fresh air between life and hospital light, where grief and fever make hands slippery. She could not say yes in any way that would satisfy the thing in me that had been made without asking. To bite her as she lay incapable would be to choose for her the architecture of her life. It would be to take the role of a god badly and of a butcher for good.

The wolf in me rose when the moon caught the rim of the window. I felt the jaw extend like a trap. Muscles I had taught to patience twitched under my skin. For a breath I let the old animal catch the scent of her, and for another I let it remember that hunger has other voices: the need to protect, to keep, to bring back what is lost.

But there is a finer, crueller hunger too. And the first man who had taken me did it because he could. That memory is a wound with a tag on it. I cannot, now that I know what it is to be taken, take from someone who cannot answer.

If I could hold her and ask, if I could see the light come back behind her eyes and have her choose, I would do it in an instant. I would teach her every emergency, every trick, every lie she would need to survive. But she was not in a place of choice. The line between a blessing and a sentence is consent.

I held myself to that small, human ethical compass and, even as the wolf's mind circled like a dog at a bone, I felt it give up the way a tired thing yields the field. The animal and the man, for once, agreed on a cruelty: to leave there, to let the doctors have their fingers and the machines their beeps, to let this story end human.

I slid off the bed, and the motion was a small betrayal and also a relief. The moon crossbred with the ceiling fan and made shadows that looked like teeth. The nurse's eyes were hazy with misunderstanding and pity; she thought I had chosen to run. I wanted to tell her the truth — that the loud animal inside me had wanted to save, had wanted to give — and that I would instead have her die without my mark because I had learned what it meant to take.

Outside, the night smelled of wet asphalt and the faint iron of distant traffic. The moon pushed down like a hand. I wanted to bite the air and tear the world in two.

What I did instead was walk until my legs could not remember their good manners and the animal had retreated to the place where it keeps its claws when we are in public. I sat on a bench under a sycamore and let the moon wash me and did not open my mouth. The beast listened to the quiet, and so did I.

When the hospital called the next day to say she had slipped away, the parts of me that had wanted to save her were a different kind of hollow. Grief is a thing that will not be dulled by claws; the wolf can pound at it and smear it with muddy paws, but grief learns to be domesticated or it eats the person who tries.

I did not save her. I held something else in my hands instead: the knowledge that freedom written without consent is another kind of chain. I had felt the ink dry on that sentence, and I had let the beast go hungry for it. The moon went on its circuit regardless, and somewhere in the dark animals were waking for reasons neither saint nor sinner would understand. I sat with that, counting the small human breaths I had left, and the terrible gift of choice that, this once, I had not stolen.

samples.prompt: You're a history major. Your final exam is to travel back in time and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen. It's not going well.
samples.output:
When Professor Haversham told us the final would be experiential, I smiled the smile of a person who has read six dissertations and can quote a statute from memory. "You will be transported to a day in the past," he said, as if passing back a midterm. "You must spend eight hours living as an ordinary citizen of that time and return. Blend in. Do not draw attention. Do not interfere." He gave the usual lecture about sources not equaling practice. I still slept like a man who'd written his bibliography. Pride, of course, was the first luxury I gave up.

They sent me to London, spring of 1536. In the lecture hall I'd argued convincingly about the dissolution, the Pilgrimage of Grace, Anne Boleyn. I knew the statutes, the coinage, the names of every guild on Cheapside. In practice, knowledge is not the same as knuckling down in somebody else's clutch of mud and expectation.

Arrival is cinematic in every sense except flattering. The time machine disgorged me into air thick with smoke, fish, and the Thames in a mood that suggested it had not consented to cleanliness. Roof thatch smelled like a rumor that never quite died. People moved with an economy I could not buy with footnotes: hands were busy, lips sealed by the necessity of work. I had a linen shirt under a vest I'd been instructed to wear. It chafed; I had never realized how much medieval self-respect one could lose through simple friction.

My plan—because any good history student will have a plan—was modest. Pose as a baker's apprentice. Bakers are everywhere, they work publicly, and bakers depend on routine. If someone sees you at the oven, you are doing something acceptable. I had practiced kneading from a how-to video last week. Videos, as it turns out, are not the same as hands that smell of flour at dawn.

First error: the bakery I drifted into was one where the journeyman was a woman with the temper of a harried saint. She handed me a lump of dough and a wooden trough and walked away. I tried to conceal the way my wrists went weak. My apprenticeship had not included sudden tasks under glare. I muttered something about hydration percentages and sourdough starters—an academic tic, offering up technical terms to soothe panic. "Hydration?" she echoed. The word on her lips had less curiosity and more accusation. In 1536, "hydration" is not an acceptable term for anyone outside a leech.

Second error: coins. I learned, sitting on a cobbled step as apprentices do, that a groat is not a groat unless you can count it while your hands are flour-dusted. The baker wanted the rent paid for a sack of barley we were to fetch. I offered what I thought was the correct change—I'd converted modern wages in my head to Tudor pence—and handed over a fistful of coins I had been given by the exam coordinator: a small pouch marked with our department crest and carefully labeled "experimental currency." They looked convincing in photographs. In context, they looked like a man attempting alchemy. The woman tipped them, sniffed them, and said, "You are not of the ward."

By this point, being suspected was the least of my fears. I had another failure that required no nuance: a boy in the street asked me the name of the King's consort as if gossip were a tax and I was on the wrong side of the ledger. My mind, which only the hour before had been a neat catalogue of regnal years, betrayed me. I spoke with the reflex of a seminar analyst and said, "Anne Boleyn is—" and then, loudly, far too echoey, "—in a precarious position given the King's Great Matter." Heads turned the way hydrangeas turn to water. Men in rough coats looked at my hands, at my fashionable collar, at the way my shoes were stitched, and the city folded me into the category it reserves for inconvenient things: curiosity, foreigner, spy.

I attempted the third strategy: find a church and perform pious gestures. I know liturgy; I have recited office hours for the amusement of friends. But there are pieties you learn from books and those you learn kneeling against mortar. Inside St. Bartholomew's or some church like it—stone damp, candle smoke making confessions visible—I did not know how to move politely around people who placed their palms in a different order when passing a reliquary. A woman muttered "papist" as I touched the wrong rail. My response, because I am incorrigibly a scholar, was to offer a tiny lecture—"The Reformation is complex; it's not a monolith, and—" A child tugged at my sleeve. Someone else called for the watch.

"Do you reckon he's a spy?" a tanner asked, and suddenly it was not a rhetorical question. People pushed papers into the hands of a man who smelled of leather and authority: a constable, broad and bored. He looked at me as if I were an unpaid bill. "You," he said, and the way he said it was enough to make me wish for any excuse that did not contain the word "you." I stammered. I told him I was an apprentice. I may have offered to knead bread for him for a week. He asked for my guild token. I panicked and produced instead the department badge, the emergency talisman of the modern student: printed card stock with a barcode and a smiling logo.

He laughed, a sound that settled my stomach into a new, more mortal shape. "Make a jest, do you?" he asked. Then, mercifully, the baker's woman stepped forward, recognized me—no, not me, but the project. She snatched my sleeve and hissed at me in the way only someone who has vomited into her own requested dignity can hisses: "You don't get to perform being poor. It's not entertainment. If you were a proper apprentice, you'd know your gutters."

The real exam, I understood then, hadn't been corroborating a date but inhabiting the quiet competence of a person who didn't have the luxury of practicing humility for a grade. I kept trying to convert discomfort into inquiry: Why do you keep your knives like that? What does the tenant's quarterly do? But questions are inflammable in such a setting. Knowledge became conspicuous, a red cloak around my shoulders.

The constable led me, with the kind of casual finality that only the before-you're-inferior can wield, toward the watch house. On the way, a woman spat and called me a social problem. Someone sold a small pie with a questionable filling for the price of a sermon. I chewed the crust and felt for a moment like everything after a first bite of the wrong thing: regret, then a guilty, undeniable thrill. I had, despite my best efforts, been made of the place: not belonging, and yet present.

They didn't throw me in the stocks. The watchman, who had once been apprenticed to a cooper, listened to my attempt at an explanation—mostly a jumble of contextualizing and apologizing—and then, with a sigh such as belongs to people with practical compassion, said, "If you are a scholar, you need to learn one thing before another: hands will betray you, but ears won't. Shut them when you must. Speak only when spoken to."

I failed the rubric, I'm sure. When I got back through the buzz of modernity to Professor Haversham's office, he didn't need to ask what had happened. The look he gave me was equal parts triumph and pity. "You know more facts than most men ache to live," he said. "But living is different."

I thought of the baker's woman, of the constable with the soft voice, of the boy who asked for gossip like a tax collector. I thought of the way my fingers tried to make a loaf and betrayed me. Books had given me dates; the street had given me inconvenience.

I failed in the way that matters for anyone who wants to study lives rather than names. I came home with a new bibliography: calluses I will not have, a memory of the smell of mud in a city that has been paved over, and the knowledge that no dissertation can teach you how not to draw attention when your hands smell wrong. Professor Haversham marked the exam with the same professional cruelty he reserved for undergraduates who think knowing is the same as being. He wrote one line on the paper when he handed it back: You can name the world — now learn to live in it.

samples.prompt: A superhero's secret identity is more famous than their superhero persona.
samples.output:
They know my face before they know my name.

The flashbulbs bloom like a sudden sunrise and my publicist teaches my smile its choreography. They shout the things the cameras know to love: applause lines, charity check figures, the punch lines from last week’s monologue. They put me on billboards and cereal boxes. They call me a philanthropist and a mogul and the “girl-next-door who’s never been next to anyone.” They dissect my hair, my wardrobe, my “authentic” vulnerability in a dozen think pieces before they ever learn the shape of my hands when they grip a steel beam to pull a child from a wrecked car.

At night I take the subway and wrap my hair into a knot no stylist would ever approve of. I trade gowns for a suit that keeps my joints warm, and I let the city swallow me whole. The mask is small and stupid compared to the costumes I wear on set: real, utilitarian, embroidered with the things I can afford but cannot advertise. I am not on magazine covers. I am not a trend. I am an answer to a 3 a.m. call: a groan from a collapsed apartment, a smoke alarm’s frantic stutter, a desperation we can’t write into content calendars.

People adore Evelyn March. They timestamp their lives with my book releases, wear T-shirts with my catchphrase, crowd my telethons like annual holidays. Evelyn March invites a guest from a shelter and brings them a check; Evelyn March sits on a stage for political primetime and speaks with practiced outrage; Evelyn March gets her teeth whitened and it makes the morning shows’ ratings rise. When streets flood or riots break out, the headlines remind you she donated twenty thousand to a relief fund—that is, if the weather doesn’t make for a better GIF.

The city’s unnamed rescuer—The Warden, The Cloak, other names depending on the blog—gets a paragraph or a late-night joke. People share grainy videos of a masked figure dragging someone's car out of a mangrove of shattered concrete, and they overlay it with badly executed captions: “anonymous vigilante, hero or menace?” We do the heavy lifting; she who signs the press release gets the trophy.

You would think being famous would make it easier. Money buys equipment, influence opens doors, and the veneer of celebrity gives us stage access in places a Chief of Police only reaches with signatures. But fame is a spotlight that doesn’t follow me into the alleys; it shines on the place I left. While cameras capture the red carpet—my public life—they miss the hack marks on a child's ribs and the way my hand feeds cotton batting into a machete gap. Fame makes me predictable and inconvenient in equal measure. There is always an appointment: a morning show, a gala, an interview I cannot miss. Publicity needs me to stand still. The city needs me to move.

Once, in the middle of an acceptance speech for a humanitarian award—an absurdly gaudy crystal ship—I felt the building tremble through the soles of my shoes. A transformer blew two blocks away and a low, hungry fire was doing what hungry things do. My handler whispered into my ear: “You can leave, but the cameras will catch you—do you want the narrative?” I thought of the mother stuck in a third-floor window and the sixty-year-old man with a bad knee who would need two people to get him out.

I left.

They took my absence as a press stunt. “Evelyn March—gone missing during her own award?” The blogs sang. There were think pieces about how "spontaneous generosity" was the new currency of fame. Meanwhile I was under a scaffolding, prying a cabinet off a child’s chest while the acrid oil smoke filled my lungs and my eyes watered as if I’d been crying for someone else’s life.

By dawn the internet had thumbnails: my empty seat at a table, the award that had a smudge of soot along its rim. In the corner of a market camera’s upload, a grainy clip showed a masked person carrying a motionless little boy down a ladder. The comments were speculative. “Is that her? No, she’s too tall.” “The Warden is a man.” “Look—this could be a paid stunt.” No one connected the limp, soot-streaked face of the child to the missing smile on my publicist’s Instagram story.

There’s a perverse comfort in that irrelevance. The mask is anonymity in every sense but one: I remain recognizable, discussed, dissected. People laud the brand while ignoring the product’s actions. Charitable dinners mean more legal leverage to buy school roofs; they also mean there will be a camera in the right place to catch me at my most human—and at my most human I am expected to sell the optics. So I learned to compartmentalize. I would wave, sign, rehearse. Then, when the night came, I would move.

But there’s a price to living two kinds of fame: people get attached to the one they can control. Fans will send gifts to my office—blanketed alpacas that smell like perfume—while the people I pull from rubble need something that publicity cannot provide: shelter, long-term care, quiet bureaucracy to stitch their lives back together. A mayor once invited me to lunch to “discuss policy” and spent the hour asking me what hair dye I used, and then launched a public campaign founded on the appearance that he and Evelyn March were “doing something,” while sweat-soaked paramedics begged for trucks.

Worse are the people who see my face and hunt the mask. There are men who hate me for what I expose beneath the bombs: unscrupulous landlords whose bricks come loose after my nightly meddling; syndicates whose profits I slice to feeding those who wake with nothing. If a person wants to retaliate, they do not have to know my secret. They hire a paparazzo to follow me, to get me alone, to find the people I love, and the angle of a camera is a weapon when the thing it points at is someone you can hurt.

The worst night was when they realized the truth they already suspected. Someone posted a photo of my car, parked late, at a location where a hostage crisis later unspooled. The comment thread did what comment threads do: they connected dots, invented motives, accused me of self-serving heroism. I sat in the back of a cramped police wagon, my clothes burned and bleeding from the shrapnel line, while internet lawgivers voted on whether my interventions were genuine. I’d just saved ten lives, and people were more interested in whether the sleeve of my coat matched the brand I’d been paid to advertise last season.

“You could always tell them,” my sister said once. “Pull the mask off during one gala. Tell them you’re tired of being a mannequin for feel-good headlines.” She had a dog-eared, earnest look—there are things storybook siblings often misunderstand about stamina.

I almost did it—on a quiet Thursday where nothing good was scheduled. I had the speech ready: an honest, ragged call for structural compassion. I planned to keep my words raw and refuse the slick teleprompter cadence my handlers loved. I imagined people’s shock, the viral confessions, the petitions, the policy shifts. I imagined the city’s policemen leaning toward my name with cooperation and the families finally getting what they needed: not hashtagged empathy, but systemic change.

Instead, late that night, after a rescue that left me with a cracked knuckle and a mattress of questions, I tucked the Warden’s cowl under a rain-logged newspaper in a library trash can. I did not want the applause for the wrong reasons. If I went public, my face would become the story; the work would be summarized into thirty-second soundbites. If I stayed hidden, my brand could continue to open doors, buy equipment, leverage influence without being the headline in every decision. Somewhere between vanity and duty there is usefulness. I chose usefulness.

There is a strange mercy in being famous for the sideshow while the city needs the carpenters of the main tent. I have food trucks at my last rescue site because my team—Evelyn March Incorporated—has logistical muscle that anonymous heroes rarely access. I can call in favors, bring in therapists, create emergency funds with a single signature. My fans tweet strips of me on red carpets, but their money, magnified through a foundation, rebuilt a block of housing. The people I save rarely scroll their feeds; they are too busy learning how to sleep again without the constant threat of the wall caving in.

So I keep my secret. I put on the public smile that keeps the investments warm and the phone lines open. I go to dinners I do not want to attend because the donor who promised an evacuation van wants a complimentary roast. I fight in alleys when my name trends for a scandal I did not cause.

Maybe one day I’ll reveal myself, and the city will clamor for confessions and signatures and trophies. Maybe they’ll elevate the spectacle of me and ignore the slow, socially messy labor my city needs. Maybe—if I am brave or foolish enough—that revelation will force the change we require.

For now, I am more famous than the thing that matters. I am a face people believe in, and a stranger in a mask with calluses no one photos. The contradiction lets me insulate the work from the applause. It also kills me in a thousand tiny ways—the missed dinners, the way no one remembers the scars because scars don’t photograph well.

At dawn, when the city smells like burnt coffee and solutions still unwrapped, I fold my mask and tuck it into the hollow under my coat. I step back into my public life like a person entering an old, ornate theater to play a part. The audience doesn’t know the lines I just learned in the dark, and they probably never will. They’ll keep loving Evelyn March, and with that love, unwittingly, I’ll keep saving them.

samples.prompt: As a professional assassin, you open the message with your new assignment. To your surprise, the target is your spouse. The payment being offered is substantial.
samples.output:
The message arrives like a splinter under the skin.

I am not the sort of person who flinches at a ping. My phone is an instrument; its notifications are levers and valves. I swipe open the encrypted app with the same muscle memory I’d use to draw a blade. The header is sterile: JOB — HIGH VALUE — NO QUESTIONS. The body of the message is economy itself: coordinates, window for the operation, method requested, and a photograph.

The photograph is of Maria lying on a picnic blanket, laughing at something I said three summers ago. The light in the picture is gold, the edges soft with lens flare. She is holding a slice of watermelon and her head is thrown back; there is a freckle I kissed last winter right between her brow and hairline. I have that freckle memorized in a way I have no business memorizing anything—fingerprints are one thing, but freckles are catalogue entries in the satellite of a life I keep separated from my work.

Payment attached. Not a number anyone needs to keep secret by being modest: enough to wipe a past clean, build a hundred new identities, buy a state. The money sits in the message like a temptation waiting for my price to be set.

I don't breathe.

There are rules to my work. They are more concrete than law. Do not take jobs with personal ties. Do not work under emotional duress. Do not leave traces that would lead back to those you love. Those rules exist because emotion is a hazard, because attachment corrodes discretion. They are my scaffolding. But rules are only useful when the world is stable; today my world rearranges itself around a photograph of a woman who cooks, who murmurs nonsense at 2 a.m., who does not know what I used to do for a living and probably never will because I promised her I would stop.

The message is anonymous, but not clumsy. The metadata is a masterclass in obfuscation; whoever sent it knows how to send it without leaving fingerprints. The method requested is "clean — no trace, surgical." The window is six days. The advance is non-negotiable in its implication: this job is important enough that whoever ordered it can pay a life.

I scroll back through memory because memory is where motive lives. Have there been threats? Has Maria been involved with men who might want her dead? In the last year she took a job at a legal firm downtown, handled estate disputes. She'd been irritated by a partner who used the word "obfuscate" as a verb. She had stayed late on the night of my retirement party and came home smelling like printer toner and cheap coffee. She whispered once about secrets that make you look guilty if you care about them, and I thought she was speaking about other people.

The phone vibrates again. Another message: a simple test—confirm your availability. The sender expects compliance.

Somewhere in my head an auction begins. Money. Freedom. Maria's laugh. The nuance of my life compressed into two squares: a photograph and a bank transfer. The professional part of my brain — cold, not unkind — starts building contingencies. Fake deaths are my art. Certificates, charred dental records, a body found on a riverbank hand-stitched to look like something it isn't; those are tools at my disposal. I have friends in coroners' offices. I have a woman who can print a passport like a god prints names. With the right script, anyone can become anyone.

Except there is a heart under my ribs, and for nine years that heart has answered to Maria.

I stand from the kitchen table and go to the bedroom. She is asleep, the kind of sleep where people make themselves small. Moonlight paints the curve of her cheek. For a long time I stand there and name memories: the first rude coffee she made me, the way she cursed at crossword clues, the soft, unfashionable sweater I stole from her closet and never returned. I touch the freckle between her brow and hairline — it is warm.

"If they paid you the amount they're offering," she says in her sleep, "we could finally—"

The rest of her sentence dissolves into night. In the dreamspace of her sleeping voice, she suggests the house by the water we never manage to buy, the trips we postpone because I am always promising a last job.

Whoever sent the photograph understands leverage. They are throwing a price at something that cannot be bought. They are inviting betrayal as if it were a currency.

I open a new message. I could decline. I could forward the file to someone higher up with the note: conflict of interest. I could trace the sender, blow their cover, take no pay and let them find someone else to do their dirty work. But the world of people who order hits does not reward abstention. That softness—me—would make a target of her anyway. They would not stop because I refused.

Instead I craft a reply the way I used to plan operations: with contingencies, with bargaining positions that give me leverage. I set terms that are visible only to somebody who knows the way my mind lives in diagrams: an advance, specific death conditions, a single meet to deliver proof. And then, like a practiced magician, I hide the sleight in plain sight.

Accepted, I type, and I add a clause: "I insist on 60% upfront. This is a delicate removal. Evidence of compliance must be evaluated by an independent third party selected by me. Final proof delivered within ten days."

It is not a bluff. It is the first stage of a complicated lie I can live with.

The money is leverage. With it I can build a fiction that satisfies whoever ordered the hit—an expertly fabricated death certificate, a body that will not be forensically challenged—and I can use the rest to buy Maria a life somewhere they will never look. If this were a simple moral calculus the answer would be easy. It is not. People rarely present moral dilemmas as binary; they come wrapped in dollars and the scent of a life we have been promised if we do the unthinkable.

I do the math not on bank accounts but on probabilities. If I refuse, the client might escalate; if they see I balk, they might order someone more desperate. If I accept and carry it out, I become the instrument that ends the woman who has kept me human. If I accept and subvert it, I will commit a different kind of deceit—one in which I take money that belonged to a man who wanted Maria dead and use it to disappear both of us.

The plan writes itself because my life is maps: a staged "accident" near the old mill, a body—an intoxicated drifter drugged into a porcelain semblance—dental work altered, a small amount of arson for char and a coroner who owes debts. I will create a narrative clean enough to satisfy the tradecraft of the sender. I will then take the remainder of the money, load Maria into a car at dawn, and be gone by noon. She will take a new name. We will choose one from the list of names I own like birds.

There is betrayal in this choice and mercy. I feel both.

At the kitchen table I write another message, this time to her. I delete it. I compose it again.

When she wakes at seven I am sitting at the sink with two mugs and the photograph between them like a smear of evidence. The way she says my name is a small weather change. The photograph is on the table. Her pupils sharpen.

"It's a ransom," she says, voice small. "Somebody doesn't like me at the firm?"

I could tell her everything. I could shield her in a blanket of lies and move her without explanation. But she deserves a version of the truth.

"I got an offer," I say. "For you."

Her laughter doesn't come. She reads the words like a topography of betrayal. "Who would want me dead?" she asks, not angrily but as if she has just been marked on a map she did not know she was standing on.

"We don't know," I say. "But we're going to make them believe they do."

There is a long, sharp intake of breath. Then she sits upright. "And us?"

"We leave," I say. I lay out the plan in the plain, clinical terms I know. I tell her about the forger and the coroner and an escrow account that will pay themselves out like a sunset. I tell her I will create a death that will hold up under scrutiny because I have made things hold up under scrutiny before. I tell her the cost. I tell her the lie I am about to commit for the sake of both of us.

She listens. When I'm done she takes my hand. Her skin is soft. "Why me?" she asks, which is a question and a plea. "Why us?"

"Because someone decided to sell our life back to us," I tell her. "Because there are people who try to control who gets to keep breathing. Because I can make them believe what they want to believe."

She considers. There is fear there and a fierce, small dignity gathering like a flame. "If we're going to disappear," she says, "we do it clean. No half measures."

"I know," I say. I kiss the freckle on her brow as if acknowledging the crime I'm about to commit. It is not a blessing. It is a promise.

I return to my phone and hit send. The message goes into the encrypted nowhere that is the underside of the world. I will take their money and make them believe their order was carried out. When the escrow drops and the coroner signs the papers, they will have what they paid for: a body, a report, a name crossed out. We will have the house in our new town. We will have names padded with numbers. We will have mornings where the only noise is a kettle.

There is a price that cannot be calculated in any ledger. I think of the woman under the blanket, the woman who laughed with watermelon in her hand. I think of the way love has a way of becoming another kind of weapon when threatened, and the way my hands have been taught to make things end.

I don't tell myself it is right. I tell myself it is necessary. The lie I am about to tell will be a quiet murder, but not of her. It will be a murder of the life someone else decided they could buy, and of the neat moral lines that protected me for as long as I needed them to. I fold the photograph into my pocket. Outside, the city is an indifferent machine. Inside, there is a woman sleeping and the sound of two hearts arguing about what to do next.

At dawn we drive with the sun on the horizon, practical and precise. The money is a thin paper map between my hands, the only proof I have that survival sometimes smells like betrayal. I will learn to live with it. I will teach her to love a name that is not hers. For now, the practical art of disappearance must be the most intimate thing I have ever done.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a cheap hotel room covered in occult symbols and paraphernalia, having no recollection of the past month and finding yourself sharing your body with a powerful demon.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the smell: stale cigarette smoke over something sweet and chemical, like incense left burning too long. The second was the light — a neon strip through the gap in the curtains, a cheap red that painted the motel carpet the color of clotted blood. The third was the taste, metallic and wrong, in the back of my mouth. My tongue came away with dust and something older.

I sat up too fast and the room tilted. A cheap alarm clock blinked 12:00 in fat orange numerals. The bedspread had a grease stain the size of a hand. The wallpaper was a pattern of tiny brass compasses that, up close, revealed themselves to be circles of inked sigils; someone had gone over them with a Sharpie, heavy, as if to emphasize a map.

I remembered my name. I remembered the sound of rain on the roof of my old apartment and the way coffee burned when I wasn't careful. I did not remember the last month. My phone was on the nightstand like a dead thing — the screen cracked, the battery cold, every contact list wiped. My wallet was empty.

And then I saw the altar.

It wasn't subtle. A sheet of plywood served as a table. On it, candles, wax drippings like the strata of a bad year; a handful of bones — not large enough to be human, but not meant for show; a pile of old coins; a stack of Polaroids with faces scratched out; ash in a Mason jar; a ledger on which a series of names had been written and crossed through. The wall behind the table was plastered with paper: inked circles, staves of symbols that crawled along the plaster, a big circle drawn in chalk on the floor like the center of a clock. Whatever ritual had been performed here had been messy and theatrical and very, very recent.

I reached for the ledger with hands that trembled a little and felt a prickle slide under my skin, a memory of pressure, of tendons and a voice not my own curling up against the underside of my thoughts.

"Finally," it said, as if I had only been late to a meeting. Not aloud. Inside me, like a heat under the ribs. Calm. Very old.

I did not mean to speak. My mouth found words anyway. "Who are you?"

A laugh. It was a sound I felt more than heard, a vibration in my molars. "Names are... delicate. We are called by what people fear, by what they bought in the back of bookstores. The important part is that I'm here."

"I don't remember a month," I said. I was careful with my voice, like I was speaking to a stranger in a diner. "I don't remember doing any of this."

"We did," it corrected. "Collective memory at its finest. You left it to me because someone had to be awake." It tapped whatever part of me answered like a knuckle on a rib. "You are useful when you sleep."

An image flashed — not a memory exactly, but a smell and a rhythm: chanting, cold air on bare feet, the taste of iron, the scrape of a pen across cheap plywood. I saw flashes of faces: bright, intense, full of belief; someone lighting black candles; my hands, brown with wax and something darker. Responsibilities sanctified by ritual. A crowd nodding in unison as I — as we — raised our hands and recited syllables that vibrated down into the bones.

"You used me," I said.

"We borrowed," it amended. "You lent the vessel; we provided the gravity. I protected you from the sharp, human truth of what we were doing. Your little life is too brittle."

Its voice knew the exact shape of my guilt and pressed on it. Somewhere inside my chest a window cracked open and a draft moved through.

"Did anyone —" I started. The ledger squatted under my fingers like a small animal. On the page I found my handwriting: shaky, the letters betraying both urgency and reverence. Names, dates, times. Crossed out. A telephone number. A scribbled phrase: Sacrifice deferred. We wait.

I traced a name and the pricked memory of a man's face — too old, beard grey like lint — and then an image of a rooftop, a slit in the sky, a sound like wind in a cathedral. The room behind my eyes filled with smoke, with light that wasn't sunlight. The demon sighed, satisfied.

"They came," it said. "We opened it. You remember things in fragments because it was kinder. You should thank me for that."

"People — were people hurt?"

"Complicated." It liked that word. It tasted of wax. "Belief is a solvent. Things come through when the door is wide enough. They were not invited, but invitation is a social convention. The price has been exchanged."

My stomach dropped. The ledger fell to the floor when my fingers went numb. I felt suddenly very small and very exposed, like a puppet whose strings had been threaded through its ribs.

"Why me?" My voice was hoarse.

Another chuckle. "You asked nicely. Or they did. Or perhaps your apartment was convenient." It paused, and in that pause something cold and sincere slid in like a knife. "You have a stubbornness I've grown fond of."

I imagined the last month as a black square I had been missing, like a slide in a projector lost between reels. The people in the Polaroids had been worshippers once; now their faces were gouged. There was blood on the corner of one — not a lot, but bright and fresh enough to assert that whatever had been performed here had not been abstract.

"Can you leave?" I asked.

It hummed at the question, as if considering whether to take pleasure. "It is not as simple as a tap on the shoulder and a goodbye. I am anchored. You like to sleep. Anchors do not have legs."

"I want to remember," I said. "I need to know."

"It is possible." It was abrupt, mercantile. "I can return the film. I can let you have the last month in full: the chants, the faces, the bargains. But there is always a cost to illumination."

I tasted the word cost like old pennies. "What does it ask?"

"A partnership," it said. "A small concession. A voice sometimes. A hand on the wheel when desire pushes. You will keep your bones. I will keep my teeth."

I thought of the ledger and the crossed names and the man on the rooftop and the slit in the sky. I thought of the empty places in my life that might be guilt-made-concrete if they were filled. I also thought of power — the sudden, terrible ease with which the world could bend if the voice in my head was turned loose.

"How powerful are you?" I asked. "What can you do that I can't?"

"Make people go where they are afraid to. Make architects draft new geometries. Make windows talk. Make money smell of iron." A smirk in syllables. "I can make you remembered."

That last promise shivered along my spine. Remembered in what sense? Hero worship? Fear? My name on a ledger? I had, for the last decade, been small in the way that doesn't hurt. The idea of being large, even monstrous, tugged at me like a limb asleep returning to the world.

A knock at the door ripped the room into the present. Four beats, then a pause, then three. Someone called my name — my real voice, a neighbor's voice? — and then the chanting of a distant rhythm, like a choir tuning.

The demon hummed, pleased. "They've come back. Some of our friends, or those who follow patterns. We have appointments."

I slid off the bed and found the weight of the world anywhere my toes touched the carpet. The ledger was still under my hand; the names looked like a map you don't want to follow. The chalk circle on the floor offered a way in, or a way out — everything was now a symbol.

"You won't control me," I said, but it wasn't an accusation as much as a promise to myself.

It softened. "I do not seek erasure. I seek companionship. Very often, humans make the best allies because they are both clever and inelegant. You will be messy, and that is a flavor."

I could have opened the door. I could have screamed for help. I could have taken the ledger, the photographs, the innards of the night and run. That, the demon knew, would set something else in motion. The people outside did not come for conversation. They came with intent as precise as a scalpel.

"Tell me everything," I said. The words surprised me with their steadiness.

It laughed, indulgent and cavernous. "Patience. I will peel it back like a scab. But first — a small thing: Speak for me once. Use the sound. Let us feel the weight of your voice."

I heard the desperation in the request, and the hunger. I realized then that the bargain was not only to regain the month but to place myself into a partnership where my life would be an instrument and my mouth the conductor's baton. It was a temptation older than I was: the promise of meaning in exchange for surrender.

I stood in the circle of chalk, the motel's neon bleeding in at my feet. The room smelled of crushed herbs and candle soot. The ledger lay open like a heart ready for incision. Through the wall, footsteps and soft rhythmic humming — an arrangement of people who had not finished what we'd started.

"You get the memories," I said. "I get my body."

"And a voice," it added, with the gentleness of a thing that loved its bargains. "A voice is all I ask."

I could have refused. I could have demanded exile or screamed myself raw until whatever price was asked for lost its teeth. Instead I closed my eyes and felt two things meet in the dark: fear — sharp and small — and something like possibility, sticky with sin.

When I spoke, the words were not quite mine. They came up from somewhere hollow and warm and old, and for the first time since I woke, the blackout felt like a doorway and not merely a wound.

samples.prompt: Sorry, boss. I'm calling in sick.
samples.output:
"Sorry, boss. I'm calling in sick."

My thumb hovered over the line like it could erase the whole morning if I pressed hard enough. The phrase felt absurdly small compared to the magnesium-white flood of nausea in my chest. It was the same sentence I’d used a dozen times in a dozen different coughs, stomachaches and migraines, but this time the words were a little heavier, as if gravity had decided title and recipient mattered.

Dawes made a small, noncommittal sound. He always did that on the phone when he wanted to remind you he was listening without saying anything kind. "Okay," he said. "Get some rest."

"Yeah," I said. The lie tasted familiar. I wasn't contagious, not in the usual sense. No fever, no feverish shivers, no gurgling cough to justify a sick day to the company calendar. I was contagious in another currency: disengagement, exhaustion, a slow erosion of care that made me resent the way weekday light looked over the building's parking lot. I was contagious with tiredness and the knowledge that I could no longer digest the things they asked me to digest.

I wedged my phone between ear and shoulder, slid my feet into slippers and shuffled to the kitchen because habits are the last things to surrender. The kettle clicked like a metronome. Outside, a siren drifted through the neighborhood — a neighbor’s cat having an existential crisis, or maybe someone else calling in sick for different reasons entirely.

There was a time when "calling in sick" meant hot tea and a blanket and a book and permission to be small for a day. Now it meant trying to make my chest less tight while thinking of the fifty emails that would gather on my desk like hungry insects. It meant projecting an appearance of weakness to men who equated tenacity with output, and sometimes I resented the necessary theater of it. Still, Dawes's voice was flatter than I wanted. He had fewer questions than I would have expected from the man who had once cornered me in the stairwell to ask if I could stay late to save a presentation.

"Thanks," I said again, then disconnected. The line felt like a thin cord retracted into the receiver. I set the phone down and watched a square of sun inch across the counter. For the first few minutes, what passed through me was a kind of suspended relief — the tiny sweetness of disobedience. I had not called in sick in two years. Not once. Not a single cough with a note on the calendar and the obligatory "Hope you feel better" from a coworker whose name I couldn't remember. Two years of swallowed headaches, of lunches eaten standing, of apologies and bribed smiles.

It wasn't that work had been suddenly worse. Work had been the same predictable machine it had always been: small metrics shapeshifted into threats, meetings that left me with nothing but a phoneful of tasks rebranded as 'priorities.' If anything, I should have seen this coming. The day's absence felt less like an illness and more like an overdue resumption of an old, unpaid debt — the self I had deferred when I first took the job and decided the comfort of security was worth the slow attrition of wonder.

I brewed tea I didn't feel like drinking. The steam circled like a tiny, apologetic ghost. On the kitchen table lay a pink slip of paper folded into an impatient rectangle: appointment at the clinic this afternoon, long overdue. My hand found it out of muscle memory. There were names: tests, numbers, a calendar that had been filled with other people's needs for so long that the margins where mine should be were faint, as if someone had been erasing them every night.

What I needed, I told myself, was time — not the theatrical two days to nap and recover, but actual time to figure out whether the exhaustion was a disease or a symptom, whether the steady sliding of my enthusiasm into a spreadsheet cell called "Other" was reversible. I had been taught to measure my health by output. If I was producing, if I was meeting quotas, if I could look awake in client presentations, I was fine. Private pain had become an improv act.

Half an hour later the streets outside were a watercolor of midday: school buses gliding by, a woman pushing a stroller with painstaking summations of the future, a busker plinking a single, defiant song. I walked because I needed to prove to myself that my limbs still obeyed, that I could move in a world that told me I owed it my constant attention.

The clinic smelled like antiseptic and canned coffee. In the waiting room, a laminated poster smiled about stress management as if it were an infographic on capturing fireflies. I filled out forms in a voice that felt borrowed: "Reason for visit: fatigue." I wanted to write a different sentence, like "Reason for visit: I am collapsing under the weight of a life I chose because someone else made it seem reasonable," but the form had been designed by people who believed efficiency could hold down the universe.

A nurse took my pulse with gentle hands and a face that did not ask for explanations. "You look tired," she said, which is the kind of observation that can be either clinical or compassionate depending on the listener. I exhaled. The tumble of withheld words — the long nights, the small betrayals of self, the endless bargaining for a moment of stillness — tumbled out instead, but softer, like a confession to a sympathetic stranger.

"It's not just physical," I said. "I think I'm... just worn thin."

She nodded and wrote something down. The doctor used phrases like "professional burnout" and "chronic stress" and "treatment plan," all of which were decent-sounding tools. He asked about sleep, appetite, whether I felt hopeless. If he had asked if I derived the shape of myself from the shape of my tasks, I might have started to cry. Instead, I received a referral to a therapist, a prescription for sleep hygiene that included the judgmental suggestion to "reduce screen time before bed," and a gentle, bureaucratic permission: two weeks off work to rest.

The cardiogram machine hummed like calm machinery. Outside, a man walked by carrying a cardboard box of office supplies; he'd been through what I was doing or maybe he was just changing his socks. When the doctor said the words "two weeks," it felt less like time and more like a small, carved-out territory. I imagined it on the calendar: a rectangle of nothing, a pocket of daylight.

On the way home I stopped at a coffee shop, the kind with succulents and employees who could always tell you where the foam is denser. The barista was new, young enough to ask me what my weekend plans were as if life remained full of unmined possibilities. For once, I told the truth. "I'm not sure," I said. "Maybe I'm going to rediscover my own name."

She smiled like she believed me, or maybe she just liked the poetry of tired people making new pronouncements. I sipped coffee that tasted like a way back into myself.

The next morning, I typed out an email I knew I could have written at ninety miles an hour the week before, but this time my fingers trembled with a different kind of resolve. Subject line: Request for leave. I kept it short, precise, but honest enough that even Dawes couldn't commodify it. Two weeks, starting today. Medical notes attached. I hit send and listened to the small ping like a bell.

I hadn't intended to look at my keycard — the plastic rectangle that slid into the slot and allowed me to become anyone at my desk — but it slid under my palm like a boggling little relic. For a moment, I pressed it to my forehead as if it were a child's lucky charm and then I did something minor and extraordinary: I left it on the kitchen counter. It was as if by not presenting my credentials I could reclaim the shape of a life that wasn't punctuated by meeting times and passive-aggressive inboxes.

I could already see the e-mails begin to flow in my mind: reminders, reassignment requests, veiled threats about missed deadlines. Who would notice? Who would care? There was comfort in that imagined indifference. But there was also a new, quiet possibility.

The phrase I had used on the phone hovered in the back of my mouth. "Calling in sick." It had always meant a clean thing: a fever, a doctor's note, the permission to be taken care of. Today it meant something wider. I was calling in sick of the pretense that relentless productivity equaled worth, sick of measuring my days in deliverables. I was calling in sick of equating my value with my availability.

When Dawes called later that afternoon — a polite, surprised inquiry — I told him the truth without theatrics. "Thank you," he said slowly. "Take your time. Get better."

I believed him enough to feel gratitude and wise enough to suspect he meant something different than what I wanted. Either way, the little portal of time I had carved open glowed like a tiny, unclaimed country. I would spend it in clinics and parks and opposite a therapist who would teach me how to make smaller contracts with myself. I would be patient with bruises I had learned to hide. Maybe I'd return. Maybe not.

I sat at the kitchen table and wrote something longhand, a relic to myself: a list of things I wanted to remember how to do. Read a book without measuring its ROI. Walk without listening to a podcast about productivity. Make an omelet and not think about whether it would post well on social media. At the bottom of the page, in letters that didn't try to perform, I added, "Do not apologize for needing a day."

There is softness in admitting that you cannot continue in the same way. There is a kind of bravery in letting your absence be visible. The world is often indifferent, but there are also corners of it that will, if only given the chance, offer rest.

I dozed off with the window open and the city breathing in and out. When I woke an hour later, my chest had unclenched a fraction, as if someone had loosened a knot. I thought of Dawes and the small civility of letting someone be human. I thought of the pink slip of paper and its appointment time and the long list of small, ordinary unlived things.

I picked up my phone, scrolled past the sent-mail confirmation, and typed a message into my notes as if I needed to tell someone else what I had done: Sorry, boss. I'm calling in sick. Thank you for understanding.

And then, a new sentence, a private one, slightly shaking but honest: Sorry, world. I'm calling in sick — to what has been expected of me.

samples.prompt: Create an original monster. Make its own rules as to how it works, and how it has to be destroyed. Explain all of this when people run into it for the first time ever and how they deal with it.
samples.output:
The first thing Mara noticed was a blank space on a page that had always been full.

It was an ordinary, dog-eared ledger from the Rosefield Historical Society—minutes of town meetings, names of donors, the town’s founding tale recorded in stale fountain-pen ink. She had been cataloging, shelf by shelf, for months. When she turned to the bicentennial entry she expected to see the sentence about Mayor Hensley’s ribbon cutting. Instead there was a crease of paper and a sliver of halo where ink had been, nothing else; the paper smelled faintly of cold ash.

At first she thought water, then mice. Photographs slid off the wall with frames full of silvering emptiness—people whose faces had been tooth and laugh the week before were now gray walls. Her brother Tom, an amateur archivist with a stubbornness for experiments, read aloud from the published diary of an old farmer. The paragraph stopped at midsentence. “He had—” Tom said. The words vanished in his mouth. He closed his eyes and, terrified, could not remember to whom the diary had once belonged.

By the third day a woman who had taught in the elementary school for thirty years walked into the library and asked who the school was named after. The whole town recited the name in unison—then fell mute. No one remembered the person who had died on the playground, no one could bring themselves to finish the story about why the plaque existed. The plaque itself looked like someone had sanded a story right off the metal.

They called it a phenomenon. They called in a linguist, a folklorist, a clever graduate student with a tape recorder. Words were recorded and played back; some parts came back hollow. They found patterns.

This is how the Archivists among them—scholars who tried to be detached—wrote down the rules.

- The thing feeds on open narratives: stories that have no settled ending, gossip that moves from person to person, drafts and half-sentences. It does not crave facts so much as the unfinished arc of things that might still become other things.

- It moves along sentences. If a story is spoken, it will progress on the breath that carries it. If written, it travels through clauses. A full stop—an explicit, deliberate ending—acts like glass to it. The Archivist cannot pass beyond a completed sentence: endings are boundaries.

- Objects and people who are embedded in unresolved tales lose the human context that ties them to community. Photos fade, names distort, memories blur. Records are altered not by subtraction but by unwriting: the event ceases to have happened in the collective hold of things.

- The creature is not incorporeal in the ordinary sense; it is a method, a grammar of erasure. It is born in places where a story is left incomplete—where a ledger never closed, where a child was never named, where an apology was never made. It grows with the appetite of things left mid-arc.

- It cannot exist where narrative is made impossible: lists of inventory, indexes, and catalog numbers resist it. An item with a catalogue number remains itemized even if everyone forgets its origin; classified data are shards of immunity.

- The only absolute, the only kill, is completion. You cannot simply march in with a hammer. You must finish its story—write its life in full, end it with a proper finality, and then force the Archivist to accept that completed form.

They learned the last rule the hard way.

Mara and the small team began experimenting. They wrote complete biographies of the missing—full, obscene, dull lives, from the date of birth to the day of death with addresses and bread-and-butter details. When they did so, photographs resolved. If they closed the biography with a full stop and placed it in the ledger, the person reappeared in a tarnished photograph, looking older or younger and bewildered as if someone had stitched them back from a bad seam. Partial biographies were eaten. A paragraph left unfinished opened a small, hungry hiss in the room, like breath slipping through a missing tooth.

Encouraged, they tried to trap the thing. They wrote a life—short, careful, named a place where the Archivist might have been born: an abandoned well near the town square, a habit the town had half-jokingly called "where names go to get lost." The problem was that you cannot simply invent an Archivist and expect it to take the bait. The creature is made of other people's omissions; it will only answer to a life that echoes a real omission.

Tom, in his stubbornness, took the bait further. He used a childhood anecdote he had been told as a rumor: a girl who fell from a swing and was never named because her mother left town. He wrote a full life for the missing child—Janet H. Kline—detailing a life of small pleasures and quiet endings, the exact kind of tidy narrative the Archivist devoured when fed. At the end he wrote a death: "Janet H. Kline died on a Tuesday, with the kettle whistling," and put a period his hand shook to make certain it was the right sort of ending. The photograph that had been nothing—an old, blank-etched oval from 1932—fused into an image of a woman with a particular smile.

When they shelved the biography, the room felt heavier for a moment. A sound like a closing book came from somewhere behind the stacks. A shadow, if you could call it that, buckled the edge of light and then was there. Not tall, not monstrous in claws; rather like a thing folded too many times and given a kind of tired awareness. It had no face they could agree upon; when they tried to describe it, their words slotted into parentheses and fell away. It was the Archivist.

They had in their notes the clear instruction: write its life, end it with a full stop, compel it to accept the end. But acceptance was the problem. To accept, it must be addressed. The act of naming it—of giving the thing a fixed narrative—felt like betrayal and mercy both. Names were what drew it near.

Mara, who had begun the ledger project in order to shore up the town against loss, understood the paradox. To kill it they would have to do the one thing that made it possible: tell a beginning.

They combed every rumor. They found the unfinished circle: a midwife's account, a mention of a winter when so many emigrated that a baby left unnamed was left sleeping by a ledger of the town. They wrote that baby’s life in full, giving it a name drawn from the tangle of ordinary syllables used in the town: Lyle Everitt. They wrote the details with their hands shaking: Lyle’s first scraped knee, the smell of coffee at his first job, the song he liked at fifty. They gave Lyle a quiet, human death in his eighties and placed a period.

The final step came from an old ritual note in the margin of a Civil War ledger: an instruction to read a will aloud where the will is kept. Stories like to be read where they are housed. They carried the book to the old well and formed a line. Everyone who had been touched by the Archivist—those who had lost a portrait or gone blank—stood with the ledger. Mara read, steady at first, then with a tremble in the throat, and Tom recorded as the linguist had insisted on recording for proof.

When she reached the end—"Lyle Everitt died on a Tuesday, with the kettle whistling."— she spoke the final period aloud.

The Archivist did not shriek. It folded like breath being released from a lung. The faces in the photographs shimmered and returned, not exactly as they had been but with the edges sewn tight. The plaque on the school kept its name. Names that had been gone returned like rain.

There was a cost. To deliver the final period, each of them had to speak other people's endings alongside their own. People who had given away their stories—who had always told gossip to keep from facing their own—found their own memories closing like shutters. The linguist lost a fragment of childhood that no one could recover because he had said it aloud in the act of finishing someone else's tale. They had promised each other they would not tell the story outside the room, because the Archivist's nature was contagious in the way of stories; to reduce its food you had to reduce its ability to move from mouth to mouth. They agreed to write, index, and lock.

Several months later, Rosefield organized its accounts differently. Ledgers were bound with a string of inventory tags. Events were closed with signatures and public readings. The school had a list of names posted, not as an epic but as an index. People learned to hold their gossip as a thing to be cataloged, not as a fuel.

The Archivist was not the type of evil that roared in a darkened cathedral and left ash. It had been a grammar error given agency: the town’s habit of leaving a sentence hanging. Destroying it required the town to change the way it told its own stories. In a way that was the point. The monster was not outside them so much as within the cracks of how they kept each other whole.

The rules they wrote—about sentences, about endings, about indexes—are still kept in the back of the ledger on the shelf that no one checks. People pass it and do not touch it; they keep their inventories, their lists, and, once a month, they read aloud a list of small endings: gratitudes, apologies, little clarifying facts. They learned the painful kindness of finishing things.

You must know, if you are ever the first to see an eyewitness suddenly blank, that the creature wants a clause unfinished. If you find the space of someone’s life folded into nothing, do not shout rumors to fill it. Sit and write the life down in full. End with a period. Read it where the paper is kept. And believe that sometimes the last thing a community needs to kill its monsters is the courage to finish a sentence.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
She is sixteen today.

Time is a different thing to me. I count in rhythms — the snap of a frightened throat, the warm throb of a heart under thin cotton, the way a child's breath quickens when a shadow in the corner of the room becomes a story and then a promise. I marked six years old by the first real laugh I made her give, a jagged sound like glass on glass. I marked seven by the way she learned to hold her chin like she’d been taught to hide scars. Ten was the year she learned to lie so beautifully the teacher cried. Fourteen was when she started locking doors for reasons that had nothing to do with privacy. That was when she began to speak to me like I was a secret friend and a family member at once.

It has been a good run. I have worn her like a coat, lined with her small mercies and brighter than I expected. A coat can wear out. It can be laid aside in another season. I move on, always.
